EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement received golf ball size hail 5 miles east-northeast of Shamrock, Texas.
Large tree limbs were blown off trees.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that knocked down some large trees.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts measured at 52 kts. by the ASOS at San Antonio International Airport.
Nickel sized hail was observed just south of Beltway 8 between Blackhawk and Beamer.
A storm chaser reported quarter size hail over rural portions of eastern Yoakum County.
Penny size hail was reported by the public along Farm to Market Road 652 north of Mentone.
Tree damage was reported on a property approximately 1.5 miles north of Montague.
A thunderstorm produced one inch hail near the intersection of Loop 1604 and Hwy 281 in northern San Antonio.

A cluster of discrete thunderstorms moving across the Texas Panhandle transitioned into a broken linear structure during the late evening hours of the 6th. As this broken line of storms moved over the town of Canyon (Randall County), the local fire department reported that several large tree limbs were blown down in the Rockwell Road area (Randall County) from estimated 59 mph thunderstorm downburst. After producing this gust the line of thunderstorms continued moving eastward across the Panhandle.
Amateur radio reported that trees and power lines were down along FM 730 in the city of Briar, TX.
Power lines and power poles were blown down along County Road 133 off of Highway 44.
Nickel sized hail was reported 11 miles west of Denton.
Several public reports showed 1-2 sized hail fell in Rockwall, TX.

A left-moving supercell produced a swath of large hail generally from near Sundown northeast to Levelland.  Trained spotters estimated the hail ranged in size from ping pong balls to as large as tennis balls.  The worst hail damage was noted in Levelland where many vehicles suffered cracked or shattered windows, particularly at the Covenant hospital.  Several homes in Levelland also sustained varying degrees of roof damage including some broken windows.
Part of the metal roof of a business near West Park Row Road and South Bowen Rd in Arlington was blown off by thunderstorm winds.
There were power poles blown down in Ballinger due to strong winds.
This report was received from mPING.
Damage was confined to a few felled pine trees, broken tree tops and tree limbs.  This tornado remained in Nacogdoches County, TX.
Golfball sized hail fell in Parker, which is approximately 5 miles east of Rio Vista.
A total of 8.25 inches of rainfall was measured 6 miles northwest of Rodessa in Cass County, Texas, midnight through 930 am cst.
Photos of hail up to golf ball size from Emergency manager.
Law enforcement officials reported golf ball size hail in Girard. No significant damage was reported.
Light struck and caused a fire at an oil storage tank near Crystal Beach.
Nickle size hail was reported at the NWS San Angelo office.
A trained spotter reported hen-egg sized hail in Cedar Hill.

A splitting discrete thunderstorm moved northward across Gray County during the evening hours of the 8th. The Gray County Sheriff's Office reported quarter size hail  (1.00 inch) as the thunderstorm moved over the northern portion of Pampa (Gray County). The thunderstorm continued to move to the north before dissipating over northern Ochiltree County.
Trees down blocking roadways on the Texas side of Texarkana. Trees down on 2 homes. Power lines were also down on Kings Highway north of Interstate 30.
Amateur Radio report egg size hail (2.25) in Honey Grove.
There were broken windows in some homes in Eldorado. Also, quarter size hail was reported.
A public report indicated half-dollar size hail approximately 8 miles east-northeast of the city of Sulphur Springs, TX.
Reported in Robstown.
A member of the public reported 0.46 inches of rain in quick bursts over the course of two and one half hour in southwest Amarillo (Randall County).
Emergency management reported that two overhead doors were damaged by high winds at the volunteer Fire Department approximately 1 mile south of Bowie on Highway 59.
A report of hen egg-sized hail was received from mPING. The time was estimated from radar.
The Ralls Fire Department reported nickel size hail in Ralls at 20:16 CST.
Hail fell in the community of Price.
Amateur radio reported 60 MPH wind gusts on FM 1202 north of Gainesville.

The third severe thunderstorm of the night dropped a great amount of quarter to half dollar size hail on far east El Paso. Unfortunately several car dealerships are located in this area and experienced damage to new vehicles. Hail sales were advertised for weeks to follow.
A 58 mph thunderstorm wind gust was measured at the Corsicana Airport.
Public reported hail up to ping pong ball sized in Seventeen Lakes.
Hail report received via mPing.
Quarter size hail observed in Corrigan.

Amateur radio operators estimated winds between 60 and 70 mph in Sulphur Springs. Several trees were blown over, and numerous carports were damaged. Additionally, the Sulphur Springs airport had several airplanes moved or damaged as a result of the storm.
An emergency manager reported quarter to ping pong ball size hail south of Kemp.
Ping pong ball size hail fell on the south side of Mount Vernon at Mount Vernon High School.
Both the front and back porches of a home were damaged by wind.  Several large trees down as well.

Newspaper articles reported that hail damaged cotton crops across southeastern Lamb County during the afternoon hours of the 26th. At least 400 acres of cotton were beaten up south of Littlefield. Reports indicated that many leaves were stripped from the cotton plants by hail estimated up to one inch in diameter. In addition to hail, strong winds accompanied the storm, and were sufficient to break small tree limbs at a farmstead south of Littlefield.

An NWS Employee sent in a picture of a power pole leaning on Grimes Rd east of the Fire Station. Time estimated by radar and the wind gust recorded at Valley International Airport (KHRL) during the event.
A thunderstorm produced wind gust estimated at 70 mph that knocked down a large tree at the intersection of McNeil Dr. and W. Parmer Ln. in northern Austin.
Some trees were blown down near Elm Mott.
Several trees were downed.
A few trees were downed on FM. 747 north about 6 miles from Hwy. 79.

Lightning strike at Richmond Police Department. Lightning struck an antique 1897 flag pole atop building and exploded it into several splinters. One 4 foot section of the pole was reported to have embedded itself in the ground across the street from the police station.
Tree limbs down which shattered two cars' windshields.
Public report of 1 inch hail southeast of Greenville conveyed via mping.
Downed trees were reported along Dartmoor Drive, Mustang Trail, and Saddlebred Trail in the Carter Ranch subdivision, and a downed power line was at Coit Road and Vest Lane.

An official storm damage survey was made of the estimated tornado path length and width.  A home and farm equipment were severely damaged.  Several large trees and power poles were also knocked down.  Several areas of non-tornadic downburst winds were also assessed...primarily in the west and southwest areas of Wheeler county.
Penny-size hail reported (Key Map 295X)
Dime sized hail was reported along the north side of Texarkana at Summerhill Road and Interstate 30.
The public reported penny size hail along Farm to Market Road 94 just south-southwest of Northfield.
Ping-pong size hail was reported in Davilla.
Trees were downed on the west side of town including one which fell on top of a car on the Texas side of State Line Road. No injuries were reported.
Public reported tennis ball size hail 5 miles southwest of Hatchel.
Quarter size hail was reported just west of Haslet.
Penny size hail fell at the intersection of Interstate 45 and Highway 31 near Corsicana.
Baseball sized hail reported along Community Drive in Alvin.
Trees were blown down across multiple roadways several miles west of Linden.
Three power poles were knocked down by severe wind gusts.  In addition, 6-8 inch diameter tree limbs were snapped.
A roof was blown off of a restaurant.
A trained spotter measured a thunderstorm wind gust of 62 mph in Anson.
Several reports of penny to quarter sized hail throughout Bishop.
Penny hail fell near Hulen Blvd and Trail Lake Drive in southwest Fort Worth.
Public reported quarter size hail.

A National Weather Service survey crew determined a tornado caused damage to several areas in Fort Worth, Keller, and the far western portions of Southlake. This tornado occurred in a broader area of thunderstorm winds, yet a convergent path of damage was noted in Keller, especially near US 377 and North Tarrant Parkway. Several homes suffered minor roof damage, while fence and tree damage was most common. One business suffered damage to their roof and several awnings.
Golfball sized hail fell in Garland.
Hail the size of tennis balls reported from a Tyler, TX television station; report relayed through NWS Shreveport.

This tornado is a continuation from Ellis County. The tornado crossed into Dallas County near I-35E at the Ellis/Dallas County line. Light damage was noted as the tornado crossed into the county but then the tornado moved into the city of Lancaster and struck the Portofino Apartments where it damaged the roofs of two buildings and tore the roof off another building. Cars were moved in the parking lots, and the windows were blown out in one car. The tornado did significant damage to homes just northeast of the apartment complex, beginning on Sunny Meadow Dr. However, the most significant damage occurred near the intersections of Wintergreen Rd, Telephone Rd, and North Dallas Ave. Many homes in this area were heavily damaged or destroyed. Some cars were pushed into fences, many trees and tree branches were knocked down, an RV was crumpled, and some fence boards penetrated homes. The Cedar Valley Christian Academy also sustained heavy damage when it lost an entire wall. The tornado continued northeast crossing Interstate 20 near Dynasty Drive. The tornado hit a trucking company along the interstate, lofting several empty semis into the air. About 50 semitrailers were damaged or destroyed. The tornado damaged a few additional trees northeast of the trucking company and caused some minor roof damage in the Stagecoach neighborhood. The damage track ended near Palm Island St and Tioga St. In the city of Lancaster, 64 homes were destroyed, 51 sustained major damage, and another 58 sustained minor damage. An additional two homes were destroyed in the Dallas city limits. One home was destroyed when one of the semis from the trucking company was thrown into the house. The path length of the tornado in Dallas County was approximately 9.4 miles long but the total length of the tornado was 13.7 miles. Maximum estimated winds were 130 mph with a maximum width of 200 yards. Ten people in the city of Lancaster were injured, and two people sustained serious injuries.
Amateur radio reported quarter size hail near Chandler, TX. at the corner of Van Zandt, Henderson and Smith counties.
Emergency manager reported damage in the Skellytown area.
Small tree down.
Several severe hail reports were received across Lubbock County. A swath of severe hail occurred from near Woodrow through Idalou ranging in size from penny to ping pong ball size.
A report via social media indicated trees and power lines down off County Road 3341 in Paradise, TX.
Picture of 1.5 hail was reported near Country Club Road and Hwy 377 north of Argyle.
Trees downed.
The public reported golf ball size hail in Katemcy.
A storm chaser observed this very brief tornado in the open field. No damage was reported with this tornado.
Emergency management reported nickel size hail at the EOC in Bowie, TX.
A member of the public on the southwest Amarillo estimated a thunderstorm wind gust of 61 mph as the line of thunderstorms moved over his location.

The side of a metal barn was blown out. Numerous trees blown onto roofs. A 140 foot broadband tower was blown over. Several older metal barns were also blown over. Several trees were downed. One large tree was blown on top of a house. A barn door and the roof of another home sustained damage.
Trees downed near the intersection of Highway 42 and FM Road 850, including a downed tree blocking the lanes of FM Road 850.
A trained spotter reported half dollar size hail that fell at the Four Sixes Ranch.

Several trees were snapped and uprooted along FM 2426 east of Pineland, Texas.  Numerous powerlines were also downed along both sides of the road.  The tornado tracked north and crossed Hwy. 83 northeast of Pineland, snapping and uprooting several trees before lifting. Maximum winds are estimated at 70-75 mph.
Quarter size hail was reported along highway 77 north of the city of La Grange.

A thunderstorm produced wind damage near Midkiff. Two unanchored construction trailers were damaged. One injury was reported. The wind was estimated to be 60 to 70 mph. The time was estimated by radar. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Several reports of large hail ranging from quarter to golfball size were received from West Odessa.

The roof of the main building on the North Central Texas College campus was blown off due to high winds. A local newspaper also reported that tree damage occurred around the campus and many large tree limbs were knocked down. A house near the college had the roof of the back porch torn off and thrown onto the roof of the house, causing significant damage. At nearby Leonard Park, major tree damage occurred.

A tornado developed near Centerpoint Rd. and Old Zorn Rd. in Guadalupe County and continued to the north-northeast for approximately 2.25 miles into Hays County ending near Centerpoint Rd. and Viewpoint Rd. The tornado caused minor roof damage to a few homes where it first developed. As it continued north-northeastward, the tornado struck a series of electrical transmission line towers, causing 11 towers to either partially or completely collapse. The tornado continued through an open field near Centerpoint Rd. causing  mainly tree damage. Several homes east of Centerpoint Rd., in the Southridge Estates subdivision, received minor roof damage along with large tree limbs snapped. In addition, a garage with an attached apartment completely collapsed in the Southridge Estates subdivision. Peak winds were estimated to be 90-100 mph. One person was injured. At the time of this writing, there is no estimate of insured losses.

A park ranger with the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department at Palo Duro Canyon State Park estimated strong thunderstorm wind gusts. There was no damage reported and no reports of injuries or fatalities.
The emergency manager reported roof and wall damage to one home on CR 213A and also 2 metal buildings in the same area were destroyed.

Numerous trees were knocked down or uprooted approximately 5 miles southwest of Weatherford by severe thunderstorm winds. In addition, some power poles were knocked down and at least one carport was damaged.
Reported via mPING south of Westworth Village.
Roofing of a screened-in porch of a house along the bay was ripped off and flipped onto the house. The porch framing was damaged and collapsed.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that knocked down a large tree in Kirby.
Law Enforcement reported nickel to quarter size hail.
Reported by the fire department at the intersection of Texas Highway 214 and County Road 208.
Strong thunderstorm winds from 65 to 75 mph damaged a shed used to house a recreational vehicle and large tree limbs of 12 inches in diameter.
A DeSoto teenager and his dog were found dead Monday Morning in a storm drain. He was last seen Sunday afternoon.
The second severe storm within 20 minutes in Aspermont produced a round of more widespread damaging winds.  Several small tree limbs were downed in the area.
Hail up to the size of baseballs caused damage at NorthPark Center. Skylights were broken at the mall. Many cars were also damaged by the hail.
Quarter size hail reported via Twitter.

Zapata County EM reported several older houses had roofs partially removed, several metal buildings and trailers had roofs totally removed, a chain link fence was blow down, numerous trees and power lines were blown down through the city, and a large object blew off a construction site at the courthouse and damaged nearby objects. Wind speeds were estimated to be 65 to 70 mph.
A roof was torn off of a home in Hooks.
Hail up to one inch in diameter fell in Anthony which brought significant roof and vehicle damage to the area.
The tornado began on Interstate 20 at Stink Creek Road and overturned a tractor trailer rig on the interstate.
Relayed by amateur radio.
Trees were downed throughout the county.  The roof was blown off a home west of Gilmer, Texas.
Quarter size hail feel at the intersection of south first and Willis in Abilene.

A line of very strong thunderstorms approached Lavaca County from the west and developed into a bow-shape just as they crossed the county line.  The storms produced strong winds that blew down trees in a small community known as Williamsburg, about 4 miles south of Hallettsville.
Quarter sized hail fell along Highway 6 about 5 miles south of Eastland.
The Moore County Emergency Manager reported one window broken by the large hail at the Walmart in Dumas Texas.

Severe thunderstorm winds destroyed a well house, uprooted a tree, and blew over a center pivot irrigation system on a farmstead west of U.S. Highway 385 southwest of Springlake. No injuries were reported.
Winds between 70-75 mph were estimated along FM 916 between Grandview and Rio Vista.

A swath of severe wind gusts were measured from near Paducah to near Hackberry. Texas Tech University mesonet sites near Paducah and Hackberry measured severe wind gusts from 1917 CST through 1933 CST. A peak wind gust of 59 mph was measured near Paducah from 1917 CST through 1919 CST. A peak wind gust of 59 mph was measured at Hackberry at 1933 CST.
Trees were downed near Birdwell Road.
Brewster County emergency manager reported baseball sized hail at Hilltop Ranch.

A supercell thunderstorm moved southward across the Texas Panhandle during the evening hours of the 14th. An amateur radio operator reported a 60 mph wind gust as the storm moved over the town of Borger (Hutchinson County). The supercell thunderstorm continued moving southward after producing this wind gust.
An amateur radio operator estimated a wind gust of 60 mph.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts measured by a trained spotter at 51 kts (59 mph) two miles south of Sawyer Ranch Rd. and Hwy 290 east of Dripping Springs near Sycamore Springs Elementary School.

An EF0 tornado touched down 5 miles northwest of San Augustine, Tx. and tracked north northeast before lifting just south of the San Augustine/Shelby County Texas line.  The initial touchdown was just east of Hwy. 96 and west of FMm 3230 where a larger tree was uprooted.  Large limbs and tin from a chicken house was peeled back near FM. 1279.  The path width was 50 yards wide with a path length of near 4 miles. Maximum winds were estimated near 70 mph.
Dime sized hail was reported in Ricardo by Kingsville Fire Department.
The tornado remained over open country and no damage or injuries were reported. The tornado path length and width were estimated.
There was penny size hail reported at the Silver Wolf Ranch.
The ASOS at KMFE reported 2.23 inches of rain fell in 2 hours, with 1.62 inches falling in 1 hour.
Trees downed in the northwest portions of Upshur County.
The McDonald's sign and a gas awning were blown over at the E-Z Mart convenience store at I-30 and Business 271 in Mount Pleasant.
Reported between Borger and Fritch in the Meadowlark section.
Quarter size hail was reported near Willow Springs Road and Bonds Ranch Road.
Harllingen ASOS measured a wind gust of 63 mph.
Report from mPING: Quarter (1.00 in.).
Damage was reported to new and under construction homes in North Richland Hills. Time was estimated via radar.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 58 mph that flipped over six boats at the Emerald Point Marina on Lake Travis.
Trees and power lines were down throughout Bonham.
Penny sized hail was reported at the Dallas North Tollway and Highway 190 in Plano.

The Hidalgo County Precinct #4 Constable recorded 4 to 4.5 inches of rainfall across his ranch to the northwest of U.S. Highway 281, approximately 6 miles north of Linn.  High standing water of unknown depth was reported on unpaved roads and in some of the fields.
A National Weather Service Employee reported quarter sized hail near the city of Aledo, TX.
A trained storm spotter estimated wind gusts between 65 and 70 mph in San Perlita
Numerous trees were downed throughout the county.
Hail was reported on U.S. Highway 67.
The local volunteer fire department reported several trees down on FM 837, blocking the road between Hwy 19 and Hwy 155.
Large quantities of penny size hail fell in western and northern sections of Gorman.
Severe thunderstorm wind gusts were measured by the  West Texas Mesonet site near Seminole.
Golf ball sized hail occurred with a severe thunderstorm in the Kenefick area.
The KMAF Midland ASOS station recorded a 58 mph wind gust.

Tropical Storm Harvey moved into Cameron Parish with most sustained storm force winds confined to the coastal areas, however wind gusts of 35 to 45 mph were experienced well inland. These gusty winds combined with saturated soils produced conditions that allowed some trees to fall. One fell on a vehicle traveling along FM 777 near Jasper killing 2 occupants. The driver died instantly while the passenger a couple house later.
Power lines down.
A large tree at the courthouse was blown down.
Severe thunderstorms winds blew down power lines in the Cuero area.
An NWS cooperative weather observer reported hail covering the ground between quarter size to ping pong ball size. No damage was reported.
Several trees were downed northwest of Ore City, Texas.
Thunderstorm winds downed trees along FM 332.
Trees were blown down along Highway 69 northwest of Huntington.
This gust was measured at the West Texas Mesonet station 1 mile west-northwest of Fritch.
Occurred in western part of Plano at Spring Creek and Tollway.

Numerous storm chasers documented a tornado that began near the intersection of US Highway 83 and Farm to Market Road 1168. The tornado moved roughly east-southeast remaining close to Farm to Market Road 1168 and 3416 for about five miles before turning east and crossing County Road 204. An NWS storm survey revealed no known damage.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail north of Liberty Hill.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that blew down a large business sign in Bulverde.

Lightning struck a home in the Seventeen Lakes neighborhood in far north Fort Worth. The fire damaged the attic and upper story, but water and smoke damage rendered the house unlivable for a few months.
Fire and rescue reported ping pong ball sized hail near the city of Nevada, TX.
Nickel size hail fell south of the town of Terrell.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail between Oakalla and Briggs.
Emergency management reported major damage caused by a tree being blown onto a home near Lake Mexia. The tree partially punctured the roof of the home causing part of the ceiling to cave in.
Law enforcement officials reported numerous downed power poles along and near Interstate 27, while storm chasers measured a 69 mph wind gust northwest of Tulia.
A thunderstorm produced nickel size hail northwest of Floresville.
A tree was blown down by high winds.
A 60 MPH wind gust was measured on the northern side of Lancaster.  A hotel awning was torn off and trees and power lines were blown down in Hutchins.
Fire department reported power lines down.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site south of Levelland measured wind gusts up to 76 mph.
A church suffered significant roof damage in the city of Denton. Several trees were also snapped at North Lakes Park in Denton.
Dime to quarter size hail fell east of Wellington on U.S. Highway 203.

The tornado was also reported by a reliable storm spotter and touched down near Spearman Texas at 1956 CST. The tornado remained over mainly open country and lifted at 1958 CST. The path width and path length were estimated. No damage or injuries were reported.

A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that severely damaged three airplanes, two hangars, and the terminal at the Castroville Municipal Airport. There was also damage to a sports complex at Medina Valley ISD next to the airport.
Three tractor trailers were overturned by damaging thunderstorm winds. Various farm equipment were also overturned.
Numerous trees and power poles were downed in Uncertain, Texas.
A nineteen year old male working outside at a construction site was struck and injured by lightning. The victim was taken to a local hospital and later released having suffered only minor injuries.
An storm spotter reported golf ball size hail in Celina.
A mesonet observation 3 miles WNW of Doole.

The Elgin tornado began roughly 9 miles southwest of Elgin near Dry Creek Road and Union Lee Church Road. It moved northeast and crossed into Bastrop County near the end of Ingrid Dr. The tornado moved northeast crossing Upper Elgin River Rd., Balch Rd., Youngs Prairie Rd., and Crooked Hollow Rd. Significant damage was observed through this region to many homes. This included the destruction of multiple mobile homes, significant roof damage to numerous slab homes, two homes having their second story destroyed, numerous large tree limbs, tree trunks, and power poles snapped, barns destroyed, and a large electrical transmission tower toppled. Pockets of high-end EF-2 damage occurred through this region. The tornado continued northeast, crossing Monkey Rd., FM 1704, Hwy 95, and U.S. 290 producing damage to roofs of slab homes, mobile homes, trees, and power poles. Damage through this region was generally rated EF-1. As the tornado reached U.S. 290 it produced significant damage to a metal framed business, buckling the roof purlins and collapsing in the south facing wall. The tornado then rolled an adjacent mobile home into and partially on top of the south facing wall of another metal framed business. Three individuals in the mobile home were injured. Damage to the business and mobile home was on the order of high-end EF-1 to low-end EF-2. As the tornado crossed U.S. 290 a moving pickup truck was rolled onto its side, spun around 360 degrees, and rolled back upright where the driver continued down the road. Several power poles were also damaged along U.S. 290. As the tornado continue northeast a mobile home was completely destroyed off Old McDade Rd. From there the tornado gradually weakened and dissipated roughly 3 miles east-northeast of Elgin, near the intersection of FM 3000 and Mundine Rd. Damage was reported to 109 residences and one business. Of those, 32 residences were classified as major damage and 20 residences and one business were reported as destroyed. Peak wind speed was estimated at 130 mph.
Quarter-size hail fell on Interstate 10 West between Wilcrest and Kirkwood.
The supercell thunderstorm in Concho County, entered western McCulloch County and produced golfball size hail near Doole.
The Graham Leader posted that thunderstorm winds uprooted trees, knocked down at least two structures, and damaged power lines.
A photo was posted on the KLTV Facebook page of golfball size hail that fell in Alba.
Wind gusts of 60 mph were reported.

An EF-2 tornado formed near TX-317 between FM 2483 and W Adams Ave where at least a dozen power poles were significantly damaged. The tornado continued to move east/southeast across the Terrace at Lake Pointe subdivision damaging many homes, especially roofs and windows. Significant roof and tree damage was found in the neighborhood south of Tarver Elementary School. At least, four homes lost most of the roof, some outside walls, and sustained significant damage to the windows. Several trees were snapped or uprooted across the neighborhood. Then, the tornado crossed Tanglehead Dr. towards W. Adams Ave damaging many businesses, including stand-alone restaurants, shops, banks, and strip malls. A few of the businesses in this area lost most of their roof (DI 9, DODs 5 &7). Several cars sustained moderate to significant damage and cars were flipped. Most of the power poles were damaged or snapped along W. Adams Ave. The tornado continued to move southeast, crossing Old Waco Rd, damaging other homes and businesses (DI 2, DOD 6). Additional tree damage was found as the tornado tracked across an open field south of W. Adams Ave and west of S Kegley Rd. Maximum estimated winds were 120 mph.
There were widespread downed trees across Highway 30.
Hail was reported along the east side of Lake Wright Patman near near community of Domino, Texas.
Large tree limbs stripped off trees near the intersection of Katy Hockley Road and Longenbaugh Road.
Strong thunderstorm wind blew down trees and snapped large tree limbs.
A social media report indicated ping pong ball sized hail in the city of Brock, TX.
Roofs in town were damaged by high winds.
Quarter size hail was reported in Wheeler.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site at Caprock Canyons State Park measured a wind gust to 60 mph.
Two reports of damaging winds were received from Pleasant Farms and the surrounding area.  Damage included: Downed trees and power poles, power outages, and the roof of a trailer home was blown off.
Golfball size hail was reported in the community of Graford.
A semi truck blew over and blocked westbound lanes of I-20 in southeast Dallas.
A Facebook photo showed tennis ball sized hail fell near Cisco.
Hail covered the ground.
The Jack County Sheriff's office reported 65 mph winds on the south side of Jacksboro.
High winds blew away a shed, flashing was torn from the roof of city hall, and a storefront window was broken.
Large hail was reported at the Fandango Gas Plant.
The hail was reported just north of Highway 82.
Reported via mPing.
Trained spotter reported golfball size hail.  Thousands of acres of cotton were destroyed.
A thunderstorm produced half dollar size hail in Fredericksburg.
A tree was downed near SH. 42 near New London.
Measured at Fort Worth Meacham Airport.
The Dallas Addison Airport Automated Weather Observation System measured a wind gust of 71 MPH.

A discrete supercell thunderstorm produced a brief tornado southwest of Bootleg (Deaf Smith County) during the evening hours of the 28th. Several eye witnesses reported this tornado and submitted pictures. A National Weather Service survey team located the path of this tornado and verified that the tornado was very narrow which matched the description of a rope tornado given by one eye witness. The max wind estimated with this tornado was 70 mph. The tornado remained over undeveloped grasslands and produced little damage. No injuries or fatalities were associated with this tornado.
Trees were blown down in Moffat.
Emergency management reported downed power poles and a 20-inch diameter tree toppled near the intersection of CR 1100 and FM 3389  just west of the city of Sulphur Springs, TX.
A trained spotter estimated winds of 64 mph.  Trees and power lines were downed by strong winds.
Trees were reported blown down on power lines just south of the Boykin Springs Recreational Area.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that moved a horse trailer and knocked down large tree limbs northwest of Uvalde.

A home on HWY 287 south of Elkhart and about 10 miles north of Grapeland had its front porch ripped off and half of its roof torn off. The roof was laying about a 100 yards from the house. Water damage occurred inside the house as a result.
Numerous trees were blown down in Newark.
Penny-size hail in the town of Roans Prairie.
A citizen reported golf ball size hail near Cotton Center.
A trailer was pushed over and large limbs were broken off trees.  A home was also damaged.
To the east of the tornado, thunderstorm winds damaged roofs and storage buildings east of Collinsville.
Quarter sized hail was observed.
A 43 year old male was killed when a semi jackknifed on a wet road and hit the oncoming car the male was driving. The accident occurred near the intersection of TX 101 and FM 1786.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet.
The public reported ping pong ball size hail along U.S. Highway 87 between Mason and Katemcy.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near McAdoo measured severe wind gusts from 2019 CST through 2027 CST. A peak wind gust of 65 mph was measured at 2020 CST.
Roof damage was reported near Kermier Rd and Pine Tree Lane as the derecho moved through the area.
Heavy rain fell near Seagraves and the Texas Tech Mesonet reported 3.96 inches of rain in one hour.
The public reported golf ball size hail in Abernathy.
Emergency management reported half-dollar sized hail along FM 1713 at Lake Whitney.
Nickel size hail reported near 105th Street and Indiana Avenue. Damage information, if any, was not available.
A trained spotter reported ping pong ball size hail approximately 3 miles northwest of the city of Lake Worth, TX.

The Childress ASOS unit measured sustained wind speeds in excess of 60 mph for several minutes prior to a widespread power outage that occurred in the area at 2001 CST.  The peak gust measured at the site prior to the outage was 97 mph.  Major damage resulted from these winds on the western side of Childress.  A hangar at the airport sustained major damage, many homes were damaged, and numerous trees and power poles were snapped.

The public estimated 2 inch diameter hail in Wheeler. A specific location was not obtained but radar data indicates the most likely location would have been the southeast side of town. No damage was reported.
A COOP observer reported a large branch fell from a mesquite tree.
Trees were downed near the town of Marietta, Texas.
A trained spotter reported quarter sized hail on the north side of Ponder.
A thunderstorm moved across Martin County and produced tree damage and estimated 60 mph winds. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Half dollar sized hail was reported by police in Big Lake.
Two inch diameter hail near the intersection of FM 119 and county road D.
Quarter to half dollar size hail in Canyon.
A National Weather Service cooperative observer reported wind gusts estimated near 60 mph accompanied by nickel size hail at Vigo Park. No damage was reported.

A cluster of severe thunderstorms produced large hail that ranged in size from pennies to golfballs over western and central Crosby County. Quarter size hail was initially reported in Crosbyton at 20:25 CST. At 20:45, golfball size hail was reported both in Lorenzo and south of the city. By 20:41 CST, penny to quarter size hail was reported in Ralls. Hail fall persisted in Ralls until 21:03 CST. No damage was reported.
The Pecos Free Press in Pecos reported that thunderstorm winds damaged several transmission poles and downed utility lines just south of Barstow.
In addition to reporting wind damage in Ralls, the Ralls Fire Department reported hail up to golf ball size.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms initially began to produce rainfall around midday on the 1st.  This activity gradually evolved toward heavy tropical downpours, especially during the evening hours of the 3rd through the morning hours of the 4th.||The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site near Floydada measured a storm total rainfall amount of 4.63 inches.
Dime to nickel sized hail was reported at East Grand Ave and Interstate 30.
Quarter size hail was reported by law enforcement officials.
A thunderstorm moved across Upton County and produced a 68 mph wind gust near McCamey at the mesonet site.
Trees were blown down by high winds.
Emergency management measured a wind gust of 59 MPH near the intersection of Highway 59 and FM 1810.
An Emergency Manager reported an 86 mph wind gust measured by a Davis Instrument. tree limbs were reported down throughout the city.

Photographs of multiple trees and some damage to a few houses, a couple of sheds, and a couple of fences were submitted to the Jasper County Emergency Management Facebook site and passed along to the NWS. The Jasper County 911 center also reported power lines downed around Buna due to trees falling on them.
KBMT 12 relayed a report of trees downed near China.
Hen egg size hail fell 4 miles south of Farnsworth.
Approximately 10 moderate sized trees in Sulphur Springs were knocked down by thunderstorm winds. The emergency manager noted that the trees were all already dead or dying.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail on Tivydale Road which broke the observer's rain gauge.
Numerous trees and powerlines were downed throughout the entire county.

A NWS Storm Survey confirmed straight line wind damage along Highway 154 and Haynes Road. Numerous trees fell into homes, with the majority of the damage focused along Highway 154. The most significant structural damage was found along Haynes Road west of Nesbitt. It was here where a barn and carport had their metal panels completely removed from their roofs with the metal wrapped around nearby trees.
Trees were downed on Farm to Marked Road 1794 and County Road 266.
MPing report.

Rope tornado verified by broadcast media video. Several power lines were knocked down...but otherwise no other damage and no injuries. The tornado occurred over open country and the path length and path width were estimated.
Golf ball sized hail was reported.
An 18 wheeler was blown off the road and was damaged.
A storm spotter reported quarter size hail west of Girard. No damage was reported.
Amateur radio operator estimated winds at 60 mph.
A 63 mph wind gust was measured in Lindsay.
Golfball size hail was reported by the public.
Broadcast media reported that a large tree was uprooted and a small shed was overturned in the city of West along Reagan Street.
The local fire department reported golfball sized hail about a mile west of Eliasville, TX along FM 1974.
A thunderstorm moved over Brewster County and produced quarter sized hail at Terlingua Ranch Lodge.  The hail lasted fifteen minutes.

Damaging thunderstorm wind gusts resulted in a roof being blown off a house and the siding ripped off the southwest side of a building on Broadway Avenue in Maud, Texas.  A large doughnut sign was also shifted from a fixed position on top of an eatery in Maud.
Emergency management reported debris and power poles in the road on FM 664 near South Westmoreland in Ovilla, TX.
A public report indicated dime-sized hail just east of the city of McGregor, TX.
A thunderstorm produced dime to quarter size hail in Boerne.
A thunderstorm moved over Brewster County and produced golfball hail in Marathon.  Windows were broken and vehicles were dented from the hail.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
HAM radio reported quarter sized hail near Bosqueville.
The duration of the hail was estimated for this event.
A thunderstorm produced a measured wind gust of 53 kts at the Castroville Municipal Airport.
Strong outflow winds around 60 mph were reported in Prosper. The strong outflow was from a thunderstorm to the northwest of the city. Fences and fence posts were blown down.

Very strong thunderstorm winds impacted the city of Snyder. The West Texas Mesonet site recorded a peak gust of 82 mph. Widespread damage occurred across the city. At least 50 power poles were downed by these high winds. A residental and commercial carport were blown over. In addition, several commercial and residental roofs received substantial damage.  In one instance, the roof from a downtown business was tossed into an adjacent bank parking lot, causing damage to the front of a bank.  I another case, portions of an irregular shaped roof were blow onto cars in a nearby lot.
The tornado remained over open country and no damage or injuries were reported. The tornado path length and width were estimated.
Large tree limbs and powerlines down across the town.
Skywarn storm spotters reported that golfball size hail covered the ground in Lorenzo.
Lightning striking numerous buildings was the cause of local fires.
The tornado damaged the metal roof of a large business south of Beltway 8 west of Cullen Blvd. The damage path extended north of Beltway 8 into the Brunswick Place subdivision.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that snapped the trunk of a six inch diameter tree in San Marcos.
A brief tornado touchdown was reported.
A Jefferson County DD6 mesonet gauge located 1 mile east-northeast of Hamshire measured a six-hour rainfall total of 5.04 inches.
Late report of 2 homes with roof damage. The first had the metal roof completely torn off and the other had a quarter of the roof shredded.
Emergency management reported that trees were uprooted neat Lake Whitney; wind speeds were estimated between 70 and 80 MPH.

A damage survey conducted by the National Weather Service in Fort Worth found that a tornado touched down in DeSoto along Meadowbrook Road just west of Hampton Road.  The tornado traveled east-northeast to the eastern edge of the city just north of Wintergreen Road.  Several homes suffered roof damage with one home losing the majority of its roof.  There were around twenty homes that sustained damage.  Many downed trees, power poles, and power lines were noted along with damage to sheds and outbuildings.  This tornado was rated an EF-1 with estimated maximum wind speeds of 95 MPH.
Numerous trees and power lines and Telco poles reported down.  A commercial sign was also reported blown down.

A fence was reported blown in the middle of the street, and tree limbs were knocked down, behind a convenience store at the intersection of State Highway 100 and Musina Street in Port Isabel.  Damage occurred within a wind speed couplet embedded within a rain band, which had a trajectory that later produced a stronger tornado in San Pedro (southwest Cameron County) about 25 minutes later.  Estimated wind speed was between 50 and 55 mph.

Emergency management reported significant roof damage to a mobile home and fiberglass stairs destroyed in DeLeon. A 20 by 20 metal shed with tie-downs was blown apart with pieces moved up to 100 feet.
A thunderstorm produced nickel size hail in Georgetown.
A thunderstorm produced 1.5 inch diameter hail near Potranco Rd. and FM 211.
Several trees were downed in the Woden community along SR. 226.
Thunderstorm winds were estimated at 55-60 MPH in Cresson. Power outages were reported.
Baseball sized hail was observed.
A tree fell on a home on County Road 4034 near Dixie Lake.
Hail fell two miles south of Gil on U.S. 59.
Spotty damage was reported to vehicles and to the roofs and windows of buildings in the Calaveras Lake area.
Quarter size hail was reported to have covered Highway 3095.  Public report.
Several reports of golfball size hail received from the southern half of San Angelo. Damage was primarily to roofs.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail in Sabinal.
The Automated Surface Observing System at Guadalupe Pass (KGDP) recorded several wind gusts of 63 mph.  No damage reported.
Nickel sized hail was observed.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 65 mph that blew a large tree down onto a house in Converse.
The large hail shattered four windows, the siding and the roof of a mobile home.  The hail also broke all of the windows on a truck.

Sporadic thunderstorm wind damage was found extending from south of Weston to the Trinity Falls neighborhood near Hwy 75. Mostly tree damage was observed but some wood signs and shingles were also damaged. This damage was likely caused by RFD winds in the aftermath of the earlier tornado.
Thunderstorm winds destroyed a very large barn 4 miles north-northwest of Cleburne.
An amateur radio operator reported numerous cars were damaged by the large hail along U.S. Highway 83 and just north of Ballinger.
A storm chaser documented a large cone tornado. No damage survey was conducted as the tornado remained over undeveloped land.
In addition to wind, golf ball hail was reported.
Thunderstorm winds downed trees.
Widespread tree damage was reported across Euless. Many large tree limbs were broken or snapped by high winds.

A thunderstorm moved across Mitchell County and produced a tornado about 20 miles south of Colorado City. This tornado was located just west of Highway 208 and did not produce any damage so it was rated as an EF-0.
A 60 MPH wind gust was reported.
Lightning started a house fire on Vera Cruz in Frisco. Damage was to the roof and second floor. Lightning also struck an outdoor warning siren on Donnie Mayfield Way.

This tornado developed fourteen miles northeast of Lutie in northeastern Collingsworth County and tracked north northeast for about a half a mile before exiting Collingsworth County about fourteen and a half miles northeast of Lutie at 1828 CST. The tornado continued north northeast into Wheeler County before finally dissipating nine miles east northeast of Shamrock at 1836 CST. The tornado caused no damage in Collingsworth County. No injuries were reported. The damage was confirmed by a survey conducted by WFO OUN.
One inch hail was observed in Dawn.
A thunderstorm produced 2.25 inch diameter hail in Brushy Creek.
The duration of the hail was estimated for this event.
Matador Fire Department reported wind damage in Roaring Springs, TX including destruction to many car ports and out-buildings.  Numerous trees and powerlines downed by thunderstorm wind gusts.
A Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site located northwest of White River Lake recorded a thunderstorm wind gust of 60 mph at 18:50 CST. No damage was reported.
MPING report of penny size hail.
This thunderstorm wind gust was reported at the Abilene ASOS site located at the Abilene Regional Airport.
The Forestburg VFD reported golfball hail covered the ground near Forestburg.
Denton County Emergency Management office reported golf ball sized hail in Corinth.
Occurred three miles southeast of the dam.

Public reported quarter to golf ball size hail at Monte Cristo and Filegonia Road in Elsa. Hail fell at approximately 630 PM, according to the report and radar reconciliation, and appears to have continued at quarter to golf-ball sized as the updraft redeveloped over and just south of Edcouch between 630 and 640 PM CDT.

A relatively long-lived, but weak (EF-1), tornado developed rapidly within a convective complex over northwestern Lubbock County shortly before 20:00 CST and tracked north-northeastward into southwestern Hale County. ||The tornadic circulation was initially embedded within heavy rain, but was well sampled at close range by the Lubbock, Texas (KLBB) WSR-88D radar. The tornado developed just south of U.S. Highway 84 at 19:56 CST. The tornado quickly crossed U.S. Highway 84 five miles northwest of Shallowater, where a National Weather Service damage survey team found tumble weeds suspended within utility wires. The tornado then tracked north-northeastward to the west of Farm to Market Road 179.  The tornado downed utility poles, damaged four structures, a livestock trailer, and additionally uprooted a large tree before crossing the Lubbock and Hale County line one mile west of the County Line community. ||Two mobile homes sustained minor damage from the tornado. Skirting was removed from one home, and mud splatters were evident on the structure. A large roof panel was additionally removed from a second mobile home along county roads west of Farm to Market 179. A well-built permanent house sustained minor damage immediately southwest of County Line, near the Lubbock and Hale County line. A carport and outbuilding were destroyed at the residence and minor roof damage occurred from debris loaded wind. In addition, a large metal garage structure on the property was partially collapsed when tornadic winds caused the door to fail. A large boat stored within the structure was subsequently damaged when it was pushed by wind-loaded debris through a portion of the structure's back wall. ||By 20:15 CST drier air began to occlude the tornadic circulation. This allowed visibility around the tornado to improve and a National Weather Service employee began witnessing and photographing the tornado and associated utility power flashes as it approached the Lubbock and Hale County line. The tornado blew down approximately a dozen wooden utility poles along its path as it crossed into Hale County one mile west of the County Line community at 20:16 CST. ||The tornado continued until 20:20 CST in southwestern Hale County, where it resulted in additional damages to farm implements, utility poles, and an oil field shed. Damages to the two mobile homes, a single family residence and metal garage, trees, and to wooden utility poles support an EF-1 rating with estimated wind speeds between 85 and 95 mph. The tornado traveled nearly eight miles between 19:56 CST and 20:20 CST and accounted for $130,000 in damages along its path in Lubbock and Hale Counties. No injuries were reported.

A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Childress measured a peak wind gust of 64 mph between 1655 CST and 1703 CST. Additionally, a church steeple was blown over in the city of Childress.
Trees and large limbs blown down in town.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail in Granite Shoals.

A line of thunderstorms moved out of the Oklahoma Panhandle and into the Texas Panhandle during the late night hours of the 22nd. As the line neared the town of Wolf Creek Park (Ochiltree County), an amateur radio operator reported an estimated 80 mph thunderstorm downburst gust 15 miles southwest of Wolf Creek Park (Ochiltree County). After producing this downburst gust the line continued to move to the south-southeast across the Texas Panhandle.

A damage survey conducted by the National Weather Service in Fort Worth found that a tornado touched down near Happy Hill and traveled northeast approximately three miles to Pleasant Point where it dissipated.  The tornado caused significant roof damage to several homes.  Three homes were considered total losses.  At least thirty other homes received minor to major damage.  Many sheds and outbuildings were damaged or destroyed.  Several trees were uprooted and at least two of them fell onto houses.  Power lines were also downed along the track.  This tornado was rated an EF-1 with maximum wind speeds between 90 and 95 MPH.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that knocked down approximately 200 feet of fence in Andice.

Newspaper articles and local farmers reported that thunderstorm wind gusts up to 70 mph combined with torrential rainfall and small hail to cause sporadic and light damage to approximately 2,000 acres of cotton crops in the immediate vicinity of Ropesville.

A thunderstorm moved across Scurry County and produced wind damage near Snyder. A storm survey was done and the first indications of damage were southwest of Snyder,  just west of Highway 351 and approximately 2 miles south of Highway 180. From this location, the swath of damage extended northeastward across the city of Snyder for nearly 4 miles. The NWS survey team found the damage to residential and business structures indicative of that produced by winds of 85 to 100 mph. With no circulations evident, the event has been determined to be a straight-line wind event. Multiple power lines were broken and RVs were toppled over. The time of the event was estimated from radar. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Numerous confirmations of significant thunderstorm wind damage in and around the community of Munday. Damage included a large radio tower collapsed, large trees uprooted, power poles snapped and/or broken, light roof damage to multiple structures, damage to a large grain bin, and multiple windows broken. Event time is estimated from radar observations.
The public estimated one inch hail. No damage was reported.
A social media report indicated quarter size hail in the city of Reno, TX.
A roof was partially blown off of a house.
A narrow strip of wind damage about a 100 yards wide and a half-mile long was located near FM 273 and CR 2100.  Numerous trees were blown across roads and two barns sustained moderate damage.
Hail to the size of golf balls was reported in Marquez.
Several trees were downed in the Jersey Village area.
A trained spotter estimated thunderstorm wind gusts of fifty-two knots in Romero.
Trailer homes damaged by high winds along Hwy 67 in the community of Liberty Eylau.
A thunderstorm produced a 63 mph wind gust at the Midland RAWS station.
A public report of golf ball sized hail was received from the general public at 617 PM just west of the town of Cundiff, TX.

Amateur radio reported power poles and trees down near Highway 174 at Highway 3048. A second report of shed damage and minor damage to gutters and shingles at a home in this same location was also received.
There were tree limbs down across the yard. The largest limb was 12 inches in diameter. The report was from Facebook.

This storm developed over eastern Harrison County about 6 miles northwest of Waskom. This tornado first touched down about one half mile west of FM 134, continuing east across FM 9 about 3 miles north of Waskom, before entering western Caddo Parish. Numerous trees were uprooted and snapped, especially east of FM 9, and across Highway 169.|There were some homes damaged from fallen trees and also from the tornado itself near Masters Road in east central Harrison County.
Ping pong to golfball size hail was reported in Keller.
A thunderstorm produced two inch diameter hail north of Twin Sisters.
This gust was due to a 'virga bomb'.
A rural resident measured a 70 MPH wind gust from a severe thunderstorm.
Several trees reported down.
Hail was reported south southwest of Huxley, Texas.
Late report of quarter sized hail.
Amateur radio spotters reported nickel sized hail near Fort Hood.

The Emergency Management Office reported that there was metal debris from a cotton gin that was strewn about. Also, one corn field was completely stripped and destroyed from the thunderstorm wind gusts. There were no reports of injuries or fatalities.
From 1535CDT through 1550CDT the ASOS located in Dalhart gusted between 58 and  64 mph with a  line of  thunderstorms moving through.
A 68 MPH wind gust was recorded at Columbia Scientific Balloon Facility.

NWS storm survey and local video concluded an EF0 tornado, with winds estimated at 65 MPH briefly touched down in north Refugio. It touched down near the intersection of west Heard Street and north Alamo Street. The tornado removed the roof and collapsed the north facing exterior wall of one mobile home. Minor shingle damage was observed on a couple of homes along east Houston Street. Several large trees were toppled.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail in Sabinal.

A trained spotter reported a tornado touched down on the King Ranch, south of Hwy 141 and roughly 4 miles west of the main entrance to the ranch.  The tornado was on the ground for roughly 1/2 mile as it moved south, producing EF-0 damage.  Minor damage of roofing tin along with twisted mesquite trees were reported by the King Ranch.  Winds were estimated between 70 and 80 mph.
There was quarter to egg sized hail near the intersection of Franz Road and North Westgreen Blvd.
Large trees were knocked down and tree limbs were snapped near Shupak Road.

Just east of Texas Highway 349, nine miles southwest of Patricia, an anticyclonic tornado developed in view of chasers and spotters.  Based on the location of the tornado in relation to the supercell, indications are that this tornado developed on the south flank of the rear flank downdraft.
Thunderstorm winds downed a tree and some power lines.
The hail was reported at rest area.
Baseball size hail reported.
Accumulating quarter-size hail was reported on the west side of Marathon.
An off duty NWS employee reported quarter size hail in rural eastern Swisher County.
Motorists traveling along Interstate 27 encountered quarter size hail just south of Happy.
Penny sized hail reported at Highway 64 and FM 314 north of Edom.
One inch hail was reported in Canyon.
A local broadcast meteorologist reported a downed tree in Tanglewood Park.
There was widespread tennis ball sized hail neat the intersection of Highway 36 and School Street.

In North Los Fresnos, two tin roofs were lifted from old, poorly constructed trailers in a colonia neighborhood just east of the intersection of FM 510 and FM 1847 (Arroyo Blvd). Severe water and structural damage occurred at each residence; insulation was peeled from the roofs and some walls had cracked or collapsed. Both structures were uninhabitable. Nine persons were displaced.  Farther west along FM 510, a power pole was leaning at a 45 degree angle, and a mesquite tree was uprooted near the intersection of FM 803 and Henderson Road, about 4 miles to the southwest of the residential damage.
Law enforcement estimated a thunderstorm wind gust of 60 mph about 1.35 miles west-southwest of Stamford.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Lesley measured a wind gust to 62 mph.
Reported at Bell Street and Loop 335 (Hollywood Road).

Law enforcement officials reported a landspout tornado beneath a rapidly developing thunderstorm near the Castro/Swisher County line. The tornado remained in open fields near Texas Highway 86 and no damage was reported.
Trees were blown down along Highway 37 North.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet measured a wind gust to 62 mph.
CoCoRaHS observer reported golf ball sized hail at Callaghan Ranch which lasted around 10 minutes.
Spotter reports power lines were downed near Simms, Texas.
A large tree was blown down across Holly Cemetary Road near Highway 79 in east Franklin.

The EF-2 tornado touched down just east of Clover Field Airport (Brazoria County) and continued on a narrow northeast track into Galveston County. This tornado expanded in size and weakened in intensity as it approached FM 518 over the last half of its track. There was extensive tree damage along the entire track. Homes sustained partial roof loss and tree damage consistent with an EF-1 rating from east of the airport through Sunset Drive in Friendswood (Galveston County). Low-end EF-2 damage occurred on Chester Drive in Friendswood where there was complete loss of a residential home's roof. Estimated peak wind was 115 mph.
Trees downed.
Golfball size hail fell near Godley.
Golf ball size hail was reported 5 miles northwest of Allison.
A metal roof was completely blown off of a portion of a one-story apartment complex on Blackjack Street on the west side of Winnsboro. A metal roof off of a nearby barn was also partially removed.
A Trained storm spotter estimated wind gusts up to 60 mph in Spring.
A roof was blown off a home on County Road 1804 near the community of Hoard, Texas. There were no injuries reported.  The damage was a result of a small downburst.
Penny size hail observed in the Heights area.
The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet station near Denver City measured a 58 mph wind gust.
Numerous trees and powerlines downed in town.
Tornado downed numerous trees in West Columbia along Hwy 36.

A brief tornado formed in southwest Freestone County, just west of the Freestone Community.  The tornado traveled a distance of approximately one half mile, and primarily affected two structures off of Freestone County Road 841. Both structures were residences.  The first residence had a portion of the aluminum cladding from its roof removed by the tornado.  A nearby outbuilding and wellhouse also sustained damage.  The tornado also impacted a nearby manufactured home, pushing the structure slightly off of its foundation piers.  Some damage to the residence's porch roofs also occurred.  The tornado subsequently crossed Freestone County Road 841, damaging large limbs on several hardwood and softwood trees lining the road.  The tornado then crossed into an open field, traveled an additional 200 yards, and dissipated.
Limbs broken off trees.

A line of thunderstorms developed over the southern Texas Panhandle during the late night hours of the 16th. This line quickly showed indications that damaging winds would be the primary hazard. As the line moved over the town of Canyon (Randall County), an estimated 75 mph downdraft gust broke numerous tree limbs up to 10 inches in diameter off in the Hunsley neighborhood. Some roads became briefly block due to the shear number of tree limbs on the road. Road crews quickly cleared these roadways, and normal traffic flow was restored. The line continued to move to the southeast after producing this gust.

A tornado formed near the intersection of Walzem Rd. and New World Dr. This tornado produced EF0 damage as it traveled to the northeast before lifting near the intersection of Crestway Dr. and O'Connor Rd. There was primarily damage to trees and minor damage to roofs and carports (DI FR12, DOD 2).  According to City of San Antonio and Bexar County assessment, there were 4 homes that had major damage, 6 with minor damage, and 74 homes that were affected.  There is currently no estimate of monetary loss.
The public estimated a thunderstorm wind gust of 65 mph in Early.
Reported along State Highway 207.
Reported via mPING 2 miles north of Wylie.

There were reports of damage to signs, power poles, and trees in the town of Lamesa from the public. The time of occurrence is estimated from radar. The cost of damages and the maximum wind gust are also estimated.
A thunderstorm produced hail from nickel to quarter size.
A social media video indicated large tree branches blown down at a rest area near the Stephens County line, or just southwest of Hubbard Creek Lake.
Downed power poles were reported on the northeast side of Odessa.  The number of power poles was not reported, and therefore, the monetary damage was estimated for this event.
Winkler County EMC reports golf ball size hail at 113 Aiport Road in Wink.

A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Spur recorded a wind gust to 80 mph. Furthermore, a swath of thunderstorm wind damage was observed near Spur to approximately six miles north of Spur. Fire department personnel in Spur reported 20 utility poles blown over along Farm to Market Road 1868 just northwest of Spur. Also, a roof was blown off of a house near the intersection of Texas Highway 70 and County Road 466.

An EF0 tornado touched down on the west side of Queen City at around 7:41 PM CDT, about one mile west of Queen City, along Highway 96, where it uprooted a large tree. The tornado proceeded into Queen City where it caused damage to several large tree limbs and branches and caused moderate damage to the roof of a building.  This tornado then exited Cass County, Texas and moved into Miller County, Arkansas.
A 62 mph wind gust was measured at the AWOS site at NAS JRB.
A trained spotter estimated winds up to 75 mph at I-20 and Green Oaks Blvd in Arlington.
Corpus Christi International Airport ASOS measured a gust to 68 mph.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 58 mph that blew down several trees. This storm also produced quarter size hail.

Multiple public reports were received of a tornado between Shallowater and Roundup around 12:30 CST. A local farmer described observing the tornado at close range as it moved across his fields, and indicated that no damage occurred. The tornadic circulation was apparently intermittent at the ground, with a continuous funnel that visibly extended from the base of the storm for approximately ten minutes.
A few trees were downed on FM 2861 north of Hughes Spring, Texas.
Golfball size hail fell in Arp.
The Kent County Sheriff's Office reported golfball size hail.
TCOON site at Port Lavaca measured a gust to 60 mph.
Hail fell in Flint.

Member of the public shared a picture of a large tree limb, the base of which was approximated 6 to 8 inches in diameter, from a Mesquite tree blown across FM2360 near La Victoria in Starr County. Time is estimated based on radar.
Severe thunderstorm winds downed a tree near Northside Elementary School.
Wind driven ping pong to golf ball sized hail damaged windows, vehicles and fences to the southeast of Paradise. The winds were estimated at 60-70 mph.
Multiple trees were blown down onto Old Silsbee Road.
Quarter and ping pong ball sized hail.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail east of Dripping Springs.

This EF-0 tornado destroyed three sheds. Three residences also sustained structural damage. Irrigation equipment was damaged as the tornado crossed a grass field. Trees and power lines were downed, and parts of County Road 100 were blocked by debris.
Barnhart Fire Department and Rescue estimated a thunderstorm wind gust of 60 mph about 7 miles northeast of Barnhart.
Severe thunderstorm produced quarter sized hail near the intersection of Southwest Parkway and FM 2154 (Wellborn Road).
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Aspermont measured a severe wind gust of 61 mph.

A slow moving band of torrential rain/thunderstorms created areas of nuisance urban flooding from the west side of Brownsville through San Benito and parts of Harlingen during the mid afternoon of September 13th, 2014.  Generally less than 2 feet of water flooded typically poor drainage roads in the area during and just after the peak of the heavy rains.  In total, the band produced 2 to 3 inches of rain in a roughly 3 hour period.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that blew down multiple large tree limbs in Spicewood.
Quarter sized hail.
Trees were blown down on County Road 325 near De Berry.
Amateur radio relayed report of measured ping pong hail just SE of Lake Dallas.
Emergency management reported a roof blown off of a building and power lines down just east of Grand Ave on US Highway 82 in Gainesville.
Multiple trees were downed near FM 726 and Zinnia Road.
Trees were downed just south of Hemphill.

This tornado was viewed by local fire department from the intersection of FM 1057 and FM 1058. Per collaboration with radar imagery it appeared to move slowly to the northeast before dissipating. No known damage occurred with this tornado and has been given the rating of EFU.
Multiple trees were downed around Van Buren Elementary and nearby streets in Groves.
Hail fell in the community of Teaselville.

Widespread damage was reported by the Sheriff's Department across the western part of Llano County.  Trees were blown over by winds from the line of thunderstorms.  Also, widespread damage to roofs was noted.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 80 mph that blew down a tree over the southbound lanes of Hwy 77 south of La Grange.
A quickly moving tornado tore a 10 mile path through southern Taylor County. This tornado hit the community of Tuscola, where it damaged the Jim Ned high school injuring two people.
A member of the public reported nickel hail fell 7 miles northeast of Bryson.
Peak winds of 68 mph were measured in Cresson.
Baseball-size hail was reported at Morgan's Point Resort.
A trained spotter estimated 60 mph winds in Sanctuary.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail in Leakey.
Quarter to ping pong ball size hail reported.
Golf ball size hail reported at the airport.

This EF-0 tornado touched just west of the intersection of North Richmond Street and Highway 59 Business along the north side of town and continued east for about a mile. A broad swath of uprooted and damaged trees and downed power lines around 200 yards in width continued to near County Road 135. Tree fall damage was mostly towards the west-northwest with a few along the left portion of the track falling towards the southeast in a convergent pattern. Nearly all the damage was along the right side of the track which is consistent with a fast moving, weak tornado. Separate swath of damage to homes and trees about 1 to 2 miles away near the Junior High School seemed more consistent with a microburst to the right of the tornado track. Estimated peak winds were 75 mph.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 75 mph that blew the roof off of a house.
Golfball sized hail was reported along the eastern shores of Lake Livingston.
A public report was received of half dollar size hail approximately five miles south of Peacock.
Ping pong ball size hail fell just south of Cushing on FM 225 just north of its intersection with FM 343.
Report received via mPING.
The thunderstorm wind gust was estimated by a trained spotter and relayed through the Amarillo Emergency Operations Center.
A National Weather Service Cooperative Observer reported numerous downed large tree limbs.  The observer also reported downed telephone poles and power lines.
Golfball size hail damaged a vehicle.
A thunderstorm produced egg size hail on Hwy 29 east of Burnet.
Winds destroyed a garage building at a residence off County Road 411.
Broadcast media reported quarter hail in far southern Bell County.
Law Enforcement reported golf ball size hail just north of Hamlin.
The public reported tennis ball size hail 1 mile north of Early. The report was from mping.
A pivot irrigation system was flipped over due to high winds associated with a severe  thunderstorm.
Large trees were blown down. A deer blind was destroyed.
A National Weather Service cooperative observer reported that half of the roof was torn off and insulation blown out of their mobile home.
Trained spotters reported golf ball sized hail just northwest of Jacksboro.
Quarter sized hail fell between Mullin and Zephyr.
A mesonet from KFDM at Toledo Bend Dam recorded a wind gust of 59 mph.
Nickel size hail was reported 0.8 miles west of Hurst via CoCoRaHS.

A Texas Coastal and Ocean Observing Network site at Baffin Bay, just a few miles northeast of Kenedy County, recorded wind gusts up to 65 mile per hour when line of strong to severe thunderstorms rapidly developed in western Kenedy County and raced east.  Wind gusts at or above 60 mph continued until 1236 PM.  Note:  Wind gust value is used as a proxy to estimated value on the nearby promontory of northeast Kenedy County.
Nickel sized hail was observed.
A swath of severe hail ranging from quarter size to two inches in diameter fell along US Highway 287 in and near Kirkland.  Some vehicles in this area suffered cracked windshields and body damage.
Trees blown down.
Light poles were blown over in a grocery store parking lot in Trophy Club.
Reported at the Victoria Advocate Newspaper.
A trained spotter reported mostly quarter size hail 4 miles north of Moody, but some golf ball sized hail stones were mixed in.

The supercell that produced the Jarrell Tornado developed near CR 139 and Ronald Reagan Blvd., on the southwest side of Jarrell. The tornado crossed the Williamson and Bell County line near CR 304. The tornado dissipated near Prairie Dell Church Rd., just west of Interstate 35 in Bell County. In Williamson County, the tornado moved northeast from its starting point, crossing CR 234 and back across CR 239. Damage through this area was rated EF-0 and confined mainly to trees and barns. The tornado then crossed FM 487 and CR 305. Several homes received substantial roof damage through this segment, including along Villa Franco Ln. Two travel trailers were rolled at a storage lot. A stone company had large doors blown out of their business, two trailers totally destroyed, a utility pole snapped at the base, and a small metal building demolished. Damage through this area was rated EF-1. The tornado continued northeast crossing CR 396 where substantial roof damage was done to several homes. A large metal building also had its doors blown out. The damage along CR 396 was the peak of the intensity surveyed, rated EF-1 with maximum winds of 100 mph and a maximum width of 300 yards. This same area was also struck by the F5 Jarrell tornado in 1997. The tornado moved northeast crossing CR 305 and CR 307, just to the north of Jarrell Memorial Park. A small trailer was destroyed on CR 307. The tornado crossed CR 308 producing minor EF-0 damage to trees and fences.

Minor wind damage was reported in parts of south-central Lubbock as dry microburst wind activity impacted the city. Tree limbs were reportedly blown down by winds estimated near 55 mph by the public at 85th and Indiana. A satellite dish was blown off of a roof and a dog house was overturned. No significant damage or injuries were reported.
Several homes in Slidell sustained wind damage. Roof damage, blown in garage doors, and shed damage were reported. This damage is believed to be RFD-related from the tornadic parent supercell.
Vehicle collided with a downed tree at the intersection of Highway 42 and County Road 468 with one minor injury reported.
Laredo International Airport AWSS measured a gust to 50 knots.
Hail was two inches deep.

A damage survey completed in Marion and Cass counties determined that a severe thunderstorm spawned an EF0 tornado along Highway 248 just south of the Cass County line in northern Marion County. This tornado touched down along Highway 248 just south of the community of Lodi and remained on the ground before crossing over into Cass County. The damage consisted of numerous trees snapped and uprooted.
A grain bin was damaged and irrigation pivots flipped near Highway 102 and McAdams, 17 miles south-southeast of Texline.
A 64 mph wind gust was measured at the Texarkana RAWS station (TEXT2).
At least two dozen trees were downed from the 323/42 intersection and FM. 1513 near the New London community.
Some quarter size hail stones were measured by the COOP Observer in Ferris.
The Fayette County Sheriff's Department reported numerous trees blown down between LaGrange and Round Top.
Golfball-size hail on County Road 120.
A lightning strike injured a male near the intersection of FM 1485 and FM 3083 near Grangerland.
Trained spotter reported that a barn had blown some forty feet away from its original place.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet near Floydada.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet near Spur measured a severe wind gust to 64 mph.

This short-lived tornado occurred about 7 miles south of Seguin along Hwy 123. This tornado overturned several recreational vehicles, damaged several sheds and outbuildings, and damaged the roof of a house (DI FR12, DOD 2).  There is no estimate of monetary damages.
A public report indicated golf ball to hen-egg size hail in the city of Marquez, TX.

This is a continuation of the Southern Cherokee County tornado. This tornado intensified to EF-2 with estimated maximum winds around 125 mph near the intersection of County Roads 885 and 886, where the damage width broadened to near a half mile with widespread snapping of hardwood and softwood trees. The tornado maintained its intensity as it tore through the Lilbert community and approached the west side of Cushing. Widespread trees were snapped on the west side of Cushing, with single family homes sustaining partial to complete loss of their roofs. Estimated maximum winds from this tornado reached 125 mph given the total loss of roofs of single family homes on the west and north side of Cushing, as well as the collapse of exterior walls on a home off of FM 225 and County Road 967. It was estimated that approximately 30 homes were damaged in Cushing, with a total of approximately 50 structures damaged. A wooden church off of County Road 967 was completely destroyed. The tornado continued northeast along FM 225 before crossing over into Southern Rusk County. ||One injury was documented from this tornado as it tore through Northwest Nacogdoches County.

A second tornado struck near the Austin-Bergstrom airport, and was also identified by the airport observer.  It moved from 1.5 miles northwest of the airport tower northeastward across SH183 and the Bastrop Highway and dissipated around 4 miles northeast of the tower.  It also lifted and dropped during its life.
The was quarter size hail in the Berea area.
A public report of a fence down, roof of a shed removed and blown 100 yards and a 4-wheeler blown 15 yards was received approximately 3 miles northwest of Briar, TX.
Strong thunderstorm winds knocked over several shipping containers at an industrial facility in Deer Park.
Dime to penny size hail was observed at the National Weather Service office at Amarillo.
Penny to nickel sized hail fell in Frisco.
There was quarter sized hail in the Katy area.
Widespread trees and power lines were down in Mineola.
At a residence near West, high winds knocked a temporary building on its side. Tree damage and other minor building damage was also reported. Power outages were also reported in town.

A thunderstorm moved across Pecos County and produced wind damage in Fort Stockton. There were multiple trees uprooted, leaning power poles, snapped power lines, and peeled or separated roofs at several homes, apartment buildings, and businesses on the south side of Fort Stockton. The storm survey results estimated peak wind speeds to be between 70 to 80 mph. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Numerous trees down across FM 2216.
Pictures relayed through social media of quarter sized hail in Alice.

The Erath County tornado continued into Palo Pinto County.  Tree and sporadic roof damage occurred across FM 2603 to near the intersection of FM 4 and Highway 281 in southeastern Palo Pinto County.  This tornado was rated an EF-0 with maximum winds between 80 and 85 MPH.
Law enforcement officials reported a brief tornado touchdown in open country west of town.  No NWS storm survey was conducted.
Victoria RAWS site measured a gust to 67 mph. Observation reported at 0504 UTC that included severe wind gust over the previous hour. Time was estimated from radar reflectivity and velocity data.
A storm chaser reported nickel size hail just west of Littlefield.
The hail report was relayed via the Spotter Network.
Lots of trees were reported down in Corrigan.
Quarter size hail was reported near Fort Concho.
A trained spotter estimated winds gusting to 60 mph at Abilene Christian University.

Tornado touched down near Trailer World RV and Boat Storage facility then crossed Interstate 10. It did minor damage to Bucees car wash area then ripped large air conditioning units off top of Pepperl Fuchs buiding. Finally in damaged awnings near Builders First building. Tornado crossed from Fort Bend into Waller County. This entry documents Fort Bend County segment.
There was penny to quarter size hail near the intersection of Highway 60 and FM 3058.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail in Quemado.
Multiple trees were downed onto Highway 190 near Dam B.
Ping pong ball size hail was reported in Campbell.
The general public reported thunderstorm wind gusts of fifty-two knots.
A thunderstorm produced penny size hail northwest of Georgetown.
Power lines downed and numerous trees downed along Hwy. 11 near Pittsburg, Texas.
Hail up to the size of baseballs was reported 2 miles east of Gruver. The viewer reported that the hailstones were disc shaped.
A 62 mph wind gust was measured by the Automated Weather Observing Station at the Dumas airport, 3 miles west of Dumas.
Golf ball size hail fell near Gilmer.
A funnel cloud was spotted by Dyess AFB weather observer.
Severe thunderstorm winds damaged trees and blew roofs off homes in the Granger area.
An 80 mph wind gust was measured in Big Salty, 8 miles south of Runaway Bay.
