Visible damage was reported across northeastern Ochiltree county with one home and a barn sustaining severe damage.  The Highway 15 storage units were totaled by the extremely high winds and a roundtop at the Roy Hughe place was lifted by the damaging winds and moved about twenty feet.  Two large overhead doors were blown down at Tom McGee's building on the west end of Highway 15.
Jack Country Sheriff's Department reported signs blown off poles on the south side of the city of Jacksboro, TX.
The Cooke County emergency manager reported egg sized hail north of Muenster.
Law enforcement reported golf ball size hail.
Severe thunderstorm winds blew down several power lines between Barksdale in Edwards County and Camp Wood in Real County.Real County
Lightning resulted in a house fire on County Rd. 246. There were no report of injuries.

Lightning sparked a structure fire near downtown Lubbock around 16:30 CST. A local business, located in the 600 block of Broadway Avenue, lost equipment in the fire. No injuries were reported. In addition, more than 350 homes and businesses were temporarily without power due to lightning strikes to local utilities.
Golf ball sized hail was reported in the Cambridge Shores area along Lake Texoma.
Storm spotter measured a 62 mph wind gust in Rockport.
An apparent tornado crossed Farm to Market Road 1760, fifteen miles west of Muleshoe.  Several utility lines and poles were damaged.  Damage corresponds to an intense low level Doppler circulation.
The winds were sustained at 54 mph for several minutes in addition to the wind gust.
Water was over FM 1119 just south of FM 811, and water across service roads of Interstate 45 south of Centerville and west service road north of Centerville.
A public report was received of hail up to quarter size hail in Lockney.
A tree was downed on Hwy. 37 near the community of Dimple, Texas.
Video recording of metal shed/garage blown over with damage to farming equipment/vehicles. Time estimated off radar. Estimated 70 mph.
The Young County Emergency Manager reported lightning struck a tank battery, resulting in a fire. No other structures were impacted.
The roof of a local hotel was almost entirely ripped off.

A NWS storm survey concluded that a weak and brief EF-0 tornado touched down near the end of Brizendine Rd. in far NW Williamson County.  Minor roof damage was observed along with tree damage. Peak winds were estimated at 85 mph.
Law enforcement officials reported that tennis ball size hail fell in the community of Maple from an isolated severe thunderstorm over southern Bailey county. No significant damage was reported.
A thunderstorm produced an estimated wind gust of 60 mph which overturned a boat on Lake Amistad near Tank Canyon.
A tornado briefly touched down in an open field south of the town of Ballinger.
Golf ball sized hail was reported on Highway 180 just west of Palo Pinto.

A supercell moved across Hartley County during the evening hours of the 9th. As the storm moved south of Dalhart (Hartley County), local law enforcement reported golf ball size hail (1.75 inches) eight miles southwest of Dalhart (Hartley County). After producing this hail, the supercell continued to moved eastward across the county.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Morton measured a severe wind gust of 67 mph.
The cooperative observer reported strong winds as a result of a collapsing thunderstorm.
A trained spotter measured a 62 mph wind gust in Cottondale.
Report was received via social media.
A wind gust to 64 mph was also measured at 2128 cdt.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet near Aiken.

An EF1 tornado touched down 8.5 miles west southwest of Gilmer, Texas.  Damage consisted of numerous trees uprooted or snapped.  One tree fell on a house but damage was minor to moderate.  Estimated peak wind speeds were between 95-105 mph.  The path length wsa 2 miles long with a path width of 700 yards wide.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Silverton measured severe wind gusts from 2106 CST through 2113 CST. A peak wind gust of 79 mph was measured at 2109 CST.

The West Texas Mesonet site 2 miles west-southwest of Clarendon reported a 61 mph downburst wind as a thunderstorm collapsed near the station during the late night hours of the 15th. After this storm collapsed, no other thunderstorms were able to reach severe levels.
Emergency management reported several trees down near the city of Becker, including one that fell on a house.

A roof was blown off of a house under construction on FM 344 near County Line Baptist Church between Teaselville and Bullard. In the vicinity of that location, a hay ring was moved, several trees were blown down, and large branches were broken.
Frisco, TX fire department reported a house fire caused by a lightning strike at the 13881 block of Round Prairie Lane.
A funnel cloud was sighted just outside of Aldine.
Trees were downed on the west side of New Summerfield on Hwy. 79 east of the Mud Creek bridge.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet located 4 miles south of Levelland.
A thunderstorm produced a 61 mph wind gust near Snyder.

An NWS Storm Survey was conducted on South Padre Island and found several areas of damage along South Padre Island. The survey found a couple of downed fences in the Isla Blanca area on the southern side of the island along with a couple of flipped recreational vehicles (RVs) that were exposed to the wind but only anchored by unfastened scissor jacks. The flipped RVs were initially reported by a member of the public shortly after the storms moved offshore. Winds here were measured at the Brazos Santiago (BZST2) Texas Coastal Ocean Observing Network site (TCOON) to be near 84 mph. A little farther north along the island, the metal roof at Longboards was peeled back along with a canvas type material that was blown onto the second story balcony of an older apartment complex along W Palm Street. Some of the most extensive damage was witnessed at the El Castile Condo at the corner of W Polaris Dr and Laguna Blvd, which lost its roof and roof decking and exposed at least two dozen units to the elements during the storm. Lastly, the South Padre Island Convention Center's Main Exposition hall lost a significant portion of its roof along with a snapped ash tree nearby, suggesting wind speeds remaining near 85 to 90 mph. Additionally, South Padre Island Police Department reported multiple powerlines down across the island immediately after the event.||Note:  times listed are based on the survey results. All severe criteria (58 mph or greater wind gusts) occurred between 148 and 206 AM based on reports from various platforms in the area.
A NWS cooperative weather observer reported a swath of wind blown hail that damaged a 12 mile long stretch of cotton in Motley and Hall Counties between Northfield and Turkey.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Brownfield measured a wind gust of 58 mph.

Numerous reports of damage were received in the Legends Park Subdivision. Cars had broken windows and heavy dents. Solar panels were damaged. Roofs and windows of homes were also damaged. This was caused by a combination of large hail and damaging winds. Time is estimated from radar. Hail size is approximate, and property damage cost is estimated.
Dime to penny size hail was reported between Donna and Alamo.
Several large branches were blown down. The largest branches were 12 inches in diameter and were 8 to 10 feet long.

This tornado developed from the same supercell that spawned the large tornado near Jayton. The tornado that formed in northern Fisher County was photographed by a constable. Also numerous storm chasers were following the storm as well as it went through northern Fisher County.
This EF-0 tornado downed or snapped several trees, including one on a trailer.
A thunderstorm produced hail that covered the ground with drifts up to eight inches deep. The largest hail was golf ball size.
A thunderstorm produced quarter to ping pong ball size hail south of Bastrop.

As a late night cold front moved across Southeast Texas, a brief EF-0 tornado formed on the southeast side of the Brazoria Reservoir and damaged some trees and power lines. There was also minor structural damage to some nearby homes.

A downburst on the periphery of a mesocyclone produced estimated wind gusts as high as 75 mph from about three miles west of Wolfforth to four miles southeast of Wolfforth.  Several power outages were noted across this swath as at least 34 power poles collapsed.  Some areas remained without power for two days until utility crews could replace poles that were previously inaccessible by swollen playa lakes.  Wind damage was most prevalent in a subdivision south of Wolfforth where many roofs and fences would require repair or complete replacement.  Some north-facing windows were completely shattered by these high winds along with large hail reported to be as big as tennis balls.  Various rural residences suffered similar damages.  Many tree limbs were downed in addition to some trees being completely uprooted.

A tornado began in western Wise Co near El Lago Road and Private Road 1732. The tornado damaged trees and 2 mobile homes in the early part of the track. The most significant damage occurred to property along Moonlight Bay Drive. Dozens of trees were uprooted, snapped or damaged in a wide swath. The roof was partially torn off of one house when the winds entered the garage and tore off the roof over the garage. The tornado then moved over Lake Bridgeport continuing to the northeast. It damaged more trees on the northeast side of the lake between the lake shore and County Road 2952. It did cross CR 2952 but its dissipation point could not be determined as it moved into unreachable land on the east side of the road. The tornado dissipated before reaching the town of Chico. The tornado traveled just over 4 miles and was about 0.3 miles wide at its widest point. The maximum winds were estimated at 110 mph.
The automated weather station at Rockwall Municipal Airport reported a 54 kt wind gust. In the area, damage to fences and carports was reported.

A brief tornado occurred east of Perryton and crossed County Road 377 and County Road 24. Damage to trees, a barbed wire fence, and the roof of a barn were observed. Three power poles were broken. The tornado was rated EF-1 with an estimated maximum wind speed of 98 mph.
Large hail between two and three inches in diameter fell in the Pineview community near the Wood, Camp, and Upshur County line.
Strong thunderstorm wind gusts downed a large tree, which fell onto and damaged a mobile home.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that blew down a tree onto a powerline in Lockhart.
Trained spotters reported quarter sized hail 3 miles west of Capps Corner.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Dimmitt measured severe wind gusts from 1654 CST through 1705 CST. A peak wind gust of 70 mph was measured at 1656 CST.

A small EF0 tornado formed early Friday morning as showers and storms were moving north through western Lavaca County. The tornado touched down just northeast of Moulton in Lavaca County and traveled 1.9 miles and then crossed into Fayette County about 100 yards west of CR 257. It continued for another 0.9 miles in Fayette County. Tree damage was found on E. Wiedemann Rd. just on the other side of the Lavaca County line in far southern Fayette County.  It appears that the weak tornado dissipated near this location as no other damage was found farther north. Maximum winds were estimated to be 75 mph.
Lightning struck the Fort Worth Weather Forecast Office and destroyed two computers and damaged Amatuer Radio equipment.
Penny size hail.
A trained spotter reported tree limbs down in Arlington.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 68 mph in Lake View.
Emergency management in Dickens County reported quarter size hail about two miles south of Spur.

F2 tornado in Ralls.In assessing the damage from the F3 tornado, the debris field diminished in areal coverage as the tornado tracked farther to the northeast along the end of its path.  Damage assessment and public accounts of the storm suggested the tornado weakened and lifted.  Meanwhile, a second tornado developed. This occurrence coincided with a break in the debris field observed during the Survey.  This cycle of one tornado weakening and lifting while another tornado forms to the right of the former path is typical in well-organized tornadic thunderstorms. This second tornado developed approximately 1.5 miles west of Ralls and tracked to the north and northwest before dissipating three miles north of Ralls. The tornado damaged a residence and a nearby barn. Two thousand pound bales of hay were tossed from one side of US Highway 62/82 to the other as the tornado scattered debris to the south and southwest across an adjacent field.  In addition, a vehicle was overturned on the property within debris from the residence and power poles were either blown down or snapped and center pivots overturned.
Tennis Ball size hail was reported at FM 485 and US 77, approximately 4 miles north of Cameron.

The NWS conducted a storm survey in Red River County, Texas in the town of Avery and determined that the damage was consistent with that of a weak tornado.  An EF0 tornado began along CR. 3326 where it snapped numerous trees, damaged the roof of the school gym and a dugout at the baseball field before lifting on the east side of town.  Winds were estimated to be near 85 mph.
The City of Fort Worth responded to 40 fallen tree requests from high winds moving through the city.
The public reported tree limbs snapped and a storage shed blown over.
The broadcast media reported the hail at the Love's Truck Stop at Interstate 40 and Arnot Road.
A thunderstorm moved over Brewster County and produced nickel sized hail three miles west southwest of Alpine.
Quarter size hail fell in New Boston.
The Texas Department of Public Safety reported several 60 mph wind gusts just east of Barstow.
Quarter size hail reported 7 miles south of Rusk.
The hail was reported near Farm to Market Road 998 and County Road O.
A tree was blown down across FM 1798 in front of the Laneville ISD campus.

The Texas Department of Public Safety estimated the thunderstorm wind gusts about four miles east of Adrian Texas in Oldham county. There was no damage and there were no reports of injuries or fatalities.
Thunderstorm winds downed trees along Highway 6 in the Hempstead area.
Storm chasers observed a brief tornado in western Hardeman County, estimated to be approximately 2 miles east of Lazare. No damage is known to have occurred.
Heavy rain occurred in Scurry County. The West Texas Mesonet measured 3.34 inches of rainfall. The duration of this rainfall is unknown.
A trained spotter reported quarter sized hail approximately 8 miles south of Decatur, TX.
Damaging thunderstorm winds knocked down trees, power lines, and tree limbs near the intersection of Cummings Drive and FM 917.
Amateur radio reported quarter-sized hail in the city of Midlothian, TX.
Hail up to the size of golf balls was covering the ground in Southlake.
A CoCoRaHS observer reported nickel size hail about 10 miles northeast of Silver Valley.
Numerous trees down countywide. Metal building damaged along with fire station's communications tower toppled in Cleveland.
A thunderstorm moved across Pecos County and produced a 71 mph wind gust at the Fort Stockton ASOS site. No damage was reported.
Reported ten miles east southeast of Buffalo Lake.
Thunderstorm wind gusts downed some trees.
Trees, powerlines, and barns were blown down.  A mobile home was damaged and a carport was destroyed.
A chimney was damaged by thunderstorm winds; report relayed by the media.
Storm spotters reported golfball size hail.
Dime sized hail was reported near Highway 199 and Newsome Mound Road.
This tornado uprooted some trees.
A trained storm spotter reported wind damage from a thunderstorm. It damaged a tin building and a couple of roofs in town.
Trained Spotter and meteorologist/storm chaser from University of Louisiana report of a tornado.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 58 mph that blew a tree down.
Trees downed on Hwy 67.
A 58 mph wind gust was measured in Trenton.
Broadcast media reported 4.5 inch diameter hail 7 miles north of Saint Jo.
Local newspaper reported a light pole and a couple of power lines downed.
Numerous reports of quarter-size hail in and near Greenville.
Peak winds of 70 mph were estimated in Granbury.
The Dallas County EOC reported quarter size hail near I-30 and Hampton Road in Dallas.
Public reported nickel size hail near Laureles.
The public reported that the hail was six inches deep.
Pea to penny sized hail fell in the 1000-1100 block of East Bowie Street for 10 minutes.
Golfball size hail was reported just east of Loop 635 along US 80 in Mesquite.
Several trees uprooted and a roof was partially removed from a house. Several powerlines downed.
Emergency manager reported 1 inch hail north of DeSoto.
Power lines were blown down at 34th Street and Globe Avenue in eastern Lubbock.
Trees were blown down on FM 2137 about a mile north of FM 855.

Numerous trees were blown down throughout Upshur County, including Crabapple and Crepe Myrtle Road just south of Pritchett, Willow Oak Road, Mockingbird Lane, Highway 154, FM 556, and Silver Maple Road. Trees and power lines were downed on Aspen Trail near Pritchett. Two trees fell onto power lines near the Harmony School.
A public report indicated widespread tree damage in Town Lake Park in the city of McKinney. Images included trees both snapped and uprooted.

A line of severe thunderstorms moved across Oldham County during the early afternoon hours of the 24th. As this line moved over the town of Boys Ranch (Oldham County), local broadcast media reported golf ball size hail (1.75 inches) in town. After producing this hail the line of storms continued moving southwestward across the county.
Lightning struck a house on Lookout Knoll Dr. causing a fire in Leander.
Thunderstorm winds damaged a house roof a half mile south of Sidney.
There was a lightning strike that caused a house fire on Legends of Hutto Trail near state highway 1660.
Wind gust was measured at KCFD.
Thunderstorm wind gusts downed a utility power pole and damaged several power lines.
A large tree crashed through a ceiling at a residence.

Johnson Space Center recorded this wind gust from an anemometer on the top of a building 152 feet above the ground. This speed is an estimated 65 mph gust at the surface. Many small trees and tree limbs were snapped and blown down across a large part of the JSC complex.
Quarter sized hail fell and was measured in Whitehouse. Reports via ham radio, with pictures shared via social media.

A small but severe thunderstorm, featuring a bow-shape on its front edge and containing small cores of microbursts, raced through southwest Starr County around 1030 PM CDT September 17th. One of those microbursts reached ground.||KRGV-TV-5 reported structural damage in the small community of Fronton (along the Rio Grande). Damage included at least two roofs torn off/peeled back, several fences blown down, power lines blown down, and numerous large mesquite and live oak limbs broken off trees.
A thunderstorm produced baseball size hail on Wishata Way in the Legend Hills subdivision in northwestern San Antonio.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet located 10 miles west-southwest of Guthrie.
Thunderstorm winds turned over RVs and trailers at Texas Motor Speedway. Signs, fencing, and flag poles were also damaged.
A thunderstorm produced penny to quarter size hail three miles northeast of Round Rock.
A second severe thunderstorm developed on the east side of the city.  This thunderstorm resulted in dime size hail.

Thunderstorm winds down trees and power lines from Highway 150 to the southwest of the Coldspring area to along Highway 190 in the Point Bland area. There was also a report of a tree down on FM 2025 south of Coldspring.
Golfball size hail reported near Walls Hospital at Henderson and HWY 67 in Cleburne.
Law enforcement in Yoakum County reported widespread power outages in the town of Plains due to blown down power poles.
Baseball to 3 sized hail was reported in The Colony.

Severe thunderstorms produced an intermittent swath of large hail over portions of Terry County for nearly an hour during the late afternoon and early evening of the 27th. Golf ball size hail was initially reported along U.S. 62/385 near the Gaines and Terry County line at 16:42 CST. By 17:22 CST, hail up to the size of nickels was reported northwest of Brownfield. Nickel size hail continued to accompany the storm northeastward to near Meadow by 17:39 CST.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Floydada measured severe wind gusts from 1851 CST through 1855 CST. A peak wind gust of 62 mph was measured at 1851 CST.

The National Weather Service in Lubbock, TX conducted a damage survey in Petersburg, TX in Hale county.  The tornado was a long-lived occurrence across southeast Hale county and traveled into southwestern Floyd county.  Significant damage resulted from a tornado at a local tractor business in Petersburg.  The roof was blown off the structure causing internal damage to equipment and furniture.  Debris was blown across the street and damaged a residence.  The tornado cut a path through the business and scattered debris for up to a mile.  Several power poles were snapped as the tornado propagated to the east.  The debris field surveyed indicated the tornado went through a cycle of frequently lifting and then regaining contact with the ground.
Public reported quarter sized hail 2 miles southeast of Kennedale via mPING.
A thunderstorm moved over Reagan County and produced a 70 mph wind gust in Big Lake.  The wind blew the roof off of the Mustang Inn.  The cost of the damage is a rough estimate.
Personnel at the Maple Gin reported golfball size hail.
Severe thunderstorm wind gusts downed trees along FM 975 in the Caldwell area.
Law enforcement officials estimated 70 mph thunderstorm wind gusts.
At 2 miles northwest of Perryton, the roof of a hay barn was partially blown off.
|Local law enforcement officials reported penny size hail east of Post along U.S. Highway 380.|
Reported via mPing.
A trained spotter reported half-dollar sized hail 1 mile south-southeast of Gatesville, TX.
Ping pong ball size hail reported in the Leesburg community.
Hail was reported east of Henderson, Texas.
The Emergency Manager at Trinity University reported significant tree damage across campus.
Penny-sized hail between Angleton and Alvin.
A tree was blown down across Farm to Market Road 1087 about 100 yards east of Highway 259.
Tennis ball size hail reported at the Family Dollar store in Clarksville.
Law enforcement officials reported golfball size hail.
McMullen County Sheriff Deputy reported a funnel cloud north of Tilden.
A thunderstorm produced baseball size hail at the Tapatio Springs Hill Country Golf Club outside Boerne.
Three inch oak branches were broken near FM 2190 and JT Graves Lane northwest of Jacksboro.
Trained spotter reports 65 mph wind gust 3 miles NNE of Plano.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 65 mph which blew down tree limbs northeast of Granite Shoals.
Several 3 inch diameter tree limbs, about 10 feet long, were blown down on the northwest side of Breckenridge.
A video was taken of a tornado crossing a rice field. No damage.
Amateur radio spotters reported golf ball sized hail between Kemp and Kaufman, along US 175.
Hail fell at 47th and Red River Street.
Trained spotter reported golf ball sized hail in north-northeast Cleburne.
Nickel size hail was reported at the intersection of I-20 and Bowman Springs.
KF46 measured a 57 mph / 50 kt gust.
Golf ball size hail.

Law enforcement reported 4 light poles blown down by high winds near mile marker 49 on Interstate 10. Extensive hail covered the ground and 0.49 inches of rain was reported in 20 minutes at Fabens Elementary School.
A thunderstorm moved across Pecos County and produced a 60 mph wind gust at Fort Stockton.
A thunderstorm produced a severe wind gust at the McDonald Observatory.

A two-story home was struck by lightning at 3 Golden Thrush Place and a fire was reported in the attic and roof. Lightning plot and radar imagery indicate the strike causing the fire could've occurred any time between 2-305 pm CST.
Golf ball size hail on US 87 2 miles west of Dumas.

Several large trees were downed in Kilgore, Texas.  One tree fell on top of a carport on Lantrip Street off of Hwy. 259.  Another tree fell across a fence in town.  Trees were also downed at the Kilgore, Police Department and a tin roof was blown off a building.

This tornado touched down just south of I-20 on the southern end of Waskom just west of Magnolia Road.  The tornado caused minor damage to metal buildings and equipment at Red Diamond Oilfield Services.  The tornado then tracked south southeast uprooting and snapping trees along its path and causing damage to a few residential homes. The tornado lifted about 0.5 miles south of I-20 and 0.25 miles east of Magnolia Road.
One large tree was partially uprooted and numerous shingles were blown off the west side of a house.
Amateur radio reported nickel-sized hail in the city of China Spring, TX.
Barns were damaged and trees were blown down.
The public reported severe thunderstorm wind gusts to at least 60 MPH. No reports of significant damage were received.
Spotter reported a large air conditioning unit blown off of the White Deer Elementary School. The AC unit was mounted on the roof.

Scattered thunderstorms developed across Hartley County during the afternoon hours of the 22nd. As a storm approached the town of Channing (Hartley County), a trained storm spotter reported an estimated 70 mph thunderstorm downburst which turned over a center pivot irrigation system 5 miles northwest of Channing (Hartley County). After producing this downburst, no further severe weather was reported.
Hail the size of hen eggs reported.
A thunderstorm produced baseball size hail in Cherry Spring.
A public report indicated nickel sized hail approximately 2 miles west-southwest of the city of Corinth, TX.
A 70 MPH wind gust was measured by amateur radio operators.
Reported on Farm to Market Road 281 just east of State Highway 70.
Nickel sized hail fell at Dallas North Tollway and George Bush Turnpike.

A NWS cooperative weather observer as well as numerous storm chasers reported hail up to baseball size near Grow and along US Highway 83 to the north and south of Grow. Many windshields and storm chaser vehicles were damaged.
Power lines and trees were blown down.
Off-duty meteorologists reported a tornado.  This tornado was also filmed by a TV station near Troy.  A few home roofs were damaged.
Power poles blown down on Old Iowa Park Road between Loop 11 and Central Freeway. Time is radar estimated.
Law enforcement officials reported that strong thunderstorm wind gusts blew an eighteen wheeler off the road. No injuries were reported.
Numerous power poles were blown down along Elmdale Road.

This tornado developed northeast of Log Cabin with the first|visible damage associated to snapped trees. As the tornado moved |north/northeast, a tall communications tower was snapped in half. |Eventually, the tornado crossed paths with several homes which led|to complete destruction and many debarked trees. The damage path |continued to the northeast, eventually stopping near the|intersection of Van Zandt County Road 2903 and FM 1256. As this|tornado occluded and dissipated, the next tornado began in the next|few minutes.
An EF0 tornado briefly touched down at an oil refinery.  There was minimal damage to one of the buildings, and one vehicle's window was shattered.
A porch was blown down by high winds.
Ping pong ball to golf ball size hail fell in Forsan, TX.
A West Texas Mesonet site measured a gust of 68 mph, 7 miles northwest of San Angelo.
The Fire Department reported golf ball size hail about 5 miles west of Clyde. The time was estimated on radar.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail at Park St. and Hwy 183 in Cedar Park.
The general public located two miles east of White Deer estimated thunderstorm wind gusts of fifty-six knots.
A metal shed was reportedly blown over due to the strong winds.
A 2-foot pecan tree was blown down in Olney. Outbuildings and fences were also damaged.
Two inch tree limbs broken off of tree.
Power lines were blown down.
Amateur radio reported a tree blown onto a home near the city of Seven Points, TX.
A social media report indicated hen-egg size hail near the intersection of Main Street and Pinebridge Drive in the city of Frisco, TX.
Emergency manager reported 60 mph winds near and north of Whitesboro. Damage was reported along HWY 377 at Ferguson Rd north of Whitesboro.
Large tree limbs were blown down in residential areas of Gun Barrel City.
This tornado was reported by the Department of Public Safety in Chillicothe. The tornado traveled a very short distance before dissipating, and no damage occurred.
Golf ball sized hail was reported near Sebastopol.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet.
Severe thunderstorm winds downed trees near the intersection of University Drive and the Hwy 6 bypass.  Power lines were downed near the bypass and Harvey Road.
Facebook report of large amounts of quarter size hail on CR 215.
One inch diameter hail was reported in Mission Bend.
Town of Halfway.
A public report indicated quarter sized hail approximately 4 miles southwest of the city of Sanctuary, TX.
A wind gust of 58 mph was reported.
Wind driven hail caused extensive damage to  house and trees. All windows on north side  of house were blown out.

The cone shaped tornado was verified by video from storm chasers and remained over open country where it damaged or destroyed crops such as cotton...milo and wheat. No injuries were reported. The tornado path length and path width were estimated.
Significant damage to cotton crops resulted from the wind-driven hail.
A couple died in an early morning house fire that fire investigators determined was started by lightning.
Hail reported received via mPing.
Emergency management reported trees down throughout the city of Mansfield, TX.
Public sent a photo of hail up to the size of ping pong balls between Calallen and Robstown.
Nickel hail was covering the ground approximately 6 miles east of Wolf Creek Park. The hail occurred near the Ochiltree County line, near County Road V.
The public estimated hail as large as baseballs in Tell. Instances of damage to property or crops were unknown.
Public photo of 2 inch hail submitted.
Local farmers reported that thunderstorm winds destroyed at least six irrigation pivot systems northwest of Hale Center.
Hail stones measuring 1 to 1.5 inches were reported approximately 4 miles south of Lipscomb.
Wind gust occurred at the Brazoria County Airport ASOS site KLBX.
A large tree limb fell on a home causing minor roof damage near Hwy. 271 on the northeast side of town.
A thunderstorm produced penny size hail in Kerrville.

An EF-0 tornado with maximum estimated winds around 80 mph touched down along County Road 3109 where it damaged the roof of a one story home. This tornadic storm traveled northeast where it damaged the roof of Liberty Hill Church located along County Road 3109. The tornado also uprooted several hardwood trees before dissipating along Highway 992.
Nickle to quarter size hail reported on south side of Laredo.
A trained spotter reported golf ball sized hail just east of the city of Moody, TX.
Golfball size hail fell on the north end of the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport.
Reported at Farm to Market Road 2186 about one mile west of Soncy Road. Several homes had damage to roofs and skylights from the hail.

Thunderstorm wind gusts knocked down numerous trees and powerlines across all of Sabine County.  Law enforcement officials described the damage as major with all the trees across county roads and highways.  Some trees fell on homes and automobiles with power outages widespread across the county.

A thunderstorm moved across Scurry County and produced wind damage in the southeast part of the county. Severe winds overturned a manufactured home near CR 4136 and CR 465 that resulted in one injury. This home was properly anchored to the ground but the survey team found that the estimated 110-120 mph winds caused the tie-down straps to fail and the house to roll from its original location. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Social media image showing minor tree damage. Time is radar estimated.
Amateur radio reported quarter-sized hail approximately 4 miles north of the city of Weatherford, TX.
Reported on Highway 385.
Large tree limbs were blown down at the intersection of Corral Avenue and 6th Street in Kingsville.
Golfball size hail fell in Weatherford.
Siding was pulled off of a home. Pea sized hail also reported.
Several customers at the Honey Island general store reported large hail.
Southeast Texas Regional Airport ASOS measured a wind gust of 60 mph.
Trees and powerlines were downed along FM Road 3098 in the Redwater community.
Tractor trailer was blown over on Interstate 40 with one person receiving injuries.
Ham radio operators and law enforcement continued to report land spout swarms off and on between the communities of Roscoe and Wastella.
A trained spotter reported half dollar sized hail.
Sighted near the intersection of FM 418 and Hwy 71.

Based on spotter footage, a tornado formed over open country just northwest of Briggs, and may at one point have lifted and reformed. The tornado occurred in an area that was not accessible by a National Weather Service survey team. The location and time is estimated based on radar data and spotter accounts. The width of this tornado is not known, and the entry is forced by the software.
A couple of trees were downed.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail near the Cienegas community.
Shingles were blown off a house and some tree limbs were blown down. Monetary damages were estimated.
The Floyd County Sheriff's Office reported golfball size hail.
The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site near Olton measured a peak thunderstorm wind gust of 58 mph. No damage was reported.
Reports of several rural buildings with wind damage.
Quarter size hail fell 11 miles south-southwest of Canyon.
Wind was measured at the Megargel Fire Department.
Amateur radio reported quarter-sized hail between the cities of Blum and Whitney.
Half dollar-size hail reported.
MPing report.
Nickel to quarter sized hail was reported 12 miles east of Breckenridge.
Shingles off roof near 360 and North Holland Road.
Emergency management reported golf ball sized hail in northeast Rowlett, TX.
Mesonet site near Bob-O's.
The Zapata County Fire Department reported hail the size of a quarter, or 1.0, in Zapata at 8:20PM CDT.
Minor roof damage with fencing and several large trees down.

Heavy Rain caused minor flooding of some roadways around Batson including FM770 and around Luberton including Candlestick Drive. Pictures were also sent in via Facebook of minor flooding around Lumberton.

A tornado formed just northeast of Thousand Oaks Dr. along Scarsdale Dr. The tornado moved to the northeast through residential neighborhoods between Nacogdoches Rd. and Stahl Rd. The tornado produced widespread EF0 damage and pockets of EF1 damage to homes and trees. Some single family homes lost sections of their roofs (DI FR12, DOD 4). There was also significant damage to large utility structures (DI ETL, DOD 4). This damage might have rated higher (DOD 6), but the utility company told us they collapse at much lower wind speeds. The tornado lifted near the intersection of Judson Rd. and Stahl Rd.  According to the City of San Antonio assessment, 22 homes had major damage, 12 had minor damage, and 81 homes were affected.  There is no estimate of monetary loss.
Trees were downed.
Amateur radio reported multiple trees down near the city of Rumley, TX.
Storm spotters affiliated with the Paducah Fire Department reported golfball size hail.
Hail fell southeast of Longview, Texas.

Report of pea-sized hail covering the ground four inches deep with several vehicle accidents as a result of hail on the roads along with near zero mile visibility from hail fog. There were no reports of injuries.
A tree was blown onto a house in Lacy-Lakeview.
Amateur radio storm spotters reported golfball size hail.
A barn roof was damaged.
A utility company reported three downed power poles west of Highways 62 and 82 along Foster Road.
The Automated Surface Observing System at Wink (KINK) recorded two 72 mph wind gusts, one at 5:26pm CDT, the other at 5:34pm CDT.  No damage was reported at this time.
The Elgin Fire Department reported a funnel cloud near the junction of FM  696 and FM 619 moving toward Lexington.
Three power poles were knocked over northeast of the intersection of Highway 385 and FM 41.
Winds briefly gusted to 63 MPH at the Brownwood Airport.
Trees and power lines down across southern parts of the county.
Penny sized hail observed 3.3 miles southeast of Spring.
An oak tree was downed by strong thunderstorm wind gusts at the Village of Rock Prairie on Mortier Dr in College Station.

A trained spotter reported a brief tornado approximately 5 TO 8 miles southeast of the intersection of FM 1379 and TX 158 at 1756 CST.  A damage survey was conducted, which confirmed one power pole was snapped near its base and another one was damaged along TX 158. Some minor tree limb damage was also noted near the same area.  Please see the attached image.
Numerous trees and power lines toppled.
A brief EF-0 tornado occurred with no damage approximately 2 miles north-northwest of Sidney.
A trained spotter reported quarter size hail in Dodd City.
A thunderstorm produced a 58 mph wind gust at the Castolon Mesonet site.
A grain bin was damaged. The new Ag barn at Electra High School was damaged. A three car garage was destroyed. The roof of one home and signs across town were also damaged.

An NWS Storm Survey Team determined that damage done east of the EF-1 tornado south of Dunlay was caused by straight line thunderstorm winds estimated at 80 to 105 mph. Two separate sections of power lines were knocked down, the roofs of two houses were damaged, several center pivot irrigation systems were damaged, and large tree limbs were knocked down.
A public report was received of quarter size hail west of Kirkland.
Some tree branches were broken.
A severe thunderstorm produced quarter sized hail.
Reported at a rural gas plant on the Upton/Reagan County line just off of Farm to Market Road 1555.
Mping report of 1 inch hail.
Penny size hail fell in Hawkins.
Golf ball sized hail was reported in the Bryan area.
Two trees were blown down by severe thunderstorm winds and caused damage to electrical transformers. In addition, a roof was blown off of a portable building at the school.
A wind gust of 60 mph was estimated in Booker.

A thunderstorm produced a swath of large hail as it tracked northeastward over portions of southwestern and central Lubbock County around 17:00 CST.  Damage to cotton crops was continuous from northern Terry County into southwestern Lubbock County.  Approximately 5,000 acres of cotton were severely damaged or destroyed in cropland south of Wolfforth between 16:50 CST and 17:00 CST.  Numerous reports of large hail were additionally received as the severe thunderstorm impacted Lubbock between roughly 17:00 CST and 17:10 CST.  Initial reports from the broadcast media indicated that quarter size hail fell near 73rd Street and Slide Road in southwest Lubbock at 16:59 CST. By 17:05 CST, golfball size hail was reported near 55th Street and Utica.  Additional reports of quarter size hail were received near 17th Street and Chicago Avenue at 17:10 CST.  No damages were reported.
Amateur radio storm spotters reported golfball size hail.

The tornado touched down on Chase Field southeast of Beeville and traveled about a half of a mile across the airport property before dissipating. The tornado damaged around 50 unsecured recreational vehicles (RVs) and severely damaged or destroyed 12 RVs. Several hangars had roof damage with asphalt roofing materials blown off on to the airport tarmac. Several unsecured, full sized single-wide mobile homes were blown over also.
Public reported half dollar size hail.
The Automated Surface Observing System at the Lubbock International Airport measured a severe thunderstorm wind gust of 62 mph. No damage was reported.
Wind damage was reported to several roofs in the Bogata community.  In addition, some trees were uprooted and snapped.  Damage was said to be very sporadic throughout the community.

A cluster of thunderstorms moved out of the Oklahoma Panhandle and into the Texas Panhandle during the evening hours of the 30th. As this cluster of thunderstorms moved near the town of Morse (Hansford County), a trained storm spotter reported an estimated 60 mph thunderstorm downburst. After producing this downburst the cluster of thunderstorms continued to move to the southeast.
Power lines were blown down near Mount Pleasant ISD.
Golfball size hail fell from a supercell thunderstorm moving across Concho County.
Heavy damage was reported in the town square.
Trees fell on houses causing roof and structural damage.
A trained spotter in Mission reported 1.5 inches of rain fell in 30 minutes.
A 58 mph wind gust was measured in Cleburne. Pea sized hail was also reported.
Nickel to quarter sized hail was reported in Frisco.
Law enforcement reported golf ball size hail.
A social media report indicated penny-sized hail along the Johnson/Tarrant County line near the city of Crowley, TX.
An amateur radio operator reported dime size hail at the intersection of Houston Harte and Glenna Road, along with large quantities of pea size hail at the Bluffs.
Large trees were uprooted on the LBJ State Park and Historic Site.  One large oak tree fell on the visitor's center building.

Report of a large tree blown down onto a vehicle and damage to the roof of an outbuilding just north of Colorado City. Time is estimated from radar and nearby observations. Wind speeds were estimated to be between 80 to 90 mph. Property damage cost amount is an estimation.
A thunderstorm produced a funnel cloud.

Multiple trees were snapped along a near 7 mile track in the Northwest sections of Smith County. A tornado moved into Smith County from Van Zandt County 1 mile south of Interstate 20. The tornado continued northeast crossing Interstate 20 about 2 miles east of the Van Zandt/Smith County line, then continued northeast ending 4 miles northwest of Lindale on FM 16. Winds are estimated at 75-85 mph.
An off duty NWS employee estimated a 60 mph wind gust and pea size hail.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet near Turkey measured a wind gust to 72  mph. Additionally, an NWS cooperative weather observer reported that a roof was blown off of a barn south of Turkey.
This tornado was observed by residents of southwest Van Zandt County, south of Van Zandt County road 2308. This tornado occurred over open fields and produced tree and ranch land damage.
Report from mPING: Quarter (1.00 in.).
Trees were downed in Harrison County in the vicinity of Marshall, Texas.
A thunderstorm produced penny size hail along Hwy 261 on the west side of Lake Buchanan.
Public reported many tree branches were broken across the city of Benavides.
A trained spotter reported half dollar size hail west of Sherman.
A slow moving tornadic cell produced a second tornado northwest of Perrin. Roofs and outbuildings were damaged near Perrin.
Strong thunderstorm wind caused roof damage and blew down power lines in town.
Law enforcement reported numerous trees and one power line down in the Flomot area. Also, an estimated 25 center pivot irrigation systems were overturned and damaged nearby.
Power lines and tree limbs were blown down around the city.
Nickel size hail was reported along Texas Highway 302 east of Kermit.
The duration of the hail was estimated for this event.
Hail was reported south of Mount Enterprise, Texas.
Trees and powerlines were blown down.
Wind gusts of 58 mph and 64 mph were measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet station at 1950 and 1955 CST, respectively.
A thunderstorm moved across Pecos County and produced a 61 mph wind gust at the Fort Stockton ASOS site.
The Eastex Freeway service road between East Lucas and Delaware was flooded due heavy rain.

A supercell moved across Potter County during the evening hours of the 9th. As the storm moved north of Amarillo (Potter County), local broadcast media reported quarter size hail (1.00 inch) twelve miles north of Amarillo (Potter County). After producing this hail, the supercell continued to moved eastward across the county.
This was a report from mPING of trees uprooted/snapped or roof blown off. Wind speeds associated with this damage were estimated to be approximately 80 MPH. Property damage cost is an estimation.
The report was relayed by amateur radio.
A thunderstorm produced a funnel cloud that was sighted along Texas HWY 97 between Nixon and Smiley.

A linear multicell thunderstorm complex impacted Yoakum County in the wake of an earlier supercell storm. This second round of thunderstorms produced a severe wind gust of 60 mph that was recorded by the Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet west-northwest of Denver City. No damage was reported.

The hail covered the ground and damaged many west-facing windows in town.  Many vehicles also sustained light to moderate damage.  Although less destructive than the onslaught of baseball size hail in the city just 2.5 weeks earlier, this hail was insult to injury for many property and business owners.
Late report of accumulating hail ranging from dimes to quarters. Ground was covered up to several inches deep.
Some 4 tree limbs were knocked down in Weatherford.
Portion of a roof was blown off of an apartment building along Carolyn Drive.
Quarter size hail fell near Lake Kiowa.

At 16:45 CST the Federal Aviation Administration relayed a pilot report of a tornado just west of Cotton Center. The tornado had formed along an outflow boundary beneath a rapidly developing severe thunderstorm. The highly visible landspout-type tornado was observed by many officials and the general public from portions of at least three counties as it moved west-northwestward over farm land until it dissipated just south of Corry (extreme eastern Lamb County) at 16:55 CST. ||An eyewitness reported that the tornado briefly broke-up as it crossed Texas Farm to Market Road 37 near the Hale and Lamb County line, then reformed as it crossed into Lamb County. Although no structural damage occurred, farmers reported that the track of the tornado was visible through cotton and wheat fields.
There was quarter sized hail in La Porte.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail three miles north of Bulverde.
Ping pong ball size hail fell on the northwest side of De Kalb.
Dime sized hail was reported on the east side of Weatherford.
Damage was reported to roofs of homes in Round Rock from severe thunderstorm winds.
A trained storm spotter estimated 65 MPH wind gusts along with trees down approximately 2 miles southwest of Duncanville, TX in the Mountain Creek area.
Trees were downed across Highway 315 just southwest of Carthage.
A thunderstorm produced hail up to the size of golf balls in Medina.
Thunderstorm winds knocked down 2 foot diameter trees on FM 2280 north of Keene.

NWS storm survey concluded a tornado touched down in a field south of Highway 35 just east of Gregory. The tornado flipped over a fireworks stand and damaged the side of an outbuilding. The tornado crossed Highway 35 and dissipated in a field. Maximum winds of 70 mph were estimated.
A 2.5 inch hail stone was measured near Greenville Avenue and Exchange Parkway in Allen.
Hail report received via mPing.
Power lines were blown dwn by high winds.
Golf ball size hail was reported in Lone Oak.
A small shed was overturned and a section of fence was knocked down at the intersection of FM 1082 and CR 327 by damaging thunderstorms winds.
Golf ball hail was reported at Little Rd and I-20 in SE Fort Worth.

The tornado touched down about four miles north northwest of Gruver at 2312 CST. The tornado was on the ground for about one half mile with a maximum path width of twenty-five yards. The tornado dissipated at 2314 CST and remained over open country. No damage or injuries were reported.
Quarter-size hail was covering Highway 380.
A public report of trailer damage was received, and this is a test.
Ping pong ball size hail was reported roughly 2 miles north of the Orange/Jasper County line on FM 105.
Trees were downed across the county.
Golfball to Hen Egg size hail fell in Downtown Decatur.
A trained spotter reported that one RV trailer was flipped, and there was damage to 3 others. Trees were also reported to have been blown down.
Several large trees were blown down in West Tawakoni.
Occurred at the intesection of Interstate 30 and Zion Road.
Law enforcement officials reported golfball size hail.

A downburst caused notable wind damage along a 4 mile long path from the Rice area to the Chatfield area. Large trees were damaged, snapped or uprooted (18-24 in diameter). A trailer was overturned and a few pole barns were damaged.

A resident first noticed a tornado over an open field approximately 1-2 miles east of U.S. Highway 77 just south of FM 491. The tornado moved westward toward U.S. Highway 77 and lifted as it approached the Highway, then dissipated. The tornado was on the ground approximately 3 to 5 minutes. No damage was reported.
Law enforcement reported tree and power line damage in Brownwood.  In addition, the roof of a small out building was damaged.

The public reported that a tornado developed in open country near the community of Flagg. Reports indicate that the tornado's condensation funnel extended downward and had the visual appearance of a rope, and that a dust filled debris cloud rose up to meet the funnel from the ground. No damage was reported.
Fences and large tree branches blown down near Beltway 8 and State Highway 249 in northwest Houston.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Caprock Canyons State Park measured a wind gust of 60 mph.

Thunderstorm winds estimated at 50 knots blew over a carport and blew it across the street. Additionally, part of the awning and roof of Rigo's Tire Shop and Road Service was torn off and tossed approximately 100 feet down the road. Radar velocity from the Corpus Christi radar indicated winds of 58 knots about 4,000 feet in elevation between 7:15PM CDT and 7:20PM CDT, which was used to estimate the timing of the event.

Two people driving an automobile got out of a truck when the vehicle drove over power lines that were downed from earlier in the evening.  The two adults were electrocuted when the exited the burning vehicle.
Trees down on Highway 42 near FM 850 in New London.
A eight inch tree branch was blown down across the road at the forty-seven hundred block of Southwest 10th Avenue.

Many residents of south Lubbock observed a landspout over open land near 114th Street and Highway 87 drifting slowly north.  No known damage accompanied this tornado, therefore an EF-Unknown rating was assigned.
A COOP Observer reported quarter size hail 11 miles north-northeast of Water Valley.
20 apartment units were unroofed and flooded in Pleasant Grove.  There were also numerous reports of trees and power lines blown down.
The AWOS at Brooks County Airport reported a 53 knot wind gust.
Several reports of hail up to 2.5 hail was reported in northern Garland via mPing and the public.

Lightning was likely the cause of a fire that destroyed a 257,000 dollar home in the 10900 block of Rolling Hills Drive.  When firefighters arrived, heavy fire was already visible from the rooftop and the house was declared a total loss.
A thunderstorm moved across Howard County and produced 50 to 60 mph winds in Coahoma.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
A tree was downed on FM 225 just south of Cushing.
A social media report indicated golf ball sized hail just south of DFW Airport.

A swath of severe thunderstorm winds were observed south of Levelland to north of Ropesville. A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Levelland measured severe wind gusts from 1624 CST through 1648 CST. A peak wind gust of 80 mph was measured at 1638 CST. Additionally, a trained spotter estimated 80 mph wind gusts north of Ropesville.
First severe wind gust of 59 mph occurred at  1840CDT. The peak wind gust of 61 mph occurred at  1852CDT. The last 60 mph wind gust occurred at  1857CDT.
Penny to nickel size hail fell in Marathon.
The public reported nickel size hail in Earth.
Half of a tree was down with a diameter of  approximately 12 to 18 at the Lake Tanglewood golf course.
Quarter sized hail was reported.
Thunderstorm winds downed a power line in Dayton at FM 546.
Trees were blown around Jasper.
Broadcast media shared a report of golf ball sized hail in Pecos. Time is estimated from radar.
Report from mPING: Dime (0.75 in.).

A thunderstorm moved across Presidio County and produced tennis ball to baseball sized hail at Big Bend Ranch State Park.  The hail broke a sideview mirror on a vehicle and broke a skylight on a camper.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Numerous trees, large tree limbs, and power poles were downed.  A tree fell on a carport on FM 36 near Caddo Mills.  Another roof collapsed near the vicinity of Polk and Pickett Streets in Greenville.  In Celeste, a tree fell on the covered parking at a church.
Sixty-five MPH wind gust reported at Runaway Bay.
The Floydada Fire Department reported penny size hail in Floydada.
A utility company official reported multiple power poles snapped east of West Point.
Trees downed throughout Harrison County.
NWS employee reported several one to two foot diameter trees snapped with estimated 60 mph wind gusts.

An abandoned brick building suffered significant wind damage in Estelline. Severe thunderstorm winds struck the community around 21:30 CST, and caused a structure's brick wall to collapse. No injuries were reported.

An isolated supercell thunderstorm propagated south across Terrell County during the late afternoon of the 9th. The storm generally affected rural areas of the county, but a local rancher reported three quarter inch hail northwest of Dryden.
Hail in the town of Weches.

Strong wind gusts knocked down trees and power lines.  Shingles were blown off some roofs and a mobile home was pushed off its foundation. |A mobile home was also damaged when a tree fell across it.  No injuries were reported.  A tree also fell across a truck in town.  The roof was taken off an old supermarket along Hwy. 271.
Trees were blown down by high winds.
The Flower Grove Co-op Gin reported penny size hail covering Farm to Market 2002 in front of the gin.
Multiple trees were reported down on a roadways in Marble Falls.

An embedded thunderstorm broke off from a line of storms moving across Northwest Texas. This storm moved to the northeast and moved across the southern Texas Panhandle during the evening hours of the 20th. As the thunderstorm moved across Randall County, a member of the public reported nickel size hail (0.88 inch) six miles south of Amarillo (Randall County). The thunderstorm continued to move to the northeast across the county after producing this hail, before diminishing over the central portion of Amarillo (Randall County).
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that knocked down some one inch tree limbs near Windcrest.
Nickel sized hail was observed in this thunderstorm.

An EF-1 tornado, with estimated maximum winds around 100 mph, first touched down on County Road 2617 and tracked almost due east through rural portions of Central Cass County for nearly 10 miles. Almost all of the damage was confined to trees along the entire path. There were a few spots where small amounts of tin roofing material were wrapped in amongst the tree debris, but the sources of the roofing material were never located. In addition, at the surveyed ending point of the tornado on County Road 1145, there was a very small shed structure whose roof was removed.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball to golf ball size hail on the east shore of Lake Buchanan.
Large limbs downed power lines and caused power outages across the county.
Nickel hail reported covering the ground near the intersection of the Highway 158 and Farm to Market Road 1788 in both Ector and Midland Counties.
A social media photo indicated baseball sized hail near Cedar Hill State Park.
Amateur radio reported quarter-sized hail in the city of Denton, TX.
The Automated Surface Observing System at Wink (KINK) recorded several wind gusts of 59 mph.  No damage was reported.

A damaging microburst occured in the northern portions of the city of Midland.  High winds up to 70 MPH resulted in numerous large trees being blown down...damage to fences...and business signs.  The most significant damage was centered near the intersection of Loop 250 and Garfield Street... however... windows were broken by the high winds as far west as Midkiff Street.  Power lines were also blown down...resulting in power outages.  One power line landed on a vehicle.  No injuries were reported.
Trees were downed in Snook.
Four telephone poles were blown down on County Road 365, just southeast of Trent.
Golf ball sized hail was reported on CR 45800 northeast of Blossom.
This hail was observed 1 mile east-southeast of Clarendon.
Local farmers reported hail up to three-quarters of an inch in diameter northwest of Maple. The hail resulted in no agricultural damage since crops were recently planted, and had not yet sprouted.
Tennis ball size hail was reported 2 miles east-northeast of Wheeler by a storm chaser.
Seventy MPH winds were estimated in Era which is between Valley View and Rosston.
Lightning started a house fire in the 6000 block of Sterling Drive in Colleyville. Flames were coming from the garage when firefighters arrived.
A tree was blown down across Hickory Hill Drive.
A tree was downed and blocking one lane of Highway 21 near Chireno.
Penny size hail fell 4 miles southeast of Lake McClellan.
Penny-size hail at the intersection of FM Road 2693 and FM Road 2778 right at the Walker-San Jacinto County line.
There was an mPING report of golf ball size hail about 5.6 miles west-northwest of Rincon, or about 16.5 miles northeast of Rio Grande City.
The Fisher County Sheriff's office estimated a 60 mph wind gust in Roby.
Pictures of barn roof damage from social media. Time is estimated.
Several trees were downed on Cannon Street in New Boston, Texas.
Nickel to golfball size hail fell in Imperial.
Trees damaged and limbs down on Copeland Road and Paluxy Drive in south Tyler.
Several large trees were blown down across the county.
No damage reported.

The second McLennan county tornado touched down just southwest of Tokio then moved east northeast and dissipated 1.3 miles east of West.  Homes, a church, and several businesses were damaged in Tokio.  After moving through Tokio, the tornado moved along FM 1858, causing heavy damage to wood-frame structures, mobile homes, storage buildings, and minor damage to several brick homes.  As the tornado moved across the extreme southern edge of West, several homes and storage buildings were damaged.

An NWS Storm Survey Team determined thunderstorm winds estimated at 80 mph caused damage to an area one mile wide and four miles long in northeastern San Antonio and adjacent parts of Bexar County outside the city limit to Bracken in Comal County. The damage was to trees, fences, and power lines.
Morgan Mill Fire Department reported ping pong ball hail in the city of Morgan Mill.
Emergency manager reported winds from 50 to 60 mph in Raymondville.
Multiple reports of quarter size hail was reported along Major Drive in Beaumont.
Leon County Sheriff's Department reported that the roofs of 6 chicken houses were blown off and other debris was scattered about in the area.

Hail up to the size of golf balls fell across a large part of the city of Coleman, causing extensive damage to area roofs and vehicles. Local insurance agencies reported nearly 1000 insurance claims, with damage reaching almost 3 million dollars.
Funnel cloud sighted on FM 521.
The public reported quarter size hail along highway 55 south of Camp Wood.
The Fire Department reported golf ball size hail in Eula.
Reports on social media depicted hail up to two inches in diameter from about eight miles west of Floydada to about nine miles southwest of Floydada.
Trees downed.
Numerous trees were toppled near Hwy 138 and Hwy 96 in Center.
Amateur radio reported nickel size hail in the Pelican Bay area of Eagle Mountain Lake.
Tree limbs were downed near the intersection of Nichols Sawmill Road and Walnut Creek.
Report from mPING: Dime (0.75 in.).
A tornado touched down along Ranch Road 384 in northeast Runnels County, striking and damaging a house. Part of the roof was torn off, allowing rainwater to enter the building.
A public report indicated ping pong ball sized hail in Sanger, TX.
A NWS cooperative weather observer reported golf ball size hail in the town of Aspermont. No damage was reported.
The Val Verde County Sheriff's Department reported power lines blown down by severe thunderstorm winds estimated at 60 knots in the southern part of Del Rio.
A large tree was blown over onto a house.  A trained spotter had collected a report from the  resident of this home. Resident said there was no  damage on the inside of the house.

A persistent funnel cloud was viewed by two local residents in the Weslaco/Donna area during the early evening of June 7th.  A resident in Donna reported a funnel on the south side of town reaching halfway to the ground at 420 PM CST.  Another resident on the southwest side of Weslaco viewed another funnel, possibly from the same parent storm, 12 minutes later southwest of the intersection of Hopper Road and 34th Street on the southwest side of town.  The second funnel lasted only a minute. Touchdowns were not witnessed in either case.
A thunderstorm produced four inch diameter hail in Del Rio.
A trained spotter reported tennis ball size hail in Wingate.
Penny size hail was reported along Farm to Market Road 1450 southeast of Pecos.
Cars were reported to be blown off the road.  No injuries were reported.
Roof was blown off of a mobile home.
Emergency management reported ping pong ball size hail in the city of Palmer, TX.
Quarter size hail was observed 6 miles south-southwest of Canyon.
One inch hail fell at the intersection of Hwy. 59 and FM. 1186.
A social media report indicated 1.25 to 1.5 inch diameter hail near the city of Cleburne, TX.
A 59 mph wind gust was recorded at Lake Striker from the Texas Water Development Board Mesonet station and a tree was downed in the 15000 block of County Road 4255 near Lake Striker.
Measured by the Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet.
Tornado near Highway 65 between Monroe City and Winnie.  Law  enforcement reported no damage or injuries.
Several tree limbs that were 3 in diameter were knocked down in the Grapevine, Colleyville, and Bedford areas. Power lines were also knocked down.
Nickel sized hail was reported west of DeLeon.
Significant damage to cotton crops resulted from the large, wind-driven hail.
The report was relayed through mPING.

Strong thunderstorm winds caused mostly tree and minor wind damage across Farmers Branch in an area boxed between Bee St, Valwood Pkwy, Brookhaven College, and Valley View Lane. Large tree branches were broken, older trees were uprooted, and a few trees fell on cars. Shingle damage and some roof decking was removed off a few homes. The corner roof of a church was damaged, too.

A detached garage was struck by lightning and destroyed by a fire at 19 West Willowood Court in the Woodlands. Time estimation by radar and lightning plot indicate the strike could've happened any time between 2-305 pm CST.
Law enforcement in Petersburg reported baseball size hail. No damage was reported.
Quarter-size hail was reported on the east side of Possum Kingdom Lake.

This tornado developed just north of FM-1919 about 2.5 miles northwest of the Seymour airport and initially moved south destroying farm buildings and equipment. As the tornado approached FM-2069, it veered sharply and began moving east along and north of FM-2069 damaging the roof of a home and heavily damaging some outbuildings. The tornado continued moving east through the Seymour Municipal Airport destroying hangars, planes and vehicles at the airport.  The tornado likely continued east and northeast from the airport, but this area was inaccessible to the ground survey team.
Emergency management reported quarter to ping pong ball size hail in the city of Paducah. No damage was observed.
Zapata County emergency manager reported quarter size hail fell in downtown Zapata. The public also reported quarter size hail with some even larger hail stones fell in Zapata.
Golf ball size hail fell 5 miles west-southwest of Panhandle, along Highway 60 near County Road J.
Observed near Leopard and Violet Roads.
A tree was downed across FM 989 and Blankinship Road.  Another tree was downed across south bound Hwy. 59 and a tree was downed across Gun Club and Perry Demarce Road.
Strong thunderstorm wind blew down trees and power poles.
A tree was downed on a house in Tyler, Texas.  There were no report of injuries.
Hail was reported in Graham. The hail was becoming smaller, but still included anything from the size of a nickel to the size of a golf ball.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 50 mph that blew down numerous trees, power lines, light poles, and street signs in Eagle Pass.
An NWS cooperative weather observer southeast of Floydada reported hail up to golf ball size.
A period of small hail was reported in Friona early this night.  No damage was noted.

Heavy rains of 1 to locally 3 or more inches fell roughly between Brownsville and the southwest corner of Cameron County during the mid morning of July 8th as weak Tropical Depression #2 made landfall along the Lower Texas coast.  Rainfall of more than 3 inches was recorded at Brownsville/South Padre Island International Airport over the course of two days, with 1.71 inches falling on the 8th.  Minor, nuisance urban-type flooding was reported in southern Cameron County as the rains moved through.
A trained spotter reported dime size hail in the city of Paris, TX.

Widespread wind damage was reported across the city of Mount Pleasant. Trees and power lines were downed on Happy Street and near the intersection of Highway 67 and FM 1402. Winds damaged the doors on a building on Madison Street in Downtown Mount Pleasant.
A Facebook photo showed spiky hail of at least 2 inches in diameter.
Public reported half dollar size hail.
A broadcast media report indicated trees down in the city of Southlake, TX.
Tree damage on the south side of Lake Leon.
The Mathis Field ASOS measured a thunderstorm wind gust of 58 mph.
Trees and power lines were blown down by high winds.
Lightning struck a house on County Road 209 in the Serbin area. The house was struck around 1 pm while the residents were away.  The house was destroyed.
Storm chaser photo showed a hail stone approximately 3.25 inches long by 2.5 inches wide fell in Joplin.

The ASOS station at McAllen International Airport (KMFE) recorded a 59 mph wind gust at 10:28PM CST. This was caused by a mini supercell that developed along a cold front trudging through Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley. There were also a few public reports of dime to penny sized hail in the Mission area.
A Caprock Canyon State Park employee estimated quarter size hail in Turkey.  Damage was not known.
Occurred on the west side of town.
Spotter estimated 60 mph wind gust.
A storm chaser reported that an out building was damaged and steel bars were found across the highway in a pattern from northeast to southwest.
Baseball sized hail was reported in Dublin.
Trees were blown down on Highway 11 near the intersection of FM 1521.
A tree was downed at FM 852 and Ocelot Road.
Trees were downed in the community of Golden.
The COOP Observer located at city hall reported hail up to the size of golfballs.

The northern most embedded thunderstorm within a squall line moving across the southeastern Texas Panhandle passed over the town of Lefors (Gray County). This same embedded thunderstorm had a history of producing hen egg size hail stones west-northwest of Lake McClellan (Gray County). While over Lefors, the thunderstorm produced hail from dime size to golf ball size hail. The Gray County Emergency Manager reported that accumulated hail had clogged drainage systems which resulted in localized flooding. No reports of damage or injuries accompanied this report.
The public reported wind gusts up to 60 miles per hour south of Andrews on U.S. Highway 385.  No damage was reported.
A public report indicated penny-sized hail approximately 2 miles southeast of the city of Denton, TX.
Local TV station measured winds to 63 mph.
Numerous trees have been blown down across western and northwest Upshur County.
Broadcast media reported quarter size hail in the city of Marlin, TX.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail at the intersection of Sparrow Ridge and Trinity Ct. in northern Bexar County.
Numerous trees and powerlines were downed across the western portions of Panola County.
A public report indicated wind damage to trees and sheds with gusts estimated at 60 MPH in a neighborhood off Avondale-Haslet Road in the city of Haslet, TX.
Golf ball sized hail was reported in Cleburne. The hail covered the ground and broke many windshields at a country club.
Wind gust was measured at KLVJ.
A 60 MPH wind gust was measured by the Automated Surface Observation System at Fort Worth Meacham Airport.
Several large trees and power lines downed. Monetary damages were estimated.
The Mitchell County Sheriff's Office reported marble to penny size hail at the intersection of Farm to Market Road 2183 and Texas Highway 163.
Numerous reports of quarter size hail were received from downtown Amarillo.
Golfball size hail fell near the Deberry community.
A mesonet station measured a wind gust of 71 mph, 5 miles west of Rotan.
The public reported ping pong size hail fell across FM 490 east of Hargill.

Frequent wind gusts, estimated at 70 to 75 mph, drove hail, some up to the size of baseballs, for more than an hour across portions of North McAllen, Mission, and Edinburg in Hidalgo County.  Wind combined with hail resulted in numerous tree limbs blown down, defoliated trees, homes with roof damage and broken windows,  knocked down fences and damage to vehicles. See Hail event for damage estimates.
A Trained Spotter reported golf ball size hail in Owens.
Amateur radio reported dime sized hail in Bartonville, TX.
Severe thunderstorm winds knocked over power lines from near Yoakum in western Lavaca County to Cuero.
An NWS employee estimated a wind gust to 70 mph.
Several fences, a trampoline, and a gazebo were lofted into the air, twisted, and destroyed.
Strong thunderstorm wind gusts derailed 35 to 40 train cars, destroyed two metal buildings, rolled a travel trailer 150 yards, snapped 15 power poles, and blew down trees.
The fire department reported that trees and power poles were blown down and that there was some minor structural damage to homes due to the thunderstorm winds.
A storm chaser reported a tornado north of town.  The tornado snapped and uprooted trees, blew down power lines, and snapped power poles.

Scattered thunderstorms moved northward into the southern Texas Panhandle during the early afternoon hours of the 16th. These thunderstorms had access to a high atmospheric moisture content which allowed for periods of heavy rain. A member of the public in Canyon reported that heavy rain led to minor flooding on Cemetery Road on the west side of Canyon. This minor flooding cleared quickly as thunderstorms continued to move northward away from the city. No stranded vehicles or swift water rescues were reported in association to this minor flooding.
A man was struck by lightning while under a tree in the Woodway area. He lost some teeth and had burns on his hands.
Amateur radio reported golf ball sized hail near the intersection of Forest Ridge Drive and Highway 183 in the city of Bedford, TX.
Quarter size hail fell in West.
Public report of tree branches blown down.
The automated weather station at Stephens County Airport in Breckenridge (KBKD) measured a 58 mph wind gust.
The public reported golf ball size hail in Glen Cove.
Multiple reports were made for hail ranging from 2 to 4.5 in diameter with this storm.
Spotter reported quarter-sized hail in northern Delta County along FM 128.
Penny size hail was reported at the Lubbock Preston Smith International Airport.
The West Texas Mesonet station south of town measured a 59 mph thunderstorm wind gust.
Hail was observed near the intersection of Farm to Market Road 433 and 2897.
Hail from dimes to quarters reported, accumulating up to an inch deep in spots.
One house unroofed, several fences were blown down, and several trees were blown down.

An official storm damage survey was made on the estimated tornado path length and width.  The tornado touched down in the Antelope Creek area approximately one mile south of State Highway 136.  This tornado originally touched down in Carson county and then moved into Hutchinson county.
A roof was partially removed from a home near the intersection of Highway 37 and County Road 3330.

A fully loaded shipping container was rolled approximately 100 yards towards the  southeast. Drone footage showed no clear indication of a tornado path. The time of occurrence is estimated from radar. The cost of damages and the maximum wind gust are also estimated.
A tornado was reported near the town of Pecos.

The West Texas Mesonet site 11 miles west northwest of Bootleg (Deaf Smith County) reported a 58 mph thunderstorm wind gust from a line of thunderstorms as they moved eastward across Deaf Smith and Oldham Counties.
Quarter size hail fell one mile south-southwest of Cactus.
A storm chaser reported quarter size hail.
A lightning strike caused a house fire in the Spring Trails subdivision.
Multiple trees and power lines were blown down across FM 225.
Heavy rain caused ponding and minor flooding of city streets in Brownfield.

The same supercell that produced a tornado in University Park produced another tornado just north of Royal Ln and east of Michaels Drive. The first signs of damage appeared on Lavendale Circle with a few uprooted small trees and down tree branches. The tornado continued moving to the northeast, strengthening to an EF-1 with 90 mph winds. The primary area of more substantial damage occurred just west and north of the North Haven Gardens. A single-family home on Northhaven Rd sustained the worst damage, with a partial roof collapse. Northeast of the worst affected residence, occasional roof/shingle damage and downed tree branches were found. Maximum estimated winds were 90 mph.

Hail up to the size of Golfballs did considerable damage in Granbury. Up to 200 windows were broken at the Bromley Apartments and the roof was damaged. Cars were also damaged at the apartment complex with the windows broken on a few cars. Approximately 150 automobiles were damaged at Mike Brown Ford, but no windows were broken on the complex. Another 130 vehicles were damaged at Jerry Durant Toyota. A skylight was broken at Oak Woods Intermediate School.
Trees down and windows blown out of a house.
Numerous trees were blown down across the county with several roads blocked. Powerlines were also reported down in some areas.

Multiple reports of large hail that ranged in size from nickels to golfballs were received along a swath from MacKenzie Reservoir to near Silverton, both from the public and the National Severe Storms Laboratory SHAVE project. Quarter size hail was reported at the MacKenzie Resrvoir marina at 18:47 CST. Additional reports indicated that nickel size hail had covered the ground and stripped trees along Texas Highway 207 northwest of Silverton by 19:15 CST.  At 19:24 CST golfball size hail was reported five miles north of Silverton. No property damage was reported.
Hail was reported at Loop 323 and Hwy. 271.
Public reported nickle sized hail along Highway 239 northwest of Tivoli.

Penny sized hail and heavy rain fell in downtown Fort Davis.  In addition, the Presidio County Sheriff's office reported power outages in Fort Davis and Valentine.  The cause of the power outage was unknown.
Quarter sized hail was reported at Interstate 635 and Beltline Road near Coppell.
A member of the broadcast media reported quarter sized hail in the city of McGregor, TX.
A social media report indicated baseball size hail near the intersection of Coit and Main Street, just east of the city of Frisco, TX.
Amateur radio reported ping pong ball sized hail in the city of China Spring, TX.
Several large trees were downed along with powerlines across the western portion of Upshur County.  Several areas were without power.
A thunderstorm produced a funnel cloud north of Cost.
Trees downed in Melrose.
No damage was reported.

An NWS Storm Survey team determined that the damage in and around the Union Hill community was consistent with that of straight line wind gusts to near 80 mph.  The local high school had roof damage with several other homes receiving damage from fallen trees.

Numerous trees had large limbs broken.  A few trees were uprooted or snapped at the trunk.  Several storage buildings were damaged, and a few homes suffered minor roof damage.  Additional homes were damaged by falling trees and limbs.
Lots of penny size hail was reported in Lorena.
An Automated Weather Observation Station reported a 61 mph wind gust.
Power poles were blown down and a roof was blown off on county road 228.
The ASOS at Childress Municipal Airport reported a wind gust to 58 mph.
Progresso Police Department reported a tree was blown down onto a vehicle at a residence on Watts Street in Progresso.
A storm chaser reported golf ball to tennis ball size hail 4 miles east-northeast of Merkel. A picture of the large hail was posted on Twitter.
Penny sized hail fell along Texas Highway 191 just east of Odessa.
Quarter size hail reported at the intersection of Nolana and 23rd in north McAllen, and at the intersection of Savannah Avenue and 2nd Street (Col. Rowe Boulevard).
MPing report.

An embedded thunderstorm broke off from a line of storms moving across Northwest Texas. This storm moved to the northeast and moved across the southern Texas Panhandle during the evening hours of the 20th. As the thunderstorm moved across Randall County, a member of the public reported ping pong ball size hail (1.50 inches) seven miles southwest of Amarillo (Randall County). The thunderstorm continued to move to the northeast across the county after producing this hail, before diminishing over the central portion of Amarillo (Randall County).
The Haskell mesonet station measured a 77 MPH wind gust.
