A 12-mile long swath of severe hail ranging from quarter to golf ball size affected a strip of far north-central Hall County.  The hail cracked a storm chaser's windshield on Highway 287 near Memphis, but additional damage to vehicles in the area was not known.
A thunderstorm produced a rope funnel cloud in  North Austin.
Fence damage and large tree limbs broken in Garland.
The Lubbock ASOS measured a wind gust to 58 mph. No damage was reported.
A public report indicated quarter sized hail in Holland, TX.

Employees at an oil field south of Fort Stockton reported nickel size hail along U.S. Highway 385 in southern Pecos County. This occurred as isolated strong to severe thunderstorms affected the Trans Pecos and Big Bend areas of west Texas during the late afternoon and evening of the 11th.
The wind gust was measured at KGLS.
A public report indicated 3-inch diameter limbs and a few power poles blown down in the city of Deport, TX.
A small metal building was blown over at a fire station about 9 miles southeast of Emory, and trees and power lines were blown down across the southern portion of the county.

The same supercell that produced the earlier Cooper tornado moved northeast about 4 miles and spawned a second very brief tornado near Enloe, in northern Delta County. The tornado touched down in an open field just southeast of Enloe, destroying a couple of small outbuildings and scattering the debris downwind a few hundred yards. The debris pattern exhibited a subtle cyclonic orientation, implying a brief, weak tornado. The tornado was rated an EF-0 with maximum winds of 75 mph.
A thunderstorm moved across Pecos County and produced a 61 mph wind gust at the ASOS site near Fort Stockton.

Golf ball size hail accumulated several inches, with strong winds blowing the hail into drifts more than 2 feet high. Driving was extremely hazardous on I-10, and crops suffered extensive damage. A funnel cloud was also observed.
An MPING report of dime-size hail was received from the public.
Hail from dimes to quarters reported, accumulating up to an inch deep in spots.
Roofs were damaged and power lines were snapped during high winds from a thunderstorm.
Baseball-sized hail was reported along State Highway 105.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts measured at 50 kts by the ASOS at New Braunfels National Airport.

Hail up to the size of ping-pong balls combined with damaging winds to destroy cotton and watermelon crops, along with one farmer's irrigation system, in far northern Upton county and far southern Midland county.
Numerous branches, trees and power lines down scattered over large area, mainly north of 59. Fourteen thousand homes were left without power.
A power pole fell onto a car in the 700 block of Rhonda Street in Italy.
Gust estimated by Emergency Manager.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail in Round Rock.
Baseball sized hail fell in the city of Seminole.
Reports from mPing of 1-2 hail across northern Garland.
Lightning set a roof on fire on a house under construction near the Sam Rayburn Tollway and North Josey Lane.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail east of Willow City.
The Hereford Fire Department reported that a few power poles had been blown down about one and a half to two miles north of Ford Road along U.S. Highway 385.
Several trees were snapped and uprooted along Highway 259 near Allen Road.

Discrete scattered thunderstorms developed across the eastern New Mexico Plains and moved to the southeast during the evening hours of the 31st. As a thunderstorm approached the city of Hereford (Deaf Smith County), a member of the public reported golf ball size hail (1.75 inches) 7 miles north of Hereford (Deaf Smith County). The thunderstorm that produced this hail continued moving slowly to the  south-southeast and exited the southern Texas Panhandle by 10 PM CST.
Storm chasers reported a brief tornado in Hockley County. A storm survey was unable to be completed to due flooded roads.
Nickel size hail fell in the city of Aubrey.
Spotter report of 2-inch hail in northern Erath County near the intersection of county road 135 and FM 1188.
Quarter sized hail was reported at Juniper Cove Marina on Lake Whitney.
A tree was downed across CR 4650.
Local agricultural officials reported that pea to nickel size hail damaged cotton crops along the Terry and Lynn County line between Meadow and New Home.
A public report of nickel sized hail was received in Rhome.

Brownsville Police Department reported water covering roads with cars being stuck in the water along portions of Palm Boulevard, Boca Chica, Alton Gloor, and Expresway 77. CoCoRaHS observers reported rainfall totals of 3 to almost 4 inches.
The KCDS ASOS unit measured 66 mph thunderstorm wind gusts.

Two NWS employees observed a tapered funnel cloud one-third of the way to the ground for about 20 seconds.  This funnel developed just as a low-level mesocyclone tightened before becoming undercut by strong outflow from a left-moving supercell to its south.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Silverton measured a wind gust of 59 mph.
Fire Department reported quarter-sized hail in downtown Whitesboro.
An off-duty NWS employee estimated 65 mph winds near the Tarrant/Parker county line.

An isolated thunderstorm developed in southern Reeves County during the afternoon of the 25th. It briefly became severe as it propagated southeast across western and southern Pecos County. A spotter reported golfball size hail southeast of Hovey. The hail was described as being soft with most stones shattering upon impact with the ground.
Trained spotters in Abilene reported power poles and large trees were down on the south side of town.
A large light pole was snapped at a baseball field. An awning was blown off of a business and into boats at the marina.
This was measured by the Mason RAWS site located at the airport.
Emergency manager reported measured wind gust of 61 mph in Lone Oak.
Four trees were downed across Hwy. 7.  The road was closed until 10 pm.
Public reported tennis ball, then baseball, size hail between Itasca and Hillsboro.
Public reported ping pong to golf ball hail just west of Double Oak.
Penny sized hail fell 6 miles northwest of Morgan's Point Resort.
A resident reported quarter size hail at the Trois Estate near Enchanted Rock.
Amateur radio reported ping pong ball size hail in the city of Hamilton, TX.
Nearby power poles leaning, distant snapped.
Penny sized hail was reported through the NSSL PING project.
A thunderstorm produced quarter to chicken egg size hail in Bastrop.
Law enforcement official reported that the hail broke out a window of a law enforcement vehicle.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail in Niederwald.
A business sign was blown over on U.S. Highway 60 southwest of Pampa.
Tornado spotted near FM 1488 and Highway 242.
The wind gust was observed at KCLL.
A 65 mph wind gust was estimated by the public at 34th Avenue and Bell Street.
A Willacy County Emergency Manager reported a power pole and lines down at 1425 N 490 in Raymondville.
Roof damage was reported in the Elmwood area near ACR 445.
Strong thunderstorm winds resulted in downed tree limbs in Conroe, as well as shingles being blown off of roofs.
A member of the public reported hail up to golf ball size on the southwest side of Plainview.

A supercell thunderstorm produced a period of intense rainfall over Hutchinson County during the evening hours of the 14th.  This thunderstorm produced 1.66 inches of heavy rain 2 miles west-southwest of Borger (Hutchinson County).
Large trees were broken and sheds were damaged in Granbury.
An amateur radio user reported building damage along east loop 304 near Crockett.

An EF-1 tornado with estimated maximum winds near 90 mph touched down northwest of the Boxelder community, just west of Crystal Lake. The damage was very sporadic and consisted entirely of damage to hardwood and softwood trees, which had large limbs downed and a few trunks snapped. The tornado traveled northeast crossing FM 44 and FM 1701, and eventually across County Roads 4310 and 4315, resulting in more sporadic tree damage. The tornado crossed Highway 82 and snapped more tree limbs along County Road 3322 before lifting.
Powerlines were downed in the community of Mid Lake, Texas.
A brief tornado was reported 2 miles southeast of St. Jo near Highway 82. Some tree damage was reported. This tornado was rated an EF-0 with maximum estimated winds of 70 MPH.
Local broadcast media relayed pictures of damage to homes to the north and northwest of Tulia associated with a strong downburst. Additionally, numerous large tree branches were broken off.
Penny size hail was reported by the public along highway 87 between Fredericksburg and Cherry Spring.
Quarter size hail was reported north of the city of Barry.
Trees blown down across Highway 16 near Possum Kingdom Dam.
A thunderstorm moved across Midland County and produced quarter sized hail and 60 mph wind gusts about five miles west of the City of Midland.
Carport destroyed.

Many large trees sustained significant damage on the property of the North Central Texas Council of Governments. Some trees were cracked at the base and very large branches were broken off at least a dozen trees. A few trees were snapped partially up the trunk. Most of the trees were about 3-5 feet in diameter.
Penny size hail reported 2.5 miles east of Slidell.
A thunderstorm produced 2.25 inches diameter hail in the Brentwood area of Austin.
Dime to nickel size hail was reported 6 miles west-southwest of Dodson.
Tree down at Hwy 75 just north of Hwy 21.

National Weather Service survey crew determined a tornado caused EF-0 and EF-1 damage in the Pecan Plantation community. The tornado began in Hood County, before moving across the Brazos into Johnson County.

The public reported sheet metal damage occurred to a carport and aluminum siding was blown off of a house near the Falfurrias airport in Brooks County. The damage occurred as a line of thunderstorms moved through the area, producing gusty winds.  The same line dumped more than 1.5 inches of rain in Hebbronville.
The Guthrie Fire Department reported golfball size hail.
Quarter size hail at Spring Cypress and Kuykendahl.

NWS damage survey information found that a tornado touchdown first occurred about 11 miles SSW of Spearman at 0336 pm CDT and lifted at 0349 pm CDT approximately 8 miles SSW of Spearman. The tornado crossed the Hansford County line around 342 pm CDT.  The tornado was rated EF-unknown, with track and times based on eyewitness accounts and video.
Thunderstorm wind gust knocked down power lines across Interstate 30 and MM 76 in Royse City.
The Paducah Fire Department reported quarter size hail along U.S. Highway 62/70 west of Paducah.
Penny size hail was reported in Marathon.

Large cedar trees were uprooted and large limbs broken on the south side of Franklin. Additional tree damage was reported elsewhere in town along with downed power lines and broken windows. A motorcycle was also thrown across the road.
A severe wind gust tore a roof off of a home.
Golfball-size hail was reported on the south side of town.
Wind damage at a gas station in the town of Hartley.
Reported via mPING just north of DeSoto.
Fire department officials estimated wind gusts to 70 mph, though no damage information was relayed.
A trained spotter reported hail covering the ground.  Law enforcement officials reported vehicle accidents along Interstate 20 as a result of hail covering the highway.
Golf ball size hail reported in Albany in central Shackelford County.
An isolated severe thunderstorm produced dime to quarter size hail at Heath Canyon.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet.
After the tornado passed through the Barlow Estates it cross the Neches River. The tornado soon dissipated in the forest.
Ping pong ball size hail reported in Ore City.
Funnel cloud was observed from the National Weather Service Office.
Several trees were felled across Noonday Road.
The same storm that caused the first tornado north of Gruver|resulted in a 2nd over the same area about 20 minutes later. This|tornado was documented by storm chasers and noted on radar.

Amateur radio reported softball sized hail in Southeast Wylie. The hail damage in Wylie was significant with many of the homes and businesses being damaged. It was reported the roofs of some homes and businesses were penetrated by the hail. Several injuries were reported due to the broken glass but a final total could not be obtained.
A NWS Storm Survey found a few trees blown down near the Trout Creek community.
Trained spotters measured a wind gust of 67 MPH approximately 5 miles north of the city of Rhome, TX.
A member of the public in Lake Tanglewood estimated a 77 mph wind gusts which also caused the corner of a metal shed to peel back.
A tree fell on a home in Elysian Fields on Strickland Spring Road.  Other trees were downed in Karnack, Texas and throughout Harrison County.
Hail was reported two miles south of Alto, Texas.
Strong thunderstorm winds blew the roof off of a mobile home and also blew down power lines in Hereford. The gusts were estimated in part based on damage.
No damage reported.
Power lines were blown down by high winds.
A home on Patterson Street in Greeville had its roof torn off. Another roof was torn off a home on County Road 2116.

Damaging winds, estimated to be near 80 mph and measured at 73 mph by a local resident, first snapped power poles near State Highway 137 over extreme northwestern Reagan County Texas around 1740 CST.   As the storm progressed north northeastward, a residence along State Highway 137 (just south of the county line) also sustained damage to its property near 1745 CST.  Numerous tree branches, some 8 to 12 inches in diameter, were snapped.  Two windows on the southwest corner of the home were also broken by the strong winds, and a windmill near the back of the home was bent in half.  From 1810 to 1820 CST, the storm continued north northeastward and snapped/downed multiple power poles. The most significant damage caused by the storm was at a residence along Farm Road 2401 about 1 mile east of the SH137/FM2401 intersection.  Here, large pine tree branches about one foot in diameter were snapped near the top of the tree.  A large A-frame metal barn was also heavy damaged, with both doors bent from a south to north direction.  The winds funneled through this structure and pushed a 4 ton trailer about 60 feet outside of the building.  This was near the end of the damage path around 1820 CST. Overall, 60 or more power poles were damaged during this event.
Law enforcement reported quarter sized hail on I-10 near mile marker 300.
An 18 wheeler was blown over and another one  had jackknifed at mile marker 134 eastbound on I-40.
A thunderstorm produced a funnel cloud near the town of Runge.

The tornado was documented via pictures and video by multiple|storm chasers, including NWS employees. It appeared weak, but|remained in open country grassland and encountered no damage|indicators. Path was estimated based on reports and radar|signatures.
A large tree was down across one lane of Highway 84 in Palestine.
Jasper County Sheriff Office reported trees blown down in Buna.
A porch attached to a home was damaged. Large limbs were also downed as well near the home.
A picture of 2 inch in diameter hail posted to social media.
A trained spotter reported wind gusts of 60 to 70 mph in Caps.
Quarter size hail was reported near Tahoka.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 65 mph that knocked numerous branches and blew shingles off a roof southeast of Seguin.
Half dollar size hail was reported by a CoCoRaHs observer southeast of the city of Comfort.
Golfball size hail fell near Argyle.

A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Slaton measured severe wind gusts from 1930 CST through 1935 CST. A peak gust of 68 mph was measured at 1933 CST. Additionally, the Automated Surface Observing System (ASOS) at Lubbock Preston Smith International Airport measured a gust to 58 mph at 1931 CST. The emergency manager for the city of Lubbock also reported downed power poles in the 5700 block of third street in Lubbock.
Large limbs measuring "several inches" in diameter were broken off of trees at a rural residence in far southeast Pecos County by severe thunderstorm winds.
A thunderstorm produced a funnel cloud in eastern Wilson County.
Strong thunderstorm wind blew down power lines.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail in western San Antonio southeast of Sea World.

This is a continuation of the Wood County tornado. The EF-1 tornado with estimated winds between 95-105 mph continued moving northeast across a heavily wooded and rural areas of western Upshur County. Numerous trees were snapped and uprooted, before the tornado finally lifted near Farm to Market Road 852 between Horse Road and Greyhound Road. The total path length of this tornado was 27.36 miles.
A storm chaser estimated a 60 mph wind gust.
Dime sized hail was reported near the Texas World Speedway.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 50 mph that knocked down some five to six inch diameter tree limbs near Georgetown.
Penny size hail.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail in the Rogers Ranch area of northern San Antonio.

According to Storm Chaser videos, this tornado was a well developed cone tornado.  NWS and Emergency Management could not find any damage since this tornado remained over open fields.  Therefore, it was given an EF0 rating.
Golf ball size hail reported.

A severe thunderstorm produced a long, narrow swath of straight line wind and tornado damage across southern Fannin County. Within the overall wind swath, the survey team found damage consistent with at least one EF-0 tornado. This tornado formed approximately 3 miles southeast of Trenton, and moved east-northeastward 11 miles before ending in the Gober community. The tornado snapped and uprooted numerous trees along the path, and produced minor structural damage to several homes and outbuildings. Peak wind speeds associated with the tornado were estimated to be 85 mph.
Golfball hail was reported 2 miles east of Alliance Airport.

A cluster of thunderstorms moved out of the Oklahoma Panhandle and into the Texas Panhandle during the evening hours of the 30th. As this cluster of thunderstorms moved near the town of Stinnett (Hutchinson County), the KVII schoolnet site 1 mile west-northwest of Stinnett (Hutchinson County) reported a 66 mph thunderstorm downburst. After producing this downburst the cluster of thunderstorms continued to move to the southeast.

Thunderstorms produced damaging winds near Union in southeastern Terry County during the early evening hours of the 10th. Severe gusts estimated up to at least 65 mph ripped the roof off of the Union School gymnasium, and scattered debris more than 125 yards downwind. Several irrigation pivot systems were overturned. A cotton module builder damaged heavy farm equipment when it was rolled over by the winds. A trailer house located at the intersection of Texas Highways 213 and 137 suffered severe roof damage. Damage estimates were $175,000. No injuries were reported.

Damaging thunderstorm winds damaged the roof and structure of a barn located approximately 2 miles south of Greenville. A large section of property fence was also knocked down, an RV was overturned, and large trees were uprooted on the same property.

Locally heavy rains accompanied several thunderstorms that affected the Brownsville-Port Isabel and Laguna Vista area during much of the day on the 13th.  The heaviest rains, dropping more than in inch in an hour, occurred generally between 9 and 1045 AM drifting northeast from the southeast portion of Brownsville toward Port Isabel and Laguna Vista.  ||Typical poor drainage flooding was likely observed on portions of Boca Chica Blvd. mainly east of the highway 77 expressway in Brownsville. ||Calendar day rain totals at Brownsville/International Airport and Cameron County Airport (Bayview) were 2.76 and 3.05 inches, respectively.
The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet recorded a severe thunderstorm wind gust of 61 mph near Turkey. No damage was reported by local officials.
A public report indicated nickel-sized hail near the intersection of US 75 and Arapaho Road in the city of Richardson, TX.
Trees were downed due to winds and saturated ground.
No damage was noted.
A member of the public reported hail with a diameter of 1 inch.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 50 knots which knocked down some large tree limbs.
Nine power poles were knocked down in Alvord.
Tree down.
Baseball size hail was reported 7 miles south of Channing.
Trees were blown down at the Westlake Subdivision.
A public report indicated quarter sized hail in Southmayd, TX.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail in downtown San Antonio.

A National Weather Service damage survey team found evidence of a tornado approximately four miles to the northwest of Kempner. This tornado occurred nearly simultaneously with a tornado near Lampasas. This tornado produced damage to several buildings, including two houses where large sections of roof damage.
Lightning struck a tall pine tree in a residential area. Electronics inside the nearby home and garage were damaged.
Downburst activity in the Lubbock vicinity produced a severe wind gust near Slaton where the Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet recorded a 58 mph peak wind at 19:05 CST. No damage was reported.
MPing report was received of tree limbs broken at Padre Isles Country Club.
Multiple trees were blown down across the south side of Corpus Christi.

Multiple reports were received of nickel to quarter size hail in and around Levelland. The hail was accompanied by destructive winds. Newspaper reports indicated that hail across the area destroyed more than one thousand acres of cotton. In addition, a total of forty-seven windows were broken by the wind-blown hail in Levelland.
A house was destroyed by high winds.
Several large trees down on FM 241.
Measured by the West Texas Mesonet station two miles east of Pampa. These winds were well ahead of the thunderstorm complex.
A large tree was downed onto a home near Tyler Street in Big Sandy.  The occupants were trapped inside.  There were no report of injuries.  Numerous powerlines were also downed across the city.
Amateur radio reported quarter-sized hail in the city of Euless, TX.
A brief tornado heavily damaged an outbuilding and damaged trees just north of State Highway 240.
Hail reported on Stone Road.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail southwest of Flatonia.
Strong winds downed trees and caused roof damage to two businesses near the intersection of Clayton Parkway and West Lake Houston Parkway.
Several trees were blown down in Ambrose due to high winds.
Public reported quarter to golf ball size hail covering the ground near Skeeterville.
A public report indicated 3 inch diameter limbs knocked down about one mile northwest of Buckingham, TX.

Local law enforcement officials reported multiple power lines had blown down...dumpsters were overturned...tree limbs had blown down...a water tank had blown over...shingles had blown off roofs of homes in the area...and a roof had blown off a local business by the strong thunderstorm wind gusts.
Quarter size hail reported near Broaddus.

Discrete thunderstorms developed over the southern Texas Panhandle during the evening hours of the 16th. One of these thunderstorms developed over northern Carson County and moved to the south-southeast into Armstrong County. A storm chaser in Goodnight (Armstrong County) reported ping pong ball size hail (1.50 inches) as the thunderstorm moved overhead. The thunderstorm continued to move to the south-southeast across the county after producing this hail.
Widespread trees were downed across the county.
Golf ball to baseball size hail was reported south of Pandale.
A rural resident reported penny to nickel size hail in western Pecos County.
A trained spotter reported quarter size hail 6 miles east-southeast of Sweetwater.
A 58 mph wind gust was recorded at Angelina County Airport.
Golfball size hail broke several windows and damaged crops in the area.

A broad swath of damaging thunderstorm straight-line winds, several miles in width, occurred over Van Zandt County early Friday morning. These winds produced substantial tree damage and some light structural damage in the city of Canton, and particularly in areas to the west, south, and southeast of Canton. A National Weather Service Fort Worth team found damage in some locations southeast of Canton consistent with wind speeds of approximately 80 to 85 mph.
A tree was snapped and a fence blown over just southwest of Tyler, Texas.

High winds, causing spotty damage over the western third of Bexar County, and nearly continuous damage over the eastern two-thirds of the county, caused widespread destruction of trees and limbs.  The high winds damaged roofs, propelled hail into homes and cars, and knocked over power poles.  About ten persons were injured by the flying debris.  The greatest devastation was in southwest Bexar County just northeast of the town of Lytle.  Emergency management and Red Cross officials estimated 50 mobile homes and houses severely damaged or destroyed, with minor damage to another 100 mobile homes and houses.  In addition to the widespread downburst damage, evidence was found of small and short-lived tornadoes.  It was very difficult to separate the widespread downburst-wind damage from the tornado damage.  The main clues were that the downburst damage was almost exclusively along a southwest to northeast path and showed a consistent and gradual gradient of damage levels from the worst of the damage to the least of the damage.  The tornado damage indicated completely different direction of movement and very strong, pronounced gradients of damage.  Often a structure would be completely destroyed, with structures to the right and left of it nearly untouched.

Picture and video evidence confirmed a brief tornado west of Celina. Minor tree damage was found along County Road 9. Maximum estimated winds were 70 mph. The tornado started in Denton County but crossed into Collin County briefly before dissipating.
A few large trees were downed in town.

The first 60 mph plus wind gust was measured at 76 mph at 1927CDT. The mesonet then quickly measured a 95 and 96 mph wind gust over  the next two minute. The last  wind gust of 61 mph was  at 1935CDT.
A trained spotter reported quarter sized hail one mile north of Alvord.

Thunderstorms formed along a dryline stretching east-northeastward across Randall and Potter Counties during the afternoon hours of the 28th. These thunderstorms would take a northeast track which allowed them to move over the dryline. This caused the thunderstorms to produce isolated downbursts across the city. The Amarillo (Potter County) ASOS reported a 58 mph gust while a thunderstorm was overhead. The thunderstorm decayed quickly after moving to the dry side of the dryline due to ingesting much drier air into the updrafts.  No damage or injuries were associated with this gust.
KJAS Radio reported tree limbs and power lines down across Jasper.
Dime to penny sized hail was reported in the Fair Oaks Ranch area.
A storm chaser reported tennis ball size hail.

Local law enforcement officials and the public reported wind gusts to 60 mph across Hockley county. The swath of winds downed several power poles from west of Levelland along Texas Highway 114 to Whitharral. Additionally, a 300 pound diesel fuel tank also was blown over just east of the Hockley and Cochran county line along Texas Highway 114.
A thunderstorm produced hen egg size hail near Mesquite Pass.

Nickel hail was reported by the Texas Department of Public Safety along Highway 87 at Forsan.The convection evolved into a squall line by mid morning. The initially short line of storms was characterized by a well-defined bookend vortex on its north end that tracked across Glasscock County. This portion of the line produced quarter to golfball size hail. Severe thunderstorm winds affected eastern Pecos and northern Terrell Counties as the southern extent of the line progressed east.Several line echo wave patterns were identified using local warning weather radar along the squall line as it expanded north with time. A tornado was confirmed to have been associated with one such signature in northeast Reagan County.
Measured by the Texas Tech/West Texas mesonet station.
A large tree was reported blown over by the high winds.
A 67 mph wind gust was observed at Mesonet Station 1757W, located in Kyle Field at Texas A&M University.
Power lines were blown down near San Diego.

Evidence of damaging winds was observed by a National Weather Service damage survey team in west-central Garza County. Numerous trees sustained damage from thunderstorm outflow winds along County Road 399 just north of U.S. Highway 380.
Emergency management reported 3 inch diameter hail in Bowie, TX near the Highway 287 exit.
Nickel size hail fell in Goldthwaite.
Three people were injured by lightning at a construction site in Austin.
Penny to golfball sized hail fell near the Midland International Airport.
Trees downed.
Nickel sized hail was reported in Bells which is approximately 7 miles east of Sherman.
Strong thunderstorm wind gusts caused the roof to be peeled off from a barn at Farm to Market Road 1062 and Bushland Road.
Nickel sized hail was reported by a trained spotter in Decatur, TX.
Nickel sized hail was reported.
Quarter sized hail was reported at the intersection of SH 195 and SH 201, in southern Killeen.
No damage was reported with the wind gust.
A public report indicated quarter sized hail approximately 1.5 miles north-northeast of the city of Richardson, TX.
Quarter to golf ball size hail covered the ground in Burkett.
Social media video showing quarter to half dollar size hail. Time is radar estimated.

A tornado touched down 2 miles southeast of Alvarado and moved northeast 2.8 miles then lifting 3 miles east of Alvarado. One person sustained head injuries from flying debris.  Two mobile homes were destroyed and one heavily damaged, a  house was unroofed, a workshop was destroyed, and numerous trees and power lines  were blown down
The ASOS station at the Rio Grande Valley International Airport (KHRL) recorded a wind gust of 58 knots, or 67 mph, at 6:20AM CDT.
A thunderstorm moved across Scurry County and produced a 60 mph wind gust at the ASOS site near Snyder.
Nickel size hail reported in Knollwood.
Several outbuildings were damaged by high winds.
Severe thunderstorm winds blew down several trees and lifted and rolled a small barn several hundred yards.
Quarter size hail fell on Highway 37 between Bogota and Clarksville.
Law enforcement officials reported that severe thunderstorm winds downed power lines on the south side of Seminole.
Amateur radio reported quarter size hail approximately 3 miles west of the city of Paris, TX.
A thunderstorm produced penny size hail in northern Real County.
A severe thunderstorm produced quarter sized hail.
Large tree limbs were broken along LCR 406 just north of LCR 412.

A bow-shaped segment of the linear complex moved across central Ector County. Damaging thunderstorm winds blew down traffic signs in West Odessa. Power lines also were blown down in Odessa. In addition, a few windows were broken by the winds and several garbage dumpsters were blown into the city streets. No injuries were reported.
The daughter of a former NWS Brownsville/Rio Grande Valley employee reported quarter sized hail along N. 17th Street in McAllen.
Amateur radio reported trees down near Granbury, TX.
Quarter size hail fell in Waskom. Report from the KSLA-TV Facebook page.
Golfball size hail fell throughout much of Longview.
Public reported this 1.25 inch hail report on the north side of Sweetwater using the Mping App.
Lightning struck the roof of St. John's Lutheran Church.  Minor damage was reported.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near O'Donnell measured a wind gust to 61 mph.
Baseball size hail was reported 4 miles west of Rotan.
Dime sized hail was reported at Lois Lane and I-35N, north of Sanger.
A storm chaser reported 2 inch hail along U.S. Highway 290 approximately 5 miles west of Harper.

A damage survey conducted by the National Weather Service in Fort Worth found that a significant tornado developed approximately three miles east-northeast of Anna.  A house was unroofed and another damaged just east of Collin County Road 477.  Trees and power lines were also downed.  A roof was damaged along FM 2862 west of Collin County Road 480.  The tornado ranged from an F1 to an F2 on the Fujita Tornado Intensity Scale during this part of its lifetime.  The tornado then turned on a slightly more northerly track.The tornado reached its maximum intensity of F3 as it crossed FM 3133 just north of the Westminster community.  Vegetation west of FM 3133 was scoured.  Two homes were heavily damaged south of Collin County Road 531.  A mobile home and several permanent structures suffered heavy damage along Brangus and Black Roads, near the Collin-Grayson County line.  These were the locations of the fatalities.  Several other people suffered injuries and were transported to hospitals.  Numerous livestock were killed.  The affected parts of Collin County were declared disaster areas.The tornado continued on its destructive path as it crossed into Grayson County.
A tree was blown onto a road by thunderstorm winds.
Hail up to the size of quarters was reported at a gasoline station along U.S. Highway 62/82 between Lorenzo and Idalou. No damage was reported.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail east of Liberty Hill.
A tree was blown down.

This is a continuation of the Northwest Panola County tornado. This EF-1 tornado, with estimated maximum winds around 110 mph, remained over pastureland in extreme Northeast Rusk County before crossing into Southwest Harrison County. Several trees were snapped and uprooted in this area before the tornado tracked across the Sabine River into Harrison County.
A thunderstorm produced baseball size hail in Bertram.
Three inch hail was reported by an NWS Employee near Presidio Vista Drive.

An EF-1 tornado with estimated maximum winds near 105 mph touched down just southwest of the Crossroads community near the intersection of Mercer and Eddington Roads, where several trees were snapped. The tornado continued northeast across FM 31 near Hays Road, where multiple trees were snapped and uprooted. A tree also fell on a home, but fortunately, the residents inside were not injured. The tornado tracked northeast, crossing FM 2525, Webb Rogers Road near Sneed Road, and Ireland Williams Road, snapping numerous large limbs and trees. The tornado crossed Interstate 20 and Highway 80, snapping additional large limbs, before lifting near Bellview Road.
Penny sized hail was reported near the intersection of Farm to Market Roads 755 and 490.
Hail up to the size of quarters was reported in Paris by several sources.
A 70 MPH wind gust was reported by a trained spotter in Rowlett.
A thunderstorm produced penny size hail in Georgetown.
One inch hail near Ford Park.
A storm spotter measured a 67 mph wind gust 8 miles west of Crowley.
Wind gust occurred at the Crab Lake WeatherFlow site.
NWS Storm Survey estimates 115 mph winds with MCS.
Amateur radio reported one inch hail at Park and Country Club in Wylie.
An amateur radio operator captured a brief tornado on camera at 5:03 PM CDT outside of Peoria. The tornado lasted only a few minutes, and produced minor damage to farmland.
Tree limbs were down in west Waco. The power was out for about 2,500 customers in Waco.
Trees were reported down along FM 1696 near Crabbs Prairie.
Amateur radio report of quarter-sized hail 1 mile east of Lake Kiowa.
A public report indicated quarter size hail 2 miles south-southwest of the city of Boyd, TX.
Quarter sized hail was reported in Mineral Wells.
A Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet station northeast of Slaton measured a gust to 68 mph at 2325 CST followed by a gust to 61 mph at 2330 CST.
A National Weather Service employee reported half dollar sized hail 2 miles west-northwest of Justin, TX.

Numerous reports of large hail were received as a multi-cell cluster of severe storms slowly propagated southwestward over northern Lynn County. Initial reports were received at 19:34 CST of penny size hail along U.S. Highway 87 just south of the Lubbock and Lynn County line. Hailstones reportedly grew in size as the storm propagated southwestward over northern Lynn County. Newspaper accounts indicated that many acres of young cotton plants were stripped and that farmers will be hard pressed to replant by the insurance dictated deadlines.

A transformer block was knocked off a power  pole towards the south. An empty semi-trailer was also flipped on its side at this location. The time of occurrence is estimated from radar. The maximum gust and cost of damages is also estimated.
Penny size hail fell 7 miles south-southeast of Borger.
Numerous reports of trees down with power outages throughout central Austin and the UT area.
Three-quarter inch hail was reported near Anderson County Road 2709 in Tennessee Colony.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail at the intersection of Tomlinson St. and Patterson Ave. in Florence.
Quarter to golf ball-size hail was reported by a trained spotter.
Quarter size hail fell near Lake Striker.
The ASOS site at the La Salle County Airport near Cotulla reported a 53 knot gust.
Ping pong ball size hail reportedly covered the ground along Texas Farm to Market Road 659 south of Post. This as the third in a series of severe storms impacted portions of Garza County.
Sheriff's office reported trees down on FM 1097.

Numerous reports of large hail were received as a severe thunderstorm impacted areas near downtown Lubbock northeastward to just east of Preston Smith International Airport. At 16:20 CST the public reported nickel size hail at the intersection of 19th Street and Indiana Avenue in Lubbock. By 16:29 CST, nickel size hail was reported at 4th Street and Interstate 27 in north Lubbock. Penny size hail was additionally reported along Farm to Market Road 1729 northeast of the city at 16:50 CST.
Ping pong ball sized hail was reported by amateur radio east of Krum, TX.
A strong wind gust was measured near Ganado.
A weak tornado caused significant roof damage to Bay Harbor apartment complex in Baytown. Approximately 16 units were damaged with the loss of one roof. Another roof was partially lifted and thrown.
Several large tree branches were broken between Glory and Slabtown.
National Weather Service storm survey crews determined a tornado produced EF-1 damage to downtown Ennis, before continuing to move northeast.
Quarter sized hail fell in north Keller.
The Sheriffs Office radio tower was blown down,  a windmill was blown down, one barn destroyed, another barn was damaged, and trees and utility lines were blown down.
NWS Storm Survey found a few trees blown down along Highway 87 near Forest Heights.
Delayed report of hail along highway 70 between Crowell and Thalia. Time estimated from radar. No damage reported.
A member of the public estimated a thunderstorm wind gust of near 60 mph.
Nickel size hail fell north northwest of Mount Enterprise, Texas.
Tornado hit a Friendswood home subdivision. Numerous homes received roof damage, garage door damage, and tree damage.
The time of this hail report was estimated by radar.
Ping pong ball sized hail occurred near Sparks Colony Drive west of Rockport.

On Tuesday morning, the National Weather Service in Midland conducted a damage survey of areas within the city of Midland affected by a heat burst. The damage survey focused on locations at and around the intersection of Loop 250 and Midland Drive, in northwest portions of the city of Midland. Between Briarwood and Navarro Avenues along Midland Drive, 13 power poles were damaged to varying degees. A 62 mph wind was reported at Midland Airpark on the 11:25 pm CDT observation. However, damage to wooden poles along Midland Drive was indicative of winds in the 80 to 100 mph range.

A discrete thunderstorm moved into Lipscomb County during the evening hours of the 28th. As the storm approached the town of Booker (Lipscomb County), the County Emergency Manager reported quarter size hail (1.00 inch) in the town of Booker (Lipscomb County). After producing this hail the storm diminished as it crossed into the Oklahoma Panhandle.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail behind the HEB in the Riverside Grove neighborhood in Bastrop.
Spotter reports indicated an estimated 70 MPH wind gust, as well as a car blown off the road near the intersection of Sandusky Road and Highway 377.
Widespread significant tree damage was observed in the Cape Malibu subdivision in Willis.

A thunderstorm moved over Gaines County and produced a 70 mph wind gust 22 miles west of Seminole.  These winds damaged a roof and uprooted a two foot diameter tree.  The cost of damage is a rough estimate.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that toppled a large 10 inch diameter tree onto a fence.
Reported via mPing, hail between 1.25-1.5 inches fell in this location.
Ping pong ball sized hail was reported at Fort Hood on the ASOS (KGRK).
Broadcast media reported quarter sized hail approximately 4 miles west of Nocona.
A thunderstorm moved across Andrews County and produced wind damage eight miles south of the City of Andrews. A few telephone poles were blown down. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
A thunderstorm produced two inch hail and wind gusts that knocked down tree limbs greater than two inches in diameter.

Slow moving thunderstorms, containing up to an hour and a half of torrential rains, dumped between 3 and 4 inches across the heart of populated Hidalgo County, from Mission to Weslaco, during the early and mid afternoon of June 22nd.  Numerous instances of nuisance urban flooding were reported, much in the typical poor drainage locations that see flooding with any locally heavy rainfall.||Nuisance flooding of roads and ditches were reported in the typical poor drainage locations of McAllen/Pharr and Weslaco.  At McAllen/Miller airport, 3.13 inches of rain fell in less than two hours before the power was knocked out due to lightning in the area. CoCoRaHS observers reported 3.08 inches and 3.18 inches in Mission and Edinburg, respectively, and nearly 3 inches (2.84) fell at the Mid Valley Airport in Weslaco.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 50 knots which blew down multiple trees, primarily on the west side of San Antonio.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Jayton measured a wind gust of 62 mph.
Report from mPING: Quarter (1.00 in.).
A large tree was blown onto a house in extreme northeast Erath County.
Nickel sized hail
Hail was reported in the Redtown community near Pollock.
A trained spotter reported 3-inch diameter hail just southwest of Belton, TX.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts measured at 51 kts. by the AWOS at Kenedy Regional Airport.
Large tree limbs were broken by damaging thunderstorm winds at a ranch headquarters southwest of Guthrie.
Strong thunderstorm winds knocked down a few tree limbs and also destroyed 2 sheds. This damage occurred near FM 1618 and Private Road 3365; just west of Interstate 45.
Numerous trees were blown down across Kilgore.
Trees and power lines were downed throughout Gilmer and much of Upshur County. Street signs were downed as well.
A trained spotter reported penny size hail in the city of Hewitt, TX.
Mostly nickle-sized hail was reported on Green Mound Drive in Glenn Heights, but a few hail stones ranged up to 1.5 in diameter.
Portion of a roof were blown off house and barn onto Highway 87 just south of FM 616. Winds of 70 mph estimated by NWS storm survey team.
Hail up to 1 was reported near Loop 820 and Davis Blvd in North Richland Hills.
A tree was blown down across Highway 42.
A thunderstorm moved across Scurry County and produced a 67 mph wind gust near Snyder.
Spotter measured a 70 MPH wind gust in town near Interstate 20.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph.
Multiple trees downed west of Carthage.
One inch diameter hail was reported by amateur radio 2 miles northeast of North Texas Regional Airport.
Dime to quarter size hail was reported in Nacogdoches, Texas.
Medium to large tree branches were downed by strong thunderstorm winds in Caldwell.
Trees and power lines were blown down by high winds.
Two fireworks stands blown over on State Route 43, between F.M. 763 and State Route 286.

A supercell thunderstorm moved southward across the Texas Panhandle during the evening hours of the 14th. The Fritch Fire Department reported a 75 mph thunderstorm gust near the town of Fritch (Hutchinson County). The supercell thunderstorm continued moving southward after producing this hail.
Large tree uprooted in south Midland.
The report of two inch diameter size hail was received from the Conoco Phillips Refinery in Borger via the Emergency Manager.
Nickel sized hail fell on the west side of Flower Mound.
A roof and an awning was damaged on a building on Richardson Drive in Henderson.
Golfball size hail was reported near London.
A Facebook picture of a carport destroyed and blown into a neighbors yard. The time was estimated off radar.

Multiple employees at a cattle feed yard in rural southwestern Swisher County observed a tornado that developed over open country southwest of Tulia. No damage was reported. The tornado was spawned by the same storm that resulted in tornadic damage near Nazareth (Castro County) during the previous hour.
Penny to nickle-sized hail reported.
Trees were downed around Cushing, Texas.
Brief touchdown near the Tom Green and Concho County line.
The Gaines County Sheriff's Office reported penny size hail covering U.S. Highway 385 caused an accident south of Seminole.  No injuries occurred.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph in Georgetown.
Hen egg sized hail was reported in the city of Bowie on Pelham and Lee streets.

A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Tahoka measured severe wind gusts from 2202 CST through 2220 CST. A peak wind gust of 66 mph was measured at 2202 and 2203 CST. Additionally, damage to several structures were reported on the south side of Tahoka.
Lightning struck a home in Lindsay, causing a small fire.

A supercell moved northeast into southwest Wood County and the storm produced an EF0 tornado which touched down briefly about 4 miles northwest of Mineola, Texas along the eastern shore of Lake Holbrook.  Damage consisted of a few trees snapped or uprooted near the lake and some tin from boat sheds removed along the shores of the lake.

An EF-0 tornado started west of the town of Frankston, close to Hwy 175 and Anderson CR 303. Initially the tornado damaged trees at a few homes along Hwy 175. As the tornado moved into town, it continued to cause tree damage, breaking large limbs from trunks and uprooting trees. Some of the limbs and trees fell on homes causing damage to roofs. One tree fell through the end of a home causing a non-life threatening injury. In the town of Frankston, the tornado was rated EF-0 with maximum winds of 85 mph. Many of the uprooted trees occurred in already saturated soils, and this was factored into the final wind speed determination.  The tornado continued east of town and was tracked by scattered tree damage along CRs 3051 and 309. The tornado likely dissipated before reaching Lake Palestine.
A 78 MPH wind gust was measured by the Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport Automated Surface Observation System.

The hailstorm that began in northeastern Hall County continued to track east-southeast across far northern Childress County, with hailstones larger than teacups at times. However, the majority of the severe hail reports were generally tennis ball size or smaller. No damage information was available.
The report was relayed through mPING.
Large trees blown down.
Military personnel reported golf ball sized hail at Phantom Warrior Lanes on Fort Hood in Killeen Texas.

Thunderstorms moved through the northern part of San Antonio and produced wind gusts estimated up to 65 mph. These winds knocked down power lines in Leon Springs, knocked down traffic lights and tore a hole in a house roof in Stone Oak, knocked down tree limbs in Alamo Heights, knocked down trees around the San Antonio International Airport, and caused power outages in Castle Hills.
Two inch hail was reported via social media in McKinney.
A thunderstorm produced hail up to tennis ball size hail near the Flying T O Ranch Airport in western Zavala County.
The Automated Weather Observing System at Big Spring (KBPG) reported a wind gust of 58 mph.
Wind measured at local media's weather net site near Mount Vernon, Texas.
Trees were blown down by high winds.-
Trees down on Highway 83 near Farm to Market Road 705 just west of the Anthony Harbor community. Only the shoulder of the road was passable.
Trees downed over Fm 1400.
No damage was reported.
One and a quarter inch hail fell in Prairie Point which is west of the town of Rosston along FM 922.
Time is radar estimated.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that knocked down several trees in Garrison Park in southern Austin.
Penny sized hail was reported in Alamo as a strong thunderstorm passed through just before sunset.
Quarter-size hail damaged sheriff vehicle's windshield.
Trees were downed on numerous county roads near the city of Pittsburg, Texas.
A thunderstorm moved across Howard County and produced quarter sized hail and 50 to 60 mph winds which blew a trash can down the road in Coahoma.
CoCoRaHS observer west of Harlingen reported 3.55 inches of rainfall in less than 2 hours.
A thunderstorm moved across Reagan County and produced a 63 mph wind gust five miles southwest of St. Lawrence.
A thunderstorm produced a wind gust measured at 53 kts. by the ASOS at Austin-Bergstrom International Airport.

Broadcast media reported a downed power pole and sheet metal outbuilding blown apart east of Graham on Highway 380. There were also multiple reports of other metal buildings and small structures damaged in and around Graham.
An off-duty National Weather Service employee reported the hail at Interstate 40 and Eastern Street.
Large trees were knocked down in Turnersville in northern Coryell County. Minor damage was reported at the fire station.
A thunderstorm produced half dollar size hail south of Liberty Hill.
Trees were downed on the west side of Tyler, Texas.
NWS employee reports hail up to 1 near the intersection of Beach Street and Shiver Road.
A storm chaser reported quarter size hail along FM 1450. Time is estimated from radar.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that blew down 10 to 12 inch diameter Oak tree limbs onto a car near Woodcreek Dr. and Marina Circle in Wimberley.
Hail from a supercell thunderstorm fell on the community of Tye for several minutes.
Odell (ODEL) Mesonet observation.

Weather played a role in the death of a person who crashed their truck in the 4500 block of Davis Street near Cockrell Hill Rd. The roads were slick due to rain at the time of the accident. No other information about the deceased could be found.
A public report was received of half dollar size hail near US Highway 83 just south of the Collingsworth/Childress County line.
This gust was measured at the West Texas Mesonet station 2 miles northwest of Lake McClellan.
Several large trees down over CR 285.
Received multiple photos of a funnel cloud via social media, northeast of Rio Hondo or southwest of Arroyo City. Time and location are approximated based on reports and on radar.
A thunderstorm moved across Culberson County and produced a 64 mph wind gust nineteen miles west southwest of Red Bluff.
A large tree was blown down in a yard on Main Street in Garrison. Report from the KYTX Facebook page.
Trees and power lines were blown down by damaging thunderstorm winds.
Large tree limbs were blown down.
Multiple public reports were received of hail ranging in size from pennies to quarters.
Quarter size hail fell at the Mclennan County Fairgrounds.
A tree was blown down in the southbound lane of Highway 259 at the intersection of CR 4235.
A trained spotter reported golf ball sized hail approximately 2 miles south of Granbury, TX.

A fast moving tornado touched down near FM1746, blowing down or snapping off several trees. While it was crossing FM92, it ripped off part of the metal roof of a small rural grocery store. Eyewitnesses saw the tornado at the Corp of Engineers office across the street. The sheet metal from the roof was blown into the COE park and damaged several picnic areas, and snapped off several more trees.

F1 tornado took the roof off of a home, overturned trailers and downed numerous trees in northern Bryan along Hwy 21. Trees and telephone poles were downed from in and around Neal Elementary School to in and around Bonham Elementary School near South Texas Avenue. Two homes were reportedly destroyed. Several downtown Bryan buildings including the Palace Theater, Howell Building and the Charles and Bryan Hotels were also damaged.

Law enforcement reported roof material was blown off of the West Side High School. In addition, a few trees were toppled, power lines were knocked down, several carports were turned over, and trampolines were blown around. Most of the damage extended to eight blocks south of the courthouse. There were also some large barn doors buckled by the highs winds on the north side of Anson.
An EF-0 tornado produced minor damage to a small home and garage. There was also minor shingle damage to a residence across the street.
Trees and power lines were blown down all across the county.
Hail fell in the Rugby, Texas community.
Powerlines were downed due to high winds.

NWS storm survey concluded a tornado touched down in an open field just east of Levien Road. The tornado traveled east crossing Gin Road where it snapped 5 utility poles and blew the roof off of a shed. The tornado dissipated before crossing Farm to Market Road 136 north of Bayside.
Nickel sized hail was reported with a passing storm.

A National Weather Service damage survey concluded that a small EF0 tornado formed and dissipated quickly the morning of October 26, near the intersection of FM 306 and Purgatory Rd. in Comal County.  A few residences along FM 306 near that intersection sustained minor damage mainly to fences and trees. No other damage was observed in the area.  Maximum winds were estimated at 70 mph with a path length just over one quarter mile.
A tree was downed on Martin Luther King Drive in Dekalb, Texas.
Storm spotters affiliated with the Matador Fire Department reported golfball size hail.
A mesonet observation station reported a 59 mph wind gust.
The Buna Sawmill reported and estimated wind gust of 60 MPH with a passing storm.
Multiple trees down in Hilshire Village.
The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet recorded a thunderstorm wind gust of 59 miles per hour near Roaring Springs. No damage was reported.
Emergency management reported baseball size hail in the city of Blossom, TX.
Half dollar sized hail was reported at the intersection of FM 2005 and FM 1047.
A thunderstorm moved across Pecos County and produced a 71 mph wind gust at the Fort Stockton ASOS site.

An NWS Storm Survey found a low-end EF1 tornado struck the eastern part of Nome. The tornado began southwest of Rodeo Drive in the southeast part of Nome and moved north-northeast, causing minor damage to a rodeo arena.  Several outbuildings were then damaged or destroyed on the west side of FM 365 with debris thrown up to 200 yards to the north-northeast.  The tornado then entered the Silver Spur Mobile Home Park, where one mobile home had its side sheared off and a nearby RV was flipped over onto a vehicle.  The occupants inside were not injured. Another mobile home lost much of its roof, while several other mobile homes suffered various degrees of siding, window, and awning damage. Two homes at the intersection of Kotz Road and FM 365 received roof and siding damage along with broken windows. Crossing FM 365, the tornado then caused minor roof damage and broken windows to several homes on the east side of the highway, and destroyed two barns.  2X4s from one of these barns were carried up to 100 yards to the west and driven several feet into the ground. The tornado crossed Highway 90 just east of the FM 365 intersection with damaged trees and embedded sheet metal noted north of the railroad tracks.  Entering open farm fields, the tornado deposited sheet metal from one of the previously destroyed barns up to 1/2 mile north of Highway 90 before it dissipated.||In total, a Red Cross survey found up to 30 homes suffered some degree of damage, and of those 2 were considered destroyed and 3 had major damage. Dozens of trees and power lines were blown down all along the path in all different directions.  No injuries were reported. Numerous local residents witnessed the tornado.
Windows blown out Torchy's Tacos.
Broadcast media reported that a lightning strike caused a house fire on Royal Glen Drive in the city of Arlington, TX. Firefighters were still putting out the fire 2 hours after arriving.
Nickel-sized hail was reported in Sugar Land.
A trained spotter reported pea to quarter size hail in Stamford.
Large tree limbs were blown down.
La Joya COOP observer reported 1.30 inches of rainfall and minor street flooding north of La Joya.
Slightly larger than golf ball sized hail was reported north of Celina on the Grayson/Collin County line.
Ping pong ball size hail was reported at the Gun Barrel City Airpark.

A swath of damaging thunderstorm winds affected portions of southern Terry County shortly after 19:00 CST. Three mobile homes were severely damaged east of Wellman. the homes sustained significant roof damage, with the roof completely removed from one structure. Several utility poles were additionally downed by the winds from just east of Wellman to ten miles east of Wellman.
A member of the public estimated a thunderstorm wind gust around 60 mph near Tuscola.
Trees were downed on Highway 21 a few miles east of Chireno.
A funnel cloud was reported along Highway 105 between Beaumont and Sour Lake by Beaumont media.
An emergency manager reported quarter size hail in Flower Mound.
A tree was blown down on County Road 4945.
The mesonet station located one mile east of McLean observed a 60mph wind gust from a few showers that moved across the region.
Severe winds in the Lytle area damaged or destroyed three mobile homes, while blowing over trees, limbs, road signs, and damaging roofs in the area.
Large tree limbs were blown down by high winds.

Softball sized hail was reported by a trained spotter one-eighth of a mile west of the Texas Woman's Campus in Denton. Additionally, this storm covered much of the city of Denton, and a considerable part of the County as well. The Insurance Council of Texas estimated approximately 35,000 vehicles, and 22,000 homes were damaged in some fashion with this storm. The damage estimate is aproximately 500 million dollars.
A National Weather Service Cooperative Observer reported numerous large tree limbs of 40 feet in length were downed by the damaging winds.  The strong winds also ripped up some metal from a building.
Tree down over CR 402 near Davilla.

For approximately 15 minutes, a barrage of northerly winds of 60 mph to as great as 120 mph inflicted heavy damage in the city of Turkey, located in far southwest Hall County.  NWS Lubbock meteorologists conducted a ground and aerial damage survey at Turkey the following afternoon. All available evidence including radar, damage patterns, eyewitness accounts, and most notably a 15-minute duration of high winds indicated that a series of wet microbursts moved from north to south across Turkey. Several homes and businesses suffered damage, most notably the Turkey Compress which was totally destroyed. At least two homes suffered major damage and were deemed uninhabitable.  Numerous large trees and power poles were snapped, building and car windows broken, garage doors collapsed, and other extensive damage occurred to car ports and canopies. Power in the city was not restored until nearly 12 hours later. Despite a large amount of airborne debris that affected the city, no fatalities or injuries occurred.  Peak wind speeds were estimated to be in the 100-120 mph range based on the degree of damage. It is important to note that the most severely damaged structures were particularly old and not well maintained, including one home built in 1927. Homes that suffered roof damage or even broken windows also sustained extensive water damage from torrential rains that followed the series of microbursts.
Numerous trees downed throughout northern Panola County.
Nickel hail was reported in Cottondale, on Wise County Road 3555.
Social media posts showed a destroyed metal baseball backstop along with several large tree limbs down on the northern side of Rio Grande City. Timing estimated by radar and social media posts.
Storm chasers reported a brief tornado over open country.  No damage resulted from the tornado.

An EF-1 tornado with estimated maximum winds near 100 mph embedded within a quasi-linear convective system (QLCS) briefly touched down on County Road 3658, before crossing Highway 59 between the Queen City and Domino communities. The tornado continued to track northeast, crossing County Road 3664 before lifting near County Road 3665. Numerous trees were uprooted along the tornado's path, and destroyed several metal outbuildings while damaging the roofs of manufactured homes along County Roads 3658 and 3664 before lifting.
Several roofs of homes were damaged between Breckenridge and Crystal Falls. Trees were also blown down.
Dime to Penny size hail was reported at Belt Line Road and Midway Road.
An estimated 800 acres of cotton were destroyed.

A slow moving supercell moved out of the Oklahoma Panhandle and into the northeastern Texas Panhandle during the evening hours of the 22nd. As the supercell moved towards Wolf Creek Park (Ochiltree County), a local law enforcement official reported ping pong ball size hail (1.50 inches) in the park. After producing this hail the supercell continue it's slow track southward across the eastern Texas Panhandle.

Broadcast media reported several homes having roof damage approximately one mile west-northwest of the city of Allen, TX. The emergency manager confirmed the wind damage. Other sporadic tree limb, shingle and car port/patio cover damage was reported across the city.
A 30 foot by 55 foot structure was destroyed.  Numerous trees were also uprooted nearby.

Additional convection developed south of the initial long-lived supercell.  The newly developed storms also produced large hail.  Multiple reports of quarter to ping pong ball size hail were recieved from the Brownfield vicinity at 16:45 CST.
Penny size hail was reported in Marathon.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 58 mph which blew down several trees and caused numerous power outages near LaVernia.
A construction trailer was damaged at the Hagerman National Wildlife Refuge Visitor Center, and several trees that were larger than 6 inches in diameter were split. One minor injury was reported.
Trees were blown down across the county.
A tree was blown down at the intersection of Highway 271 and FM 726 in the West Mountain community.
Severe thunderstorm winds downed trees across the county, and especially in and around the Crockett area.
ASOS at Alice International Airport measured a 67 mph gust.
A public report indicated half-dollar sized hail about one mile northeast of Blue Mound, TX.

Tornado touched down along Farm to Market Road 468 near the Dimmit County line. The tornado flipped an 18 wheeler then proceeded northeast about 5 miles. The tornado then crossed Farm to Market Road 469 and struck an oil hydraulic fracturing flow back site. The tornado flipped one RV trailer at the site. Two people inside the RV trailer sustained serious injuries. Both were released from the hospital the next day. The winds were estimated to be around 80 mph with this damage. The tornado proceeded northeast across open ranch land another 5 miles before dissipating.
The report was relayed through mPING.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that blew over fences and a shed and took parts of metal roof panels off a house.
Thunderstorms produced wind gusts estimated at 75 mph that peeled back a portion of a metal roof, blew over a 10 inch Cedar Elm, and tore 10 inch diameter branches off trees.

The Automated Surface Observing Station at Wink (KINK) recorded a wind gust of 67 mph. A local media outlet reported downed powerlines and trees in Kermit. The roof at the Family Activity Center of the First Baptist Church in Kermit was severely damaged.
Thunderstorms associated with a strong arctic cold front produced a measured wind gust of 52 knots on the AWOS at the Gillespie County Airpot in Fredericksburg.
Tree was blown down on to the roof of a garage.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that split the trunk of a 30 inch diameter Arizona ash tree in Leon Valley.
A public report indicated a 60 MPH wind gust in Annetta South, TX.
Short-lived tornado was relayed by Zapata County Sheriff's Office.  Tornado occurred over open ranch land.  No damage reported.

Thunderstorm winds associated with a bow echo system gusted to over 58 mph and peaked at 83 mph at the NWS Office on the south side of town.  A 40' by 100' tent that belonged to a traveling ministry was destroyed by the wind.
Golf ball sized hail was reported near FM 67 and CR 1138 to the east of Blum.
Golf ball size hail was reported one mile north of Dalhart.
Trees were blown down near FM 1745.
An emergency manager reported golf ball size hail in Weimar.
Penny to golfball-size hail.
Thunderstorm winds caused roof damage, blew down several trees, and blew over a small travel camper.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet station near Northfield. A gust to 58 mph occurred at 1550 CST.
A thunderstorm moved across Pecos County and produced a 64 mph wind gust in Fort Stockton.
Nickel to golfball size hail fell on U.S. Highway 84, 12 miles northwest of Snyder.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 65 mph that knocked down some three inch tree limbs and damaged a roof in Jonestown.
A thunderstorm produced half dollar size hail in Hondo.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near New Deal measured a wind gust of 70 mph.
Heavy rain occurred in Pecos County and affected Fort Stockton and surrounding areas.  There was minor street flooding that occurred as a result of this heavy rain.

A 800' x 400' steel building that was still under construction was damaged and partially collapsed in microburst winds. Portable toilets on the job site were blown over 100 feet, and an 18-wheeler on I-35 was blown over.
Trees were blown down north of Wills Point due to high winds.
Amateur radio reported that 3 inch diameter tree limbs were blown down near Eagle Mountain Lake.
Member of the public shared two large trees either uprooted or snapped near the base of the tree near the intersection of Del Mar and Russell Avenue. Timing based on radar.
Several trees were downed along with a barn that was blow down and powerlines north of Leesburg between Leesburg and Lake Bob Sandlin.  Several roads were blocked by fallen trees as well.
A 78 MPH wind gust was measured at Dyess Air Force Base at 1212 AM CDT.
Strong winds knocked down powerlines and two trees on FM 2929 near Grant Cemetary Road.
A trained spotter reported quarter-sized hail at PJC in the southeast part of the city of Paris, TX.
Occurred in Southwest Fort Worth.

Large uprooted hardwood tree, metal barn with roof and walls peeled back to the west, along with downed power poles. The estimated maximum wind gust speed is 100 mph. Property damage cost is an estimation.

A severe thunderstorm in Jack County developed a tornado southeast of Jacksboro between Highways US-281 and US-380. The storm also produced two additional areas of straight line wind damage in the county. The tornado started northeast of US-281 in an open field and damaged several low-topped tree limbs. The tornado then crossed over a ridge and onto Dos Equis Ranch Road where it blew a manufactured building off its blocks. The building was secured with up-to-date straps. The tornado then continued northeast before lifting shortly after passing Dos Equis Ranch Road. The tornado was on the ground for approximately 1.8 miles and was 55 yards in width. It was rated an EF-0 with max winds estimated at 80 mph.
Quarter size hail was reported 25 miles south-southwest of Perryton.
Strong thunderstorm winds damaged a Stripes Convenience Store sign.

Discrete thunderstorms developed across Donley County during the afternoon hours of the 8th. As these thunderstorms moved over Howardwick (Donley County), a storm chaser reported an estimated 80 mph thunderstorm downburst which damaged 5 carports. After producing this gusts the storms continued to move to the northeast across the county.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail near Austin Bergstrom International Airport. There was a picture of the hail on social media.
Large hail damaged approximately 1,000 cars and about the same number of homes.
Golf ball sized hail was reported.
Several reports of large hail up to the size of golfballs were received along U.S. Highway 285 north of Pecos.
Tree downed on FM Road 2089 just north of the intersection with FM Road 838 south of Overton.
Trees were downed near the Walnut Street and Travis Street intersection.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near McAdoo measured severe wind gusts from 0750 CST through 0804 CST. A peak wind gust of 76 was measured at 0754 CST.

Hail up to the size of ping-pong balls combined with damaging winds to destroy cotton and watermelon crops, along with one farmer's irrigation system, in far northern Upton county and far southern Midland county.
Measured winds of 67 mph were reported in Thorp Springs with debris blowing around.
Ham radio operator reported thunderstorm wind damage south of Rio Vista near 8932 TX 174. Multiple power poles were downed and a carport roof was blow 20-30 yards from its original location.
Hail ranging from quarter to golfball size fell across the city of Midland.
Freestone County Sheriff's department reported trees down on FM 489.
Trees were blown down by high winds.
A trained spotter reported tennis ball sized hail in the city of Mart, TX.
Several outbuildings and barns sustained damage in the Lone Oak area. Some barns lost their metal roofs.
Severe thunderstorm winds blew down trees and power lines between Weir and Taylor.  Power was out to over 2000 people for several hours.
There were trees and power lines downed in and around Lovelady.
An NWS storm survey team identified a narrow tornado track just north of town, in which trees were uprooted and snapped.
Port Arthur Daily News reported large tree branches blown down in Port Arthur.

This tornado formed four miles west of Boys Ranch at 1751 CST and tracked north northeast. The tornado crossed U.S. Highway 385 at the Oldham and Hartley county line before exiting Oldham county at 1759 CST five miles northwest of Boys Ranch. The tornado continued in Hartley county for about another thirteen miles... before dissipating at 1827 CST. The tornado was rated as EF1 in Hartley county...but was rated as EF0 in Oldham county since it remained over open country. No damage or injuries were reported.
In addition to the hail, a wind gust of 60 mph was estimated.

A 21 year old male was struck by lightning in the community of Simms, Texas.  The man was working on an oil rig when lightning struck the oil derrick.  The man was treated at a local hospital from burns but was released.
Parking lot light pole was blown over in Flour Bluff.
A 59 mph wind gust was measured at Sugar Land Regional Airport.
A large tree was uprooted and fell onto a house and a peach tree.  The house suffered roof and wall damage.  Another tree fell in the town center of Greenville.

This EF-0 tornado touched down in the Home Depot parking lot on the west side of Interstate 45 where damage was done to a portable building.  The tornado crossed the interstate and caused some damage at a car dealership when metal awnings were carried up and over nearby power lines and dropped on two vehicles.  The tornado then lifted back into the clouds around a nearby motel.
There was some damage to a barn on Maggie Lane.

A supercell thunderstorm that developed along a retreating dryline in Deaf Smith and Oldham Counties tracked to the northeast across the southern Texas Panhandle. An off duty National Weather Service employee reported tennis ball size hail 10 miles north of Bootleg (Deaf Smith County). The supercell continued traveling in a northeastern direction which took it out of the county shortly after 10 pm. No injuries were relayed with this report.
Hail was reported at County Line Road.
A large tree fell onto a pickup truck near the Linda Lane and FM 1485 intersection.
Measured by the Texas Tech West Texas Mesonet.
Several reports of hail up to nickel size in Dalhart were received.
Several trees were blown down across the city of Three Rivers. An abandoned building collapsed. The Boys and Girls Club building received roof damage.

A rancher located in rural portions of central Hall County reported severe thunderstorm wind gusts that were intermittently accompanied by large hail around 18:00 CST on the 14th. The winds, estimated to be near 70 mph, broke numerous large tree limbs.
A solar farm near Baileyville suffered damage to some solar panels, and trees were reported down in the same area.
The Bailey volunteer fire department reported ping pong ball sized hail.

A cluster of thunderstorms developed along a stalled frontal boundary during the early morning hours of the 6th. These thunderstorms quickly intensified while moving to the east. As the storms moved east of Bushland (Potter County), the KVII schoolnet site 3 miles was of Bushland (Potter County) reported 58 mph thunderstorm wind gust. After producing this gust the cluster of thunderstorms continued to move across the southern Texas Panhandle.

Large hail ranging in size from pennies to golfballs fell across the north side of Midland. The largest hail was observed in the area along Loop 250 between Midkiff and Midland Drive. No damage was reported.
Ping Pong size hail fell west of Greenwood.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 58 mph which blew the roof off a home in Dale.
The Sheriff's Office in Collingsworth County reported golf ball size hail at the intersection of U.S. Highways 83 and 62 in Childress County. No damage was reported.
Penny sized hail fell at the intersection of Beach Street and Basswood Blvd.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet.
Brief landspout on ground a minute or less, reported by multiple chasers in the area.
Three 12 trees were knocked down along Highway 164 about half a mile west of I-45.
The public reported large tree limbs down south of Hebbronville.
Hail was reported in Lufkin, Texas.
Amateur Radio reported quarter size hail south of Mexia.
A thunderstorm moved across Reeves County and produced a 62 mph wind gust four miles southwest of Pecos.
The awning and marquee of the historic Texas Theater on Waco Street was torn off.  Support cables for the awning were also pulled from the wall.
A trained weather spotter reported golf ball size hail in the town of Cee Vee. No damage was reported.
A trained spotter reported numerous trees down across the City of Cross Plains. Some of the trees fell on cars.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that knocked down some large trees.
Hail larger than golfballs fell in Bogota.
Golfball size hail fell in Glen Rose.

Thunderstorm winds, likely associated with the RFD of a tornadic supercell, knocked down trees in the Vintage subdivision located in the southwestern portions of the city of Denton. Fences were also knocked down.
A funnel cloud was sighted off of FM 2004 heading east towards Hitchcock.
A thunderstorm produced hail from pea to ping pong ball size in Kingsland.
Wind gust of 58 MPH at Schoolnet site at the Brandt Farms.
Law enforcement officials reported golfball size hail on Highway 82.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Graham measured severe wind gusts from 2250 CST through 2254 CST.

While this was a breezy to windy day, the brief gust of 60 mph Texline site stood out to be much higher than any others in the area.  Investigation into this by the West Texas Mesonet team showed pressure changes which suggested this gust was likely due to a large dust devil.
Trees were blown down across roads in Ennis and Waxahachie.
Public reported golf ball size hail.
A photograph posted on social media indicated golf ball sized hail in Leona, TX.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet.
Nickel to quarter sized hail fell near Purtis Creek State Park for 5 minutes.
A tree fell on a home on Hickory Street in De Kalb. Power lines were also downed at this same location.
Golf ball to baseball size hail was reported over a swath of the heavily populated urban center of Mission and McAllen.
A trained spotter reported four to six inch diameter tree limbs down by damaging thunderstorm winds at County Road 300 and FM 765.
Penny to quarter size hail was observed in Wharton and lasted for approximately twenty minutes.

Damage to several homes was reported in Haltom City, including the partial loss of roof decking. Multiple large trees were snapped around 5 feet from the ground, and one tree was uprooted. A damage survey found straight line wind damage consistent with 105 mph winds along Wathall Rd between Field St and 377.
Occurred at Valley Ranch in far north central Irving.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph.

A line of thunderstorms traversed the southern Texas Panhandle during the evening hours of the 13th. As this line neared the town of Hereford (Deaf Smith County), the KVII Schoolnet site in Hereford (Deaf Smith County) reported a 72 mph thunderstorm gust. This line continued moving eastward across the southern Texas Panhandle after producing this gust.
Measured by the Victoria Regional Airport ASOS.  In addition, small tree branches were broken and few power lines pulled downed, but poles not broken, in the city of Victoria.
Billboard signs down.
Golfball sized hail was reported just east of the community of Redwater, Texas.
This report was received from mPing.
Numerous trees and powerlines downed across the entire county.
Late report of hail at one inch.

A lightning strike hit a home in the Chisholm Spring subdivision in Newark.  The lightning strike entered the home through the satellite dish and traveled through the cable, charring the walls and floor around the cable. The charge caused a computer to catch on fire.
The emergency manager reports that two power poles snapped in half. The estimated maximum wind gust speed is 100 mph. The property damage cost is an estimation.

Heavy rainfall began over much of west Texas during the early morning hours of the 15th.  By the time rainfall subsided early on the 17th, 48-hour rainfall record totals between 6 and 8 inches were measured in the vicinity of Caprock Canyons State Park.
