Local law enforcement officials reported a number of rock slides along Texas Highway 256, where the scenic route winds through steep canyon slopes.  No serious damage or injuries were reported.
Trees and power lines blown down by high winds.
Estimated winds of 60 mph with gusts up to 70 mph were reported in Pottsboro. Tree limbs were knocked down.
Quarter sized hail was reported.
The NWS COOP Observer at Spicewood reported large tree limbs down and roof damage to their residence.
Social media video showed major wind damage occurred to a solar panel farm near Cunningham.
A public report indicated that half of a roof was removed and a car port destroyed by thunderstorm winds in the city of Kerens, TX.
Several reports were received of hail in the city of Brownfield ranging in size from ping pongs to 2.25 inches in diameter. No damage was reported.
A thunderstorm produced a wind gust measured at 65 mph by a spotter in Nordheim.
A storm chaser reported half dollar size hail along Farm to Market Road 179 southwest of New Home.

Rainfall amounts of two to three inches fell throughout the morning near Floydada. A few inches of standing water were observed on roadways in and around Floydada, but law enforcement confirmed that all highways were passable throughout the event.

The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site southwest of Wolfforth recorded a 63 mph thunderstorm wind gust at 17:15 CST.  Local authorities reported that the winds downed utility poles and resulted in a prolonged electrical outage for more than 1,500 households.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail near the Del Rio International Airport.
A thunderstorm produced two inch hail southwest of Jarrell.
Roofs were ripped off two houses in Tennessee Colony.
Storm spotters reported hail covering the ground along Highway 652.
Ping pong ball size hail fell about 2 miles south of Alto on Highway 69.
Several trees were downed in Dekalb, Texas.  There was a report of damage to one outbuilding on Hwy. 44.
Rain wrapped tornado is on the ground approximately 4 NW Wellington.
Penny to half dollar size hail hail fell for about 5 minutes. Hail was flat and oblong, with some of the pieces 2 inches long and three quarter inches wide.
A tree was blown down on Quail Lane.

Significant damage occurred at Eagle Mountain Lake Marina. Most of the damage was to the docks, dock roofs, and walkways. Only one boat was lost and a few had scratches and dings. Eight teenagers were trapped during the storm and had to be lead out to safety.
An emergency manager estimated wind gusts to 60 mph in the town of Matador. The strong winds were also accompanied by nickel size hail.
Storm chasers reported penny size hail along U.S. Highway 70 west of Earth.
Measured by Texas Tech Mesonet.
A social media report indicated penny sized hail approximately 1 mile west of University Park.
A public report indicated that a metal roof was blown off of a detached wood-framed workshop in the city of Blue Ridge, TX.
Pea to nickel size hail was reported from just northwest of Andrews to just southwest of the intersection of Texas Highway 176 and Farm to Market Road 1788.
A thunderstorm produced estimated wind gusts of 50 kts which knocked down numerous tree limbs in Leakey near County Road 337 and FM 83.
A thunderstorm produced one inch diameter hail in Johnson City.
Nickel size hail was reported  by amateur radio operators just south of the Brownwood Airport.
The Comanche County-City Airport AWOS measured 50 kts of wind.
Baseball size hail fell just west of the town of Beattie.

This tornado occurred on the northeast side of Spearman. It initially touched down near Brandt Street and Kenneth Avenue(FM 759 760). Here it snapped some tree branches, lifted some carports and caused minor fence damage. It then traveled north along County Road 25, where it snapped a few power poles and this is where it was given its highest rating. As it neared Highway 15, it collapsed an empty grain silo and caused some minor shingle damage to a few roofs along County Road 25. The tornado|turned east, crossing Highway 15 and caused additional minor roof damage and snapped branches to hardwood trees. It finally lifted just to the east of Highway 15. The maximum estimated wind speed was 98mph.
Hail fell over much of the eastern half of Comal County, causing damage to some windows of homes and vehicles
Quarter sized hail was reported by a trained spotter 3 miles north of Sanger, TX.
NWS storm survey estimated 70 mph winds occurred in the community of Driscoll. Many large trees were blown down. Several moderate to poorly constructed homes suffered roof damage.

An EF-2 tornado with maximum estimated winds near 115 mph touched down along County Road 1857 southwest of Rusk, where it snapped numerous trees and bent a power pole about 45-50 degrees above the ground. One home on County Road 2210 had its roof ripped off. The tornado crossed County Road 2211 where it snapped the tops of several trees, before it tracked across an open field before crossing FM 23. Numerous trees were either snapped or uprooted along FM 23, with portions of a metal roof and shingles beneath it ripped off of a home and thrown into a open field behind the home. A nearby metal outbuilding was also lofted and destroyed. The tornado continued northeast across FM 752 an intensified where it snapped additional trees and broke/bent 5 concrete poles and cracked an additional 2 poles. The tornado lifted shortly thereafter just east of FM 752 south of the city of Rusk.

Pea to golfball size hail was reported at a gas plant near the intersection of Farm to Market Road 1492 and Texas Highway 329. The hail fell at the plant for twenty minutes, but no damage was reported. Employees at the gas plant watched a rotating wall cloud produce funnel clouds south of the plant while the hail was falling. A National Weather Service damage survey to the area found no evidence of a tornado.
The County Judge reported five inch diameter tree limbs snapped in town.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Plains measured a peak wind gust to 69 mph.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet station.
A 60 mph wind gust was estimated in Rising Star.
A funnel cloud was spotted just outside the town of Bonney.
Baseball size hail occurred around 12 miles south of Higgins.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail near the intersection of CR 206 and CR 207 in northern Burnet County.
Several trees were downed in Hooks.
Reported along U.S. Highway 385.

A thunderstorm developed over southern Randall County during the mid-morning hours of the 21st. As the thunderstorm moved to the northeast it encountered a strongly sheared environment which toppled the storm structure. The core of the thunderstorm collapsed 1 mile east of the city of Canyon (Randall County) causing a 61 mph downburst. This downburst was measured by a trained storm spotter near the West Texas A&M University Event Center.
The public reported dime to golf ball size hail falling.
Reports of funnels along the McClennan/Hill County line.

A NWS Storm Survey determined an EF-0 tornado began approximately 2.5 miles west-northwest of Rainbow. This tornado had a path length of approximately 0.75 miles and an estimated width of 50 yards. Mostly tree damage occurred with this tornado and winds were estimated at 75-80 mph.
Hail damaged a vehicle's windshield on US Highway 285.
Quarter sized hail reported along Interstate 10 to the west of Columbus.

NWS storm survey identified an 8 and a half mile long path of straight line wind damage extending from Riviera to near Loyola Beach. Peak wind gusts were estimated to be between 70 and 80 mph. Hundreds of large trees were damaged or snapped. A few shingles were missing from the roof of a home in Riviera. Several utility poles were damaged. The scoreboard from the Riviera High School football field and the dugout from the baseball field were destroyed.
Strong winds downed 4 power poles south of San Angelo.
A lightning strike caused significant damage to a home.
The Trinity River Authority measured this severe wind gust at the Lake Livingston Dam.
A trained spotter estimated winds up to 67 mph, approximately three miles north of Waxahachie.

A rope-shaped tornado was witnessed by several people north of Smyer just before 11:00 CST. The tornado reportedly remained in open fields near the Spade Ranch north of Texas Highway 114, and generally west of Farm to Market Road 168. Although the tornado may have actually crossed Farm to Market Road 168 before it dissipated, no damage was reported.
There was wind damage to a home on Gamewood Drive.
Hen egg size hail was reported on FM Road 1636, halfway between Anson and Stamford. The time was estimated by radar.
The Wolfforth Fire Department reported that pea to nickel size hail covered the ground south of the city.
Quarter sized hail was reported.
A thunderstorm moved across Crane County and produced a 64 mph wind gust one mile north northwest of Crane at the Mesonet site.
Baseball size hail was reported northwest of Roscoe in northwestern Nolan County.
Hail stones slightly larger than 1 in diameter were reported west of Collinsville in Cooke County.
Dime sized hail reported via mPing.
Dime sized hail was reported in Frisco.
A 64 mph wind gust was measured at the Center Municipal Airport from a shower that moved over the airport.
East side of old airport terminal collapsedboth airport doors blown out due to microburst winds.
Spotter is at highway 15 and FM 2387 just west of Spearman.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet station.
Thunderstorms produced wind gusts estimated at just under 60 mph in The Woodlands.
Quarter to golfball size hail occurred at Axtell.
Several trees were snapped or blown down along FM 1005 near the|intersection with US Hwy 96. The peak winds in the tornado was estimated at 105 MPH. The path was 0.4 mile long and 25 yards wide.
Hail was reported near Highway 210.
Report of 1 inch hail from mPING.
A fireworks stand was blown over with two people inside.

An EF-1 tornado with maximum estimated winds around 105 mph developed within a squall line of thunderstorms that produced sporadic straight line wind damage mainly to trees across Northern Harrison County. The tornado touched down a few miles west of Highway 59 on FM 1997, tracking east across County Road 4000 where several trees were snapped and uprooted.  As the tornado crossed Highway 59 along the north side of Suburban Acres Road, numerous hardwood trees were snapped with a few homes receiving roof damage due to trees or large limbs falling on the structures. The tornado continued to uproot and snap several more trees before crossing County Road 2012, and lifting shortly thereafter.

New damage reports received from Milam County Emergency Management confirmed a tornado occurred near the city of South Elm in northwest Milam County. The tornado likely developed in an open field between CR 116 and FM 1915. It then snapped two wooden electrical transmission line poles near FM 1915. As the tornado continued northeast, it snapped a tree in half and severely damaged the roof of a barn, ripping most of the aluminum roof structure off the walls. It crossed FM 1915 one more time, blew out the walls of a barn and tore off a significant amount of shingles from the roof of a home. The damage is consistent with an EF1 tornado with max winds of 110 mph.
Tree damage was reported in and around Comanche. Some business signs and carports were also damaged.
Dime to penny-size hail was reported east of Bardwell.

Scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms throughout the day produced rain-slicked roads across the area. According to the Texas Department of Public Service in McLennan County, 13 minor accidents were reported along I-35 in the county. Five people were transported to the hospital with minor injuries.
A pulse severe thunderstorm produced strong winds that downed a couple of trees.
Quarter size hail fell in the Central Heights Community.
Several trees were reported downed on Highway 356, Highway 19, and Highway 287. Roofs were reported blown off of houses in Trinity.
Knox City (KNOX) Mesonet observation.
No damage reported.
A second severe storm produced penny size hail in southeastern Swisher County near the intersection of Texas Highway 86 and Farm to Market Road 2301.
Spotter reported estimated wind gust of 70 mph 3 miles E of Murchison.
First wind gust was at 1749CDT was 60 mph.  The max  wind gust of 61 mph occurred at 1751CDT.  Severe wind gusts persisted for 6 minutes from 1749  through 1755CDT.
The public reported half dollar size hail.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail east of Leon Valley.
A public report indicated quarter sized hail 3 miles southwest of Haslet, TX.
Dime size hail at Veterans Memorial Drive and Beltway 8.
Quarter size hail was reported along County Road 535 southwest of the city of Smithville.
Thunderstorm winds were estimated to be near 60 MPH. Power outages were also reported.
The report was from mping.
A 10-year-old girl was struck by lightning on Landfill Road in Holland while playing under a tree. She was hospitalized for several days.
Power lines were blown down in the Santa Ana area.
Quarter size hail covered the ground east of Wills Point.
This tornado touched down in an open cotton field in the outer rainbands of Hurricane Dolly.  No damage was reported.  This tornado moved northeast to southwest.
Hen egg sized hail reported just north of the Texas A&M campus.
Late report over Facebook of golf ball size hail with time estimated from radar.

An amateur radio operator measured a 62 mph wind gust at Camp James Ray boy scout camp in northwestern Grayson County. Tree damage was reported near the camp with 21 trees knocked down. The trees averaged 4-6 inches in diameter, but one post oak was 7 in diameter. Hail up to the size of dimes was also reported.

Straight line winds from a severe thunderstorm resulted in damage across the west side of Beeville.  A 4 by 8 section of a one story apartment on West Fannin St. was blown off by the winds.  There was damage to large tree limbs in the area and a large hackberry tree was blown down, damaging three vehicles.
Lightning struck an oil tank farm south of Saint Jo.  Three tanks exploded from the lightning strike and the resulting fire.
There was half dollar to ping pong ball size hail falling.
The West Texas Mesonet site near O' Donnell recorded a severe thunderstorm wind gust of 61 MPH. The winds were accompanied by blowing dust that restricted visibilities to near zero.
Emergency management in Hockley County reported that a power pole was blown over at the intersection of Mexico Road and US Highway 385 just south of Whitharral.
The public reported numerous large pecan tree limbs down along with a flag pole that was bent a few feet above the ground.
Emergency management reported a tree blown onto a home in the city of Point, TX.

This tornado started near highway 67 southwest of Ballinger and moved to the east southeast. The tornado lifted just to the southe of Bruce Field airport. Damage was limited to mainly tin roofs and trees. However a tractor trailer was overturned and two hangers at the airport were damaged as well. The tornado also killed some livestock as well.
Hail slightly larger than golf balls was reported one mile southwest of Gruver.
Nickel to quarter sized hail fell northeast of Knott.
A public report indicated half-dollar sized hail in South McKinney.
The time estimated from  radar.
Reported via mPing.
There was minor roof damage and windows blown out of a residence due to high winds. The shed next to the residence was destroyed.
A public report was received of tennis ball size hail north of Littlefield near the intersection of Farm to Market Road 2197 and US Highway 385. No damage was reported.
No damage reported. 60 to 70 mph winds estimated.
Hail up to quarter size fell along County Road X.
A storm chaser measured 65 mph thunderstorm wind gusts.
Several trees were blown down in Whitehouse.

The Fire Chief for Weslaco called and reported several business signs either damaged or blown down along Business 83. The largest sign blown down was an 8 foot tall Long John Silvers sign. An NWS Survey found there to be rust at the bottom of the sign, which kept wind estimates from being higher.
Measured by the Childress ASOS.
The Yoakum County Sheriff's Office reported a tornado over open country.
Golf ball to baseball size hail damaged skylights of a residence.
The Travis County Emergency Manager reported numerous trees blown down and blocking the intersection of Bluff Bend Dr. and Newport Ave.
Part of a roof was blown off of a building. Multiple 55-gallon drums were blown down the street and some tree limbs were broken around town in Higgins.
Quarter sized hail was reported near the intersections of Anderson County roads 2304 and 2311.
There were 20 to 25 trees blown down.
Golfball size hail was reported in town by law enforcement officials.

Frisco Fire Department determined that a house fire was caused by lightning from a Thursday evening thunderstorm. The fire rendered the building unsafe and generated approximately 400,000 dollars in damage.
The tornado path length and width were estimated.  The tornado remained over open country.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 52 kts.
A report of dime size hail was received from mPING.
Ping pong ball size hail reported along Highway 271 northeast of Tyler.
A thunderstorm produced half dollar size hail south of Liberty Hill.
Fire and Rescue reported trees and power lines down in Loving, TX.
No damage information was available.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail in Nameless southwest of Leander.
Video from the public shows the metal roof of a carport peeled back near the intersection of Mile 3 Road and Tom Gill Road. Time estimated by radar.
Trees were blown down along Highway 94 near the Hudson community.
Quarter size hail was reported 2 miles east of Canyon.
Trained spotters reported quarter sized hail on Interstate 35 in the city of Denton.
Hail fell just south of the Harrison County Airport along Hwy. 31 just north of Interstate 20.

Public shared a photo of a landspout tornado about 5 miles south of the Corpus Christi International Airport near Farm to Market Road 43 and County Road 53. There was no damage as the tornado remained over farm land.
A thunderstorm moved across Dawson County and produced a 61 mph wind gust two miles southeast of Lamesa.
Golfball size hail was reported along FM 490 near Faysville.
Pictures posted to social media showed hail around the size of golf ball in Kountze.
Hail ranging from the size of dimes to ping pong balls was reported in the city of Fort Davis.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that knocked down a large tree.
A lightning strike ignited a fire in a church along FM 518 in League City, causing damage to the building.
A severe thunderstorm produced quarter size hail at the intersection of Interstate 10 and the East Beltway 8 Loop.
Hen egg size hail was reported on the Allison Ranch just off of U.S. Highway 385 in southern Pecos County. No damage was reported.
Penny size hail was observed in Grapeland.
A thunderstorm moved through Odessa and the public reported a wind gust measurement of 72 mph.
A billboard was downed.
Ping pong ball sized hail was reported at Coit Rd and Spring Creek Pkwy in Plano.
A small tree was blown down on Highway 84 just west of FM 225.
Softball sized hail was reported.
Reported on the Midland and Upton County Line.

A very brief EF0 tornado partially removed a roof off a home on Bowspirit Lane in northeast Fort Worth. Several wood fences were also damaged in the subdivision. The maximum estimated winds were 75 mph.
Reported by Gorman Police Department along CR 575.
Observer measured 5.15 inches of rainfall.
Reported on Highway 208.

A line of thunderstorms developed in response to a cold front moving through the southeastern Texas Panhandle during the late evening hours of the 11th. As the line moved toward the town of Hedley (Donley County), a trained spotter reported penny size hail (0.75 inch). After producing this hail the line continued to slowly move to the east.
Emergency management reported that a 30 by 40 foot barn and several small cow shelters were damaged by thunderstorm winds near Campbell, TX.
The Park Service reported quarter size hail at Fort Lancaster State Historical Site.
Trees were knocked down in the western portion of the county.
An automated weather observation station at the Brady Municipal Airport measured a 63 mph wind gust.
Skywarn spotters reported pea to nickel size hail just south of Littlefield just before 16:15 CST.
A second brief tornado was observed by storm spotters in rural areas northwest of Brownfield. No damage was reported.
Hail fell on U.S. Hwy 259.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet near Dimmitt.
Damage to several smaller shed structures with significant damage to one large shed-barn structure. Minor damage to a local ball park's grandstand metal roofing.
Trees were downed just south of Pineland.
A social media report indicated 2-inch diameter hail in the city of Mesquite, TX.
A trained spotter reported hail estimated to be nickel to quarter size in Bishop Hills.
A trained spotter estimated the winds were gusting near 75 mph.  Since there were a limited number of structures and trees near the area, no damage was reported.

The roof was blown off 2-story condominium complex on Runaway Bay Drive in Runaway Bay. All of the units in the complex were damaged or destroyed. Also, a tree fell on a house on Lakeview Drive, and the house was significantly damaged. A man at the condo complex was slightly injured and treated at the scene.
Trees were blown down on FM 999 just east of County Road 420.
A mesonet station reported a 66 mph wind gust northwest of Haskell.
Ping pong ball size hail fell near the Brachfield community.
Knox City (KNOX) Mesonet observation.
Quarter sized hail was reported near Preston Road and Park Blvd in Plano.
Tree limbs with a diameter between 6 and 8 inches were blown down in Montague.
A social media report indicated quarter-sized hail on Club Lake Road in the city of Nocona, TX.
Law enforcement reported quarter size hail in the city of Plains.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 65 mph that damaged a carport and barn roof on the westside of Bastrop. The carport was ripped from the building.
A trained spotter reported quarter sized hail near the intersection of Highway 287 and Lone Star Rd in northeast Johnson County.
A trained spotter 5 miles east of Andice reported nickel size hail.
Around 80 power poles snapped near the base at this location.
Measured by the Texas Tech/West Texas mesonet station.
Lightning struck a tree, causing the tree to split and fall on a car.
The Throckmorton Sheriff Office reported hen egg size hail just northeast of Throckmorton.

The tornado developed just north of County Road Z and just east of State Highway 23 or about nineteen miles south of Booker at 2140 CST. The tornado traveled north northeast causing damage to trees...power poles...barns...and full oil drums. The tornado was confirmed by photographs. The tornado dissipated about twelve miles west of Lipscomb or north of Farm to Market Road 3260 and east of State Highway 23. No injuries were reported.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail on the east side of Georgetown.
Nickel size hail at FM 528 and Bay Area Blvd.
A thunderstorm moved across Martin County and produced a 61 mph wind gust near Tarzan.
Wind gust occurred at KHOU.
A large tree fell across County Road 2320.
Report from mPING: Quarter (1.00 in.).
Golfball sized hail was reported 4 miles west of Keller.
Penny sized hail was reported between Buffalo and Donie.

As the line of thunderstorms associated with the late season cold front moved southward into Fayette County, they produced severe winds that knocked down numerous trees, blew over signs along the road,  and damaged roofs of homes and businesses across central Fayette County from north to south.  Some parts of the county were without power until the following afternoon.
The Deaf Smith County Emergency Manager reported that thunderstorm wind gusts had blown down some power poles west of Hereford.
DPS Reported half-dollar sized (1.25) hail at intersection if I-37 and FM 99, near Whitsett.
Hail with a diameter of 2 inches was reported by the Roma City Police Department.
Reported at the intersection of Highways 1213 and 349.
Emergency manager reported quarter size hail.
A trained spotter estimated a 60 mph wind gust in Rio Vista.
Amateur radio operator reported 0.75 inch hail Stonebrook.
A thunderstorm moved across Mitchell County and produced wind damage in Colorado City.  The roof was blown off of the Wallace school in Colorado City.  The cost of damage is a rough estimate.

A severe thunderstorm moved across Andrews County and produced a tornado about an eighth of a mile east of Frankle City, TX.  A National Weather Service employee spotted the damage at about 9:30 PM CDT.  The damage consisted of one power pole bent at a 60 degree angle to the south of FM1967 with power lines about ten feet above the road.  A power pole to the north of the first one was snapped, and another power pole was bent slightly.  Based on radar data, the circulation was over the affected area around 8:58 PM CDT, and the tornado was rated an EF-1 based on the damage reported.  Since no other damage was reported, the path length and time were an estimate.
Roof damage to local businesses.
Softball sized hail was reported east of Tennessee Colony.
A public report included pictures of a 3-inch diameter hailstone 10 miles northeast of Palestine. Two other hailstones in the photo appeared to be golf ball sized.
The fire department in Grassland reported hail up to baseball size south of town.
Twenty-one windows were broken at Seguin High School in Arlington. One student needed stitches. Three vehicles also had back windows broken out.
Motorists encountered half dollar sized hail about 2 miles west of the U.S. Border Patrol check point.
Golfball size hail was reported 3 miles west of Hillsboro.
Law enforcement officials reported a (landspout) tornado just east of town.  The tornado remained nearly stationary over open country.
A thunderstorm produced 2.5 inch hail that broke a sky light in a house.

A tornado touched down just west of Liverpool. It took down 4 power poles on highway 35 along with several trees near the Gulf Coast Speedway. The tornado then traveled across generally open field before damaging some barns and outbuildings as well as trees on County Road 511.
Reported on Highway 349.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Northfield measured a wind gust to 82 mph. Additionally, an NWS cooperative weather observer near Northfield reported several trees blown down.
A 67 mph wind gust was measured at the Automated Weather Observing Station located at the Borger Airport.

A line of thunderstorms developed in response to a cold front moving through the southeastern Texas Panhandle during the late evening hours of the 11th. As the line moved over the town of Clarendon (Donley County), a law enforcement official reported quarter size hail (1.00 inch). After producing this hail the line continued to slowly move to the east.
Funnel cloud sighted as thunderstorms began to develop.
Short damage path near William Penn Rd. Numerous trees downed, few uprooted,  in convergent pattern along path.
Social Media reported half dollar size hail in Chandler.
Reported via mPing.
A spotter reported trees and power lines down onto Concord Street Vidor.
Half dollar size hail fell just southeast of Mount Pleasant. Report from mPING.
Strong thunderstorm wind blew down power lines in town.
Trees down along two mile stretch north of Dayton along route 321.
Hail report was received via mPing.
Late report of 70 mph wind gust that lasted a few minutes.
A thunderstorm produced half dollar size hail in the North Oaks area of Austin.
Reported by NWS employee at Weber and Saratoga.
Quarter size hail fell at the intersection of East Loop 281 and Alpine Road in Northeast Longview.
Quarter to golfball sized hail was reported 10 miles north-northeast of Weatherford.
Quarter to golf ball sized hail was reported near Whitehouse, Texas.
Trained spotters observed and photographed a brief tornado near the south shore of Lake Fork.
Several large trees were blown down in Mineral Wells. Most of the residents in the southeast area of town lost power.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Smyer measured a peak wind gust of 71 mph at 2245 CST. Severe winds were measured from 2242 through 2252 CST.

A National Weather Service damage survey crew found evidence of a tornado south and west of the city of Rio Vista. This tornado moved northeast to southwest, in a semicircular pattern. The damage from this tornado was mainly to trees and a few power lines. The tornado did impact an uncompleted housing development, damaging three homes. The damage to homes was limited to roof and shingle damage, only producing the EF-0 rating.
Emergency Manager reported ping[pong ball size hail.

A thunderstorm produced wind damage in Odessa, TX. There were multiple buildings with tin roof damage south of Business 20 near Dixie Boulevard. Wind speeds were estimated to be 85 mph based on the wind damage. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Nickel to quarter size hail was reported in Lajitas.A pair of severe thunderstorms propagated northward and crossed the Rio Grande during the afternoon of the 9th. These storms produced large hail in southern Brewster County.
Public reported half dollar size hail.
Tree downed in Appleby.
Several power lines blown down.
Quarter to half dollar sized hail was reported in Whitesboro.
The ASOS at KDFW reported a 58 mph wind gust.
The COOP Observer located 5 miles north of Granbury estimated 70-80 mph wind gusts.
The Sheffield Fire Department reported skylight windows were knocked out due to quarter sized hail on the western side of town.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail in northern Burnet County.
Trees were downed along Hwy 59 north of Jefferson, Texas.
Tennis ball size hail fell 1 miles east of Panhandle.
Hail was observed along US 285.
Public reported nickel to quarter size hail. The time was estimated by radar.
Power lines were blown down.
Numerous large tree limbs snapped around a farmhouse complex. One large tree was uprooted landing on pickup temporarily trapping a resident inside. Half of metal barn collapsed.
Trees were downed by strong thunderstorm winds on Calendar Lake Dr.
A thunderstorm produced pea to quarter size hail in Horseshoe Bay for five minutes.
Public reports indicated numerous trees down and homes/roofs damaged in Haltom City.
Hail ranging from golfball to baseball size reported by the public southwest of Dalhart. Property damage from the hail and wind was reported as well.
Numerous trees down across the southwest portion of the county.
Tornado sighted near the Alabama-Coushatta Reservation.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that collapsed a roof that was under construction at a rodeo venue north of Camp Verde.
The automated weather station at the Sherman-Denison Airport (KGYI) measured a 63 mph thunderstorm wind gust.
Ping pong to tennis ball size hail was reported in Waxahachie.
A tree was blown down across a road 3 miles east of Celina.
A large pecan tree was split at the intersection of Avenue H and Pecan Street.
Trees were downed near the intersection of FM 389 and Sawmill Road.
Nickel to quarter size hail was reported in Kermit.
Multiple trees were downed along FM 1004. A barn also partially lost its roof.
Trees were downed on 31st Street in Texarkana.
Quarter size hail fell a few miles north of the Bettie community.
A tree fell on a house in Canutillo.
Law Enforcement reported quarter size hail, 4 miles south of Eden.
The public measured larger than 3 inch diameter hail 5 miles west-northwest of Katemcy.
An 18 Wheeler was knocked onto its side on Interstate 30 between FM 1570 and HWY 34.
Several funnel clouds were spotted out of thunderstorms in Uvalde County.
A picture was posted to social media of half dollar size hail that fell in the Johnson Creek area on Lake O' the Pines.
A thunderstorm produced hail from pea size to one inch for five minutes.
A heatburst associated with dissipating convection occurred in Young County. The fire department in Graham estimated 60 MPH winds with the heatburst. No damage was reported.
Penny size hail fell in Star.

Hill County Emergency Management and storm spotters reported a brief tornado southeast of the community of Hubbard.  This tornado occurred over open country and was only briefly on the ground and produced no damage. The tornado was rated EF-0, producing winds around 70 mph.
Local law enforcement officials reported nickel size hail along U.S. Highway 287 just northwest of Childress.
Sixty-five MPH winds were estimated between Richardson and Addison.
Insurance companies reported 19 auto claims and 112 house claims for window and roof damage caused by hail.  Most of the damage was reported in the communities of Telephone and Monkstown.
There was a report received from a HAM Operator of 1 inch hail.  The hail lasted for ten minutes at this location.
Penny sized hail fell 1 mile southeast of Eagle Mountain.
Emergency management reported a tree down and structure damage to a car wash near the intersection of Polo Road and Robinson Road in Grand Prairie, TX.
Golf ball sized hail reported on CR 1517 between Jacksonville and Gallatin, Texas.
There was some roof damage in and around the Bryan area.
A Trained Spotter reported golf ball to tennis ball size hail 6 miles north-northwest of Blanket.
A contract weather observer at Lubbock Preston Smith International Airport reported ping pong ball size hail.
A public report indicated considerable wind damage around the FM 917 and FM 2738 area near Lillian. Several trees were blown down, sheds damaged, and an RV was turned on its side.
Emergency manager reported golf ball size hail north of Tilden on TX-16.
Observer reported 60 to 70 mph wind gusts. No damage was reported.
The public reported golf ball size hail in Blanket.
Storm Spotter reported quarter size hail south of Stephenville, TX.

A supercell thunderstorm that developed along a retreating dryline in Deaf Smith and Oldham Counties tracked to the northeast across the southern Texas Panhandle. A trained storm spotter reported half dollar size hail 7 miles west of Simms (Deaf Smith County). The hail accumulated up to 2 inches deep in some spots. The supercell continued traveling in a northeastern direction which took it out of the county shortly after 10 pm. No injuries were relayed with this report.
A roof was blown off a house.
A dry microburst occurred at the El Paso International Airport.
Power poles downed across southern portions of Franklin County.
Public reported nickel sized hail in Mirando City.
The weather station at the Angleton Police Department had sustained winds of 53 mph with gusts to 75 mph.
Late report of quarter size hail with 61 mph measured wind gust.
Large tree limbs were downed by thunderstorm winds.
Tree blown over.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 58 mph which blew down several trees near McMahan.
Ping pong ball size hail fell in the Lilbert community.
No damage reported.
Sixty MPH winds were estimated at Longhorn Rd and North Main Street in Saginaw. A basketball goal was knocked over in town.
A thunderstorm moved over Reeves County and produced a 71 mph wind gust two miles southwest of Pecos.
Penny sized hail was reported in Weimar.
The Jasper County Sheriff's Department reported hail in Kirbyville.
Trees were downed on Hwy 7 near the community of Aiken, Texas.

Lightning struck a transmission and distributing line near the intersection of F.M. 2143 and Highway 172.  Eight spans of primary wire were destroyed along with insulators.  Puncture holes in the cooling fans also occurred.  Power was knocked out to the Olivia and Port Alto communities.
Strong thunderstorm wind destroyed a railroad crossing arm and shattered the windows out of a car.
A thunderstorm produced a 58 mph wind gust near Big Lake.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail in Uhland.
A cattle truck was reported blown over.
Tornado was associated with Tropical Depression Fay.  No damage reported.
A power pole was downed across Hwy. 11 just west of Pittsburg, Texas.

The tornado touched down three miles south of Goodnight in Armstrong County at 1620 CST and then lifted at 1643 CST eight miles northeast of Goodnight. The tornado was on the ground for approximately eleven miles with a maximum path width of one hundred yards. Two power poles were reported broken just southwest of Goodnight along with considerable damage to barbed wire fencing.
Nickel sized hail was reported by a CoCoRAHS observer approximately 2.5 miles northwest of Godley.
Measured by the Texas Tech West Texas Mesonet.
TCOON site at Port O'Connor measured a gust to 63 mph.
Occurred at the dam.
Emergency management reported an overturned 18-wheeler on Interstate 45 southbound near Overton Road.
The Bear Creek Apartment complex in Euless was damaged.
Power poles, trees, and fences blown down in Oak Leaf.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail in Paige.
A RAWS observation site measured a wind gust of 69 mph, 4 miles west-northwest of Stacy.
Penny-size hail.

Trained spotters observed one tornado touch down briefly around 1723 CST about five miles east of Wolf Creek Park. This tornado lifted back up less than a minute later.  There were additional tornadoes that briefly touched down as witnessed by dust and grass being lifted up around the circulation.  The tornadoes were located in open country with the last tornado lifting at 1729 CST.  The trained spotter was located about two miles from the tornadoes. The path length of the tornadoes was around a quarter of a mile with a width of around fifty yards.
Strong thunderstorms in the City of Brownwood produced a thunderstorm microburst that knocked down power lines and some trees in the city.
A tree was downed on a poweline on CR 552 south of Woden, Texas.
No damage was reported.
A tree was blown down onto Highway 92 near Dam B.
A thunderstorm produced three inch diameter hail on Heather Dr. in Round Rock.
Homes in the Coryell City area were damaged due to thunderstorm winds.
Trained spotters reported quarter sized hail in Seagoville.
The general public estimated wind gusts of fifty-two knots six miles south of Hedley.
One mobile home destroyed.
A tree was downed on FM 1987.
The public reported penny size hail falling at a gas station along Interstate 10 for fifteen minutes.
18 inch diameter tree snapped in half at 4416 Fairmont Parkway.
As the thunderstorms moved through Canyon, downdrafts produced by the storms blew power lines onto the intersection of 15th Street and the railroad tracks.
Large hail reported on the east side of Lake Palo Pinto.
Strong winds from a thunderstorm caused tree and structure damage near the Lost Valley Golf Course.
Large trees were blown down by high winds.
Numerous power outages occurred after trees and power lines were downed during a storm.
A few trees were reported downed at several locations across the county.
A tree was blown down near Hooks.
A member of the broadcast media reported building damage near the intersection of Interstate 35 and Teasley Dr in Hickory Creek.

A third round of destructive hail struck Levelland this night.  Golf ball size hail was reported by an amateur radio operator, although the extent of additional hail damage following the previous rounds of storms was unknown.
Trees down on Highway 71 near Talco.
Nickel-size hail was reported at the Crawford Ranch.
Hail was observed at the intersection of Kell Boulevard and Fairway Boulevard.
Public reported 2 inch hail in Chicota.
A large tree was uprooted and knocked down powerlines in Walnut Springs.
Trees were downed from Whitehouse to Chaper Hill.
Quarter size hail was reported northeast of Mount Vernon, Texas.
Multiple trees were downed by strong wind gusts across the Creek Ranch Area of Fort Bend County.
A trained spotter reported half dollar sized hail along Interstate 45 near the Buc-ees in Ennis, TX.
Multiple reports of trees down on power lines across the City of Sherman.

Trained spotters observed a tornado outside of Eliasville. This was the second of two tornadoes this day. This tornado was very narrow, but produced EF-1 damage to a home. This tornado moved from the northeast to the southwest.
Penny size hail accumulated to a depth of two inches in Hacienda Del Norte Estates of the Montana Vista area.
An off-duty National Weather Service employee located ten miles east of Amarillo estimated fifty-six knot thunderstorm wind gusts.
A tree was snapped off at the top and damaged the nearby roof of a building in South Lufkin. Other large limbs were downed in the area as well.
Reported by DPS Trooper at mile marker 18 on Interstate 35.
I-45 and FM 1960 (Enchanted Oaks Subdivision).
Member of the public reported quarter (1.0) sized hail in the Alton area.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near McAdoo measured a severe wind gust of 65 mph.
A classic supercell thunderstorm moved northeastward across Angelina County, TX into Nacogdoches County, TX producing a strong tornado.  Damage was confined to uprooted and snapped trees.
An EF-1 tornado with estimated winds between 95-105 mph touched down in a wooded area southwest of the Reklaw community, and moved northeast through a cluster of new chicken coops before lifting.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that snapped some large tree limbs in Kirby.
Power line/poles downed.

A cluster of thunderstorms developed along a stalled frontal boundary during the early morning hours of the 6th. These thunderstorms quickly intensified while moving to the east. As the storms neared the city of Amarillo (Randall County), the local broadcast media reported golf ball size hail (1.75 inches) in the Sleepy Hollow neighborhood on the southwest side of town (Randall County). After producing this hail the cluster of thunderstorms continued to move across the southern Texas Panhandle.
The high wind gust was measured at the Amarillo ASOS station located at Rick Husband International Airport.
Report from mPING: Dime (0.75 in.).
A storm spotter reported a brief tornado about 4 miles south of Lake Sweetwater.

Nickel to quarter sized hail was reported by the public around 9:25PM CDT a little over 2 miles southwest of Hebbronville along Texas Highway 16 near the intersection of Farm to Market 3073. Additional reports of penny to quarter sized hail were reported by the public from the same storm in and around the town of Hebbronville between 9:30PM CDT and 9:50PM CDT.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Morton measured a wind gust to 62 mph.
Reported via mPing.
Golf ball size hail fell across the extreme northern portions of San Angelo.

Widespread wind damage was reported at Lake Colorado City. Several trailer homes were overturned or experienced roof damage.   A 25-foot tree was toppled and others were stripped of their leaves.  Another resident reported that a tire was blown from the roof of their carport and loosened gutters at a neighbor's house.

The tornado touched down near Cunningham Middle School just north of Golihar Road where trees were snapped and uprooted. A residence just north of the school at the corner of Hudson and Stafford Streets sustained moderate roof damage and a had a fence blown down. The tornado continued to the northeast crossing Horne Road and parallel to Sarita Street. Dozens of trees were snapped and uprooted with many falling on homes or vehicles. Several residences suffered roof and siding damage in this area. Further northeast, the tornado hit a grocery store on Tarlton Street destroying a sign and blowing several windows out. Tree and minor roof damaged was observed northeast of this area as the tornado crossed Baldwin and Morgan Avenues. The last evidence of the tornado was at 16th Street and Crosstown Expressway where a nursery sustained damage and a baseball dugout was destroyed. Maximum winds were estimated around 90 mph.
Ping pong ball sized hail was reported 5 miles north of Rising Star.
Large hail was reported by a CO-OP observer.
Thunderstorm winds downed a tree along FM 1488 near Oak Hollow Blvd.
The Terry County emergency manager reported golfball size hail in Meadow. Some farmers reported having to replant cotton due to hail damage.
A 60 mph wind gust was estimated in Breckenridge.
A trained spotter reported half dollar hail at I-20 and FM 740 in Forney.
The utility company reported large tree limbs down on powerlines.
Multiple trees were blown down and some onto homes and power lines near Vidor. The microburst also downed some fencing in the area.
The public reported hail along County Road 4581.
The family of a National Weather Service employee saw a brief funnel cloud that extended half way to the ground.
A report of 2.5 inch hail two miles north of Keller was received via social media.

More than three inches of rain fell in a two hour period across southern Cameron County. The ASOS at Brownsville/South Padre Island International Airport measured 3.08 inches and a CoCoRaHS site measured 3.35 inches of rain. Nuisance urban flooding of poor drainage locations in downtown and along Boca Chica Boulevard occurred during the time of the heaviest rainfall.
Golf ball sized hail caused roof damage to a local Apple Springs business.
A storm survey revealed that a tornado with winds between 65 and 85 mph caused damage to storage buildings, a marina, trees, and other vegetation along the southeast side of Brady Lake.
Public reported golf ball size hail.
A 62 mph wind gust was reported by the media at McDonald Observatory.  No damage was reported.
Social media video of hail with videographer, estimating quarter size hail near Freer high school. Time estimated by radar.

Ping pong ball sized hail fell three quarters of a mile north of Highway 380 and Paloma Creek Blvd.  This location is approximately 4 miles northeast of Little Elm. The hail damaged numerous roofs and vehicles in the Little Elm and surrounding area.

A bow echo moved across Potter County during the late night hours of the 18th. As this line moved over the city of Amarillo (Potter County), a member of the public reported penny size hail (0.75 inch) in the city. The bow echo continued moving east across the Panhandle after producing this hail.
Nickel sized hail was reported in Neches.
Several trees were downed near the Wildwood Circle and Briarwood Dr area. Two homes sustained exterior damage, and one of the homes hat its roof partially peeled off.
Storm spotters estimated thunderstorm winds of 60 mph in Newcastle.
Hail covered the ground.
Broadcast media reported nickel to quarter size hail.
Several large trees down.
Sixty mph winds were estimated west of McKinney.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet station.
The emergency manager for Memphis reported hail up to two inches in diameter. No damage was reported.
A tree was blown down along Highway 80 near the Longview City limits.
Trees were blown down on Barber Road.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 75 mph that snapped and uprooted trees in Camp Verde.
Two inch diameter hail was reported in Borger.
Strong thunderstorm wind gusts downed a gas station awning as well as several trees in the College Station area.

The National Weather Service conducted a storm survey in Wood County, Texas and concluded that storm damage was the result of an EF0 tornado. The tornado touched down at around 2:31 AM CDT, about five miles north-northwest of Mineola, along County Road 4919, where it uprooted several large trees. The tornado proceeded east, causing damage to several trees along County Road 4925. Several homes sustained damage east of Lake Fork Texas due to falling trees.  The tornado then uprooted a tree along County Road 4930, and lifted soon after. Maximum winds are estimated at 75-85 mph.
Ping Pong size hail was reported in Nocona.
Golf ball sized hail was reported in Senate, which is approximately 8 miles west-southwest of Jacksboro on Highway 380.
Strong thunderstorm wind damaged roofs in town and blew down trees and power poles.
Heavy rainfall of 2 to 3 inches led to excessive runoff across US 83. Zapata County Sheriff's Deputy reported 3 to 4 inches of water over US 83 along the Zapata Webb County line.

A cyclic tornadic supercell produced several tornadoes over a period of approximately two hours. An NWS storm survey revealed that this supercell produced nine separate tornadoes. This tornado was the second tornado. The instantaneous width and center of the tornado was estimated from TTU-Kal radar data. Extensive photo and video evidence existed of a wide, dusty, wedge tornado with numerous sub-vortices present at times. Maximum winds were estimated at 120 mph. This tornado continued into Bailey County.
A thunderstorm produced one inch hail near Sandy Oaks.
Several tree limbs and trees were damaged by thunderstorm winds in the western part of Navarro County. Some barns and outbuildings were also damaged.
Trees downed on Highway 92 along the west side of BA Steinhagen Lake.
Penny sized hail was reported 12 miles south of Saint Jo.
A thunderstorm moved across Culberson County and produced two inch hail along Ranch Road 652. Over 20 vehicles were damaged along this road. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
A roof was blown off a camp house.
Severe thunderstorm winds blew the roof off of a well house in Odessa.
Public reported several large tree limbs were blown down in that area.
The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site in Muleshoe sampled a 59 mph wind gust. In addition, numerous utility poles, power lines, and trees were reported downed near and south of town.

Broadcast media relayed a photo of hail estimated to be the size of at least golf balls near Spade.  No damage information was available.  At one point, reliable multi-radar hail algorithms estimated that hail approached tennis ball size in southeast Lamb County.
One inch in diameter hail reported near Burkeville.

A thunderstorm produced a tornado about two miles east of Arvana. There were multiple reports of a funnel cloud with rotating dust underneath it for three to five minutes. The tornado remained over open fields with no damage reported. The tornado was rated as an EF-0.
A picture posted to social media showed a golf ball size hail stone.
A brief funnel cloud was sighted at Highway 60 just south of Highway 521.

A powerful microburst struck about 5 miles northeast of Grape Creek and produced one injury and extensive damage across the Indian Creek neighborhood located near the intersection of Glass Road and Grape Creek Road.  ||Shingles were blown off several residences, a single wide mobile home was moved off its blocks, and several windows of mobile homes and vehicles were broken by the wind-driven hail. Mobile home skirting was blown out by the strong thunderstorm winds.  In addition, several outbuildings were destroyed, a large metal building housing large hay bales was also destroyed as the metal was strewn a couple of hundred yards into a nearby field.
A public report indicated quarter-sized hail in the city of Rio Vista, TX.
Thunderstorm winds gusted up to 70 mph.
Lightning struck a gas well on County Road 350, causing a large fire. No injuries were reported.
Broadcast media chasers captured video of a tornado approximately 11 miles northwest of St. Jo. This tornado produced EF0 damage to trees and one home.
Hail slightly larger than quarters fell in Groesbeck.
A roof was removed off a building and fences were damaged at Glen Lake Camp.
Four hangars were reported damaged at West Houston Airport.
Nickel sized hail was reported 2 miles northeast of Venus.

The National Weather Service conducted a storm survey in northwest Upshur County and concluded that the damage was the result of an EF0 tornado.  The tornado first touched down to the east of Simpsonville, Tx.  The storm continued on an east northeast track crossing Wolverine Road and lifted near FM 2454. Damage consisted mostly of trees snapped and/or uprooted especially along the end of the track where damage included Rear Flank Downdraft and Inflow damage.  Estimated wind speeds were 75-80 mph.
Pea to golfball-size hail was reported by the Buffalo Police Department and relayed by the Centerville Sherriff's office.
A trained spotter estimated golf ball size hail five miles north of Dickens. No damage was reported.

Tornado appeared to touch down at an RV and boat storage facility then cross Interstate 10. It then damaged Pepperl Fuchs facility on north side of Interstate. Tornado crossed from Fort Bend into Waller County.

Motorists reported that hail was sufficiently large to lightly damage a vehicle along U.S. Highway 82 east-southeast of Guthrie. The exact hail size is unknown, therefore a minimal severe size estimate is assigned here.

To the southeast of Hallettsville, and southeast of the first tornado, a second tornado touched down near 0345 CST.  This was just off FM530 on Road 16C, near the community of Light Chapel.  This tornado touched down just south of a mobile home and began moving toward the northeast.  A father, along with two sons and a daughter, had just arrived home less than an hour before the touchdown and had fallen asleep when the storm struck.  The father reported feeling a jolt that awakened him as severe thunderstorm winds ahead of the tornado struck the mobile home.  He reported that it became quiet again and then the mobile home exploded as the tornado stuck.  He and his three children were blown and tossed almost 150 feet, coming to rest on the top of the former south wall of his mobile home.  Broken glass was everywhere, but, in spite of cuts and bruises, they took shelter in a small nearby roofless shack as hail continued to fall.  He then walked, carrying an injured son and daughter, to a neighbors house to call for help.  His truck, parked under an awning just south of the mobile home was rolled and crushed.  Had he and his children arrived only a few minutes later at their home, they could easily have been killed.  That all have recovered except for minor bruises and cuts can only be considered a miracle.  The fathers comments were that its all okay  were okay.  What was destroyed is just stuff.  Based on the destroyed mobile home, which had been tied down, and the rolled and twisted metal frame, the tornado was rated EF-2 on the Enhanced Fujita Scale.  Winds were estimated at 115 mph.  The tornado path length was placed at four-tenths of a mile with a path width of 75 yards.
Trees and powerlines were downed in Winona, Texas.
The West Texas Mesonet site near Tahoka measured a 76 mph wind gust.
A shoe store building collapsed at 4th St and High St in Wills Point.
The media relayed reports of one trailer flipped and another crushed by a falling tree near Vidor.
There were several roofs partially blown off homes and one roof completely blown off an office building.

An EF-1 tornado with peak winds estimated at 95 mph briefly touched down near the intersection of Bissonnet and Gains Road.  Several homes were damaged along Turphin Way with one home sustaining significant roof damage.  The tornado crossed north of Bissonnet, downed fences, and produced roof damage to approximately ten homes along Royal Way.  The damage path continued north and east with minor roof and fence damage observed along Havencrest and Vistamont Drives.  The damage path ended near the intersection of Rocky Valley Road and High Haven Drive.
Severe thunderstorm winds damaged roofs of homes and knocked over trees near Willow City.  A home weather station recorded wind gusts to 51 knots
Powerlines were downed just west of Center, Texas.
Occurred 3 miles north of Lake Nocona.
Roof blown off of a horse barn and several large trees down. Report received via phone call.
Amateur radio operator reported one inch hail at Kempwood and Gessner in NW Houston.
Hail occurred at 58th and Washington.
The funnel cloud was reported just west of Windthorst, lasting about 1 minute.
The KVII-TV Schoolnet measured a severe thunderstorm wind gust of 70 mph at 19:35 CST in Friona. No damage was reported.
Starr County Sheriffs Office reported quarter size hail at the intersection of FM 1367 and Eisenhower Road.
Tornado caused significant damage to 25 homes and minor damage to 200 other homes. Roof damage to structures with numerous trees and power lines down around the city. One injury was reported.

Reports from local police of several downed power lines a few miles west of Spearman around the 15/207 area and a few miles north of Gruver on HWY 136. Additionally, several downed tree branches as well as loose objects, such as trampolines, had been displaced in town.
Fire and rescue reported that a boat dock became detached and destroyed, shingles were removed from a roof and heavy damage was done to a back porch from thunderstorm winds at Lake Graham.
Estimated dime to quarter size hail falling at time of the report.
A trained spotter reported golf ball size breaking windows to a house. The hail was possibly larger up to tennis ball size hail. Time based on radar.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 75 mph that blew down trees near Hwy 281 and FM 473 in southern Blanco County.
Public reported quarter sized hail northeast of Swinney Switch through social media.
Minor roof damage was reported in Morgan's Point Resort on Lake Park Road.

A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Plainview measured severe wind gusts from 1746 CST through 1748 CST. A peak gust of 71 mph was measured at 1747 CST. Furthermore, the AWOS at the Hale County Airport (KPVW) measured a wind gust of 61 mph at 1750 CST.
A public report indicated that planes were overturned and sheet metal ripped off at Waco Regional Airport. The ASOS reported a wind gust of 45 MPH before it was damaged.
A semi-truck was damaged by severe thunderstorm winds.

The tornado damaged electrical transmission lines on several|metal truss towers. One of the metal truss towers collapsed due|to the tornado increasing in intensity to an EF2. The path length |and width of the tornado was based on radar and photos of the|damage. The estimated peak wind of the tornado was 130 mph.
A member of the public reported quarter size hail 10 miles southwest of Claude.
The public reported hail up to golf ball size along Mile Marker 445 on I-10 west of Junction.
Quarter size hail was reported on the north side of San Angelo.
Tree downed on Stoddard Drive.
Public reported wind estimates up to 60 mph that resulted in small tree limbs down.

An EF-0 tornado was documented by storm chasers touching down between Mount Vernon and Hagansport. The damage survey team found that this tornado produced estimated maximum winds near 80 mph which downed tree limbs of several trees along its 5+ mile long path.
Trees were blown down in the community of Ander.
High winds estimated at 50 to 60 knots, caused widespread minor damage to buildings and vehicles across much of Kinney County.
Several fences and trees were blown down in the Gemstone Estates, northeast of Granbury. A 25-foot bradford pear tree was sheared in half. Other homes in the area suffered minor roof and shed damage.
A thunderstorm moved across Midland County and produced a 60 mph wind gust five miles west northwest of the City of Midland.
A utility trailer was reported to have been blown into a pickup trick causing damage to both vehicles. Wind speeds are estimated to be about 60 mph. Property damage cost is an estimation.

There were multiple reports from local government officials and storm spotters of this tornado developing between County Road H and County Road F, west of Booker. The tornado crossed Highway 15 near County Road 28. The tornado then continued to move northeast and passed north of Booker. Multiple power flashes were witnessed just west of town. Tree and fence damage was found near the Texas/Oklahoma state line. A rating of EF-1 was given with a maximum wind speed of 86 mph.

A member of the public shared video of a landspout just east of La Villa. This landspout formed along the leading edge of an outflow boundary that raced through the Lower Rio Grande Valley the afternoon of September 16th. According to the member of the public who shared video of the event, it only last a minute or so and didn't appear to cause any damage as it was near the levee just east of La Villa.
Trees were downed onto several homes along Hickory Drive.
Several storm chasers reported a brief tornado touchdown in open country.  No NWS storm survey was conducted.
A trained spotter reported a lot of hail covering the ground, with the largest hail the size of tennis balls.
The Waco ASOS reported several gusts of 50 kts over a 30 min period.

A thunderstorm produced one and one half inch hail which broke windows in a house and office buildings.  This large hail also produced damage to several buildings in and around Rocksprings including the county courthouse where several windows were broken.  The hail accumulated to several inches deep.
No damage reported. Report relayed via emergency manager.
A trained spotter reported penny size hail in the city of Dublin, TX.

This tornado formed in the outer rainbands of Hurricane Emily, 2 miles west of Premont, in Jim Wells County, and entered Duval county roughly 2 miles southeast of Cruz Calle.  The tornado continued west for roughly another 1/2 to 1 mile, producing minor roof damage to a house and snapping trees.  This tornado may have continue further west into the county, however a NWS Storm Survey team was unable to confirm this.

A line of thunderstorms developed across the western half of the Texas Panhandle and moved to the south. As this line moved over across Moore County, the Dumas (Moore County) AWOS reported an 81 mph thunderstorm wind gust. The line that produced this gust continued to move to the south across the western Texas Panhandle.
Approximate 1.5 hail was reported near the football stadium at Kennedale High School.
Small branches down with dime sized hail and winds up to 70 mph estimated.

A supercell thunderstorm tracked southeast along U.S. Highway 90 in Terrell County. Multiple reports of large hail ranging in size from quarters to tennis balls were received between Sanderson and the Terrell County Airport.
Trees downed across a gas line causing a fire in the community of Centerpoint, Texas.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Turkey measured a wind gust to 58 mph.
Public reported quarter size hail at the intersection of Lincoln and 5th in downtown Zapata.  Also reported winds of 65 mph (estimated).
A tree fell onto a home in White Oak.
A thunderstorm produced hail from ping pong ball to baseball size south of Hunt.
The Austin Emergency Manager reported power lines blown down in the 12000 block of Dringenberg Drive.
KTXS reported an estimated wind gust of 75 MPH.
A man was hospitalized from a lightning in an office parking lot.
Trees were downed in the Hoard community about 1 mile east of FM 1801.
Numerous trees and power lines were blown down.

Multiple power lines were knocked down by falling tree limbs; also a neighborhood fence was destroyed by strong winds.  City crews and tree service companies were dispatched to cut up and shred tree limbs.

Law enforcement in Castro County reported a swath of hail up to two inches in diameter along Texas State Highway 86 from approximately two miles west-southwest of Dimmitt into Dimmitt. Numerous windshields were reported to be destroyed.
A thunderstorm produced dime to penny size hail.

Intense thunderstorm winds produced significant damage across Richardson. A wind sensor at Methodist Richardson measured 83 mph, but a NWS Storm Survey determined wind speeds up to 90 mph moved through part of the city. The strongest winds and most notable wind damage was observed from Hillside Avenue stretching southeast to Bowser Rd south of Main Street. Numerous trees were damaged, snapped, or uprooted across the city, and roofs and fences were damaged. Local officials reported 111 facilities with varying degrees of damage. The public reported a large, 70-year old live oak tree uprooted onto a home, causing roof damage.
Wind gusts were estimated at 65 mph in Cottondale.
Refugio County Sheriff's Office reported a funnel cloud northwest of Refugio.
Marble to Golfball size hail fell 2 miles east-northeast of Greenville.

A small tornado developed over open country and moved northeast. The tornado lasted for less than one minute and was confirmed from spotter video. The tornado path length and path width were estimated. No damage or injuries were reported.
A thunderstorm moved across Midland County and produced estimated 50 to 60 mph wind gusts ten miles southwest of Stanton on I-20.
A powerline was downed along County Road 1515.

An NWS survey on the west side of Canyon Lake found sporadic tree damage, along with two power poles snapped and approximately 1/4 of a single family home torn off. The damage area was near Canyon Lake Boat Ramp #6 on the south central side of the|lake along and near Canyon Lake Drive and Rimrock Pass. The damage was rated EF-1 and winds were estimated at 100 mph.
Tennis ball size hail fell 7 miles south of Perryton. This public report was relayed by social media.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site in Reese Center recorded wind gusts up to 81 mph.
Numerous trees downed in the New London, Texas area.
A brief EF-0 tornado was confirmed from 3 videos just east of the town of Mumford, TX in southern Robertson County. No damage was reported as the track stayed in open farmland.
Hail was reported by the general public at the intersection of Interstate 20 and U.S. Highway 385.
A storm spotter reported street signs blown down and billboards ripped off.
Two foot diameter tree down at Highway 288 and Ash Road.
Golfball to baseball sized hail was reported about 2 miles north of Springtown.
A public report of mixed small and large tree (limbs) occurred in north Brownsville near Cameron Park.
Report from mPing.
Amateur radio operator reported half dollar sized hail in downtown Princeton.
Trees were downed 255 and Highway 87.
Broadcast media reported nickel size hail approximately one mile west of the city of Oak Ridge, TX on Highway 82.
The Atascosa County Sheriff's Office reported quarter size hail.
Poles and power lines were down on Highway 144, 3 miles south of Granbury.
A public report indicated half-dollar sized hail about a mile northeast of Everman, TX.
Also reported 45 mph wind gust.
Thunderstorm winds downed a tree next to the bridge at the Navasota River along FM 105.
A tree was downed on a mobile home on Litton Circle in RedWater, Texas.  The mobile home was totaled but there were no injuries reported.
Large tree limbs were blown onto vehicles and power lines.  A large tree was blown down at the intersection of College Avenue and North Lane Street.

A thunderstorm produced three inch diameter hail south of Dripping Springs.  As of this writing there is no official estimate of monetary loss due to the hail across Hays County including Dripping Springs and the Wimberley area.  Will go with an initial 10 million dollars and this will be updated at a later time if more accurate estimates come in from city or county officials.
Half dollar size hail was reported in Fritch.
Hail reported to be two inches deep.
Occurred in Saltillo and Weaver communities.
Quarter sized hail fell near the intersection of Interstate 35 and Ovilla Road.
Spotter estimated 65 mph winds to the southeast of Clegg.
Quarter size hail occurred just north of Grapeland.
Quarter size hail was reported 2 miles northeast of Nocona.
Several large trees were downed in Simms, Texas.
The Levelland fire department estimated wind gusts to 70 mph.  A few power lines were downed in the area.

A thunderstorm moved across Gaines County and produced wind damage about three miles southwest of Seagraves. Several power lines were blown down due to thunderstorm winds at County Road 226 and US 385. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Telephone poles were blown down around Albany.
Garza County Sheriff's Office reported golfball size hail.
High winds knocked down a tree which was blocking State Highway 23.
A large tree was blown down.

The local broadcast media relayed a report of nickel size hail along Interstate 27 on the Hale and Swisher County line south of Kress. Delayed reports in newspaper clipping from the area suggested that some minor crop damage may have occurred, but no details were included. Therefore a small amount of agricultural damage is reported here.

NWS Storm survey found EF1 tornado damage along a path across portions of northern Grimes and southern Madison counties, generally parallel and to the west of SH 90 between Bedias and Madisonville. Damage included trees downed and uprooted, and there was also some roof damage to a few homes.

Lightning struck a residence in the late afternoon hours while a roofer was delivering shingles to the residence near 27000 Bordelon Way in Bexar County.  A male worker was struck by the lightning and was revived and taken to a local hospital in critical condition.  The man later died in the hospital on July 13.

An EF1 tornado touched down 4 miles southwest of Hooks, Texas at the Red River Army Depot.  Trees were downed and snapped.  An outbuilding was destroyed, and a security guard shelter was pushed over.  The intermittent tornado then moved northeast and crossed Interstate 30 where it knocked trees down on a house and damaged and destroyed several campers at a camper sale store on the interstate.  Some of the main building was also damaged.
Penny sized hail.
Hail on US 59 North just outside Beltway 8.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail in Fredericksburg.
Nickel to half dollar sized hail was reported by a trained spotter near Elkhart.
Wet microburst damaged roof of United Way building and the backdoors of a nearby warehouse.
MPing report.
NWS storm survey indicated scattered coverage of large trees down in the community of Palito Blanco. Damage to roofs of several homes occurred due to the winds.
Measured by KJTV Fox34 News Channel 9 anemometer.
Off-duty NWS Employee reported several tree limbs up to 5 inches in diameter snapped off of trees nearby. Time and duration was estimated via radar.
A tree was blown down onto power lines at the intersection of FM 1798 and FM 840 in the Brachfield community.

F1 tornado on the south side of Conroe caused significant roof, window and wall damage to around eight residential homes in the Rivershire Subdivision and a few local businesses, including a car dealership that had signs and light poles blown down onto parked vehicles. A nearby church and motel also had roof damage (ceramic tile from the motel impaled into dealership's walls). Trees were also snapped or uprooted in the area.
Windows were blown out of the dairy queen, and trees were blown down around the county.
Hail to the size of quarters was reported in Mustang Park, at the tip of Lake Benbrook.
A video was posted to social media which showed quarter size hail in Denver City.
The KTXS TV Station from Abilene reported quarter size hail covering the ground just north of their location on Highway 277.
A power line was downed in Bogata, setting a tree on fire.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 58 mph that snapped two power poles and downed power lines. Winds also damaged some roofs and blew down some trees.
Law enforcement officials reported that 60 to 70 MPH severe thunderstorm wind gusts accompanied large hail south of Orla.
Trees were downed on power lines along Highway 259 south of Dekalb.
Law enforcement reported nickel size hail. No damage was reported.
A small shed was blown over by high winds.
A trained spotter reported several large tree limbs down.
Half dollar size hail fell at Interstate 40 and Eastern in Amarillo.

A large downburst toppled multiple trees from Tulia to roughly four miles west of Tulia.  Some of these trees damaged power lines, fences and structures.  The Swisher County Emergency Manager estimated the high winds lasted up to seven minutes.
A Coop Observer measured a wind gust of 60 mph about 1 mile southeast of Wingate.
Storm chasers observed the tornado as it developed in open country and became rain wrapped. No damage was reported with this tornado.
A trained spotter reported multiple trees damaged in the city of Malakoff, TX.
Tennis ball sized hail was reported near Highway 175 and Lake June Road in Dallas.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail in Timberwood Park.
Media reported dime size hail at Highway 290 and FM 1960 in NW Houston.
A public report was received of a fence and large branches down near the intersection of Ridgeview Drive and Custer Road.
Golfball sized hail was reported at Nocona General Hospital.

A severe thunderstorm moved over Mitchell County and produced a tornado eighteen miles south of Westbrook.  This tornado remained over ranch land adjacent to and west of State Highway 163.  No damage was identified with this tornado, and it was rated as an EF-0.
NWS meteorologist and University of Oklahoma Graduate Student and Storm Chasers report of a tornado.

A thunderstorm developed over southern Randall County during the mid-morning hours of the 21st. As the thunderstorm moved to the northeast it encountered a strongly sheared environment which toppled the storm structure. The core of the thunderstorm collapsed 1 mile east of the city of Canyon (Randall County) causing a dangerous cross wind on Interstate 27. This cross wind caused two semi-tractor trailers to be overturned. No injuries were reported in association with this damage, wind speed estimated from similar report in the area, and property damage values estimated.
Damage to 5-6 warehouse building garage doors which were blown out/in.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 65 mph that uprooted a large tree at the corner of Beaver Ln. and Deer Run Way in New Braunfels.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail in Giddings.
Hail to the size of hen eggs reported in Gober.
Trees and power lines were down in Abilene after a severe thunderstorm moved through the area. Several homes also received roof damage.
Trailer overturned, power lines down, and roof damage two miles north of Pattison.  Roofs damaged and trees down along FM 529 from Pattison to the county line.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that knocked down a one inch tree limb and blew some shingles off a roof.

A line of thunderstorms moved out of the Oklahoma Panhandle and into the Texas Panhandle during the late night hours of the 22nd. As the line neared the town of Perryton (Ochiltree County), a member of the public reported an estimated 80 mph thunderstorm downburst gust in town. After producing this downburst gust the line continued to move to the south-southeast across the Texas Panhandle.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail in Cedar Park.
Some cattle feeders were damaged by a brief tornado touchdown.
A trained spotter reported a few large trees blown down near CR 2319 approximately 4 miles north of the city of Walton, TX.
Ping pong ball size hail was reported near the South Sam Houston Tollway.
Quarter-sized hail was reported by the Stoneburg Volunteer Fire Department approximately 9 miles north-northwest of the city of Bowie, TX.
Trained spotters reported hail between nickel and golf ball sized hail with very little rainfall.

Couple of trees downed in and around Needville, one down on Violet Street and another at the SPJST Hall. Minor structural damage at Needville City Hall and tin roof damage to a business just north of Needville. Damage also reported to a rice dryer. A bank across Highway 36 received minor damage from the rice dryer's debris.
One inch hail fell in Wheeler.

Damaging thunderstorm winds swept over portions of Upton County during the early morning hours of the 3rd. A storage shed that was located at an oil field near the intersection of Farm to Market Road 1492 and Texas Highway 329 was destroyed. Debris from the shed was blown into an electrical transformer and caused additional damage including power outages.
Small Barns or Farm Outbuildings (SBO). Uplift or collapse of roof structure.
Storm chaser reported hail up to the size of golf balls.
A thunderstorm moved over Scurry County and produced a 60 mph wind gust five miles northwest of Snyder.
MPing report.
A local emergency manager in Cottle County reported hail ranging from quarter size to golf ball size approximately six miles to the west of Paducah along US Highway 62.
There were trees reported blown down along highway 237 near the town of Warrenton.
Storm spotter reported ping pong hail size approximately 4 miles WSW of Celina.
Emergency management reported quarter-sized hail in the towns of Mildred and Eureka.
Trees were downed.
Estimated 70 mph winds were reported in Greenville.
Chasers said there was lots of quarter size to half dollar size hail stones. Hail  accumulating on the ground up to 2 inches.  Really strong winds estimating without  descriptors about 70 to 80 mph.
Emergency management reported that a 69 MPH wind gust was measured in the city of Dalworthington Gardens, TX.
Hail up to 2 inches in diameter fell in the town of Saint Jo.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph which knocked down several large tree limbs.
An off duty National Weather Service employee reported golf ball size hail in San Antonio.

The public estimated that thunderstorm wind gusts near 70 mph accompanied very heavy rainfall in Amherst around 16:15 CST. These estimates were confirmed by a nearby Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet station which measured a 73 mph gust just east of the town. At least one irrigation pivot was destroyed by the winds north of Amherst.
Video submitted of tennis ball sized hail near Laredo Rachettes. Large tree limbs were broken also.
A trained spotter measured a wind gust of 63 MPH just south of Northeast Mall in the city of Hurst, TX.
Mostly dime size hail, however a few quarters also mixed in during a thunderstorm.

Private meteorologist reported a wind gust of 73 mph at 100 feet in elevation near Boca Chica Beach with wind gusts above 58 mph starting around 1:35AM CDT. The highest gust was recorded at 1:53AM CDT.
Nickel size hail at the Fry Road and Sun Glenn Blvd intersection.
Reported at Tascosa Road and Amarillo Boulevard.
The combination of 70 mph winds and golfball sized hail resulted in several windows blown out of houses, minor roof damage and several trees blown over near Priddy.
Small hardwood tree limbs broken (up to 1 inch diameter).

A bow-shaped echo across Comal, Bexar and Wilson Counties began producing severe winds just before midnight that were estimated generally in the 60 to 70 knot range.  The storms produced widespread wind gusts of 40 to 50 knots, with spotty higher gusts near 70 knots.  The damage was mainly to trees in the northern part of Wilson County.
An off-duty NWS employee reported golfball size hail.

Additional severe storms over Hale County produced a swath of severe winds over western and southern portions of the county. Local fire department officials reported 60 mph winds in Halfway.
