Also, the Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site near Abernathy recorded a wind gust of 58 mph. No damage was reported.
COOP observer reported a wind gust of 60 mph.
Nickel to quarter-size hail was reported.
An NWS Cooperative Observer reported a large tree was uprooted.
Emergency management reported roofs blown off homes near Lake Bridgeport. Pictures showed the roof losses were partial but did include the decking and attached insulation on at least 1 home.
Amateur radio reported that a 2.5 foot diameter tree was uprooted by thunderstorm winds near Randol Mill Park.
Several trees downed in Dialville.
Mping report of 1.25 inch hail.
Alice International Airport ASOS measured a gust to 50 knots.
A NWS COOP observer near Northfield reported a roof blown off a shop building about six miles east of Northfield.
The roof of a Texas Inn was blown off and several nearby homes and cars were damaged from the debris.
The pong ball size hail was reported at OH Ivie Lake.
A large tree was downed 2 miles south of Interstate 20 on Farm to Market road 9.
Strong thunderstorm winds estimated at 60 to 70 mph were reported at Portwood Ranch.
A trained spotter reported golf ball sized hail approximately 7 miles west of the city of Valley View, TX. Hail near 2 was also reported in this same approximate area by the public.
A severe thunderstorm wind gust of 64 mph was measured by the Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet near Floydada. No damage was reported.

The West Texas Mesonet station two miles east-southeast of Gail measured an 86 mph wind gust before communications were lost.  After the storm, a West Texas Mesonet representative went to the station and reported that the radio antenna had been bent and one of the guy wires was damaged.  The fence surrounding the instrumentation was damaged by wind blown mesquite.
A thunderstorm produced dime to quarter size hail in La Grange.

A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that uprooted a tree. The tree fell on, and damaged, three vehicles at the Mission Villas Apartment complex in the Harlandale neighborhood of San Antonio.
Law enforcement reported six to seven large trees snapped and uprooted at the Winters Country Club. Also, a roof was damaged at the same location.
Amateur radio reported nickel sized hail near the intersection of I-35 and Torres Road in the city of Waco, TX.
Trees were downed in Omaha, Texas.
Observer reported quarter sized hail.
A 59 MPH wind gust reported 1.5 miles west of KFWD by David Vantage Pro2 anemometer.
Winds were estimated to be 60 MPH associated with the outflow of the thunderstorm.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail west of Sutherland Springs.
A wind gust of 78 mph was recorded at Moody Gardens.
Semi truck flipped near the Wal-Mart in Calallen. Street signs were blown and shopping carts were blown onto Highway 77.
A thunderstorm produced a 59 mph wind gust at the Mesonet site near Van Horn.
Public reported quarter to half dollar size hail south of Lorena.

Hail slightly larger than quarters pummeled the Flagg community for nearly 30 minutes. Combined with ferocious downburst winds, hundreds of acres of mature corn and grain crops were destroyed or severely damaged. Torrential rains piled the hail into drifts nearly 12 inches deep in places. With record high corn prices, total crop losses would likely top $100,000.
Several storm chasers reported a swath of hail between ping pong ball size and 2.25 inches in far southern Bailey County. No damage was reported.
Quarter size hail was reported in Petersburg by local fire department officials as a cluster of severe storms impacted far southeastern Hale County and parts of northeastern Lubbock County.
Quarter to Golfball sized hail was reported around the City of Uvalde.
Multiple trees were uprooted along HWY 287 by the wind.
Baseball sized hail occurred near Ricardo. Hail caused damage to several vehicles.
A power pole was snapped by high winds between Banquete and Robstown just off Highway 44. Wood fences and a metal shed were also damaged in the area.
Farmers near the Borden and Howard County line reported extensive loss to cotton crops due to wind driven hail.
Nickel sized hail was reported in Bevel Oaks. The small hail lasted for about 8 minutes.
Public reported ping pong ball size hail.
The Sterling City 4 WSW Mesonet recorded a wind gust of 61 mph.
Penny size hail accompanied by damaging winds were reported near the intersection of Texas Highways 168 and 1075 north of Nazareth.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail in Reedville.
Social media reported golf ball size near Prosper.
Dime to quarter size hail was reported in Menard.
Severe winds were estimated and no damage was reported.
Baseball size hail was reported 9 miles east-southeast of Wayside.
A trained spotter reported a brief tornado touchdown in an open field.
Wind-driven hail caused extensive property damage.
A member of the public reported 1 inch hail near Point Blank.

A NWS Storm Survey concluded that damage was done to 44 power poles near Ranch Road 2627 in Brewster County, TX.  Some of the poles were snapped 3 to 4 feet above the ground and all the poles fell to the south as the storm moved in the same direction around 20 mph.  The poles were not consecutively snapped in a row.  At times, there were 15 snapped...then a gap...and then more snapped as you moved southeastward down the line.  Please see the attached images for a detailed look at the damage path.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Levelland measured a wind gust of 61 mph at 1917 CST.
Tree limbs were reported to be snapped in half in Laredo.
Golf ball sized hail was reported in The Colony.
The roof was peeled back on a barn in Troup, Texas.
A severe thunderstorm resulted in penny size hail along Highway 158 west of Garden City.
Report from mPING: Quarter (1.00 in.).
Winds estimated at 60 mph.

This tornado started just to the north of the Jiffy Cleaners,|where some tree limbs broke off a few trees. The top half of a|tree snapped and fell alongside the Cleaners building. A rusty air|conditioning unit lifted from the roof of the cleaners and was|tossed into the median of Ross Osage Road. The sign of Cliffside|Coffee Shop was blown out on the south side of the sign. The|tornado crossed the street and appeared to gain a little more|strength as it caused the brick siding of the Toot N Totum gas |station to collapse. The tornado continued across SE 27th Avenue, |where it caused minor damage to the Stars Drive- In and some cars |in the parking lot had their windows blown out from debris. The |tornado appeared to have dissipated in the field behind the Drive-|In. This tornado was documented by multiple people and we are |grateful for their video evidence. Times were estimated based on |video documentation and may be adjusted with further analysis and |information.
Measured by the Texas Tech/West Texas mesonet station 6 miles northwest of White River Lake.
Multiple 6-inch diameter tree limbs blown down. Time is radar estimated.
Several trees and fences were blown down in Lumberton.
Multiple reports of trees and power lines downed throughout the county.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 50 mph that blew down numerous trees across the northern half of Fayette County. The AWOS at La Grange Airport measured a gust of 47 mph.
Reported via mPing.
The wind gusts was measured at Houston Hobby Airport.
Broadcast media reported 1.5 inch hail at KBTX Studio.
A trained spotter estimated wind gusts up to 65 mph and extensive blowing dust.
Hail stones up to 2 in diameter fell in the Sendera Ranch neighborhood just west of Haslet.

A cluster of thunderstorms developed over Roberts County during the evening hours of the 13th. These thunderstorms moved slowly and produced heavy rain over portions of the county. This heavy rain led to a member of the public reporting minor flooding of their property west of State Highway 70 along North River Road (Roberts County). The minor flooding stayed contained to the yard and did not enter the home. This minor flooding dissipated once storm coverage diminished by 7 PM CST. No swift water rescues or stranded motorist were reported in association to this minor flooding.
Public reported half dollar size hail on social media near Ovalo.
Forest Service reported damage from winds.
A tornado developed from a low topped storm south of the community of Novice and moved northwest across the community. Portions of two roofs were blown off of homes and numerous windows were broken.
Golfball size hail was reported by the public.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet station measured a wind gust to 58 mph near Abernathy.
A tornado briefly touched down to the northwest of Wharton.  There was no damage.
Storm chaser estimated wind gusts to 70 mph.
Pea to nickel size hail covered the ground in portions of northwestern Andrews County.

An EF-2 tornado moved through Arlington producing mostly EF-0 and EF-1 damage, but a small area of EF-2 damage was found. The tornado began near West Mayfield Road and South Bowen Road where fence, shed and tree damage was found. The tornado traveled northeast from this location causing minor tree damage. Significant roof damage to several structures was noted along Colorado Lane. The tornado then crossed South Cooper Street and damaged a Burger Box fast food restaurant, Safelite AutoGlass store, and several warehouses in the area. The tornado damage in his location and along Colorado Lane was at EF-1 intensity. The tornado continued along an east-northeast track where it soon impacted the Waterdance and Mirage Apartments. Considerable roof damage was noted at these complexes, but the most significant damage occurred at the Waterdance Apartment complex. Large sections of the roof were ripped off of two buildings, resulting in an EF-2 rating at this location. From the apartment complex, the tornado weakened and traveled northeast for a few more miles before dissipating near East Park Row Drive and Carter Drive. Sporadic tree, siding, fence, and shingle damage was noted to the end of the path. The maximum winds with this tornado were around 115 mph. Five people were injured in this tornado, but none of the injuries were life threatening.

A tornado formed approximately 2 miles southwest of Barry in open country, based on storm spotter video and eyewitness reports. This tornado moved north and northeast of Barry, impacting several residences and outbuildings along Navarro County roads 1210 and 1230. Most of the structural damage was confined to roofs and outbuilding sheet metal and was consistent with damage intensities of EF-0 and lower end EF-1 magnitude. However, one manufactured home along CR 1230 was totally destroyed, consistent with EF-1 winds of approximately 110 mph. The tornado traveled several additional miles to the east, passing north of Emhouse and producing EF-0 damage to trees and outbuildings. This tornado eventually dissipated in the Chambers Creek drainage west of Rice.
Broadcast media reported that some signs were blown down in what was estimated to be 60 to 70 MPH wind gusts on Interstate 35 east of Krum, TX.
A wind gust of 60 mph was reported.
A roof was taken off of a front porch. Also a heavy duty  swing-set was blown over and several tree limbs were blown down.
Hail was reported via MPING near Creek.
The fire department reported trees down in Bronte.
A thunderstorm produced nickel to penny size hail.
The hail report was relayed by KSWO-TV.
Several large trees toppled across Highway 96.
Quarter size hail was reported 5 miles northeast of the intersection of US 69 and HWY 19.

Strong downburst winds from a summertime thunderstorm knocked down small trees and tree limbs in Cheneyboro. The storm also produced small hail around 0.50 in diameter, and the hail damaged the sides of homes and awnings.
Several large trees downed by estimated 65 mph winds from an NWS Cooperative Observer.
Golf ball size hail was reported at the Sheriff's office. There were also reports of roof and window damage across Bellville.
A trained spotter reported that the hail fell near 34th Avenue and Georgia Street.
A tree was blown down by high winds.
Trees blown down from Wharton to El Campo...some fell on houses and cars.
A 1-2 foot diameter tree was uprooted approximately 7 miles northwest of Glen Rose.
Large tree branches were knocked down in Denton. At least one large branch landed on the roof of a house.
Picture of measured 1.25 hail was reported near Country Club Road and Hickory Creek Road.
Penny size hail was reported near Bishop Hills.
A thunderstorm moved across Gaines County and produced a 62 mph wind gust near Seagraves.  No damage was reported.
Large piles of small hail along the side of the road, some hail may be larger.
Dime size hail was reported near Peaster.
Willacy County Sheriffs Office reported estimated wind gusts of 60 mph at their location.
Telephone poles reported blown down along Highway 16, north of Freer.  Winds were estimated between 60 and 80 mph.
Quarter size hail was reported near Caddo Mills.
The public reported a few large tree limbs down. The limbs were at least 10 feet in length.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Turkey measured severe wind gusts from 0008 CST through 0009 CST. A peak wind gust of 60 mph was measured at 0008 CST.
A power pole was bent over due to severe thunderstorm winds.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball sized hail west of Dryden. The hail was measured by  IBHS hail study researchers. The time of the hail was estimated from radar.
Late report of thunderstorm wind gust and an inch of rain.
Heavy rainfall was accompanied by a few penny size hail stones east of Flomot at 17:30 CST.
A funnel cloud was sighted about 8 miles north northeast of De Kalb.
Trained spotters reported hail to the size of baseballs in the city of Caradan.
Trees and power lines downed in Hughes Springs.
A trained spotter reported nickel sized hail 3 miles south-southeast of Calvert, TX.
A porch was blown off a house and a tree was blown down.

The tornado damaged several structures on Acton Ranch about|26 miles south-southwest of Ozona, Texas. The tornado uplifted|and destroyed the roof structure of a barn with concrete walls. |The tornado also lifted a heavy metal bulk feeder at least 5 |feet in the air and moved it at least 150 feet from its original |location. The tornado also snapped the trunk of a 150 year old |cottonwood tree. The estimated peak wind speed of the |tornado was 115 mph.
Multiple large trees were downed in Orange and West Orange.
A thunderstorm produced 1 to 1.25 inch hail west of Rio Medina.
Hai9l fell at the intersection of Highway 31 and West Loop.
A thunderstorm produced penny size hail northwest of Dripping Springs.
Motorists along Interstate 27 north of Plainview encountered quarter size hail. The report was relayed by the local broadcast media.
A thunderstorm produced five minutes of quarter size hail.
A large tree was blown over a county road.
Two grain bins reported to be overturned by the high winds.

A thunderstorm moved across Howard County and produced wind damage near Big Spring.  There was a three mile long stretch of Centerpoint Road between Big Spring and Coahoma where there were 31 power poles snapped.  The cost of damage is a rough estimate.
Trees were downed along Hwy. 726 just east of Lake O The Pines.
Power lines were blown down by high winds.
Reported that three semi trucks had been blown over near the town of Shamrock. No injuries or fatalities were reported.
A large tree limb was blown down onto a road at Annetta.
Large hail was reported by the Zapata County Sheriff's Department in San Ygnacio.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Spur measured a wind gust to 65 mph.
A Trained Spotter reported a wind gust of 58 mph.
A thunderstorm produced 2.5 diameter hail  in Kerrville.
Widespread tree and fence damage along with minor residential roof and home damage at FM 518 and Bay Area Blvd near Hall Elementary School in the Countyside South subdivision.
The Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport Automated Surface Observation System measured a wind gust of 70 MPH.
A public report indicated penny sized hail 3 miles east-northeast of Arlington, TX.
A trained spotter measured a 60 MPH wind gust on home weather equipment near Highway 199 and Salt Creek Road. Small tree limbs were knocked down.
Mesonet site reported 68 mph wind gust.
The Texas Department of Public Safety closed Texas Highway 17 at Verhalen after 15 power poles were toppled onto the highway by severe thunderstorm winds.
Occurred in the western part of the county.
A member of the public reported hail up to golf balls (1.75) in and around the Mission area.
Reported twelve miles southwest of Amarillo.
There were old live trees and one to one and a half inch tree limbs blown down on the south and southwest side of Amarillo.  The tree limb damage was pretty widespread throughout town.
The large hail came through the window of the vehicle which the storm chaser was driving and caused minor cuts to the driver.
Golfball size hail was reported in Tioga.
Numerous power lines were blown down on Highway 121.
Part of the roof was torn off a house on CR 103 between Kaufman and Abner.
Penny size hail near West Road.

An EF-0 tornado touched down in the Spring Branch area of Houston. The tornado caused a cinder block wall to fall near the initial touchdown point. Damage further north primarily consisted of snapped large tree limbs. An apartment complex suffered several broken windows and a commercial garage door was blown in. A large tree was broken and a residential carport was destroyed at the end of the damage path.
Several trees were downed across the county.
Trees were downed in the 900 block of Old Highway 59.
Golf ball size hail reported in Bivins.
Public reported dime sized hail along Highway 361 on the causeway 2 to 3 miles to the east-southeast of Aransas Pass.
The Mills County Emergency Manager and local storm spotters observed a tornado. The tornado occurred in open land and did minimal damage to trees.
Tennis ball size hail reported on County Road 4420 between Winnsboro and Scroggins.
Metal buildings were blown down by high winds.
Several trees, power lines and a transformer downed by thunderstorm wind gust.
The hail was reported on U.S. Highway 385 about five miles south of the Canadian River.
Half a dozen trees were reported down across different portions of the county resulting in numerous power outages.
Local fire department officials reported golfball size hail along U.S. Highway 62/83 on the Childress and Cottle County line south of Childress.
A Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site measured a 58 mph thunderstorm wind gust southwest of Guthrie. No damage was reported.
Emergency manager reported ping-pong sized hail near Corbet, southwest of Corsicana.
A social media report indicated damage to a small shed near the Verizon store just north of Loop 820 in Lake Worth, TX.

The tornado touched down at approximately 2039 CST six miles south southeast of White Deer and moved east southeast to around seven miles southeast of White Deer when it lifted around 2048 CST. The tornado remained over open country and the path length and path width were estimated. No damage or injuries were reported.
A tree was blown onto power lines at the intersection of FM 726 and Myrtle Road.
Three downed trees damaged a fence in the Sunset Lakes area.
A Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet station north of Roaring Springs observed a 58 mph severe thunderstorm wind gust.
A 70 year old woman was in critical condition after being struck in the head by a tree limb. The limb was blown down by high winds at a Denison Dam campground.
Quarter size hail was observed near the intersection of Beltway 8 and Interstate 45.
Large trees were knocked down at the intersection of 4th Street and Terrell Ave. Power lines were also knocked down in the city of Cooper.
Numerous trees and power lines downed as storms swept through the area.  A large tree also fell onto a house, causing significant damage.

Local law enforcement officials reported that damaging thunderstorm winds destroyed large tents and blew down utility poles at Mackenzie Reservoir in western Briscoe County. No injuries were reported.
Golf ball sized hail was reported in Grand Prairie.
Trees and large limbs were blown down.
According to news sources, a fire sparked by a lightning strike caused major damage to a home near Timarron Country Club in the city of Southlake, TX.
A Tempest weather station recorded a wind gust of 63 mph.
A storage building was blown over by high winds.

Tree and roof damage was reported throughout the Frankston area. The roof of a restaurant was also damaged including loss of shingles, partial decking removal and collapse of portions of the awning. One tree fell onto a manufactured house, killing two adults in the home. A post event assessment determined 70-90 mph winds caused the damage.
A helicopter was spun around and a boarding stairway was blown down the tarmac. The KBPT ASOS registered a wind gust of 56 mph before the sensor stopped reporting.

The Booker Fire Department reported lots of hail damage in Booker due to tennis ball size hail. Car windows and the windows of businesses were broken...most roofs of buildings sustained hail damage...and a large trampoline was reported to be in a tree. The time of the damage was estimated to be between 1645 and 1715 CST.

Much of the roof was blown off a home, another home lost a chimney, an outbuilding was destroyed, and fences and large tree limbs were blown down in the area along Hedgcoxe Rd between Iola Dr and Freeland Dr.
The hail nearly covered the ground.
A wind gust of 62 mph was reported at the Dyess Air Force Base ASOS.
Hail was reported at Geneva.
Nickel size hail fell in the town of Gordonville.

In Opelika, two two-hundred year-old oak trees were split in half and another was uprooted.  Large limbs from the downed trees were thrown across the yard, on the roof of a house, and on top of a storage building.  One resident said that their front door was blown open, and the male owner was not able to pull it shut again until the wind subsided.  The cost to haul away the oak trees and repair the roof of the house was estimated at $20,000.  Also in the same area, a carport was blown off, the car inside the carport was shifted about four feet, and several trees were leveled.  In Cross Roads, the elementary school had limbs strewn across the football field.  A nearby house had its roof damaged, tin was blown off of a storage building, and numerous trees were knocked down, including a 100 year-old peach tree.  Some of the trees had their tops sheared off.
A tree was downed across FM Road 843.
A power line was reported down.

Results from this survey indicated that a tornado began just east of US Highway 35 south of Fort Stockton in rural central Pecos County. This tornado was documented by numerous observers, quickly developing into a photogenic stovepipe before becoming increasingly wrapped in rain. The tornado slowly moved southeast, before completely wrapping in rain and likely dissipating. This tornado occurred over mainly open terrain only causing damage to vegetation and a few wooden electrical power poles in the area. This tornado was rated as a mid-range EF-2 with maximum wind speeds of 125 MPH given the degree of damage to these wooden power poles which were snapped cleanly near the base. Property damage cost amount is an estimation.

A wet microburst affected a portion of rural Lynn County between O'Donnell and Tahoka. A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near O'Donnell measured severe wind gusts from 1508 CST through 1515 CST. A peak wind gust of 62 mph was measured at 1515 CST. Additionally, an NWS cooperative weather observer reported roof damage to a barn as well as crop damage from wind-driven small hail.
A trained spotter reported quarter sized hail in Quinlan, TX.
Hen egg size hail was observed.

The third and final tornado from a cyclic tornadic supercell occurred for about one minute over open land in northeast Dickens County. No damage survey was conducted as the tornado remained over undeveloped land.
An amateur radio operator estimated the thunderstorm wind gusts near Four Way.
Relayed via social media. Hailfall likely occurred prior to report (1720-1730 CST).
Dime sized hail was reported in Plano.
The second of two brief landspout tornadoes occurred near Lubbock Preston Smith International Airport began around 1546 CDT and lasted until 1553 CDT. No damage was reported.
Storm chaser reported half dollar sized hail on Highway 44 northwest of Freer.
A penny-size hail report was relayed by the media.
The Emergency Operations Center reported quarter sized hail four to five miles west of Seminole.
A large tree was downed on a home on Oak Isle Drive.  There were no report of injuries.
A funnel cloud was sighted near the Woodlands.

An EF-2 tornado affected Collin and Fannin Counties from west of Blue Ridge to northwest of Bailey with damage noted around the northwestern side of Leonard. The tornado touched down on the west side of Blue Ridge along FM 545 where tree damage and structure damage was noted. Moving northeast the tornado impacted the athletic fields near the junior high and high school with several free standing light poles bent near the ground, the complete collapse of the brick dug outs near the baseball field, and damage to trees, fences, and other equipment around the property. The tornado appeared to strengthen as it struck 3 manufactured homes just east of the schools where two of the single wide trailers rolled, and the walls and roof of the homes became separated from the undercarriage. The next notable damage occurred in northeast Collin County where a double wide manufactured home rolled and collapsed leading to 1 injury from occupant entrapment. The narrow path of tree and structural damage continued across the county line into Fannin County to the west and north of Leonard. The tornado continued to do damage to several structures including a water plant and several single family homes until it lifted near State Highway 11 west of Bailey. Maximum estimated winds were 125 mph.
A supercell thunderstorm moving through Concho County produced its third tornado of the evening northwest of Eden. This tornado moved over open country.
Dallas-Fort Worth Broadcast Media reported quarter sized hail in the town of Ennis.
Emergency Manager reported golf ball size hail in Groesbeck.
A trained spotter reported golf ball size hail just northeast of Donna, TX.
Relayed social media images show a house fire caused by a suspected lightning strike. Event time is estimated.
Ping pong ball size hail fell in the Purley community.
A home northwest of Tyler, Texas sustained minor wind damage on FM. 724.
Severe thunderstorm produced golf ball sized hail in the town of Caldwell.

Local newspapers and utility officials reported that a lightning strike on a home in Tahoka resulted in a ruptured natural gas line beneath the home.  The leak was detected and repaired without incident, but crews reported that a small hole and burn mark were present in the gas pipe when it was replaced the next day.  Other electronics and appliances inside the home were additionally destroyed by the lightning strike.
Hail fell at the intersection of Hwy. 21 and FM 3121.
A thunderstorm moved across Brewster County and produced a 58 mph wind gust at the Big Bend Portable RAWS station.

NWS employee reported trees and powerlines down on the west and north side of Robstown. Shingle and wooden roof damage occurred to homes. The damaging straight-line winds occurred after the tornado moved through the northwest edge of the city.
This report was received from mPING.
Some siding was blown off a building just off the southwest loop in Tyler, Texas.
Several funnel clouds reported halfway to ground, just west of Freer.
An emergency manager reported 1.25 inch hail near Huffman at FM 1960 and FM2100.
The general public reported several storage sheds were damaged.
Quarter sized hail in Rhea.
A traveler on U.S. Highway 285 reported golfball size hail.
A National Weather Service cooperative observer reported nickel size hail and wind gusts estimated near 60 mph at Vigo Park. No damage was reported.
Reported via mPing.
A trained spotter reported a roof ripped off of a barn.

Outflow from thunderstorms to the east produced wind gusts in excess of 45 MPH on the campus of The University of Texas-Dallas, in the city of Richardson. This outflow caused the collapse of a crane which was being dismantled at a construction project. Two workers, a 58 year old male, and a 50 year old male died in the crane collapse.
Residents reported this tornado was on the ground for about 10 minutes 2 miles west northwest of May.  The twister was also videotaped and posted on Facebook.
Tennis ball size hail was reported 2 miles east of Nocona.
Several trees and powerlines were blown down due to high winds near the 2000 block of Old Maypearl Rd.
Reported in downtown Corpus Christi by Fire Dept.
Numerous reports of baseball sized hail were reported by the public in Odessa. This hail broke windows on cars and homes. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

A local television station relayed pictures of hail estimated to be 2 inches in diameter that fell near the intersection of Western and Cherry in Northwest Amarillo. The pictures also indicated that car windows were damaged as a result of the hail.

The tornado was reported by the Carson County Sheriff's Office at 1730 CST about seven miles southeast of McBride. The tornado crossed Texas State Highway 207 as it moved generally east or southeast north of Panhandle. At least eleven power poles were snapped and were facing east. The Carson County Sheriff's Office stopped all northbound traffic on Highway 207. The tornado lifted approximately 1731 CST about seven miles north of Panhandle. No injuries were reported.
Trees were downed in the Ace area.
Trees were blown down and windows were broken in the northeast part of Zavala County from Batesville to the Uvalde and Frio County lines.
Twenty-four to twenty-six train cars were derailed by high thunderstorm winds near the intersection of Highway 31 and SE CR 0080 in Powell, stretching west along the railroad towards Corsicana.
Quarter sized hail was reported on Business Highway 287 in downtown Waxahachie.
Dime to nickel sized hail was reported 1 mile south of Neylandville.
Thunderstorm winds blew down a large flag pole and a few large limbs off trees.

A supercell thunderstorm which developed over portions of northern Hale and southern Swisher Counties evolved into a small convective complex which effectively trained over Interstate 27. As a result, vast amounts of large hail and very heavy rainfall resulted in dangerous travel conditions.||Hail up to the size of half dollars accumulated to depths greater than half a foot in places along Interstate 27 between Kress and Tulia. The hail combined with nearly six inches of rainfall produced significant flooding. A local law enforcement official was quoted as saying that it was just like an ice jam...it looked like North Dakota, referring to recent national headlines concerning historic ice jam flooding in that state. Newspaper reports indicate that more than 50 vehicles were stranded by hail and high water. Several motorists were rescued from  stalled vehicles by boat and fire engines. As a result, local officials were forced to close portions of Interstate 27 until hail and flood waters receded sufficiently around 07:00 CST on the 17th. Combined damages from hail and flood were estimated near $1 million.
Dime to quarter size hail covering the road at Highway 60 and 207.

A rancher in southern Borden County, while conversing with National Weather Service meteorologists conducting a damage survey, described tennis ball size hail that fell at his residence for at least thirty minutes. The ranch house is located near Farm to Market Road 1785 west of Lake J.B. Thomas. The hail pounded crops in the area as the man and his wife watched a large tornado (see the next event entry) track to the southeast and south of their home.
Hail fell for about two minutes covering the ground.
Trained spotter reported tree limbs being snapped off, and ending up 2 to 3 blocks before  landing on the ground. Also, power lines are arcing.
Golfball sized hail fell near Greenwood.
A personal weather station near Tilden measure wind gusts up to 65 mph.
Fannin County Sheriff's Department reported roof damage and trees down in Bonham, TX.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail west of Harper. Quarter was the largest size with most of the hail being dime size.
Multiple power lines and transmission lines down throughout the city of Driscoll.
The public reported hen egg size hail three miles west of Maryneal. The large hail broke windows out of a pickup truck.
An awning was torn off a home on Farm to Market 2328 just north of Queen City, Texas.  Windows were blown out of the home as well.
A truck driver reported that the windshield of his rig was broken from the large hail and the damage occurred near mile marker thirty-five on Interstate 40. No injuries were reported.

Several reports were received from social media and storm spotters of very large hail in Silverton. The largest hail size was estimated at 3.25 inches in diameter. Numerous vehicles were damaged by the hail.
A 60 MPH wind gust was recorded.
A Skywarn spotter reported half dollar size hail in Aiken. The hail was also reported to have damaged cotton fields in the area.
A swath of tennis ball size hail was observed from about three miles northwest of Post to about five miles north of Post. No damage was reported.
Numerous trees and power lines were downed across Red River County.
Eastland County Sheriff's Department reported quarter-sized hail in the city of Ranger, TX.
The roof was torn off a building under construction in the Coolidge area.
Power lines were downed near the intersection of West Norris Street and West Loop Street.
A trained spotter reported quarter sized hail in Celeste, TX.
A social media report indicated golf ball size hail near the intersection of Stratford Drive and 15th Street just west of the city of Plano, TX.
A thunderstorm produced penny size hail in Schertz.
Power lines were reported blown down due the high winds.

Emergency manager reported that the Senior Center in Springtown suffered damage from an estimated 85 mph winds. These winds lifted the carport awning off the front of the building and peeled the attached metal and wood paneling roof back at that location. Part of the brick facade was also knocked off on one corner. The wood covering of another covered patio was partially separated from the brick columns. Also in Springtown, a brand new mobile home was also destroyed, but its location could not be confirmed.
Hail was reported in Henderson, Texas.
Numerous trees and powerlines were downed across the city.
Reported by School Net site at River Road.

This tornado caused mostly intermittent EF0 damage along a one mile path. There was a small area of EF1 rated damage at the start of the path with a brick facade on a multi-story office building failing and nearby tree trunks snapped.
Golfball-size hail in Goodrich.
Amateur radio operator reported quarter hail 5 miles west of Centerville.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail at Lake Side Dr. and Lake Side Cove in Leander.
Power lines were blown down.
Baseball sized hail was measured in Walnut Springs.

A supercell thunderstorm that developed along a retreating dryline in Deaf Smith and Oldham Counties tracked to the northeast across the southern Texas Panhandle. The supercell entered the city limits of Amarillo during the late night hours of the 28th. This supercell thunderstorm produced copious amounts of large destructive hail across the city. An off duty National Weather Service employee reported golf ball size hail at their residence. This hail caused damage to neighboring homes and vehicles. The supercell continued traveling in a northeastern direction which took it out of the Amarillo city limits shortly before midnight on the 29th.
Mesonet station reported a 61 mph wind gust.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet station in New Home.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Hart measured severe wind gusts from 1758 CST through 1802 CST. A peak wind gust of 69 mph was measured at 1800 CST.

The first of two hail storms to affect the Marfa area struck at 23:00 CST. Large hail ranging in size from ping pong balls to golfballs fell along U.S. Highway 67 near the city. This initial storm is believed to be responsible for minor roof damage, however, a more significant hail storm impacted Marfa just an hour later and likely produced a majority of the damage.

Waxahachie Fire Department reported that 5 houses were struck by lightning around 8 PM CDT in the city of Waxahachie. Four of the houses caught fire with varying amounts of damage. One home suffered $80,000 worth of damage, while another house only had minor damage and suffered $1,000 worth of damage. The two other homes suffered $150,000 and $40,000 of damage.
Horizon City got hit a second time overnight with large hail, this time ping pong ball size.
There were large 6 inches in diameter branches down on Farm to Market Road 584 south of San Angelo Regional Airport. The time was estimated on radar.
Several trees were downed near  Highway 21 East and County Road 331.
Half dollar size hail fell on Farm to Market Road 1797 near Tatum. Report via the KLTV Facebook page.
Report from mPING: Half Dollar (1.25 in.).

A law enforcement officer observed a brief tornado over open range land in extreme southeastern Dickens County shortly after 21:30 CST. The tornado was associated with a small radar reflectivity derived supercell structure that evolved on the southern flank of the previously tornadic storm near Girard (Kent County). No damage was reported.
Dime sized hail was reported by the COOP Observer in Centerville.
A metal fence was blown out of the ground and into the roadway.
Penny size hail fell at the intersection of Farm-to-Market Road 315 and County Road 441 about 10 miles north of Palestine.
Quarter size hail was reported in Sanger.
A large tree downed near the intersection of County Road 3206 and County Road 3155 just west of Mount Enterprise.
Emergency management reported trees down on County Road 4079.
Damage to several roofs from the large hail.
Six power line poles were snapped. The damage was all in the same direction, towards the south. Wind gust speed and property damage cost are estimations.
Trees were downed across Hwy. 135 near Jacksonville, as well as on CR. 3305 and one on Kilo Monument Road and on FM. 177.

This is a continuation of the Smith County tornado, which crossed Highway 80 between Brimley Lake and Lake Hawkins, snapping and uprooting additional trees. The Ozarka Water Bottling Plant north of Hawkins sustained major roof damage consistent with EF-1 winds estimated between 95-105 mph. More trees were snapped and uprooted as the tornado continued northeast and passed just east of Holly Lake and into Upshur County.
This thunderstorm wind was reported by law enforcement.

A tornado touched down in the Rayburn Country community, blowing|down multiple trees on the golf course and surrounding properties.|The tornado ended at US Hwy 96. The estimated peak wind was 105 MPH.
Golfball size hail fell in Ozona.
Power poles were reported down near Highway 148 and FM 2332.
Quarter sized hail was reported in Cisco.
Late report...68 mph thunderstorm wind gust received from broadcast media.
Tree down blocking street.

Scattered thunderstorms developed across Deaf Smith County during the evening hours of the 12th. As a storm approached the town of Hereford (Deaf Smith County), the KVII schoolnet site one mile north-northwest of Hereford recorded a 60 mph downburst. After producing this downburst the storm continued to move eastward across the county.
Penny to quarter sized hail was observed near the Highway 6 and FM 529 intersection.
A public report indicated half-dollar sized hail approximately 2 miles east-southeast of the city of Irving, TX.

A long track multi-vortex EF-2 tornado with peak winds estimated between 120-125 mph touched down just east of Lindale near the intersection of County Road 499 and County Road 4100. The tornado traveled northeast resulting in extensive damage to trees along its path. The tornado was strongest between Farm To Market Road 16 and Farm To Market Road 2710, where a cell phone tower, a house, and two mobile homes sustained major damage from estimated EF-2 tornado winds. This tornado remained on the ground as it crossed a heavily wooded area and the Sabine River into Southeast Wood County.

There were numerous reports of damage through much of the southern half of the county from near Carmine to Brenham to the Brazos River as a series of severe thunderstorms moved eastward across the county.
Personnel at the Bula Gin reported quarter size hail that lasted about one half hour.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that knocked down a large tree limb on Thomaston River Rd.
Nine total fatalities occurred due to the derecho across the City of Houston. One was from a fire from a lightning strike which is entered separately.
Golfball size hail fell just northeast of Longview.
The public reported thunderstorm winds estimated to exceed 60 mph.  The winds were accompanied by penny size hail.  No damage was reported.
The Jack County sheriff's office relayed a report of hail damage. Several vehicles had broken windshields between Bryson and Jacksboro.
A public report indicated a 12-inch tree blown over approximately 4 miles south-southwest of Ovilla, TX.
Several trees and power lines were blown down in Linden.
MPing report.
A report of a thunderstorm that produced golf ball size hail in Terrel Hills was passed to us by one of our media partners, KSAT12.
A thunderstorm produced lightning that caused an oil field tank battery to catch fire near Sweet Home.
A thunderstorm produced hail up to the size of golf balls. A picture on Twitter showed several ping pong ball to golf ball size hail stones.

Straight-line winds caused damage along White Lane Road in south Haslet. Several trees were snapped or knocked over, two lean-tos that house horses were destroyed, a horse trailer was overturned, and an air conditioning unit was tossed across a yard. Other outbuildings, barns, and sheds were damaged.  Five acres of fencing was also knocked down on one property and part of the trim of a house was torn off.
An off duty NWS employee measured quarter size hail around the intersection of 42nd Street and Indiana Avenue in the city of Lubbock.
Spotter estimated 70 mph winds 3 miles east of Laredo.
Amateur radio spotters reported trees knocked down in Krum.
Local law enforcement officials reported that thunderstorm winds blew a deer stand across the parking lot of a business and across U.S. Highway 287.
City of Pharr Emergency Manager reported golf ball size hail south of Pharr.
A trained spotter reported that damaging thunderstorm winds knocked down trees 1.5 miles west-northwest of Potosi.
A trained spotter observed a tornado northwest of Loving. The tornado occurred in open fields, and produced little to no damage.
The wind gust occurred at the WeatherFlow station TXSUGAR66.
An emergency management official and NWS cooperative weather observer reported hail ranging in size from baseballs to 4.50 inches in diameter.

NWS damage survey information found that a tornado briefly touched down at 0449 pm CDT 3 miles north of Borger. The tornado was rated EF-0 due to minor damage to homes, with roof and shingle damage noted.
A thunderstorm moved across Ector County and produced wind damage in Odessa.  Twenty power poles were blown down at Yukon and Grandview in Odessa.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Numerous two to twelve inch tree branches blown down...two willow trees uprooted...and two irrigation pivots overturned and damaged by the high winds at the Pheasant Trails Golf Course. Also...two aluminum garage doors were blown in and badly damaged. One house lost many shingles on the north facing side...a fence with metal posts was partially blown down...and an aluminum roof on a storage shed was ripped up.
A storm spotter reported damage to his home and several of his vehicles. This damage was caused by baseball size hail.
Power poles and large trees were snapped in the northeast portion of Richland Hills. A carwash building collapsed along Blvd 10.
Storm Spotters reported nickel size hail along U.S. Highway 82 near the Texas and New Mexico state line southwest of Plains.
A report of quarter size hail was received through mPING.
The Armstrong County Emergency Manager estimated thunderstorm wind gusts just north of Claude, Texas, however there was no damage and no reports of injuries or fatalities.
A wind gust to 61 MPH was reported by the Automated Weather Observation System at the Granbury, TX airport.
Trees were blown down on I-20 at Exit 604 near Hallsville.

The tornado touched down in northern Roberts County around 659 pm CDT, crossed the Roberts/Ochiltree county line around 704 pm CDT and the Ochiltree/Lipscomb county line around 719 pm CDT before dissipating through a rope out process by 733 pm CDT. Damage from the tornado consisted mostly of damage to trees, power lines and |oil/natural gas field equipment and sheds. There was also two manufactured homes being transported via truck the were blown off Highway 83. The tornado was noted to be larger and possibly stronger in inaccessible open county to the southwest of|the location where it was measured to be around 1/2 mile wide and rated an EF2 by the survey team.

A NWS Storm Survey determined an EF-0 tornado began approximately 3.75 miles east-northeast of Elm Mott. This tornado had a path length of approximately a third of a mile and an estimated width of 50 yards. Some tree damage occurred with this tornado and winds were estimated near 75 mph.
Report from MPing.
Penny size hail fell on the Gaines, Texas/Lea, New Mexico county line just east of Hobbs.
Public reported golf ball sized hail 2 miles NE of Arlington via mPING.
A spotter measured a 63 MPH wind gust west of Texas Motor Speedway.
Fire and Rescue indicated half-dollar sized hail near the intersection of White Avenue and and Hardin Blvd in the city of Mckinney, TX.
An amateur radio operator relayed a report of quarter sized hail in Irene.
A thunderstorm produced hail ranging from quarter to golf ball size. The largest hail fell along Highway 183 in Anderson Mill.
Tree blown down 2 miles north of Mission Bend (FM 1464&Red Timber).
Thunderstorm winds downed trees in Weches.
There were numerous reports of trees and power lines blown down.
Numerous trees were blown down throughout the western half of the county.
Trees were blown down in several locations across Lamar County.

Scattered thunderstorms over Deaf Smith County merged and intensified during the evening hours of the 17th. This intensification was brief, and as the merged thunderstorm diminished, a localized downburst of 60 mph was measured by the West Texas Mesonet 11 miles west-northwest of Bootleg (Deaf Smith County).

This EF-1 was the third brief tornado with the larger mesocyclone associated with the HP supercell which moved across La Porte and Morgans Point. This couplet |was well defined on the Houston Hobby terminal doppler radar which spun up quickly|along the north side of strong westerly outflow winds from the initial couplet that was responsible for two earlier weak tornadoes near and in parts of La Porte. This tornado was witnessed to start near the railroad tracks near Highway 146 and it tracked east southeastward across the Barbours Cut Port Facility and parts of Morgans Point. Much of the more significant damage was to industrial areas around the Port complex. Large steel storage tanks were bent inward from the wind, and many large, metal shipping containers were toppled over. The tornado lifted near the eastern end of Morgans Point near the Ship Channel. Estimated peak winds were around 105 mph.
Reported at Waco EOC station.
Nickel size hail fell on Highway 21 and West Loop 224.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 75 mph that blew down trees and power lines in Elgin.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail northwest of Briggs.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail near FM78 and Springfield Rd in Kirby.
Roof blown off of a small extension on the west side of a building near KFDX studio.
Hailstones were estimated by the member of the public to be just under two inches.

It was determined that storm damage east of New Summerfield, Texas was consistent with that of an EF-1 tornado.  The most extensive damage was located west of County Road 2274 between County Road 235 and County Road 4504.  The damage consisted of several trees snapped and/or uprooted.
A thunderstorm moved across Midland County and produced a 64 mph wind gust at the Midland International Airport.  No damage was reported.
Large hailstones ranging in size from dimes to quarters covered the ground and stripped the leaves from trees at a rural residence on the Andrews/Martin County line just off of Highway 176.

Semi-tractor trailer overturned onto another vehicle on Interstate 45 at FM 646. Winds also blew down a few large concrete wall structures at a construction site at the same intersection. Numerous fences and store signs were also blown down in and around League City and Dickinson.
Dime size hail reported in Gallatin, Texas.
Golfball to baseball size hail was reported.
Trees and power lines blown down by high winds.
Large tree limbs were snapped causing damage to several roofs in the Edro area.|

Severe thunderstorms moved into Lee County in the late afternoon.  They began producing severe winds as they approached US77, knocking down trees and power lines from near Lincoln eastward to near Dime Box.  The storm also destroyed outbuildings and damaged several mobile homes along the path.  Near Dime Box the storms destroyed several barns, with the damage estimated near $200,000.
Large tree limbs greater than 2 inches in diameter were downed southwest of Burke, Texas.
Power lines knocked down in and around Bonham.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail two miles south of Canyon Lake.

The collision of two outflow boundaries caused the development of thunderstorms over the southern Texas Panhandle during the evening hours of the 14th. This allowed storms to quickly intensify slowly move southward across the southern Texas Panhandle. As the storms neared the town of Bootleg (Deaf Smith County), the West Texas Mesonet 11 miles west-northwest of Bootleg (Deaf Smith County) reported a 61 mph downburst. These storms weakening as sunset approached, and did not produce any further severe weather after sunset.
The Jim Hogg Sheriffs Department reported golf ball size hail fell on Highway 16 approximately 10 miles south of the city of Hebbronville as a severe thunderstorm  moved through the area.
Ping pong ball sized hail was reported 5 miles east of Gordon near Interstate 20.
58 knot winds were observed at Randolph AFB as severe thunderstorm winds knocked down power lines between Garden Ridge and Randolph AFB.
Reported via mPing.
The thunderstorm wind gust was measured at the Amarillo ASOS site located six miles east northeast of Amarillo...or at the Rick Husband International Airport.
Trees downed, barns and buildings damaged along Highway 36 between Wallis and Orchard.
There were power poles reported blown down in Roscoe by the Nolan County Sheriff's Office.
Numerous trees were down from the Novice community northeastward into Red River County.
Knox City (KNOX) Mesonet observation.
Wind-driven large hail damaged numerous homes and automobiles.
A car wash that was being renovated was blown down onto a van, fences, telephone poles, and two storage shed were blown down.
Large tree limbs and some fencing were blown down.
An amateur radio operator relayed a report of ping pong ball size hail at the hospital in Ballinger.
City of Combes shared a picture of a landspout northeast of Woods Road just before 3 PM CDT. Radar estimated time and location.

A National Weather Service damage survey concluded an EF-0 tornado occurred in far northern Caldwell County. It started near Rolling Ridge Rd. to the northeast of the Two Wishes Polo Club. As the weak circulation was moving to the northeast into the intersection of Rolling Ridge Rd. and Schuelke Rd., the small tornado hit what used to be an old school (which is being converted into a residential home). Nobody was at the home at the time of the small tornado hitting the property. This was a very small tornado that was on the ground for about a minute. The time of the tornado was determined from radar data. The tornado path length was 0.49 miles, and maximum winds were estimated at 65 mph.
Video showed quarter size hail near the intersection of La Homa Road and Mile 7 Road north of Mission.

Emergency management reported significant damage in Leonard with downed trees, trees on vehicles, and damages to the Leonard ISD campuses. Damage estimates to the school facilities were near 1.5 million.
Dime size hail reported in the Hideaway Community.
Emergency management reported a few trees down in the central part of Sherman, TX.
A tree was blown down near Broaddus.
Golf ball size hail reported 7 miles northeast of Tyler.

An isolated severe storm dropped hail up to tennis ball size across extreme northwest McCulloch County. The hail broke all of the double pane windows and a skylight on one side of a house, allowing rain water to enter.
Near golf ball sized hail for nearly 10 minutes.

Eleven power poles were reported down between County Road 242 and County Road 264 along FM 1611. Time estimated from radar. Wind speeds were estimated to be 100 mph. Property cost damage is an estimation.
A member of the public reported 1 inch hail in Point Blank.

NWS survey team concluded that a downburst of straight-line winds impacted Kingsville during the early evening. Damaging winds were observed across north Kingsville with the highest concentration of damage along Corral Avenue. Wind speeds were estimated between 80 to 90 mph. Widespread tree damaged occurred along with several large trees being uprooted. Power poles were snapped and moderate to major damage occurred to 15 structures. Wind speeds decreased as the winds propagated to the southeast. Winds were measured at 77 mph by the Naval Air Station Kingsville ASOS. The damage path was 2 miles wide and 9 miles in length.
A storm chaser reported baseball size hail 7 miles west-northwest of Voca.
Report from mPING: Half Dollar (1.25 in.).
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that blew a metal storage building into power lines and knocked down the power poles on Tolle Rd. near Steele High School in Cibolo.
Dime to nickel size hail fell in the Kildare community.

A thunderstorm produced around one inch of rain in 30 minutes that filled a drainage ditch near the intersection of Hwy 281 and Bitters Rd. in northern San Antonio. A homeless man was camping in the ditch at the time and was washed away and drowned.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that knocked down a tree along the Rio Grande south of Comstock.
Damage in and around the Houston area from this squall line included trees down (several on vehicles), fences damaged and extensive roof damage to several area businesses and apartments.
A  thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that knocked down some large tree limbs between Manheim and Giddings.
A utility pole was blown down on FM 129 near Brazos.
Public reported half dollar size hail.
A thunderstorm produced three inch hail on the campus of the University of the Incarnate Word.
Quarter size hail and 50 mph winds were reported in the city of Campbell.
Two broken power poles on Railroad Street.  A stop sign was uprooted along CR 136.  Broken power poles were reported at Hwy 181 and CR 3677.
Emergency management reported power poles being snapped from a large tree branch falling on them. This occurred along County Road 735 between 5 and 8 miles south of the city of Groesbeck, TX.
Penny sized hail was observed 5 miles north of Hereford.
Part of the metal roof of a manufactured home was torn up by strong thunderstorm winds.
Travel trailer damaged...fences blown over...power lines blown down and metal sheds destroyed due to thunderstorm wind gusts.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 65 mph which caused the roof of the Lifetime Fitness Center to partially collapse.
Sheriff's office reported trees and power lines down.
Nickel size hail fell 2 miles northwest of Stephenville.

Downburst winds around 80 mph lofted the roof from the Allsup's convenience store in Petersburg.  The roof landed on an adjacent mobile home, causing moderate damage to the residence.  Much of the store suffered water damage from the ensuing heavy rainfall.

Severe wind gusts generated by dry microbursts accompanied high-based thunderstorm activity over the Lubbock vicinity around 16:00 CST on the 15th. A 63 mph gust was initially measured by the Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site at Reese Center at 15:45 CST and a 60 mph gust was later measured there at 16:00 CST. The parent convection and associated winds spread northeastward over the Lubbock area and a 59 mph gust was measured by the Automated Surface Observing System at Lubbock's Preston Smith International Airport at 16:17 CST. No damage were reported.
A 60 MPH wind gust was reported east of De Leon.
KTXS TV studio on the northwest side of Abilene measured a 76 mph wind gust.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet.
Report received of quarter size hail from MPing.
Thunderstorm winds were responsible for broken windows approximately 6 miles south-southwest of Midlothian.

A rapidly intensifying thunderstorm produced an intense downburst that struck the west half of the city of Ralls before continuing south for about one mile south of Ralls.  In addition to disrupting power to 2400 people in the area for much of the night and inflicting various degrees of damage to many homes and buildings, three large cotton compress buildings on the west side of town were completely destroyed with debris strewn up to 1/4 mile south of Highway 82.  The extent of debris required the closure of the 4-lane highway for nearly one hour until debris could be cleared for passage.  A nearby power sub-station belonging to Excel was heavily damaged and a total of 42 power poles were downed.  Radar and debris patterns observed from the NWS storm survey revealed a classic downburst signature with destructive wind gusts determined to be as high as 90 mph, with sustained speeds likely ranging between 50 and 70 mph for roughly two minutes.

A microburst occurred over Roby at approximately 730 PM CDT. Two large, south-facing windows at the Roby City Hall were blown in and several trees were uprooted within the city limits. An outbuilding was destroyed on the south side of town.

A supercell thunderstorm that developed along a retreating dryline in Deaf Smith and Oldham Counties tracked to the northeast across the southern Texas Panhandle. The supercell entered the city limits of Amarillo during the late night hours of the 28th. This supercell thunderstorm produced copious amounts of large destructive hail across the city. The supercell produced a mixture of pea to half dollar size hail at the National Weather Service office. This hail caused varying degrees of damage to vehicles and structures in the area. The supercell continued traveling in a northeastern direction which took it out of the Amarillo city limits shortly before midnight on the 29th.
Hen egg to tennis ball sized hail reported following at this time.
A social media report indicated tennis ball size hail in McKinney, TX.
Social media photos indicated a mobile home was destroyed between Lingleville and Stephenville. No injuries were reported.

An amateur radio operator reported that the Isla Grande Resort weatherbug station recorded a peak wind gust of 59 miles per hour when a thunderstorm moved through the resort during the passage of a cold front.
Occurred near the airport.
Sheriff reported quarter sized hail.
Reports relayed by local broadcast media and on social media showed hail up to two inches in diameter. No damage was reported.
A thunderstorm produced two inch hail between Roosevelt Ave. and S. Presa St. near Robert B. Green Elementary School in San Antonio.
A DPS trooper traveling on Interstate 10 reported a "long and skinny" tornado east of Van Horn.  Radar indicated a strong thunderstorm in the area with cloud tops to 50,000 feet.
A photo was received of a weak landspout tornado near the town of Clint. No damage done.
Numerous trees were downed throughout the northern part of Wood County, especially in the Yantis and Winnsboro communities.
Penny size hail was estimated in Claytonville with no damage reported.
Broadcast media sent a picture from a viewer showing ping-pong sized hail near Burton short stop and Burton ISD.
Half dollar sized hail fell at Highway 180 and Old Millsap Highway, approximately 5 miles west of Weatherford.
Public reported quarter size hail.
At least one tree was uprooted and another tree splintered in the Bluffview Estates on Richland Chambers Lake.
This tornado seen by a Knox County DPS officer caused significant damage to a shed and downed several power poles northwest of Knox City. Numerous trees were also uprooted in this area.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Paducah measured severe wind gusts from 0215 CST through 0221 CST. A peak wind gust of 61 mph was measured at 0216 CST.
60 mph wind gust Kirby and Westheimer.
Quarter to hen egg sized hail was reported in Evant over a ten minute period.
Emergency management reported downed trees brought down powerlines on College Street between 9th and Bledsoe St in the town of Gunter, TX.
A lightning strike is believed to have started a fire that burned the saltwater disposal tanks on Highway 16 South.

A damage survey in Marion County found that a severe thunderstorms spawned an EF0 tornado northeast of Jefferson near Highway 248. The tornado snapped and uprooted several trees near Highway 248 northeast of Jefferson before lifting.
Trees and power outages were reported in the Spurger and Hillister areas.
CO-OP observer in Armstrong reported 5.12 inches of rainfall.
Damaging thunderstorm wind gusts of at least 60 mph knocked down Mesquite tree limbs that were four inches in diameter around Lohn.
Reported via mPing.
Public reported ping pong size hail.
Large tree limbs were blown down due to high winds.
A few reports of quarter size hail were noted on Facebook at Beauregard and Pierce.
Emergency management for the city of Lubbock reported that the left lane of southbound Interstate-27 was closed due to standing water on the roadway.
Ping pong ball size hail reported at West Grande Boulevard and Old Jacksonville Highway in South Tyler.
Time estimated from radar.
Measured 1.25 inch diameter hail and reported approximately 6 miles north-northeast of Gruver.
A report of quarter size hail in Claude was relayed by broadcast media.
Emergency management reported golf ball sized hail on Highway 81 approximately 2 miles north of Bowie, TX.
Nickel size hail fell 1 mile northwest of Stephenville.
Numerous tree limbs were blown down. A garage door was also blown in. Monetary damages were estimated.
Tree was blown down on the road near Delmar Drive and Lone Tree Road in Victoria.
An NWS cooperative weather observer reported golf ball size hail in Matador.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph uprooted some large Oak trees and damaged a mobile home and the roofs of several houses.
Truscott (TRUS) Mesonet observation.
A tree was downed on Floyd Evans Road and Old Town Road north of Elysian Fields.
A thunderstorm produced half dollar size hail southeast of La Vernia.

A brief tornado developed near a residence, doing minor damage.  The time of the tornado's formation was estimated from radar and the storm report from the owner of the home.  At approximately 17:35 pm CST, the tornado blew an old telephone antenna a couple hundred yards away.  It then blew a stack of wooden pallets 15 to 20 yards away.  In addition, several 5 inch limbs were broken off of trees.  The tornado lasted less than 2 minutes.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail in northeastern Burnet County.
Numerous reports were received of hail up to tennis ball size south of Ralls along Texas State Highway 207. No damage was reported.
The roof was reported blown off of a barn with additional tree and shingle damage in the town of Washburn. No injuries were reported.
Dallas Love Field (KDAL) measured a 66 MPH wind gust.
A lightning strike damaged a nursing home's fire alarm system.
The public reported slightly larger than baseball size hail in Noodle.
Large hail was reported at the Fandango Gas Plant.
Skywarn spotter reported three ten-inch tree branches snapped off tree in yard.
A spotter estimated a 60 MPH wind gust in Buffalo.
Up to nickel-size hail also occurred.
There were several broadcast media reports of golf ball sized hail near the community of Castor, in Mills County.
Broadcast media relayed a report of approximately ping pong ball size hail in Big Spring. Time estimated by radar.
Medina County Sheriff's Deputies reported heavy rain after the strong winds, followed by hail up to golfball-size, and then the winds began to diminish just before the tornado struck.
Nickle sized hail fell for 10 minutes on the southeast side of Victoria, near Business 59 and Loop 463.|
Golf ball size hail reported in Noonday.
Department of Public Safety reported a brief tornado south of Wills Point.  No damage was reported.

Measured by NGP ASOS.  Wind damage also observed on the JFK causeway, where four illumination heads on the illumination poles were damage, including one completely blown off.  Unable to confirm exact wind speed over the causeway, and structural integrity of illumination heads were in question according to engineers.
Two large trees were blown over roads along Lake Granbury.
Half dollar size hail fell in the Bagwell community.
A tree was blown onto a house in Spurger.
The Guadalupe Valley Electric Cooperative reported multiple power outages as a result of trees and tree limbs being knocked down on power lines during a severe thunderstorm.
A thunderstorm produced two inch hail between La Vernia and Sutherland Springs. The report was from social media.
Several trees were downed, including one that fell on a house and another on a car in Atlanta, Texas.  There were no reports of injuries.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that broke some three inch tree limbs off Vance Jackson Rd. in northwestern San Antonio.
Fort Hood soldiers reported penny-sized hail near the intersection of Murphy Road and 53rd street.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail west of Liberty Hill.
Quarter size hail fell near Kilgore.
A NWS employee reported intermittent quarter-size hail for three minutes. No damage was reported.
A trained spotter estimated a wind gust to 60 mph.
Trees and power lines down near the intersection of County Road 404 and Neely Trail.
A thunderstorm produced half dollar size hail near Lake Amistad.
Trained spotters reported golf ball sized hail at the rest stop on U.S. 287 northwest of Decatur.
Hen egg size hail fell just northeast of Kilgore near the Rolling Meadows community.
A large tree was downed on a wheelchair ramp at the Perryville Methodist Church in the Perryville community. Trees were also downed nearby on FM 2088 near County Road 852.
Mping report received.
Reported at Plains Boulevard and Western Street.
Heavy rain fell near Alpine with three quarters to near an inch falling in one hour and fifteen minutes.
Hail fell in the community of Leesburg.
An amateur radio operator reported baseball size hail just east of Prosper.
An emergency manager reported quarter sized hail west of Grapeland.
Eighty-foot power poles were destroyed by high winds along U.S. Highway 60 just southwest of Hereford. The time of the damage was estimated based on radar and the wind speed was also estimated.

An intense supercell thunderstorm, which previously produced a tornado earlier in the evening, produced a large hail swath from approximately six miles south of Hale Center to Petersburg. Numerous reports of hail were received along this path length. Hail sizes ranged from quarter size at the initial report near the intersection of Interstate 27 and Farm to Market Road 37 at 2131 CST to three inches in diameter about five miles northwest of Petersburg at 2157 CST.
The public reported ping pong ball to baseball size hail.

A supercell thunderstorm that developed along a retreating dryline in Deaf Smith and Oldham Counties tracked to the northeast across the southern Texas Panhandle. The supercell entered the city limits of Amarillo during the late night hours of the 28th. This supercell thunderstorm produced copious amounts of large destructive hail across the city. The supercell brought a mix of pea to quarter size hail to the National Weather Service office (Potter County). The hail nearly covered the ground and caused minor damage to vehicles of employees. The supercell continued traveling in a northeastern direction which took it out of the Amarillo city limits shortly before midnight on the 29th.
Trees were downed along FM 360.
Frisco Fire Department reported a small fire in the attic of a home in the city of Frisco. The fire was caused by lightning and resulted in approximately 1,000 dollars in damage.

Broadcast media reported that several homes suffered shingle and fence damage in Josephine. The public reported that similar damage was also reported in the Magnolia Point neighborhood on the south side of Josephine.
Public reported quarter size hail.
Dime to nickel size hail fell in Texarkana.
Law enforcement estimated golfball size hail ten miles north of Childress along Highway 83. No damage was reported.
Half dollar and larger sized hail was reported in the Hubbard Creek area via Facebook.
Report of hail via mPing.
A large tree was downed on FM. 1650.
Half dollar size hail occurred in the town of Wixon Valley.
Trees downed on CR 434.
A patrol car along the Nolan and Fisher county line ran into golfball size hail that did considerable damage to the car.
Trees and power lines were downed around Crockett and the surrounding communities. There was a report of minor deck damage to a residence off of Highway 7.
Amateur radio operator reported 2 inch sized hail in Hico.
KWES reported tennis ball-sized hail in the city of Fort Stockton, TX. The time is estimated from radar.
A tree was blown over onto a home in Jacksboro.
An NWS cooperative weather observer reported wind damage to his cotton crop.
Multiple reports of tree damage across Corpus Christi. One tree fell on the hood of a car.
Late report via social media of golf ball hail size.
Numerous trees down in the Houston metro area.
Ping pong ball sized hail fell in Powderly which is approximately 9 miles north of Paris.
Amateur radio reported hen-egg size hail approximately 1 mile southwest of the city of Sunset, TX.
A report from the public of tennis ball-size hail in Crane was shared on social media.
Golf ball size hail reported by the public in Morales-Sanchez community.
The second severe thunderstorm of the day that moved across Robert Lee produced winds up to 80 MPH causing damage to numerous houses and carports.
An amateur radio operator estimated thunderstorm wind gusts of sixty-one knots east northeast of Channing.
The public reported power poles broken and 3 inch diameter tree limbs snapped. The report was from mping.
Reported from the 45th Avenue and Bell Street area and also the 45th Avenue and Coulter Street area.
Pea to quarter sized hail.
Delayed report: There were several public reports of wind damage in the Carlsbad area, including large tree limbs and small trees knocked down.
Spotter reported a funnel cloud near Highway 35.
Widespread power outages reported with downed trees and power lines in Milam.
Newspaper reported wind damage to a mobile home.

A swath of severe thunderstorm winds ripped across the northern portion of the county and city of Lubbock extending from Reese Center to four miles east of Lubbock from 1739 CST through 1802 CST. Most of these severe wind reports were from the Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet. A peak gust of 74 mph was measured at 1801 CST four miles east of Lubbock by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet. Additionally, the Automated Surface Observing System at Lubbock International Airport measured a wind gust of 66 mph at 1753 CST.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail at Graytown Rd. just northeast of FM 1604 near Converse.
The report was relayed through mPING.
Quarter sized hail in the community of Fairmount, Texas.
Downburst winds blew down trees and tree limbs that knocked out power lines in Seguin.
A 58 mph severe thunderstorm wind gust was measured at a local television studio. Several reports of damage to buildings and vehicles were reported around the same time.
Numerous reports of trees down on the west side of Houston.  Power lines down near South Post Oak Road and Beltway 8.
Trees were downed in the city of Jacksonville, Texas.
A thunderstorm moved across Mitchell County and produced a 61 mph wind gust five miles northwest of Colorado City.
A home weather station measured a 59 mph wind gust.
A trained spotter reported broken six inch diameter tree limbs near Moran along State Highway 6.
Nickel size hail was reported 3 miles south of Harker Heights.
The Cedar Island Ranch on Limestone County Road 198 lost several large cedar trees. Structural damage to a horse barn also occurred.
A large tree snapped and fell on a 60 year old male standing in his driveway, fatally injuring him.
Baseball size hail was reported in San Ygnacio, related by the Zapata County Sheriff's office.
Law enforcement reported large branches down over the roadways.

A line of thunderstorms moved across Oldham County during the late evening hours of the 16th. As the line moved near the town of Dawn (Deaf Smith County), the County Emergency Manager reported quarter size hail (1.00 inch) 6 miles north-northwest of Dawn (Deaf Smith County). After producing this hail, the line of thunderstorms continued to move to the south-southeast across the Texas Panhandle.
No damage.

A brief tornado was reported crossing FM 1246 between Thornton and Oletha. The exact location is unknown but is close to the plotted track. This tornado was the third of 4 brief tornadoes a parent supercell produced as it moved across Falls and Limestone counties.
Torrential rain of 3.02 inches was measured by a NWS Cooperative Observer at the Valley Peanut Growers in Turkey.
One-inch hail was reported in Stinnett.
A thunderstorm produced two inch diameter hail at the Hill Top Cafe near the intersection of Hwy 87 and RR 648 southeast of Cherry Spring.

A waterspout was observed over Richland Chambers Lake between the FM 2859 bridge and Hwy 287. It was reported the waterspout may have started as a tornado on the west shore of the lake, but this could be not confirmed and no damage was reported.
An amateur radio operator reported golf ball size hail broke windows at a home.
Law enforcement relayed tornado on ground near Highway 188 and Interstate 37.  Tornado was briefly on ground over open country and produced no damage.

A member of the broadcast media reported that a large tree was uprooted around the 800 block of Samuels Drive in Fort Worth, TX. The wood framed steeple was also torn off the Samuels Avenue Baptist Church.
No damage reported.
The public reported that large hail up to the size of nickels was accompanied by 40 to 50 mph wind gusts at McAdoo around 18:50 CST.
Hail damage was not observed.
Hail up to golf ball size was reported at the intersection of Interstate 10 and George Dieter.

A cluster of thunderstorms moved into the Texas Panhandle during the early afternoon hours of the 14th. As storms neared Texline (Dallam County), a member of the public reported a downburst severely damaged a grain elevator and silo. The speed of this downburst was estimated at 65 mph. After producing this downburst the cluster of storms continued moving southward across the Panhandle.
Residents at a ranch headquarters in northeastern Reagan County reported penny size hail that covered the ground.
A tree was downed across Torry Pines Drive in the Crown Colony Subdivision.
Numerous power lines and telephone lines downed. Roofs also blown off several businesses.
Public reported quarter size hail.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail near the intersection of I-35 and Hwy 183 in the St. John area of Austin.
Wind gusts collapsed a metal bleacher at the East Bernard High School.
Pearland regional airport ASOS recorded a 61 mph wind gust.
Trees were blown down on Homer Cooper Road west of Highway 59.
Severe storm winds caused tree damage in the town of Deanville.

The Hutchinson County Emergency Managers Office reported that several trees and power lines were blown by the thunderstorm wind gust. Also, a metal carport was blown over. There were no reports of injuries or fatalities.
Report from MPing.
Golf ball size hail on Highway 150 between Coldspring and Shepherd.
Several trees were downed across Hwy. 80 and the FM. 1799 intersection.
Quarter to golf ball sized hail was reported in the Caldwell area.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near White River Lake measured a wind gust to 60 mph.
Damage was widespread in Bullard.
A thunderstorm moved across Howard County and produced an 83 mph wind gust at the mesonet site near Lomax.
Quarter sized hail was reported in Bristol.
One of the broadcast media relayed a report of penny size hail.
Penny size hail fell 2 miles south of the town of Argyle.
Nickle sized hail reported by trained spotter near the Five Points area, just south of Calallen.
Thunderstorm winds blew off metal tin from an old barn. Several tree limbs were blown down also.
Several reports were received of golfball size hail in Wink.
A wind gust of 59 mph was measured by the Automated Weather Observing System at the Mesa Vista Ranch airport located 26 miles northwest of Miami.
A storm chaser reported baseball size hail.

Numerous broken tree branches were observed around Alice with most damage concentrated along Schley and Rankin Avenues. There were at least four observed downed power lines within this neighborhood as well as damage to a car port and loss of roofing materials at a local bingo hall. Farther east of this location, a 53 MPH wind gust was reported at the Alice airport at 00:54 AM LST.
Dime size hail was reported just northwest of McNary.
Lightning struck a utility substation and knocked out power to some 1,200 residences and businesses.
A lightning strike caused a residential structure fire.
Large tree branches down near Highway 3 and Fuqua.
Measured at NWS Corpus Christi Forecast Office.
A downed tree fell onto an RV at Bonham State Park.
Trees and power lines were downed.
Reported nine miles north of the town of McLean on State Highway 273.
