A National Weather Service cooperative observer reported that several buildings on his property near Farm to Market Road 1901 were affected by damaging winds.  Part of the metal roof on his house was blown off and two portable buildings were blown down.  The winds were accompanied by large hail.
Multiple trees were downed near the intersection of FM 1179 and Copperfield Drive.

A National Weather Service storm survey team found evidence of a brief tornado which affected several houses near Rapp Road and Rufe Snow Drive in Keller. The damage was concentrated along a 30 to 50 yard path and included several trees which were blown down. Approximately 10 homes suffered minor roof damage as well.
Multiple pictures of quarter to half dollar size hail that fell a couple of miles south of Downtown Tyler were posted to social media.

More than a dozen farmers in Parmer County suffered varying degrees of damage to corn and cotton crops following a slow-moving hailstorm. About 20,000 acres were damaged in total, with about 3,500 acres reported as a complete loss. The hail was estimated to be as large as golf ball size.
Five power poles sustained damage near Highway 240 and FM 369. A metal roof was blown off of a trailer at FM 269 and Kramer Road. Monetary damages were estimated.
Hail fell in the Greggton area.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail north of Blanco. This report was from MPING.

F1 tornado near Highway 149 and Graham Street caused significant townhouse roof damage. A bank and a grocery store were also damaged and a car was overturned at a local dealership. Trees were also downed.
Seventy mph winds were reported just south of Whitesboro.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet.

A National Weather Service damage survey crew found evidence of a small tornado near the Johnson/Tarrant County line.  The tornado began near Lone Star Road and US 287 in the far southern portion of the City of Mansfield. The tornado did minor damage to four businesses, damaging overhead doors on metal buildings. One manufactured home suffered roof damage in Johnson County, while one barn was destroyed as the tornado moved into far southern Tarrant County.

A thunderstorm moved across Pecos County and produced downburst winds near Fort Stockton.  An 18 wheeler was flipped over, nine power poles snapped, a large billboard sign fell to the ground, and an exit sign blew over as a result of this wind.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Strong wind gusts caused tree damage in Brazoria County, resulting in trees blocking roads.
Golfball sized hail was reported at mile marker 273 on I-10.
A 70 mph wind gust was measured at the NWS Fort Worth office.
Local broadcast media relayed a report of quarter size hail in Ralls.
Trees were blown down near the intersection of FM 747 and County Road 1905 in the Pierces Chapel community.
Trees were downed on Sabine Street in South Longview.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail at the intersection of Tulley Rd. and Bubba Palmer Rd. in Cuero.
Downburst and straight-line winds caused tree and roof damage in Teague. Time was estimated by radar.
Mping report of 1.5 inch hail.
Nickel size hail.
The public reported quarter size hail just east of Flomot at the intersection of Farm to Market Roads 97 and 2009.
Trees down across county.
A tree was downed in the city of Mount Pleasant.
Large hail damaged or destroyed wheat...corn...and cotton crops north of Hereford.
A storage building was blown to the side of the roadway on Highway 64 near the intersection of Highway 42 in the Turnertown community.
Alice Municipal Airport ASOS measured a gust to 70 mph.
Golfball sized hail fell 5 miles west of Kaufman.
Reported from mPING: Quarter (1.00 in.).
Quarter size hail fell in Spearman.
Severe winds at Anderson Mill and FM620.

A second Gillespie County tornado was reported by the Sheriff's Department to have struck the community of Willow City near 1910CST. It was about 20 yards wide and was on the ground for less than short-lived and caused minor damage to some trees before lifting and dissipating.  It was rated F0 on the Fujita Scale.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Paducah measured a severe wind gust of 60 mph.

A home near Boat Club Road and Caballo Street was struck by lightning and sustained moderate damage. The lightning bolt entered through the roof and emerged through the laundry room. No possessions in the home were lost.
Penny size hail was reported west of 82nd Street and Milwaukee Avenue in Lubbock. No damage was observed.
A thunderstorm produced quarter to golf ball size hail in Kerrville.
A thunderstorm moved across Winkler County and produced wind damage in Kermit.  A roof was blown off of a building.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Broadcast media relayed photos of golf ball hail 3 miles NW of Whitney.

An off-duty National Weather Service employee reported that power was out in the area. Also...roads were covered with water from Western Street to Bell Street and that the water was flowing over the curbs and into resident's yards.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that snapped power poles and damaged a business sign on Hwy 277 in Carrizo Springs.
A trained spotter reported ping pong ball size hail near Highway 287 in the city of Haslet, TX.

The public reported thunderstorm wind damage at 26th Avenue and Buchanan Street where a metal roof was blown off of a metal workshop and came to rest on 26th Avenue. Also, there was a report of two inch diameter tree limbs blown down. There were no reports of injuries or fatalities.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail on N. St. Mary's St. just south of I-35 in San Antonio.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet station.
The Floyd County Sheriff's office reported golfball size hail.  The hail damaged automobiles and the roofs of homes.
Multiple reports of tree damage across  Wellington were given to the weather office in Amarillo. Branches ranges from 1 inch to  greater than 3 inches.
Lightning struck a home and started a fire which caused substantial damage to the residence.
A thunderstorm produced two inch diameter hail near Sea World.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that knocked down a tree near Sea World in San Antonio.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail in Muldoon.
Large tree limbs were blown down near Tom Bean.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 65 mph that blew down trees and caused power outages in San Marcos.
Trees were blown down and a trampoline was blown over by damaging winds.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail along I-35 near Jarrell.
Many windshields were broken in White River Lake and at least one house window was shattered.
Trees blown down.
Several trees were blown down.
The public reported quarter size hail along Farm to Market Road 211 west of Slide around 16:00 CST.
Trees were downed on Bethlehem Road in Hudson.
Law Enforcement estimated a thunderstorm wind gust of 60 mph just east of Echo.

Strong storms moved into Tyler County before sunrise on the 4th. Multiple reports were received of trees and power lines down from north of Wildwood to Hillister and to near Fred. One mobile home had the roof removed during the event.
On the north side of town.
Quarter sized hail was reported 7 miles north of Pottsboro.

A severe thunderstorm over southwest Midland County produced an intense downburst. Texas Department of Public Safety officers reported 60 MPH winds along Farm to Market Road 1788 just south of Interstate 20.
A trained spotter reported nickel size hail about 2 miles northwest of Brownwood.

The Borden County Sheriff's Office reported that a second tornado developed within a few minutes of the previous entry dissipating. This tornado also remained over open country south of U.S. Highway 180, and it was reported to be short-lived in nature.
Hail completely covered the ground along Highway 96.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail and wind gusts estimated at 55 mph in Moore.

This brief EF0 tornado occurred near IAH. It tracked across JFK Blvd and did some minor damage to a few structures including a hotel and knocked over a few trees. Video showed the tornado crossing San Houston Parkway.

A small tornado touched down near Wimberley, knocking down trees and causing scattered area of minor damage to buildings in Wimberley.  Most damage was confined to roofs and fences.  The tornado lifted shortly afterward and dissipated.
Quarter sized hail was reported in the Metcalf Gap area.

A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Wolfforth measured severe wind gusts from 2118 CST through 2130 CST. A peak wind gust of 78 mph was measured at 2119 CST. Additionally, several irrigation center pivots were overturned south of the observed severe wind gust. An NWS employee reported an eight inch diameter tree was snapped off at it's base.
Report from mPING: Dime (0.75 in.).
Reported via mPing.
An amateur radio operator reported penny size west of Georgetown. This report was relayed to us by the National Weather Service Weather Forecast Office in Fort Worth.

Pecos County Emergency Manager reports an 18-wheeler flipped over due to wind 10 miles south of Fort Stockton on Highway 285. Wind speeds were estimated to be approximately 80 MPH. The time and amount of property damage are estimates.

Thunderstorm winds snapped numerous power poles at their bases, downed street signs and numerous trees, and damaged the roofs of two homes. Scattered damage occurred generally from Crosby to the Lake Houston Dam area around FM 2100.
Texas Department of Transportation reported a mobile home flipped over in northeast El Paso.

A survey team found areas of enhanced wind damage northwest of Sulphur Springs in Hopkins County. Most of the observed damage was consistent with wind speeds around 90 mph. The most significant damage was observed at the Cross Spur Arena where the front of a metal structure was uplifted, causing the front of the structure to collapse. This damage was consistent with maximum wind speeds of 95 mph. Significant tree damage was also observed near the Cross Spur Arena and along County Road 4760 and County Road 4763. None of this damage was convergent and generally in an east to north direction. A few additional swaths of notable damage were found along County Road 4759 and County Road 4763 where snapped and uprooted trees were observed along with roof/siding damage at a few homes. A mobile home on County Road 4761 had its roof removed, but all walls remained standing.  Review of the damage and all available radar evidence, all suggest the Hopkins County damage was the result of locally enhanced straight-line winds. Most of the more notable damage occurred in areas of notches or bows along the leading edge of the morning storms, which is where locally enhanced winds typically occur that can cause higher-end damage.
A public report indicated quarter sized hail about a mile west of Springtown.
Many signs were reported blown down.
Trees and power lines knocked down.

Several trees were knocked down across the county but the hardest hit area was along Hwy 19 north of Sulphur Springs. On either side of the highway, numerous trees were knocked down and many trees blocked roads. On CR 4769, a carport was blown across the road. The roof of an unoccupied trailer on CR 4591 was ripped off. A few trees were also knocked down across the southern half of the county.
A public report indicated hen-egg sized hail approximately 2 miles west of the city of Aquila, TX.
Accumulating hail was reported in south Amarillo.
Reported via mPing.
Quarter-sized hail was reported at the intersection of State Highway 59 and FM 1960 near Deerbrook Mall.
Golf ball-sized hail was reported at the intersection of Loop 494 and Kingwood Drive.

Heavy rains, estimated by radar between 2 and 4 inches and measured by both cooperative and CoCoRaHS rain gages (between 1.84 and 2.97 inches), including 2.41 inches in Mercedes, 2.24 inches in Edinburg, and 2.47 inches in Weslaco.  The core of the heavy rain fell between 1 PM and 330 PM CST and included Progresso, Weslaco, Donna, and Alamo.  Nuisance urban-type poor drainage flooding likely occurred in areas of heavy rain; there was no indication of any enhanced flooding along the main and north floodway between Progresso and Mercedes.
Hail was reported in the New London community.

National Weather Service Storm Survey revealed that an EF0 tornado caused roof damage to a home 5 miles west-southwest of Avoca. There was also broken tree limbs along the path and many power poles snapped along U.S. Highway 277 just south of the Farm Road 1636 intersection.
The Denton Enterprise Airport ASOS measured a 69 mph wind gust. A spotter reported roof damage east of this location near the I-35 split.
Storm spotters reported nickel size hail on U.S. Highway 84 along the Hockley and Lubbock County line between Anton and Shallowater.
Thunderstorm winds downed three trees.
Witnesses observed a funnel cloud that touched down and produced EF0 tree and power line damage in the area.  The tornado also lifted a paddle boat into a tree.
Local law officials reported large trees blown down by thunderstorm winds.
A report of telephone poles bent over and tree limbs on the roadway on U.S. Highway 283 north of Baird.  The time of this report was estimated by radar.
A member of the Happy Fire Department reported quarter size hail immediately east of the city.
Trees were blown down.
Penny size hail was reported off the Crosby Freeway (Highway 90).
Report from mPING: Quarter (1.00 in.).
About eight manufactured homes were destroyed in the community of Carlsbad from a tornado. Other structures received minor damage.
A thunderstorm produced one inch hail east of Rocksprings.
Baseball sized hail fell in Evant.
Fisher County Emergency Manager reported tree limbs down and roof damage in the town of Rotan.
Emergency manager reported a 72 mph wind gust in Trenton.
Palo Pinto County Sheriff's Department reported roof damage to a house located on FM 1195 off Hwy 281.
Trees were downed in Mount Pleasant, Texas.
Hail at Anderson Mill and FM620
Hail reported in Flint, Texas.
Trees and powerlines were downed near Hwy. 259 near Kilgore, Texas.
A HAM radio operator reported nickel (0.88) to quarter (1.0) sized hail on the north side of La Feria.

There are reports of four separate house fires being started due to lightning. One has been confirmed via a picture on twitter. The time estimated from radar and a lightning plot is between 14-1505 CST.
Numerous trees down, roofs off of 2 buildings, transformer and structure fires from downed power lines.
A portion of the metal roof of the Trinity Community Center was peeled back due to strong winds.
Trees downed.
A thunderstorm produced penny size hail in Hondo.
Penny sized hail near i-40 and Helium Road, just west of Amarillo.
Trees were downed.
Report from mPING: Dime (0.75 in.).
A storm chaser reported quarter size hail covering the ground five miles southeast of Petersburg.
Spotter reported half dollar hail fell 1.16 miles west of Agnes.
Tower personnel reported a Cessna was flipped over by high winds and several hangar doors were blown down.
Penny to nickel size hail was reported in Valley View.

A 31-year old male was struck by lightning at the Rednecks with Paychecks event. The lightning struck the tree he was taking cover under and entered his body through his boot. He survived without serious injury.

Law enforcement officials and Skywarn storm spotters reported large hail that ranged in size from quarters to half dollars along a swath from Ransom Canyon to Idalou as a cluster of severe thunderstorms impacted northeastern Lubbock County.
Law Enforcement reported two inch hail at the TA Truck Stop along Interstate 20 at Mile Marker 242.
Tennis ball size hail reported via social media in the Swan community.

The strong damaging winds damaged and destroyed many properties. A barn, made of aluminum and tin and built in the 1930s, was completely destroyed. A number of poorly constructed mobile homes, that were not tied down, and had no or poorly anchored roofs were destroyed and rendered uninhabitable. One mobile home, completely unanchored, was rolled by the winds.  One home lost portions of a metal roof.
Damaging thunderstorm winds, likely associated with the RFD of a tornadic supercell, removed some metal panels from the roof of a motel near Highway 183 and Estrada Pkwy in Irving.
Tennis to softball sized hail was reported.
Trees were blown down on FM 315 approximately 10 miles north of Palestine. One of the trees was 15 inches in diameter.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail northwest of Fredericksburg.
Measured at the West Texas Mesonet station one mile east of McLean.

A NWS survey determined that a downburst with winds near 70 MPH occurred in Greenville. Significant damage occurred on the southwest side of the city where half of the roof and 15 air conditioning units were blown off a medical office building and an apartment building just east of there also lost some roofing material. In Downtown Greenville, a large awning collapsed.

Scattered thunderstorms developed across Randall County during the evening hours of the 12th. As a storm approached the town of Amarillo (Potter County), the KVII Schoolnet site two miles south of Amarillo recorded a 60 mph downburst. After producing this downburst the storm continued to move eastward across the county.
A lightning strike caused a grass fire on a golf course.
Fire department storm spotters reported golfball size hail.
The San Angelo ASOS recorded a 78  mph wind at Mathis Field in San Angelo.
Roof damage due to thunderstorm winds was reported near the intersection of Loop 286 and Highway 24.

A swath of severe thunderstorm winds affected an area from Shallowater to Texas Tech University. On the campus of Texas Tech University, several utility poles were blown down. A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Shallowater measured a wind gust to 64 mph. Another mesonet on the campus of Texas Tech University measured severe wind gusts from 2117 CST through 2118 CST. A peak wind gust of 66 mph was measured at 2117 CST. Additionally, the Automated Surface Observing System at Lubbock Preston Smith International Airport measured a severe wind gust of 61 mph at 2115 CST.

Destructive straight line winds measured up to 74 mph by a KVII-TV mesonet in Memphis resulted in numerous instances of mostly minor damage throughout the town.  The most visible damage was caused after a tin roof was lifted and thrown into a nearby health clinic collapsing a small exterior wall.  Also, portions of the high school football stadium press box were removed.  The majority of the damage reports involved downed tree limbs, power lines and road signs.  Some fences were also blown over and roofs were reported to have sustained generally minor damage.  No injuries were reported.
Trees down on Picket Run Road near Hwy 101 in Sunset.
Thunderstorm winds downed four inch diameter tree limbs.
Two severe wind gusts were measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet south of Olton.  The first was 58 mph at 525 PM CST and the second gust to 63 mph occurred at 540 PM CST.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail in Georgetown.
Robertson County Sheriff's Department reported trees down along Highway 7; approximately 12 miles north of Easterly.

A swath of strong winds and damage associated with a rear flank downdraft occurred over a three county area. The Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Spur measured a wind gust of 84 mph at 2032 CST. However, there was no significant damage noted in Spur.
A storm chaser observed tea cup sized hail, which is about the size of an orange, approximately 5 miles north-northwest of Hillsboro.
A Skywarn-trained spotter reported that severe thunderstorm winds had blown down trees near Dilley.  No other damage was indicated.
Quarter sized hail was reported near Graford.

Hail up to the size of baseballs caused considerable damage in the Lakewood area of Dallas. The roofs of many homes were damaged with the hail leaving holes in some of the roofs. House and vehicle windows were smashed out, and tree limbs and leaves were shredded off the trees. A greenhouse attached to a home on Mercedes Avenue was also destroyed. The tower at the Lakewood Theater was damaged and one side of the theater marquee was smashed. At the Lakewood Country Club, the hail damaged nearly the entire course leaving thousands of divots. The hail reportedly lasted for nearly 30 minutes.
Amateur radio SKYWARN spotters reported walnut size hail on Highway 114 west of town.
Thunderstorm winds damaged metal roofs in the Maysfield area along FM 485.
A large apple tree was toppled which heavily damaged a fence.  Dime size hail also occurred in addition to one inch of rain.
Pea to penny sized hail was reported at the intersection of FM 1464 and Westheimer Road.
Severe thunderstorm winds damaged the walls and screen of an outdoor drive-in theater and destroyed several outbuildings just west of Hallettsville.
A trained spotter reported quarter sized hail approximately 4 miles north of the city of Waxahachie, TX.

A supercell moved across Carson County during the evening hours of the 9th. As the storm moved north of Pantex (Carson County), a storm chaser reported tennis ball size hail (2.50 inches) six miles north of Pantex (Carson County). After producing this hail, the supercell continued to moved eastward across the county.
Half dollar to ping pong ball size hail reported in the Beulah community east of Diboll.
High based convection resulted in severe wind gusts near Wink. A gust to 62 MPH was recorded at the Winkler County Airport. No damage was reported.
Storm chasers reported the tornado touched down briefly in an open field.
Nickel-size hail in Deer Park.
A tin roof was removed off a shed on Martha Lane.

A discrete supercell thunderstorm developed over northern Sherman County during the evening hours of the 16th. As this storm moved southeastward over the town of Stratford (Sherman County), a local law enforcement officer reported an estimated 70 mph thunderstorm gust which blew down a 20 foot tree, downed power lines, and downed fences in Stratford (Sherman County). After producing this gust the storm continued moving southeastward across the county.
Emergency management reported nickel size hail approximately 7 miles southwest of the city of Bowie along Scout Road.

A tornado survey was conducted on this tornado. The tornado touched down at 1847 CST approximately three miles northeast of Umbarger. The tornado was on the ground for approximately one mile or less with a path width of fifty yards. The tornado dissipated at approximately 1849 CST approximately four miles northeast of Umbarger. The tornado remained over open country and no damage or injuries were reported directly from the tornado. However...several homes received damage from wind blown hail associated with the rear flank downdraft. Several north facing windows were blown out and hundreds of acres of crops were destroyed.
Quarter size hail was reported downstream of Lake Whitney Dam.
Amateur radio reported quarter sized hail in Irving, TX.
AWOS reported a wind gust of 74 mph.
A barn in Kerens that housed tractors and other similar equipment was destroyed by high thunderstorm winds.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet.
Trees were downed in and around Gary City.
Public reported half dollar sized hail 4 miles NW of Grandview.
Visibility was near zero in blowing dust.  No hail damage information was available.
A trained spotter reported quarter sized hail near the intersection of Highway 360 and Park Row Dr in Arlington, TX.
Emergency management reported penny-sized hail in Muenster, TX.
An oak tree fell onto a house in Edgewood.
The automated weather station at Cox Field in Paris (KPRX) recorded a 61 mph wind gust. Some tree damage was reported in and around Paris.
A trained spotter reported a 65 mph wind gust in Grape Creek.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Aiken measured severe wind gusts from 0046 CST through 0047 CST. A peak wind gust of 67 was measured at 0047 CST.
A power line was downed.
Law enforcement reported half dollar size hail.
Penny size hail was reported in the community of Willow Park, 9 miles east of Weatherford.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that blew down a tree onto a fence in South Austin.
Winds of 50 to 60 MPH winds and nickel sized hail was reported near Bear Creek Community Church.
Numerous trees down across Blanchard Latex Road.
Trees and power lines were blown down. A travel trailer was flipped over.
A swath of hail up to nickel size fell across southwest Lubbock. No evidence of damage occurred.

The tornado crossed from Jackson County Oklahoma into far northern Wilbarger County between Odell TX and Elmer OK, before crossing the Red River for the third time back into Jackson County Oklahoma. Again, no damage is known to have occurred in this portion of Wilbarger County.

Channel 12 (McAllen Cable Access Television) reported quarter size and perhaps larger hail fell during a thunderstorm in the city of Mission during the evening. Nickel size hail was reported a bit earlier by a resident 1 mile north of Palmview, as well as several large limbs being knocked down.  The mini supercell raced south southeast, likely producing additional hail southeast of Mission.  Most reports were received between 927 and 930 PM CDT.
Several reports of penny sized hail in the Sanger area.
Barn roof and out-building damaged.
NOS site at Bob Hall Pier measured a gust to 60 mph.
Wind Gust measured in the City of Mission.
The public estimated the thunderstorm wind gust in Dumas Texas.
Reported at the World Trade Center Bridge, along with strong winds and heavy rain.
A thunderstorm moved across Scurry County and produced a 62 mph wind gust at the Snyder ASOS site.
Quarter size hail was reported at ACR 460 and FM 860 near Bois D'Arc.
Numerous trees downed along FM 225 between Cushing and Douglass.

A very brief EF-0 tornado occurred along West Half Moon Road in Santa Fe, just to the northwest of Santa Fe High School. A large oak tree was snapped, causing roof damage and destroying a well pump. The garage door in a single family home was blown out. A utility building had its metal siding destroyed. Several large pieces of heavy equipment sitting outdoors were picked up and moved by the tornado.
Two houses unroofed on the south side of Decatur along Highway 730.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near White River Lake measured severe wind gusts from 2044 CST through 2111 CST. A peak wind gust of 71 mph was measured at 2045 CST.
1 metal building blown down by severe winds.

A truck carrying eight people hit standing water on the eastbound lanes of I-30 and lost control. The vehicle flipped over the guardrail and traveled another 200 feet before stopping. A 20 year old male passenger was killed and 5 others were transported to the hospital.
Hail was observed near the intersection of Highway 277 and Turkey Ranch Road.
Numerous trees down between Hwy 146 and Hwy 190 and in the Indian Hills Subdivision near Lake Livingston where one tree fell on a home.
A thunderstorm produced penny size hail in Kingsland.

A thunderstorm moved across Ward County and produced damage in Monahans.  There were four to five telephone poles snapped, trees knocked over, a storage building turned on its side, and windows in mobile homes were broke.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

|Numerous reports, including from local media and off duty National Weather Service meteorologists, were received of large hail ranging from penny to quarter size in the west side of Lubbock. The largest hail affected the Shadow Hills subdivision in northwest Lubbock. No damage was reported.
The Erath County Sheriff's Department reported trees blown down off of Timbercreek Drive, approximately 4 miles northeast of Stephenville.
An NWS cooperative weather observer reported hail up to golf ball size about nine miles southeast of Floydada. No damage was reported.
A thunderstorm produced a measured wind gust of 57 kts. at Kelly Field in San Antonio.
An off-duty National Weather Service employee reported hail covering the ground.

A long lived supercell tracked from Bailey County into Lamb County and then into Castro County producing periodic severe hail and a tornado from Lamb County into Castro County. Several funnel and tornado reports were received early in the morning of the 26th as WSR-88D data showed increasing and tightening low-level circulation east of Springlake. A photograph of a wedge-type tornado was taken by a storm chaser at 0135 CST southwest of Hart. No reports of damage were received.
A tree was downed on Georgia Richie Road just west of town.
A trained spotter measured a 62 mph wind gust at the intersection of Spring Valley Rd and Old Lorena Rd west of the city of Hewitt.

A line of severe thunderstorms moved across Oldham County during the early afternoon hours of the 24th. As this line moved over the town of Boys Ranch (Oldham County), a member of the public reported golf ball size hail (1.75 inches) in town. After producing this hail the line of storms continued moving southwestward across the county.
The public reported softball size hail 4 miles north of Knickerbocker.

A narrow tornado track of tree damage was found by the survey team. The tornado was reported by several chasers and spotters. Tree damage was consistent with EF-0 damage and estimated peak wind of 75 mph.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts measured at 65 kts by the ASOS at Austin-Bergstrom International Airport.  Fairly widespread wind damage was seen east of the airport along Toll Road 130.
Golf ball sized hail was reported near the intersection of Montague, Jack and Wise counties.
Report from mPING: Quarter (1.00 in.).
Numerous trees and powerlines were downed in the area.  Several of these trees fell on homes.  The roof was removed from a business on Hwy. 80.  A portion of the roof landed on an automobile.
Large trees were blown down in the Westworth Village area of Ft. Worth.
The Garza County Sheriff's Office reported golfball size hail.
Penny size hail was reported in Millsap.
Trees and powerlines downed on CR 4591 near the Perryville community.
The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet station recorded a severe thunderstorm wind gust of 58 mph just north of Roaring Springs. No damage was reported.
A public report indicated quarter sized hail about a mile north of Boyd, TX.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail in Bandera.
Quarter-size hail was reported in the Reagan community.
Large trees were blown down by high winds.
Observed at Citizens Medical Center in Victoria.
The metal siding and roof of a large barn was partially torn off.
Public reported quarter size hail on social media.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms initially began to produce rainfall around midday on the 1st.  This activity gradually evolved toward heavy tropical downpours, especially during the evening hours of the 3rd through the morning hours of the 4th.||The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet sites near Ralls and White River Lake recorded storm total rainfall amounts of 6.74 inches and 6.10 inches respectively.||Four-day storm total rainfall amounts measured by the Crosbyton National Weather Service cooperative observer shattered records for Crosbyton per reports from the Crosby County Reporter-Examiner.  The official observer measured 9.43 inches, which exceeded the local record for total July rainfall of 8.40 inches set in 1900.||Local agricultural officials reported that the rains resulted in no adverse impacts for Crosby County crops.  As a result of the heavy rain and subsequent run-off, however, White River Lake experienced a rise of nine feet which crested on the 12th.
Quarter size hail was reported in Big Sandy, Texas.
A trained spotter reported golf ball size hail near County Road 304 southwest of the town of Upton.
Golfball sized hail fell at the intersection of Highway 281 and Farm-to-Market Road 2905, just north of the city of Hamilton. Golfball sized hail was also reported in the city of Hamilton.
Large hail, propelled by winds of 35 to 40 knots, damaged roofs and knocked over trees in the Quemado area.
Winds were estimated to be near 60 mph in Dekalb.
A thunderstorm developed over Culberson County and produced penny sized hail in Van Horn.
Quarter to golf ball sized hail was reported near I-35 and Loop 363 in Temple.
Storm spotters observed a tornado approximately 6 miles west of Crowell. No damage was reported.
A thunderstorm wind gust of 60 mph was estimated by a trained spotter in Borger.
This tornado briefly touched down in the Canadian River Valley, and was documented by law enforcement reports and storm chaser footage. This tornado did not produce any damage.
Hail fell on the southwest side of town.

An EF-0 tornado with maximum estimated winds around 80 mph produced damage in the city of Coppell. The tornado began near the intersection of E Belt Line Rd and S Denton Tap Rd. The awning at a gas station was damaged at this intersection. The tornado moved to the northeast through a residential area causing minor damage to some roofs of homes and businesses and also damaging trees. The total path of the tornado was 2 miles long, but the damage path was non-continuous. The damage path was also narrow at about 75 yards wide.
A tree fell on a residence in Rising Star.
The large hail was found off Highway 283.
The public reported the hail near the intersection of Parker Street and Douglas Drive in southwest Amarillo.
A thunderstorm moved across Mitchell County and produced wind damage in Loraine.  Power lines were reported to be down in Loraine.  The cost of damage is a rough estimate.
Social Media reported egg size hail SE of Celina.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail along Hwy 181 northwest of Floresville.
Golfball to tea cup size hail caused considerable damage to vehicles...windows and roofs.

The downburst winds tore the roof and at least one wall from a poorly constructed trailer at a colonia of Pueblo de Palmas, east of La Joya. In Alton, winds downed two trees, one of which fell onto a recreational vehicle. Five to seven power poles were downed or snapped in the same area. At the peak of the storm, nearly 9,000 AEP customers in western Hidalgo County were without power.
Numerous reports of damage in central part of county.
A trained spotter reported hail up to tennis ball size west of Floydada. No damage was reported.
Golfball size hail was reported 1 mile northwest of Muenster by the fire department.
Power lines down.
Quarter size hail was reported 10 miles northwest of Canadian.
Tennis ball sized hail was reported near Highway 174 between Joshua and Burleson.

Several reports were received of a swath of hail from approximately eight miles west-northwest of Denver City to the city of Denver City. The largest hail reported was baseball size. No damage was reported.
Cwop W5lRK LE in Little Elm reported 65 mph winds.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph. These winds damaged two roofs and downed power lines in El Indio.
Strong thunderstorm winds downed power lines and set a transformer on fire in the Palacios area.
The Llano ASOS (KAQO) reported a wind gust to 58 mph.  Emergency Management reported some structure damage to a few businesses in the town of Llano as a result of the strong thunderstorm winds.
A building on Alamo Road south of Montague sustained roof damage. The metal roof of the building was partially peeled back.

The West Texas Mesonet site 2 miles west northwest of Hereford (Deaf Smith County) reported a 58 mph thunderstorm wind gust from the outflow of a line of thunderstorms moving across the southwestern Texas Panhandle.
The Hamlin Fire Department reported damaging thunderstorm winds broke a telephone pole, destroyed a carport and knocked down some tree limbs in Hamlin.
Dime to nickel sized hail was reported in Muenster.
Wind gusts were estimated up to 60 mph near the intersection of Highway 290 and Loop 610.
Golf ball to tennis ball size hail shattered a skylight on residents home and cracked another.  A recreational vehicle was also damaged.

An embedded thunderstorm with a line of storms collapsed east of the town of Dalhart (Dallam County). A member of the public reported 4 miles east of Dalhart (Dallam County) blew tree limbs between one and three inches of a Chinese Elm down. The line of thunderstorms continued moving to the east-southeast after producing this downburst.
Tennis ball size hail was reported on FM 587 near the Eastland/Comanche county line.
Lightning struck a water heater gas line connected to a house, causing a small fire that the homeowner extinguished.
Public reported quarter sized hail near Poolville.
The automated weather station at Arlington Municipal Airport (KGKY) measured a 52 kt wind gust.
A thunderstorm moved across Terrell County and produced a 59 mph wind gust at the Dryden AWOS site.
A thunderstorm produced a lightning strike that caused a structural fire.
Hail was reported in Lufkin, Texas.
Numerous reports of tree damage in the city of Denton.
The public estimated the thunderstorm wind gust about four miles north of Canyon Texas in Randall County. There were no reports of damage or injuries.
A thunderstorm moved across Gaines County and produced a 61 mph wind gust south of Seagraves.
Broadcast media relayed a report of a landspout tornado along US Highway 287 between Memphis and Estelline. No damage was reported.
Media reported roof damage to a business in Nederland.
Hail up to quarter size was reported 4 miles west of Stratford.
Trees down Roofs damaged

A homeowner interviewed by a local television station reported severe damage to trees, shingles, and a destroyed wooden playground due to very gusty winds. He also reported ping pong to golf ball sized hail, which damaged his roof and several of his windows.  Radar indicated this storm strengthening with the potential for even higher wind gusts as it moved into extreme eastern Starr County, but there were not additional corroborating reports as of this writing.
Public photo showing golf ball-sized hail. Time estimated by radar.
An oil tank was struck by lightning on FM 1795 just north of the Kelsey Community.  The tank was destroyed.
Belding mesonet land owner reports half-dollar size hail at the mesonet.
Nickel sized Hail occurred in the Countryside subdivision at FM 518 and Bay Area Boulevard.

A damage survey conducted by the National Weather Service in Fort Worth found that a tornado touched down at a park near Highway 64 and Old Kaufman Road.  Several trees were damaged, a power pole was broken, and fencing was blown down.  East of the park, two power poles were broken along Highway 64.  A mobile home to the northeast suffered minor roof damage and a shed was damaged.  The tornado then moved through the First Monday trade site, heavily damaging several trees and pushing over a trailer in the western portion of the grounds.  Several vehicles were damaged by falling trees and limbs.  Additional tree damage was noted as the tornado approached Highway 19.  The damage swath ended about 200 yards east of Highway 19.  This tornado was rated a low EF-1 with maximum sustained winds of 85-90 MPH.  Two people were trapped in a van under a fallen tree in the First Monday parking lot.  A truck travelling north on Highway 19 was thrown 38 yards.  The driver was not injured.
Corner of Highway 64 and the Loop.

The tornado touched down in a marshy area a few miles south southeast of Hitchcock as reported by several witnesses and captured on video. The damage path extended into the Harborwalk community with damage to several homes. Six garage doors were damaged or destroyed. A large wood and steel observing platform was destroyed. There was also some damage to shingles. The tornado was estimated to be a high end EF-0 with winds reaching 80 mph.

This is a continuation of the Nacogdoches County EF-2 tornado that initially touched down just southwest of Garrison along Highway 59. Additional EF-2 damage, with estimated winds of 115-120 mph occurred in the extreme southeast corner of Rusk County along Highway 59, where the tornado tore through a chicken farm, destroying one chicken coop and killing all chickens, while also damaging 5 other coops. Several homes sustained roof damage from snapped or uprooted trees, and at least 20 outbuildings were damaged or destroyed. The tornado also snapped several power poles in this area and continued northeast along Highway 59 into Northwest Shelby County.
Thunderstorm winds were measured at 59 mph in White Settlement.

A thunderstorm moved across Gaines County and produced a downburst in Seagraves. A 74 mph wind gust was recorded by the West Texas Mesonet. Roof damage occurred in the town of Seagraves. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size at the intersection of I-35 and Hwy 45 in Round Rock.
A spotter reported damage to Wright's BBQ on Main Street in Vidor.
Late report with time estimated by radar.
Thunderstorm winds blew a roof off a home.
Thunderstorm winds knocked down trees off FM 19 near Neches.
Report via Facebook.
Multiple trees downed on FM Road 1798 near the Pine Hill community.
Emergency manager reported golf ball sized hail in Olney.
A trained spotter reported nickel size hail in the city of Callisburg, TX.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail between Uvalde and Camp Wood on Hwy 55.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail northwest of Cedar Park.

An EF-1 tornado with maximum estimated winds between 90-95 mph touched down in a pasture just south of County Road 3376, snapping and uprooting numerous trees and damaging a small farm outbuilding. The tornado continued northeast and snapped several more trees near a home but did not damage the home. The tornado then crossed County Road 3376 snapping and uprooting more trees before causing some minor roof damage to a chicken house on Farm to Market Road 139, lifting just northeast of the roadway.
Reported at Farm to Market Road 1551 and Farm to Market Road 207.
A tree was blown down in Reklaw.
Thunderstorm wind gusts downed trees in Carthage.  One of these trees fell across a mobile home.  There were no report of injuries.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Muleshoe measured severe wind gusts from 1735 to 1740 CST. A peak gust of 68 mph was measured at 1735 CST.
Baseball to softball size hail fell in a swath along Farm to Market Road 670 from Cuthbert to just south of Westbrook.
Golfball size hail was reported on the southwest side of Lubbock.
A thunderstorm produced straightline microburst wind gusts estimated at 58 mph which uprooted numerous large trees and knocked down large tree branches.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Earth measured a wind gust to 64 mph from 1757 to 1758 CST.
Quarter sized hail was observed.
Marble to quarter size hail fell in Westbrook.
A public report indicated penny to quarter sized hail approximately 3 miles south-southeast of the city of Addison, TX near the intersection of Dallas North Tollway and Loop 635.
A tree was downed blocking the east bound lane of Hwy. 11 at Leesburg, Texas.
A damage survey suggested thunderstorm wind gusts on the order of around 70 mph resulted in minor structural damage in town.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 50 kts which broke numerous 5-6 inch diameter tree limbs on the east side of town.
Trees and power lines were downed in the Newsome community.
Occurred on the east side of town.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 50 mph which knocked down several trees.
A trained spotter measured a wind gust of 61 mph about 1 mile northeast of Merkel.
The hail covered the ground. The hail report was relayed via the Spotter Network.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts measured at 60 mph by a personal weather station near FM 3240 and Panther Hollow Dr. between Bandera and Medina.
A thunderstorms produced half dollar size hail in Hutto.
Emergency management reported a wind gust of 66 MPH at North Central Texas College in Gainesville, TX.

A NWS survey determined straight-line winds caused damage south of Decatur. Near FM 730 and Private Road 4184, trees were uprooted, large tree limbs were broken, the roof of a home was damaged, and a large metal barn at a dairy farm was heavily damaged. Tree damage then extended to the northeast, and a few manufactured homes and RVs were damaged at a business near Highway 287.
Trained spotter reported damage near the intersection of FM3073 and Highway 16, southwest of Hebbronville. Travel trailers, portable buildings and trees were blown over.
The spotter indicated trees were bending nearly parallel to the ground during the peak winds.
A public report indicated quarter sized hail near Mount Calm, TX.
The public reported a large Oak Tree down in Moran.
Reports of quarter sized hail and strong outflow winds from storm.
Report from mPING: Dime (0.75 in.).
Penny size hail was reported in White Deer.
Pictures were posted to social media of half dollar to ping pong ball size hail that fell in and just south of the Brookeland community near the Sabine/Jasper County line.
This hail occurred with the same thunderstorm that produced the hail in Grape Creek. The storm moved very slowly as it entered the northern portions of San Angelo.
Damaging thunderstorm winds blew the roof off of a barn, uprooted a tree and broke large mesquite tree limbs.
Emergency management reported nickel sized hail in the city of Gainesville, TX.
Residential homes were damaged in and around the Sagegreen Drive and Sagevale Lane neighborhoods off of Scarsdale Blvd.
Hail was reported via MPING in College Station.
Trees were downed over roadways in and around the Crockett area.
Emergency management reported penny-sized hail at the Crowley Fire Station.
Hen egg size hail fell in Marshall.

A thunderstorm moved across Loving County and produced wind damage. There were 30 power poles that were broken and blown down seven miles north of Mentone. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
A thunderstorm produced nickel to chicken egg size hail for 20 minutes in Cedar Park.

The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet station near Post measured a 60 mph wind gust as the line of severe thunderstorms moved eastward across central Garza County at 23:30 CST. Severe winds continued to accompany the squall line as it progressed eastward over eastern Garza County, and a wind gust of 62 mph was additionally measured by Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site near Lake Alan Henry at midnight CST.  No damage was reported.
Law enforcement reported 8 trees down between Franklin and Bremond, TX, with some of them blocking roads.
Trees down along FM 976 one mile off of Hwy 36.
A storm chaser reported ping pong ball size hail along Texas State Highway 70 north of Matador.
Golfball size hail was reported at the intersection of Texas Highways 17 and 166 southwest of Fort Davis.
Windows blown out, hotel roof blown onto parking lot, major damage to vehicles due to the destroyed roof.
A thunderstorm produced half dollar size hail in northern Austin.
Nickel to quarter size hail was reported at the United States Border Patrol Station in Sierra Blanca.
Baseball sized hail fell at Skillman Street and Southwestern Blvd in Dallas.
A social media report indicated three-inch diameter hail in the city of Coppell, TX.
The Brownfield PD reported golfball size hail in town.  The hail damaged roofs and automobiles.
The Mills County Emergency Manager observed a tornado to the east and northeast of Priddy. The tornado occurred over open land and produced minimal damage.
Quarter to half dollar size hail was reported in Elm Mott.
A wind gust to 65 mph was estimated in a severe thunderstorm by the Hebbronville Fire Department.
Public reported quarter size hail.
Numerous reports of quarter sized hail to the west of Jersey Village.

A National Weather Service survey team found evidence of damage consistent with winds of 95 to 105 mph.  The damaging thunderstorms impacted the south side of Mason.  Most of the damage and debris pointed towards the east.  The damaging winds snapped large oak tree trunks and broke the glass of a sliding glass door.  Wind driven debris also broke windows in a couple of homes and the back window of a brand new truck.  The high winds uprooted trees, broke numerous tree limbs, peeled off some roof covering and even blew a heavy deer blind from a nearby pasture onto U.S. Highway 87.  This downburst was about a mile long and about 175 yards wide.  There was some evidence this damage path may have also been associated with a tornado as the path was narrow and there was some convergence along the path.  However, the evidence was somewhat inconclusive.
Quarter sized hail along with very heavy rain producing near zero visibility in Laredo was relayed through amateur radio.
A house was unroofed by high winds.
Hail from a stationary supercell thunderstorm pounded the little community of Putnam for almost an hour with hail of Baseball size or larger.
A landspout was reported in Donna. Image was shared on Slack/NWS Chat 2.0. Timing was based off their observation along with radar.
Several trees downed in Alba.
There was some damage to a church's roof, a sign and a nearby portable building. Trees and tree limbs were also downed.
Amatuer radio spotters reported nickel sized hail.

An overturned 18 wheeler was reported on southbound I-35E at Bear Creek Rd in Glenn Heights due to intense thunderstorm winds. Across the city, trees and power poles were damaged and knocked down, a few of which were blocking roadways. Some business signs were also knocked down. More considerable damage was reported to a small mattress shop on Bear Creek that had a tree fall on its roof, and damaged mobile homes on Happy Bear and also on South Uhl.
Roof damage to a home was reported near Chapel Hill along Hwy. 49 southeast of Mount Pleasant.
The public reported golfball size hail.
Numerous large tree limbs and power lines down.
Three large trees were downed at FM 114 just off of Hwy 259.  Another tree was downed just north of Hwy 259 on FM 2735.
One mile of power lines were reported blown down.
Numerous trees were downed across the county.
Large tree limbs were blown down.
Emergency management reported penny sized hail in the city of Dawson, TX.
Golfball size hail fell on the southeast side of Lufkin.
Local broadcast media relayed a report of golf ball size hail in Petersburg. No damage was reported.
Estimated measurement of 70 MPH.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that knocked down a large tree limb on N. Main St. in Boerne.
Ping pong ball sized hail occurred in Cotulla causing damage to plants. Images relayed to the NWS through Facebook.
Loose gravel roofing material was blown from the top of a building into a parking lot causing extensive window damage to numerous vehicles at the Harris County Appraisal District office.
The Automated Surface Observation System at Waco Regional Airport measured a wind gust of 58 MPH.
Trees were downed at various locations throughout Tyler and Smith County, including the intersection of West Grande Avenue and Old Noonday Road.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet station located two miles northeast of Friona.
Hail from quarter to golf ball size fell from Halfway to Edmonson.  Damage was unknown.
This hail fell along U.S. Highway 277 which is approximately 4 miles north of Eldorado.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Lake Alan Henry measured a wind gust to 74 mph.
Public reports indicated dime to quarter sized hail near Lincoln Park, TX.
Golf ball size hail was reported via mPING.
A Facebook video showed golf ball to baseball size hail near Joshua.
A thunderstorm moved across Ector County and produced a 69 mph wind gust at the Odessa Schlemeyer Field Airport.
A social media report indicated golf-ball sized hail in Cedar Hill.
Penny sized hail occurred near North Avenue E in Beeville.
A trained spotter reported hen egg size hail on U.S. Highway 190.
The Fort Stockton ASOS station recorded a maximum wind gust of 68 MPH with a likely microburst.
A storm chaser reported golf ball size hail 2 miles east of Wellington.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Paducah, TX measured severe wind gusts for ten minutes. No damage was reported.
Quarter sized hail occurred on Lindenwood Drive behind United High School.
A thunderstorm moved across Gaines County and produced a 62 mph wind gust near Seminole.
Ping pong ball sized hail was reported 1 mile southeast of Lacy-Lakeview.
Retired NWS employee reported measured hail up to 2 inches in diameter just west of the intersection of Davis Blvd and North Tarrant Pkwy.
The public estimated the thunderstorm wind gusts just northwest of Wayside.
Leonard VFD reported 1 inch hail.
Winds blew street signs down near Victoria Mall.
Penny size hail was reported along Farm-to-Market Road 837 near the town of Bradford.
A large tree was blown down by strong winds at East Walker and Eden.

The tornado touched down in the small community of Old Union east of Simms, Texas.  A small portion of a roof to a home was removed along with two metal garage doors that were pushed inward.  A few trees were wither uprooted or snapped.  The tornado was rated an EF1 on the Enhanced Fujita Scale with a path length of 3 miles and a path width of 50 yards.  The tornado lifted approximately 315 pm...one mile west of the community of Old Boston.  DOD-2.

Several reports of large hail were received from areas of southern Lubbock County as thunderstorms increased in coverage during the mid morning hours of the 10th. Law enforcement officials initially reported dime to quarter size hail along County Road 1600 between Alcove and Upland Avenues at 08:17 CST. Trained storm spotters additionally reported penny size hail near the intersection of South Loop 289 and U.S. Highway 84.
Law enforcement reported a power line down on east Lee Street.
Multiple reports of downed trees and powerlines due to a tornado along us Highway 207 in far southern Armstrong County.
Widespread trees down, including on homes and vehicles, was reported across Henderson County.
Quarter size hail was reported along US-277 near View.
Trees and power lines down from near Esperanza to Fort Hancock. Barn blown down, tin roofing peeled from several barns and older buildings.
An eighteen wheeler was reported blown over and a house lost its roof.
Golfball size hail was reported by law enforcement officials on Highway 385 north of Needmore.
Half dollar size hail fell in Lone Star.
Pictures and videos were received via social media of multiple funnel clouds observed between Progreso and Weslaco. Timing is estimated.
Quarter sized hail was observed at the intersection of FM 646 and FM 517. Report came from a Spaceflight Meteorology Group (SMG) meteorologist.
Leonard VFD reported golf ball sized hail in the city of Leonard.
A storm spotter measured a 65 MPH wind gust about 1 mile south of Springtown. Small tree limbs were also knocked down.
Large steel framed building blown down by high winds.
Nickel size hail was reported at MacArthur Blvd and Interstate 635 in Irving.

Discrete thunderstorms developed over the southern Texas Panhandle during the evening hours of the 16th. One of these thunderstorms developed over northern Carson County and moved to the south-southeast across the county. A trained storm spotter 7 miles north-northeast of Pantex reported quarter size hail (1.00 inch) as the thunderstorm moved overhead. The thunderstorm continued to move to the south-southeast across the county after producing this hail.
A fence was blown away.

This is a continuation of the Cherokee and Northwest Nacogdoches County tornado that tore through the Alto and Sacul communities. This tornado crossed County Roads 4265 and 4238 in extreme Southern Rusk County, where numerous trees were snapped and uprooted. The tornado continued northeast across the East Fork Angelina River, Highway 84, and County Road 4233, where it began to weaken as much of the damage over these areas consisted of snapped large limbs. The tornado finally lifted on County Road 4233 near the intersection of FM 2753. The maximum estimated winds in Southern Rusk County was near 105 mph primarily in the area of County Roads 4265 and 4238.
A social media report showed half-dollar sized hail along CR 213 south of FM 1807.
A COOP observer reported three power poles down on the west end of his farm.
Lightning reportedly caused a car fire, melting the cars antenna and battery.
Many trees were knocked down at Purtis Creek State Park, and the clean up took about a week to complete.
Quarter size hail was reported by a storm chaser.
Several reports were received indicating power lines and power poles down, fences down and trees down across Tarrant County.
There was damage to a large shed like structure near Sebesta Lane.

A member of the public located 8 miles east-southeast of Lefors estimated the largest hail stones to be quarter size. This occurred as a cluster of multicell thunderstorms moved east across the county. No other hail reports were received in Gray County although the storms generally remained over rural areas.
Trees blown down with power. outages in Brady.
A member of the public reported hailstones estimated to be the size of nickels hail 3 miles west-southwest of Borger.
Public reported half dollar hail in Kosse.
A trained spotter reported a funnel cloud 2 miles northwest of Weinert.

A Taco Bell sign was destroyed, the sheet metal roof of a funeral home was peeled back, a plate glass window was blown out, and numerous trees were uprooted.  The weathernet site has a wind gust to 58 miles an hour.
Law enforcement reported nickel to quarter size hail in McCamey.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail northwest of Marble Falls.
A thunderstorm produced a wind gust measured at 58 mph by the ASOS at Laughlin AFB.
Spotter reported 1 inch hail in Garland.
A social media report indicated golf ball sized hail in the northern part of the city of Carrollton, TX.
Emergency manager reported 2 inch hail. Reports of 1.25 inch and 1.75 inch hail were also received within Vernon city limits between 7:06 and 7:11pm CST.
A severe thunderstorm produced quarter size hail east of New Waverly.

Broadcast media reported damage in Somerville around the school campus. One home sustained major damage from a fallen tree. One vehicle was damaged by a fallen tree. No injuries were reported. Wind gusts were estimated at 70 MPH.
Broadcast media reported measured 1.25 inch hail.
Damage to 30 ft high billboard near the intersection of Bellaire Boulevard and Stella Link Road.
A combination of heavy rainfall and accumulating hail resulted in minor flooding of several city streets in Post. No road closures or damages were reported.

Spotters watched a large one quarter mile wide tornado that moved across the northeast portion of lake Stamford. This tornado came within yards of hitting the lake Stamford power plant, however it did knock down 11 transmission poles coming out of the power plant and eight distribution poles. This tornado was also filmed by a weather broadcaster from a local Abilene television station.
Reported by the Sheriff's Office.
Metal Building System (MBS). Column anchorage failed.
One inch diameter hail was reported by amateur radio 3 miles west of Krum.
Skywarn storm spotters reported golfball size hail along Texas Farm to Market Road 1081 northwest of Clairemont.
Barns, a porch and some trees were damaged near CR 111.
A picture was posted on Facebook. The time was based on radar.
A thunderstorm moved across Glasscock County and lightning struck and caused a tank battery fire near Garden City.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.  There were no injuries reported.
The public reported small tree branches blown down in downtown San Angelo.
Nickle size hail reported for 20 minutes in San Diego.
Thunderstorm winds caused some carport and fencing damage.
These strong winds knocked down power poles about 5 miles east of Brady on highway 190.
Golf ball size hail was observed in Bellville.
Golf ball size hail fell, damaging several cars and knocking out at least one windshield.  Roofs were also damaged.
A brief rope tornado was witnessed by a storm spotter approximately 5 miles south-southwest of Higgins. An EF-U rating was assigned as the tornado remained in open grassland.
Numerous tree limbs down.
A thunderstorm produced hail up to half dollar size in Sun City.
The KCBD television station on the southeast side of town measured a 59 mph wind gust.
Public report of golf ball-sized hail off of US Highway 87. Time is estimated from radar.
Quarter size hail was reported on I-30 at mile marker 125 on the southeast side of Sulphur Springs.
KHLR measured a 67 mph wind gust.
A 50 foot tall oak tree with a 16 inch wide trunk was blown down across the 5000 block of East Lake Drive in the Union Grove community.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet station near Morton.

A very slow moving thunderstorm tracked across the northwestern portion of Plainview and produced heavy rainfall. The Sheriff's Office in Hale County reported that Farm to Market Road 194 was flooded on the north side of Plainview.
Golfball to hen egg size hail fell in Winnsboro.
Golf ball size hail was reported in Deport.
A brief tornado was reported to have multiple funnels. The viewer was located approximately 20 miles to the southeast of the tornado.

A four and a half inch diameter tree limb was blown down on the Abilene Christian University campus. Also, debris and tree limbs were cleared from city streets, and along Highway 36 near Abilene Regional Airport.

Destructive straight-line winds spread south-southwest in the rear flank downdraft of a supercell creating scattered to widespread damage in and around the city of Paducah. These winds caused a swath of damage to trees, power lines, homes, vehicles, and other buildings from about 4NE Paducah southwest to the south side of the city. An NWS storm survey indicated winds up to 100 mph partially swept away a multi-car garage and overturned one car in the process. Three other vehicles inside suffered various degrees of damage. Sheet metal from the garage was found to be blown southwest nearly 300 yards from its origin. On the north side of Paducah, a portion of a large warehouse collapsed from straight line winds of similar intensity. Several vehicles in Paducah had windows blown out by airborne gravel and other small debris. Fortunately, no injuries were reported as residents received ample warning to seek shelter.
A mobile home was unroofed between Krum and Ponder.
A public report indicated quarter-sized hail approximately 1 mile west of the city of Clifton, TX.
Golf ball sized hail was reported in Carbon.
Severe thunderstorm winds blew a tree down onto FM Road 1791.
Trees were downed by strong wind gusts along CR-106 to the northwest of Rock Island.
1 fatality was reported near Hagansport when a tree fell on top of a mobile home on CR 1040.
Trained spotters reported ping pong ball sized hail.
A picture was posted to social media showing a tree fell on a truck in Kirbyville.
Ping pong ball sized hail was reported 7 miles north of Callisburg.
An off-duty NWS meteorologist reported quarter size hail on the southwest side of town.
Power lines were blown down by high winds.
Trees were downed on County Road 2212.
Estimated thunderstorm winds of 60-70 mph were reported in Sherman by a local newspaper reporter. Powerlines and trees were knocked down in the city.
Reported via mPing.
Power lines were downed along Highway 77 in town.
A thunderstorm produced lots of nickel size hail along with some quarter size south of Ingram.
Power lines were blown down 3 miles east of Love Field.
Trees downed.
A storm chaser reported quarter size hail covering the ground six miles northeast of Abernathy.
Dime size hail covered the ground.
Trained spotter reported quarter sized hail 2 miles south of Jewett via amateur radio.
Numerous power poles and trees were reported down north of Highway 82 between Texoma Parkway and Loy Lake Road. Additional wind damage was also noted to the north and east of this location.

Local newspapers published photos of standing water that ponded over a number of roadways in the Levelland area following early morning heavy rainfall. Unofficial rainfall totals reportedly approached 3.00 inches during the overnight storms, but a nearby Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site recorded only 1.52 inches. Minor flooding of low lying areas and turn rows was reported along U.S. Highway 385 and Alaska Road.
Tree was downed on Birch Street due to thunderstorm winds.

A storm chaser reported a snapped power pole at the intersection of Farm to Market Roads 400 and 788 northeast of Plainview. The snapped power pole was likely due to rear flank downdraft winds within the supercell.
An isolated severe thunderstorm traveled across Pecos county, producing hen egg size hail southeast of Bakersfield.
Law enforcement reported trees blown down in Call.
Several trees were reported down and power outages in the town of Penitas.
Several trees were downed near Talco, Texas.
A thunderstorm produced nickel size hail just north of San Antonio International Airport.
Trees and power lines were downed on Highway 1113 in Maud.
Golf ball size hail reported along FM 350.
Public report of ping pong size hail was from mping.
Meridian VFD reported nickel sized hail.
A public report indicated half dollar sized hail near Elkhart.
Several trees were blown down along county roads near Highway 51 northeast of Springtown.
Trees were downed on Hwy. 44 south of Annona, Texas.
The public reported that the quarter size hail had covered the ground.
A thunderstorm moved across Brewster County and produced an estimated 60 mph wind gust.
Hail was in size of dimes with a few quarters along Highway 287.
Amateur radio report of golf ball sized hail in Pecan Plantation.
Several trees were downed across the county.
Measured by the West Texas Mesonet site near Gail. Indicated wind gust was the average gust over a fifteen minute period.
A 62 mph wind gust was measured in the southern portions of Reno.
Broadcast media reported roof damage to a strip shopping center on Bosque Blvd.
Niclel to quarter size hail was reported.
Quarter size hail fell 3 miles east-southeast of Washburn.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail southwest of Castroville.
Severe thunderstorms winds rolled over two mobile homes and blew down trees and power lines northwest of Sayers.
The damaging thunderstorm winds blew down trees, power lines and damaged one boat.
Golf ball size hail reported near Bogata.
Hail of 1.25 inches was reported near the intersection of highway 277 and Loop 306.

No injuries were reported. The tornado severely damaged several homes and outbuildings...uprooted or snapped large trees...and knocked down powerlines.  The tornado crossed the Oklahoma and Texas state line along State Highway 152...fifteen miles east of the town of Wheeler.
Large amounts of baseball sized hail was reported southeast of Valley Mills.
A thunderstorm moved across Pecos County and produced a funnel cloud north northwest of Bakersfield.

Scattered thunderstorms developed across Collingsworth County during the evening hours of the 12th. As a storm approached the town of Dozier (Collingsworth County), the West Texas Mesonet site three miles west of Dozier recorded a 68 mph downburst. After producing this downburst the storm continued to move eastward across the county.
Baseball size hail fell at the intersection of Highway 259 and County Road 317.
Multiple trees were blown down along FM 230 near Lovelady.
A wind gust of 59 MPH was reported by the automated weather station at Cox Field (KPRX).

An off duty inspector for Zapata County reported, and photographed, wind damage to an under construction foam building in Zapata after a vigorous outflow boundary/gust front crossed the area during the late afternoon of September 29th.  Winds at nearby Zapata County Airport (Medina) were clocked at 44 mph 5 minutes earlier. Construction type and damage, combined with no nearby reports of more traditional damage (large limbs, roof material, etc.) suggested a pulse gust below 58 mph.
No damage was reported.
The wind gust caused minor roof damage, as well as minor tree and power line damage. Monetary damages were estimated.
A thunderstorm produced one inch hail in Bulverde.
An abandoned house near Agnes suffered wind damage.  The house that collapsed was made of plywood and had a metal roof.  A couple trees were blown onto carports and debris was blown through windows.
Amateur radio personnel reported 2 brief tornado touchdowns simultaneously just south of lawn in southern Taylor County.
A NWS cooperative weather observer reported quarter size hail. No damage was reported.

On County Road 1450 near Chico, a mobile home was blown off its foundation, part of the roof was torn off a second home, a barn was destroyed, a boat was tossed, trees were uprooted or snapped near the top, and other outbuildings were blown into trees. Additional scattered tree damage extended northeast of this location into southern Montague County. A NWS survey determined straight-line winds caused this damage.

As a line of thunderstorms moved across Oldham and Deaf Smith County, tree limbs were blown down in Adrian (Oldham County). An estimation of 60 mph outflow winds from the thunderstorms was determined using radar.
A mobile home was moved off it's blocks, a barn was destroyed, the concession stand of a ball field was destroyed, fences were blown down, and numerous trees were blown down.
On Junius Street in San Angelo, a power pole was snapped in the alley.
Public reported via Facebook that a tree was blown down in Buna.
Numerous large trees were downed.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail in Round Rock.
A National Weather service Employee reported hail up to three quarters of an inch in size fell at the Sunrise Mall in Brownsville during a thunderstorm.
Golf ball sized hail was reported in, and west of, the city of Priddy.
A motel was unroofed by high winds. Large signs were blown down.
Emergency management reported poles from a driving range netting were snapped and blown onto an apartment complex in the city of Carrollton, TX.
Trees were blown down on FM 910 near Clarksville.
A large tree was downed across Hwy. 155.
Amateur radio reported a 60 MPH wind gust approximately 1 mile northwest of Comanche, TX.
A public report indicated penny-sized hail approximately 7 miles north-northeast of the city of Sadler, TX.
Trees and power lines down near State Line Road.

A pair of severe storms produced large hail in southern Gaines County. Emergency management officials reported nickel size hail along Farm to Market Road 181 in southwestern Gaines County. Nickel size hail also was reported along U.S. Highway 385 south of Seminole.

A 62 MPH thunderstorm wind gust was measured at North Texas Regional Airport (KGYI). The doors of the T-hangers and GYI hanger were slightly pushed in. The HVAC unit on the American Bank hangar was blown over. Hangar 5513 had one door blown in, another door broken, and two garage doors damaged. Some small windows were broken and other buildings were missing shingles.
Numerous large trees were snapped at their base in Benbrook.

An automated observation site on top of Mount Locke in the Davis Mountains recorded strong east to northeast winds as the center of Tropical Depression Claudette moved across the Big Bend of West Texas. A peak wind of 53 MPH was recorded at 1220 CST. Maximum sustained winds reached 28 MPH at 1225 CST. Frequent gusts between 40 and 50 MPH were common. Strong east winds were also recorded by automated observing systems in the Guadalupe Mountains as Tropical Depression Claudette moved south of that mountain range. Channeling of east winds through Guadalupe Pass (5,500 feet MSL) resulted in localized topographically enhanced tropical storm force winds, but these winds were not representative of the storm's ambient wind strength at that time. Such winds were observed at 2151 CST when sustained winds reached 41 MPH (36 kt) with gusts to 46 MPH (40 kt), and again at 2351 CST with sustained winds of 44 MPH (38 kt) with gusts to 52 MPH (45 kt). Winds which were more representative of the ambient gradient wind were measured at The Bowl (7,755 feet MSL) where maximum sustained winds reached 35 MPH (30 kt) at 2104 CST. Gusts at The Bowl reached 70 MPH (61kt) at 0104 CST.
Law enforcement reported lots of pea size hail and estimated a thunderstorm wind gust of 60 mph in Early.
Winds were estimated near 60 mph south of Whitehouse, Texas.
A few trees downed at Junction of FM 1751 and FM 103.
One and a quarter inch diameter hail was reported 1 mile west of Ringgold.
A tree was downed at mile marker 612 on Interstate 20.
Storm spotters reported a wind gust of 83 mph on I-20 near Wills Point.
Several large trees were down in Crowley.
A picture of quarter size hail was posted to the KTRE-TV Facebook page.
The public reported tennis ball size hail on the north side of Brady.
Quarter size hail fell 2 miles southeast of Fritch. The time of occurrence has been estimated from radar data.
An irrigation center pivot was destroyed by severe thunderstorm winds just northwest of Spade.
Trees were blown down onto Main and International streets.
Minor structural damage occurred to a building. Power line damage was also reported. Monetary damages were not available.
Golf ball to 2 hail was reported from south of Goldthwaite east along CR 306. Some windows were broken south of Goldthwaite on Hwy 183.
Nickel size hail fell in 60 to 65 mph winds on the Midland/Upton County line.
Baseball sized hail was reported at the Lockheed Martin Fire Control Facility on Marshall Drive.
KBPT ASOS recorded a wind gust of 52 knots.
Law enforcement officials reported golfball size hail.
Two roofs were damaged in Kerens. Trees were also down and power outages were reported in the city.
A mobile home was blown over.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that uprooted a tree on Ave. I in Poteet.
A trained spotter reported a wind gust of 63 MPH about 4 miles east-southeast of Forney, TX.
Wind gust was measured by the KF05 AWOS station at the Vernon Airport. This wind gust may have been due to a dry microburst.
A thunderstorm produced a wind gust measured at 61 kts by the ASOS at Pleasanton Municipal Airport.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that snapped some eight to 10 inch diameter trees about four to five feet above the ground.
A trained spotter estimated 60-65 MPH winds on Mountain Creek Parkway.
Quarter sized hail occurred at FM 762 and Meyer Field airport.
A trained spotter reported large tree branches down at the intersection of Collins Rd and Cleveland St in Denton, TX.
A chimney was blown out to the side of a house. A detached garage or outbuilding also had minor door damage.

A NWS survey team found the damage in Lavon was consistent with straight line winds up to 75 mph. A local weather station in Lavon also measured 75 mph winds at the time. Most of the damage observed was to large tree limbs, shingles on roofs, and fences. A bank drive through also collapsed. Aluminum panel roofing was removed from one business and one manufactured home.
A thunderstorm produced half dollar size hail in Lockhart.
Several trees were knocked down in San Angelo when a line of thunderstorms moved through the area. There were also a few power lines that were knocked down as well.
A social media report indicated quarter-sized hail near Eagle Mountain Lake.
The hail fell near Texas State Highway 70 and U.S. Highway 60.

A cluster of thunderstorms developed along a stalling cold front during the evening hours of the 8th. This cluster of thunderstorms moved to the south across the northern Texas Panhandle. Penny size hail (0.75 inches) was reported by Pantex officials (Carson County). The storm that produced this hail continued moving to the south across the county.
Penny sized hail 14 miles north of Fort Worth.
A thunderstorm produced nickel size hail near the University of the Incarnate Word.
The report was from mping.
Very large hail fell up to 3.25 inches in diameter 3 miles east-southeast of Vega.
Estimated by the Emergency Manager.
A member of the public reported golf ball size hail Colleyville.
A wind gust was estimated to be 60 mph. Dime size hail was also reported.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 50 to 60 mph that knocked down some one inch tree limbs near Buda.
Trees were blown down by high winds.
Ping pong sized hail was reported.
Damaging winds associated with a severe thunderstorm completely blew a roof off of a medical clinic in Zapata.  The winds also destroyed a mobile home and damaged canopies at a gas station.
A trained spotter reported a 63 MPH wind gust in the city of Pottsboro, TX.
Several reports of multiple funnel clouds were received west of Port Lavaca, near the Green Lake area.
Golfball size hail fell 1 mile north of Strawn.
Lightning started a house fire on Claybrook in Wylie. Damage occurred to the attic and second story of the home.
The West Texas Mesonet 3 miles west-northwest of Doole reported a wind gust of 73 mph along with a few gusts over 60 mph from 10:17 to 10:32 PM CDT.

Law enforcement reported that four utility poles were toppled by strong gusty winds which occurred during a squall line which moved through Hebbronville late Wednesday evening June 2nd.  There was a brief power loss affecting the entire city of Hebbronville as a result of the utility pole damages.  At 834 PM CST, the public reported estimated gusts of 50 mph on the leading edge of the line.  At Hebbronville Airport (about 4 miles northwest of town), a peak gust of 38 mph was recorded at 820 PM CST.
A funnel cloud was sighted south of the Fort Bend Toll Road at Highway 6.
The Abilene Police Department reported a utility pole down in the Button Willow area of Abilene.
Pea to quarter size hail fell 4 miles southwest of Lelia Lake.
Trees and power lines downed throughout the county.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail in Fredericksburg.
A National Weather Service Cooperative Observer reported pecan tree limbs blown down. The time was estimated from radar.
A brief tornado touchdown occurred with no known damage.
Thunderstorm winds downed a tree and knocked over some street signs.
Hail was reported along Hwy. 80 between Longview and Marshall, Texas.
Nickel size hail covering the ground was reported.
A tree was blown down in the Woodlawn community.
Man injured in Hillje while trying to cover a grain trailer with a tarp when wind gust blew him down.
Trees were downed across SR. 11 just northeast of Leesburg, Texas.
60 mph wind gust reported by Border Patrol checkpoint 16 miles southwest of Freer on U.S. 59.
Large tree limbs (greater than 2 inches in diameter) were reported down, and 6 roofs were removed from barns.
Baseball size hail fell 2 miles west-southwest of Pottsboro.

A severe thunderstorm produced a swath of damaging winds, accompanied by large hail, from the Levelland vicinity to near Ropesville. A meteorologist initially estimated winds gusting up to 60 mph west of Levelland along Texas Highway 114 at 20:23 CST.
