By 20:30 CST, the Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site south of Levelland recorded a peak gust of 74 mph. The winds downed numerous power lines and utility poles. A roof was blown off of an apartment complex in Levelland, where a storm chaser measured a peak gust of 63 mph. No injuries occurred, but the American Red Cross assisted several families that became homeless due to the damage at the Lone Star Town Homes. All four families, a total of seventeen people, required assistance. In addition, a local AM radio station sustained damage. A Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet meteorologist later estimated winds up to 65 mph near Ropesville.
Emergency management reported quarter sized hail near the intersection of Brown Trail and Highway 183 in the city of Bedford, TX.
A thunderstorm moved over Pecos County and produced penny sized hail fourteen miles south southwest of Imperial.
A tree was downed along 7100 Tram Road in Beaumont.
Multiple accidents reported along US 77. 2 18 wheelers flipped southbound. 1 18 wheeler reported flipped northbound.
Wind damage reported in Alto via mPING.
Wind damage along FM 709 south of Corsicana stretching east along Highway 31, and points south around US 287 near Mildred.
The local newspaper reported multiple trees were knocked down by thunderstorm winds.
A man on a bicycle suffered very minor injuries when struck by lightning.
Several trees downed.  Some power lines were pulled down.
Hen egg sized hail in Kempner damaged vehicles.

A discrete thunderstorm moved southeastward across Carson County during the morning hours of the 19th. The outflow from this storm lifted a trampoline in Skellytown (Carson County), and lofted it into a tree. The thunderstorm continued moving to the southeast after producing this outflow.

A rapidly intensifying supercell moved to the northeast across southern Grey County. A storm chaser traveling north along US Highway 70 intercepted the storm south of the Farm to Market road 2447 and US Highway 70 intersection. The storm chaser reported that the supercell produced hen egg size hail on US Highway 70. The supercell continued a northeasterly track and crossed Farm to Market road 2477 before merging with a developing squall line.
Social media reports indicated widespread tree damage from the derecho in the Prairie View area.
Parker County Fire and Rescue reported that a 2-car garage was destroyed near HWY 51 and Carter Road, approximately 4 miles south of Springtown, TX.
Quarter sized hail was reported.
Thunderstorm winds downed two palm trees on Harborside Drive and 29th Street.
Several trees were downed near the town of Karnack, Texas.
A thunderstorm moved across Pecos County and produced a tornado near FM 2886 and Harral Road.  No damage was reported so the tornado was rated as an EF-0.
Occurred 3 miles south of Antelope.
Three barns damaged and phone poles down (reported by Lavaca Navidad River Authority).
A 70 MPH wind gust was measured at the National Weather Service office in Fort Worth, TX.
Quarter size hail was reported by the public via Facebook near the intersection of Business 83 and 23rd Street in McAllen.
Amateur radio operators reported quarter sized hail in Red Oak.
A thunderstorm produced half dollar size hail on the south shore of Lake Amistad.
Reported via mPING 8 miles north of Bonham.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail in Utopia.
Report from mPING: Golf Ball (1.75 in.).
Richland Hills police department reported a 10 to 12 foot section of a  roof blew into a street and damaged a car.  Additionally, a roof was blown off a vacant building in Haltom City.

An NWS Storm Survey found more than 50 percent of shingles off on a two story building with full exposure to the west-northwest along S 29th St in McAllen. To the southeast of there, a tin roof and over a dozen trusses and rafters were taken off a lumber store and blown across the road. Additionally, the parapet roof over the Ross Department store was partially blown off. The roof was approximately 50 feet off the ground.
A thunderstorm produced baseball size hail on FM 609 between Mach Rd. and Black Jack Rd. near O'Quinn.
A thunderstorm moved across Terrell County and produced hail damage near Sanderson.  A windshield was broken by two inch hail on Highway 90 west of Sanderson.  The cost of damage is a rough estimate.
Amateur radio operators reported golf ball sized hail in Granbury.
Powerlines downed.
Amateur radio operator reported quarter size hail.
The emergency manager also reported a snapped power pole at the local airport associated with this wind gust.

A small tornado touched down near Hayride Road about 5 miles east of the Austin Bergstrom Airport and moved north near 1/2 mile, crossing Pearce Lane before lifting and dissipating.  Shortly after it touched down, it struck a permanent home, causing it to collapse.  The collapse may have been partially due to the type of construction.  Seconds later it struck several mobile homes, causing only minor damage.  It then struck a second permanent home, causing damage to the roof.  The resident of this second home was asleep at the time and awoke to a "rumbling" sound shortly before windows started blowing in.  He sought shelter in an interior bathroom tub.
Quarter sized hail was reported.
A brick facade of the MLK Community Center was destroyed by strong thunderstorm wind gusts.
A Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet station located 10 miles southwest of Paducah measured a 60 mph severe thunderstorm wind gust.
MPing report.
A thunderstorm produced half dollar size hail and wind gusts estimated at 55 mph.
A thunderstorm produced two inch hail east of Boerne.
Power lines were downed.
Golfball size hail fell at the intersection of Skillman St. and Richmond Ave. northeast of Downtown Dallas.
Lightning struck the home of an elderly man in the Lower Greenville area of Dallas. The house was a total loss, but neighbors helped get the man safely out of the house unharmed.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 58 mph that blew down some wooden fencing and tore shingles from a roof.
Emergency management reported quarter sized hail 3 miles east-southeast of Denison, TX.
A home in the Chisholm Springs subdivision in Newark, TX was struck by lightning. The bolt set the house on fire, destroying it. Three girls inside the home escaped without injury.

Two thunderstorms merged northwest of Borger (Hutchinson County) around the 9 PM CST hour before collapsing upon it's own updraft. This produced an estimated 95 mph microburst in Borger (Hutchinson County). The microburst winds slowed as reaching the southern portion of the town, and a member of the public on the south side of Borger (Hutchinson County) reported a 60 mph gust.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that blew over a grain bin and some yard fixtures near Falls City.

A swath of quarter to half dollar size hail fell to the north of Lake Tanglewood. Hail of at least quarter size fell near Circle C Trail and Claude Highway. Window and gutter damage occurred as well as some vehicle damage, which included a significant amount of small dents in the hood and top of a pickup truck. Hail broke one window in a chicken coop and damaged a vinyl gutter.

A collapsing thunderstorm produced destructive downburst winds measured up to 88 mph by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet station northeast of Friona. Two quarter-mile long irrigation pivots located just east of the mesonet were flipped over. In Friona, similar winds caused widespread light to moderate structural damage mostly to fences, roofs and trees. A hangar door at the airport also sustained damage.
A trained spotter reported hail up to golf ball size in diameter during a thunderstorm which moved north between Raymondville and Perlita during the afternoon of June first.

A storm severely impacted the area near and south of Paducah. The Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site 10 miles southwest of Paducah measured a wind gust to 80 mph. A schoolnet site in Paducah measured a wind gust to 64 mph 11 minutes later. There were also multiple reports of thunderstorm wind damage especially at Paducah High School. The Paducah fire department reported utility poles downed 10 miles south of Paducah. Minor structural damage was reported at Paducah High School including severe damage to the press box at the football field. Additionally, the garage door was blown in at the High School agricultural building with accompanying tree damage in the area.
Large signs blown down.
Multiple trees and large branches were down near CR 1373 near State Highway 6. The winds were estimated at 70 mph. Time estimated by radar.
Storm spotter reported wind gusts to 55 mph
A wind gust of 63 mph was measured at the West Texas University Mesonet site located 2 miles west-northwest of Hereford.
Trees and power lines were downed near Oak Hollow Boulevard and FM 1488.
The report was relayed by amateur radio.
There was an eight inch diameter tree branch blown down.
The West Texas Mesonet station southwest of Graham reported 59 mph thunderstorm wind gusts.
Measured by the Texas Tech/West Texas Mesonet.
Siding was blown off to the Cougar Stop convivence store in Buna.
There was quarter sized hail in the Friendswood area and there were also several trees downed in the area of Tall Ships Lane.
Quarter size hail fell in the Leary community.
Trees downed in town...including one that fell on a house.
Reported by NWS employee near Staples and Holly.
A tornado destroyed a barn and blew over a tractor trailer.
The Terry County Sheriff's Office reported golfball size hail.
Powerlines were downed in the Lake Gladewater community.
Trees downed in Hawkins.
Nickel size hail fell in the city of Nocona.
One telephone pole was snapped off near the top. Several other power poles were damaged. Monetary damages were estimated.

The broadcast media relayed photographs of a non-mesocyclonic tornado near U.S. Highway 62/82 north of Meadow. The tornado reportedly remained in open country just south of the Hockley and Terry County line for approximately ten minutes.
Porch destroyed on Highway 60.
High winds broke a utility pole on the frontage road of Highway 75 near Howe.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 58 mph that uprooted a large tree and peeled a tin roof off a barn.
Severe thunderstorm winds blew down trees along SH532 east of Moulton.
Broadcast media reported nickel to dime sized hail covering the ground on FM 929.
A thunderstorm produced dime to golf ball size hail that dented some cars east of Frio Town.
Strong thunderstorm winds downed trees and damaged power lines, resulting in loss of power to residents.
A thunderstorm produced a 59 mph wind gust at the Seminole Mesonet site.

Several trees and tree limbs were knocked down in Temple by strong thunderstorm winds. Many of the fallen trees and limbs blocked several roads. Temple Fire Station #4 sustained minor roof damage; part of the metal awning of the roof was peeled off.
The report was relayed by amateur radio. Location is approximate.
Several power poles were knocked down in the View area where U.S. Highway 277 intersects County Road 209 and Farm to Market Road 1235.
Reported from Ceta Canyon.
Quarter size hail was reported in De Kalb, Texas.

NWS employees viewed a storm chaser's live stream of a very brief tornado. The funnel cloud extended 1/3 of the way down and kicked up a narrow debris cloud for less than 20 seconds. This tornado remained over open land and caused no damage.
Partial roof loss and damage occurred at a storage facility on FM 521 south of Brazoria.
Trees were blown down across County Road 413.
Numerous reports of trees and power lines across roads in Coffee City and Berryville.
Hail covered the ground at Wolf Creek State Park and turned the ground white.

Widespread straight line wind damage was reported across parts of Jackson County as a strong thunderstorm moved through the area. This included extensive tree damage as well as damage to power lines and some buildings.
Two weak landspout tornadoes were reported about 12 miles north of Sierra Blanca.  Both lasted an unknown amount of time with no injuries or damage reported from them.
Trained spotters reported ping pong ball sized hail in Flower Mound.
A 24 year old female was killed in a chain reaction accident on Ranger Hill in rainy conditions.
Reported by NBC/KCBD11 Storm Chaser.
Lightning struck the second floor of an apartment complex near the intersection of FM 528 and Blackhawk Blvd in Friendswood and set fire to several units.
Fire and rescue reported quarter-sized hail on FM Highway 47 near FM Highway 276, west of the city of Emory, TX.

A swath of large hail occurred across Clarendon, resulting from a supercell that formed just to the west of the city. Hail ranged from 1.5 inches up to 4 inches. The 4 inch hailstone occurred 4 miles west northwest of Clarendon just south of Highway 287.
The tornado touched down over open country just north of Interstate 40. The path length and path width were estimated. No damage or injuries occurred with this tornado.
Golfball size hail covered the ground in Ballinger.

The Automated Surface Observing Station at Midland International Airport (KMAF) recorded several wind gusts above 70 mph over a 20 minute period, including two of 93 mph.  Shortly after the third recorded gust of 93 mph the power went out to much of the area around the airport, including the ASOS.  Observations were missing for the next 12 to 16 hours as power was eventually restored and the ASOS was repaired.  The 93 mph wind gust is the highest wind gust recorded at Midland International Airport.  ||Also, a trained spotter in Midland measured an 80 mph wind gust along with power outages on Farm to Market Road 1788 near Texas State Highway 158.  ||Numerous reports of damage occured in Midland including: numerous trees downed across Midland, including one at a television station and numerous trees at two apartment complexes, north facing windows at an apartment complex in north Midland, and a roof blown off a mobile home at the intersection of West County Road 150 and Farm to Market Road 1788.  Two local news stations (KMID and KWES) went off the air due to satellite dish problems. At the Commemorative Air Force headquarters, a 75-by-25 foot section of the hangar's roof was ripped open and one ticket booth was destroyed.
Social media picture reported golf ball hail just to the SSE of Lewisville.
Lightning struck multiple oil tanks resulting in and explosion in Chapel Hill near the intersection of FM. 2607 and Smith County Road 223.
Emergency Management reported golf ball sized hail near the intersection of FM 2210 and Pump Station Road; approximately 3 miles northwest of Perrin, TX.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Muleshoe measured severe wind gusts from 2105 CST through 2125 CST. A peak wind gust of 67 mph was measured at 2105 and 2110 CST.
Golf ball size hail reported.
The ASOS at Port Isabel-Cameron County Airport (KPIL) recorded at wind gust of 59 knots, or 68 mph, at 1:38PM CDT.

A discrete thunderstorm developed over Lipscomb County during the early evening hours of the 18th. This storm intensified as it neared the town of Lipscomb (Lipscomb County), a member of the public one mile north of Lipscomb reported penny size hail (0.75 inch). The storm continued to move to the northeast after producing this hail.

A squall line of strong to severe thunderstorms moved through northern and central Brooks County during the late evening of June 2nd, producing gusty winds which knocked down some power lines in Falfurrias.  Law enforcement measured a gust of 54 mph at 922 PM CST as the line plowed through.
Several large trees downed across U.S. Highway 79 in the Panola area.
The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site in Dimmitt measured a 58 mph gust.
A thunderstorm produced half dollar size hail and covered the ground with hail.
The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet recorded a 73 mph gust near Tahoka at 23:00 CST. A subsequent gust of 61 mph was recorded at 23:05 CST. No damage was reported.
Golf ball sized hail was reported.
Vehicle windows were blown out in the parking lot of Liberty-Eylau High School southeast of Wake Villiage, Texas.
U.S. Military at Fort Hood reported penny sized hail near the intersection if Interstate 14 and TJ Mills Blvd. in the city of Killeen, TX.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site.
The broadcast media also reported dime size hail along with the thunderstorm wind gusts.

At 16:45 CST the Federal Aviation Administration relayed a pilot report of a tornado just west of Cotton Center (western Hale County). The tornado had formed along an outflow boundary beneath a rapidly developing severe thunderstorm. The highly visible landspout-type tornado was observed by many officials and the general public from portions of at least three counties as it moved west-northwestward over farm land until it dissipated just south of Corry (extreme eastern Lamb County) at 16:55 CST. ||An eyewitness reported that the tornado briefly broke-up as it crossed Texas Farm to Market Road 37 near the Hale and Lamb County line, then reformed as it crossed into Lamb County. Although no structural damage occurred, farmers reported that the track of the tornado was visible through cotton and wheat fields.
Corpus Christi International Airport ASOS measured a gust to 59 mph.
A trained spotter measured hail at 2.25 inches 4 miles west of Robert Lee.
Trees and power lines down along HWY 14 north of Groesbeck and near Fort Parker State Park.
A social media report indicated 4-inch diameter hail in Flower Mound.
Lightning struck a tree near De Berry and ignited a fire nearby. Hail was also observed, but a size was not reported.
Power lines down.
The Westridge Apartments suffered wind damage.  One unit destroyed, five had major damage, andthree had minor damage.
Trees were downed by a storm. Half inch hail was also reported.
Penny sized hail was reported 1 mile southwest of Grandview.
Golf ball sized hail was reported on Bullard Road near Highway 287.
Ping-pong size hail was reported in Burleson.
Quarter to half dollar size hail fell a few miles northeast of Daingerfield.
Social media pictures showed damage to the metal roof of a home, and a wall removed from a sheet metal outbuilding in Eastland.

A tornado formed approximately 3.5 miles southeast of Jacksboro, near the intersection of Fields Lane and U.S. 281.  The tornado formed in open pasture south of Hwy 281, then moved northeast and impacted 2 manufactured homes along Fields Lane, producing light roofing and siding damage.  The tornado crossed Hwy 281, producing damage to a commercial building system and another manufactured home on the east side of 281.  The tornado tracked northeast over mostly open pastureland, crossing U.S. Hwy 380 southeast of Jacksboro before dissipating.  The most significant damage occurred to the commercial building along Hwy 281, consistent with high end EF-0 intensity winds of 80 mph.
Public reported quarter size hail south of Cottondale.
The Decatur AWOS reported a wind gust of 55 knots.
No reports of damage accompanied the hail.
Local emergency management officials reported large hail up to the size of pennies in Slaton. The hail was accompanied by severe wind gusts.
A picture of hail 1.5 inches in diameter was received through social media.
Hail covered the ground.
Spotter reported a funnel cloud low to the ground west of Refugio.
A public report indicated penny-sized hail approximately 4 miles southeast of the city of Prosper, TX.
Dime to penny size hail reported 1.8 miles northwest of Sanger.
The largest hail stones were noted just to the northeast of Mason.
Amateur Radio reported 2 ft diameter trees and light poles down at Legacy Dr and Independence Pkwy in Plano.
Law Enforcement reported baseball size hail in Wall.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 65 mph that knocked down some six inch diameter tree limbs.
Hail ranging in size from dimes to golfballs was reported in the city of Alpine. No damage was reported.
Minor damage was reported to windows and roofs of buildings as well as vehicles in the Floresville area.
Mesonet station reported a wind gust of 74 mph.
Estimated by the public who called in for the report.
Numerous reports of tree damage throughout town.
Law enforcement reported baseball size hail on State Highway 16.
Wind gust of 61 MPH measured at Schoolnet site at Walcott.
Lightning started a fire at a house in south Grand Prairie.

A tornado reportedly touched down along FM 4668 just west of Aurora.  Trained spotters reported damage to a home under construction and to several trees.  Volunteer firefighters also reported seeing debris.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near McAdoo measured severe wind gusts from 1754 CST through 1804 CST. A peak gust of 71 mph was measured at 1758 CST.
Baseball size hail damaged homes and cars.
Several large trees down.
A storm chaser reported golf ball size hail north of Whitharral along US Highway 385.
Large hail was reported by local broadcast media.
A large tree was blown down on Highway 114 approximately 2 miles west of Jacksboro.
Penny sized hail at Monnig Middle School.
Reported via mPING south of Crowley.
Numerous trees were reported down across the county.
Trees were blown down around Kirbyville.
Half-dollar size hail was reported by an observer.

Initial damage to tree limbs and some poorly built roofs in the Mission/Palmview area would intensify by the time the downburst reached the Madero and Granjeno communities, where more than 100 homes sustained varying levels of damage, dozens of power poles were felled, and hundreds of softwood trees were uprooted. Specific damage and associated impacts included the following: At least 150 homes and businesses sustained notable damage, and several dozen required significant repair. This included varied damage to nearly every building (RV, trailer, and fixed structure) in the Chimney Park RV and Mobile Home Park along the Rio Grande, as well as the adjacent neighborhood of Madero. The State Farm Arena lost a large part of its cladding (side wall) and up to 40% of its roof shingles and underneath decking allowing rainwater to leak into the facility. A several thousand foot community center in the town of Granejo was destroyed as free-standing reinforced cinderblock walls crumbled, and the wind destroyed ductwork/HVAC and an entire side wall on its way out of the building. A tractor trailer weighing 79,000 pounds, including freight, was moved and then tipped on its side in the community of Madero. Hundreds of softwood trees were uprooted and thousands of tree limbs were snapped, these included ash, mesquite, ebony, and palm. Dozens of wooden power poles were snapped, with more than 20,000 customers without power.
Trees were down on Rosemary Lane.
Trees and power lines knocked down.
Reported via mPING south of Dublin.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail near Sayers.
Picture submitted through social media showed hail up to hen egg size fell near Ricardo.
A thunderstorm produced half dollar size hail in Brackettville.
Damage was not known.
Intense straight line winds accompanied hail as great as 4 inches in diameter.

Substantial wind damage occurred in and around Childress due to severe thunderstorm winds. At 1901 CST, the Automated Surface Observing System at the Childress Municipal Airport recorded a wind gust to 81 mph. Ten minutes later at 1911 CST, a trained spotter reported a wind gust to 87 mph five miles north of Childress on US Highway 83/62. In the city of Childress, a tractor trailer was blown over in a parking lot. Considerable damage came from the partial destruction of the Veteran's Memorial Wall in Childress as a large tree was blown over on the structure.
Broadcast media reported quarter sized hail about 2 miles north of Greenville, TX.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that blew down an eight inch diameter China Berry, a five inch diameter Elm, and many tree limbs.

A line of thunderstorms moved across Armstrong County during the evening hours of the 8th. As the southern portion of this line neared Goodnight (Armstrong County), the line took on a bowed appearance and a rear-inflow notch was evident on radar. A KVII Schoolnet site 15 miles south of Goodwell (Armstrong County) at JA Ranch reported a 62 mph thunderstorm gust as the bowed line moved overhead. The bowed line weakened after producing this gust and moved into the southeastern Texas Panhandle.
A delayed report from trained spotter indicated large trees split in Richland Hills.
According to a city official...a representative of the XCEL electric company reported that four thousand customers in Pampa and Lefors had lost power due to thunderstorm winds.
Small limbs were reported down at the intersection of Highway 66 and Interstate 30 east of Rockwall.
The public reported golf ball size hail 6 miles south of Santa Anna.
Nickel sized hail was observed.
Golfball size hail fell in the city of Montague.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 58 mph which blew a patio cover off a house and onto a road.
These winds were well ahead of the thunderstorms.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 40 mph that blew down some large tree limbs.
A trained spotter reported nickel size hail approximately 5 miles north of the city of Rhome, TX.
A 66 MPH wind gust was reported at Nolan Catholic High School in Fort Worth.
Several trees were blown down across the northwest portion of the county.
Trees blown down across the county.
Nickel size hail was observed at the intersection of Eldridge and Briar Forest.
Trees down along Highway 21 West.
Mission Police Department reported power lines and large tree branches down due to strong winds at the intersection of Inspiration and FM 495 and in the 1400 block of Doherty.
Nickel sized hail was reported to the north northwest of Huntsville.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail north of Gruene.
A thunderstorm moved across Midland County and produced a 65 mph wind gust at Midland International Air and Space Port.

A National Weather Service Cooperative Observer reported half dollar size hail in St. Lawrence. Multiple reports were received by local officials of additional large hail as the storm moved east of St. Lawrence during the next hour.
A tree was downed on Astor Road and FM. 2796.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that knocked down a large tree limb in Fort Clark Springs.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 50 mph which knocked down large tree limbs in Panna Maria and Kenedy.
Part of a tin roof was torn off a manufactured home in Granbury.
Several trees downed near FM Road 1798 and County Road 2174 near Laneville.

A 63 MPH wind gust was reported by the Automated Surface Observation System at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport. Trees were reported down just outside the airport property on Bedford Road in Bedford.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts measured at 52 kts. by the ASOS at Laughlin AFB.
Thunderstorm winds downed trees around the town of Brazoria and caused residential roof damage south of Angleton. There was also minor hanger damage reported at the Brazoria County Airport.
Reported in Woodriver subdivision in Calallen.

A National Weather Service storm survey crew found evidence of a tornado which began south of the city of Trinidad, and move northeast to the city of Malakoff. The tornado began by damaging several trees and homes near Trinidad. As the tornado moved northeast, trees were damaged along State Highway 34, before entering southwest Malakoff. Approximately 10 homes were damaged in Malakoff, with one home losing a chimney, part of the roof, and several large trees on the property.
Quarter size hail fell on the south side of Sherman.
A 61 mph wind gust was estimated at Denton Municipal Airport.

A thunderstorm moved across Ward County and produced wind damage south of Monahans. The damage swath included metal roofs/carports lifted or bent, downed tree branches between one to three inches in diameter, and several damaged travel trailers. The damage was generally oriented in an easterly direction. After re-analysis of radar data, the damage was determined to be the result of a microburst that occurred at approximately 9:15 pm CDT. The survey team estimated the peak wind speeds to be between 75 to 85 mph. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Reported at Loop 20 and Clark.
Member of the public shared pictures of damage to several large oak trees, including several large branches about 8 to 12 inches in diameter, that had snapped. Timing estimated by radar.
Trees and powerlines were blown down by high winds.
The Automated Surface Observing System at Fort Stockton (KFST) recorded a wind gust of 59 mph.
There were reports of wind damage to buildings. Also, several tree branches (3 to 4 inches in diameter) broken off and trash dumpsters overturned on County Road 495. The time was estimated by radar.
Dime to half dollar size hail fell and covered the ground along FM 838 just south of Overton and New London.
Power poles were downed.
Powerlines were downed east of Mount Enterprise, Texas.
A National Weather Service cooperative observer reported nickel size hail just south of Tell.
Half dollar size hail was measured 3 miles west-southwest of Dalhart.
Numerous power lines and trees were blown down and minor roof damage was reported.  Also, a barn was destroyed near Hewitt.
Multiple storm chasers published photograph and video evidence of an anticyclonic tornado that crossed from northern Floyd County into southern Briscoe County over open fields.
The Cottle County emergency manager estimated hail from quarter to golf ball size.  Damage was not known.
Hail was reported on the 571 Loop.
Law enforcement officials reported golfball size hail.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Lesley measured a wind gust to 84 mph.
Trees were downed by strong thunderstorm wind gusts. Some roof damage to homes was reported.
Over 60 MPH winds reported southeast of Ponder and southwest of Denton.
The public reported golf ball size hail in Erna.
Emergency management reported trees snapped or uprooted approximately 6 miles northeast of Sherman, TX.
The Anderson County emergency manager reported hail grew to the size of half dollars near Highway 294 and Farm to Market Road 1990.
Amateur Radio reports 4-6 inch tree limbs and 6-8 feet tall fences down near El Dorado Parkway and FM 423.

A trailer home was completely destroyed and concrete-rooted support posts were pulled out of the ground and tossed by high winds.  Numerous other trailer homes, sheds, awnings, chimneys, as well as a boat and a trampoline were damaged or destroyed by high wind.  Most of the damage occurred near the intersection of FM 637 and FM 2859 between Mildred and Eureka.
Golf ball sized hail was observed (via MPING).
Emergency management reported that outbuildings were damaged in the city of Ennis, TX.
Measured by the Texas Tech/West Texas Mesonet site in Paducah.
A Jefferson County DD6 Mesonet gauge located 2 miles west of Hamshire measured a six-hour rainfall total of 5.71 inches.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 80 mph that blew a large section of a roof off a house in Niederwald.
The Wilson County emergency manager reported several large tree limbs snapped by strong winds just west of Highway 181 between Poth and Falls City.
A photo of half dollar size hail that fell in the New Hope community just south of Bloomburg was posted to social media.
Trees downed.
A semi truck and travel trailer were overturned near the westbound Interstate 10 area of Alleytown and Columbus. A mobile home was blown over, and there were also multiple trees blown down.
Strong wind gusts downed some trees.
Baseball size hail.
Several trees and powerlines were downed in and around the city of Henderson, Texas.
An NWS employee reported several windows broken by baseball size hail.
Several roofs were reported blown off...cattle trucks were turned over...and power lines were blown down.
The Rotan Fire Department reported a wind gust of 60 mph.
Nickel to Quarter size hail fell at the intersection of  Loop 820 and Team Ranch Rd in southwest Ft. Worth.
Occurred in the Glen Garden area of Fort Worth.
The broadcast media reported that a viewer measured fifty-six knot winds from a home weather station located about one mile east of Canyon.
A trained spotter reported penny sized hail near the Texas Motor Speedway in Justin, TX.
Several trees reported down in McAllen.
Reports were received from both law enforcement and a storm chaser in Stonewall County of hail ranging from half dollar to golf ball size.
The observation site at KDTO reported a 68 mph wind gust.
Damage, if any, was not known.
A tree was downed on Farm to Market 2454 in the community of Brumley, Texas.
Spotter estimated wind gusts to 60 mph.
Reported by ASOS.
Numerous fences blown down, as well as roof and window damage reported in South Grand Prairie.
Several large tree limbs and at least one large tree was blown down in Normangee.
A thunderstorm produced penny size hail west-southwest of Hunter.
A trained spotter reported baseball size hail in Brady.
Penny sized hail was reported.
Tornado was reported by general public and relayed through law enforcement.  Tornado remained over open country producing no damage.
Tornado caused no damage near the Intracoastal Bridge on Highway 124 near the Chambers-Galveston county line.
Public reported half dollar coin size hail.
Quarter size hail was reported in Groom.
A barn was reported damaged.
Most homes in the Pear Valley community received damage from baseball size hail that fell for several minutes.
KRGV Television station reported that the public had reported a brief touchdown of a tornado near the town of Willamar. No damage was reported and there werent any homes in the area.
Quarter sized hail was reported in the Houston Heights area.
Trees and powerlines were downed.
Law enforcement officers spotted a tornado just to the south of Mason.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that knocked down a few large mesquite trees along Hwy 277 just north of Eagle Pass.
A 60 mph wind gust was estimated by a trained spotter.
Local fire department officials reported golfball size hail in Olton. No significant damages were reported.
A trained spotter reported half-dollar sized hail in the city of Loan Oak, TX.
Trees down.

A landspout tornado touched down approximately 10 miles north of Sunray. The tornado moved very little, remained in a field and did no damage, before lifting approximately 10 miles north of Sunray. This tornado was rated EF-0 with an estimated peak wind speed of 75 MPH. Location and path details are estimated based on photographs from a local storm spotter.
Kent County emergency management estimated winds of 50 to 60 mph.
McAllen Miller Airport (KMFE) ASOS reported peak wind gusts at minimal hurricane force, 74 mph.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph near the intersection of FM 1431 and Phillips Ranch Rd. in Granite Shoals. The winds knocked downed some trees.
A Facebook post reported nickel sized hail near Pottsboro.
Golf ball size hail fell for ten minutes north northeast of Big Spring.

An intense satellite tornado hit a few homes along Prairie Meadow Lane, just north of Celina (in unincorporated Collin County), causing destructive damage. At least 2 residences along this street sustained moderate to high end EF-3 damage (DI 2, DOD 7 & 8) with estimated maximum winds of 165 mph, with roofs and walls destroyed. Several additional homes sustained EF-2 or EF-1 damage along this street.

Storm chasers initially reported that quarter size hail had covered the ground in Abernathy at 21:13 CST.  A swath of large hail accompanied the parent storm east-northeastward to near Petersburg through 21:47 CST.  The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site northeast of Abernathy was severely damaged by the hail.
The Clyde Volunteer Fire Department estimated winds gusting to 65 mph.
Multiple reports of hail the size of golf balls to hen eggs in Pecos. Time verified by reports and radar.
University of Oklahoma Graduate Student and Storm Chasers report of a tornado.
A tree was blown down onto power lines on Don Long Road.

A line of thunderstorms moved out of the Oklahoma Panhandle and into the Texas Panhandle during the late night hours of the 22nd. As the line neared the town of Amarillo (Randall County), the KVII Schoolnet site 5 miles west-northwest of Timbercreek Canyon at Midway Alternative High School (Randall County) reported a 60 mph thunderstorm downburst gust. After producing this downburst gust the line continued to move to the south-southeast across the Texas Panhandle.
Numerous trees and power lines downed across Wood County.
Occurred at Sipe Springs.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet station.
Amateur radio reported quarter sized hail in the community of Moffat, TX.

A wind gust of 70 MPH was measured by the Automated Weather Observation System at Fort Cavazos Air Force Base (HLR, formerly known as Fort Hood). Damage was reported to several tents belonging to a unit that was in the field on Fort Cavazos. Four soldiers sustained minor injuries when the tents were damaged.  All the injuries were minor and the soldiers were returned to duty. Yoakum Defrenn Army Heliport reported they received some damage to one of the Hangars.
The fire department reported four inch hail 18 miles west of Coleman along Texas Highway 153.

A fast moving tornado briefly touched down at two points in southwest Houston. There was damage to a storage facility along and just west of Gessner Road, an apartment complex, and an office building. There were ten structures that had roof damage at the apartment complex, including one with complete roof removal and interior wall damage. A twelve story glass faade building just south of the apartment complex along Bissonnet Street had several north facing windows blown out. Damage was indicative of an EF1 tornado. There were four minor injuries at the apartment complex where the most significant damage occurred.
Trees were blown down onto County Road 107.
A 60 mph wind gust was measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet station south of Anton.
Public reported half dollar to ping pong ball size hail.
Quarter to half dollar size hail fell in the Burke community.
A tree was downed partially blocking Hwy. 59 near Kings Highway.
There were several reports relayed by media of three quarter inch hail across the downtown area including Lake Austin Blvd and the University of Texas campus.
A severe thunderstorm downed power lines in Bellville.
A social media report indicated trees blown down in the Sand Flat area near Lake Bridgeport.
Pea size hail was reported, with some hailstones to half dollar size. This occurred over a thirty minute duration with accumulation up to 4 inches in depth.

This is a continuation of an EF-3 tornado that occurred in Morris County and tracked into extreme northwestern Cass County. This tornado produced mainly EF-1 damage with estimated maximum winds near 105 mph to a mix of trees and structures as it crossed CR-2888 and CR-2738, before lifting shortly after crossing Texas Highway 77.
Report from mPING: Dime (0.75 in.).
A tree was blown down by high winds.
Amateur radio reported that a stage was blown down at the Heart of Texas State Fair.
Quarter size hail fell in the town of Priddy.
A limb fell on a car, and a power pole was blown down.
Hail estimated to be 1.5 inches in diameter fell approximately 12 miles south of Borger.
Golfball size hail reported at Tye.
Multiple reports of quarter to golf ball size hail were received from Quitaque and areas near the Valley ISD campus along Texas Highway 86 east of Quitaque. No damage was reported.

Emergency management reported a downed telephone pole, a carport thrown into a nearby field, damage to an awning, and damage to an RV between Kaufman and Kemp. A 4-wheeler was also pushed across the yard and other trailers on the property were moved 2-3 feet.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site in the city of Lubbock measured a wind gust of 59 mph.
Large tree limbs were blown down.
The Garza County Sheriff's Office reported golfball size hail.
Trees were blown down between Huntington and Zavalla.
Emergency management reported two homes with roof damage. One was completely blown off near Tarleton Rd and CR 4005. Survey of damage suggests strong RFD winds.
A severe thunderstorm produced damage to several cars at a camp near Maryneal.
Metal buildings were reported damaged 3 miles Northwest of Venus, TX.
Quarter size hail reported near Martinsville.
A convenience store employee reported golfball size hail and 60 mph winds in Iraan.  No damage was reported.
A storm moved across the Andrews/Ector county line and briefly produced a funnel cloud.
The West Texas Mesonet Station 26 Gail 2SE recorded a 59 mph wind gust.
Tree blown down by high winds.
Emergency management reported damage to a barn.
Spotters reported a brief tornado just northwest of Anna.  No significant damage was noted during a storm survey conducted by the National Weather Service in Fort Worth.
A lightning strike caused an attic fire at a residential home.

An EF-1 tornado with estimated maximum winds near 100 mph touched down near the intersection of County Road 1220 and County Road 1230 in Western Titus County several miles northeast of the Winfield community, where it snapped and uprooted numerous trees along County Road 1230 as it moved north. This tornado then flipped a two ton cattle trailer numerous times about 75-80 yards from a pasture to the front yard of a home, with two other smaller trailers also thrown about 75 yards in front of the home as well. It is believed that these trailers knocked down the support beams of the front porch of the home, with a license plate to the cattle trailer found about 1.5 miles down the road adjacent to a pond at a nearby farm. Several more trees were snapped and uprooted along and north of the intersection of County Road 1230 and County Road 1165, before the tornado lifted in a pasture just to the west of County Road 1165.

A cluster of thunderstorms developed along a stalled frontal boundary during the early morning hours of the 6th. These thunderstorms quickly intensified while moving to the east. As the storms neared the city of Amarillo (Randall County), a member of the public 4 miles south of Bushland (Randall County) reported quarter size hail (1.00 inch). After producing this hail the cluster of thunderstorms continued to move across the southern Texas Panhandle.
No damage occurred with the wind gust.
A storm chaser estimated 80 mph winds.
Marble to penny sized hail.

A mini-supercell thunderstorm rolled through central and southeastern Willacy County a little more than an hour after sunrise, and produced damaging winds near San Perlita and on nearby ranches around 830 AM CDT. One residence in San Perlita, fully exposed to the northwest, sustained significant damage when its poorly constructed roof lifted off.  The residence was a mobile home with a separate addition on a pier/block foundation. Nearby damage was noted along an 5.28 mile stretch of State Highway 186, with more than a dozen wooden power poles broken, uprooted, or leaning. Nearly all of the broken poles showed notable rot at the breakpoint, and others were only anchored in shallow soil. In total, county Emergency Management mentioned a total of 26 poles were damaged.  The survey revealed a range of estimated wind speeds from 61 to 70 mph.
An estimated wind gust of 70 mph was reported west of Wills Point near the Kaufman/Van Zandt county line.
A few large tree limbs were blown down.
Several large trees were uprooted on Highway 322 and Scarbrough Road north of Henderson. A metal roof was peeled off of a barn on Scarbrough Road.
A storm chaser reported quarter size hail at 8th Street and Milwaukee Avenue.  Wind-driven hail caused extensive property damage.

A thunderstorm moved across Reeves County and produced a tornado near Toyah Lake.  The tornado was observed by a storm chaser and lasted about 2 minutes.  It was located 4 miles east of Toyah Lake and no damage was reported.  The path length and width were both estimated.  Due to no damage being reported, it was rated as an EF-0.
Trees downed along Hwy. 1252.
Hail covered the ground near Dimple.
Occurred at the Alliance Airport.
Strong thunderstorm winds split a tree.
Nickel to half dollar size hail was reported to last for almost fifteen minutes at Lake Colorado City State Park.

A supercell thunderstorm moved southward across the Texas Panhandle during the evening hours of the 14th. A trained storm spotter reported quarter size hail (1.00 inch) near the town of Morse (Hansford County). The supercell thunderstorm continued moving southward after producing this hail.
This hail was observed 7 miles northwest of Lake McClellan.
Hail reported along Hwy. 59 south southwest of Diboll.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 65 mph at Engel Rd. and I-35 southwest of New Braunfels.
Local emergency management officials reported half dollar size hail at the intersection of U.S. Highway 385 and Farm to Market Road 403 near Brownfield.
Reported just off of Highway 349.
A local fire department official observed quarter size hail north of Matador. Additionally, damage to trees and roofs were reported on the north side of Matador.
A public report and photos indicated ping pong to golf ball sized hail.
A thunderstorm moved over Borden County and produced a 62 mph wind gust three miles west northwest of Fluvanna.
A 69 mph gust was recorded at Richland Chambers Reservoir.
A woman driving along FM 226 near the town of Etoile was killed when the top of a pine tree was snapped off and went through her windshield. Reported by Departement of Public Safety.
Hail was on the west side of town.
A storm chaser reported a tornado in open country approximately nine miles northeast of Comstock. No damage was reported.

A rancher a few miles north of Farm to Market Road 2400 in rural parts of northwest Terrell County reported three inch hail stones as a supercell thunderstorm moved across rural sections of the county. The hail stones were reported to be sporadic.
A thunderstorm wind gust of 72 mph was measured by the Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet near Ralls. No damage was reported.
3/4 inch hail.
No damage information was available.
Victoria Airport ASOS measured a gust to 58 mph.
Ping pong ball sized hail was reported by the COOP Observer in Frisco.
Reported by law enforcement.
The hail fell in The Colony.

Power poles and trees were blown down.  The tree sizes and number of power poles/trees were unknown.  Power outages were also reported just west of Colorado City, TX.  The property damage for this event was estimated.
Storm spotters reported baseball size hail.  At least 7500 acres of cotton were destroyed.
Severe thunderstorm winds blew down trees and damaged roofs in the area of Lakehills on the north side of Medina Lake.
Emergency management reported power poles down and mobile home damage in the city of Bryson, TX.

The tornado formed in extreme northern Hill County, NW of the Blum community, near the intersection of Texas Highway 174 and Hill County Road 1106. The tornado traveled across open country for approximately 3.4 miles. Scattered tree and powerline damage of EF-0 intensity was noted along the length of this path. Near the end of the tornado's lifespan, it struck a brick-clad frame home, removing most of the roof and part of the walls of the structure. The tornado's peak intensity of EF-2, with estimated wind speeds of 130 mph, was inferred from the damage to this structure. Some other trees and outbuildings sustained EF-0 to EF-1 damage near this home. The tornado dissipated several hundred yards beyond the point where the tornado impacted the frame home.
Multiple large hardwood trees uprooted in Big Sandy.
Strong thunderstorm winds downed trees and damaged power lines, resulting in loss of power to residents.
The tornado remained over open country.  The tornado path length and width were estimated.  No damgae or injuries occurred from this tornado.
Emergency management measured a wind gust of 80 MPH in the city of Grand Prairie, TX.
Several trees downed in Tyler.
Power lines were blown down by high thunderstorm winds.

High winds blew down several radio towers, destroyed an outdoor movie screen, destroyed a fireworks stand, blew down an awning on a gas station, blew down trees and power lines.  Minor damage was reported all over town to homes, outbuildings, and businesses.
Laredo International Airport AWOS measured a gust to 76 mph.
Quarter size hail reported in Marshall.
A tree was downed on Highway 84 near the intersection of County Road 3167 just west of Mount Enterprise.
An amateur radio operator reported 1 inch hail about 4 miles north of Voss along County Road 503.

A thunderstorm that developed over western Beaver County during the evening hours of the 3rd took a southeast track into the northeastern Texas Panhandle. As the thunderstorm approached Booker (Lipscomb County) it produced a downburst. A member of the public reported that an 18 inch diameter tree branch had been broken off a tree at their residence (Lipscomb County). This thunderstorm would continue a southeastern track across the county.
A social media report with photos showed planes and hangars that were destroyed at the Eastland Municipal Airport.
A trained spotter sent in a picture of approximate baseball sized hail in the Farmer, Texas area in Young County.
A trained spotter reported quarter sized hail about 5 miles north of Cameron, TX.
Reported at Buffalo Stadium just north of Canyon.
The wind gust was estimated one mile northeast of the North Groesbeck community.
Public sent picture of quarter sized hail in central Laredo.
Peak winds of 70 mph were estimated 1 mile east-northeast of New Hope.

A National Weather Service Damage Assessment Team found evidence of an EF1 Tornado that formed about 3 miles east northeast of Katemcy in northern Mason County and lifted about 2 miles north northwest of Fredonia in McCulloch County. The tornado mainly damaged a grove of trees snapping many tree trunks about half way down. The tornado also destroyed an outbuilding. Winds were estimated between 95 to 110 mph.
A report of baseball size hail in far eastern Childress County was relayed to the office from a trained spotter. No damage was reported.
The Navarro County Emergency Manager reported a carport was blown onto Highway 22 near Barry. Power lines in the area were also blown over.
Reported southwest of Westdale.
A member of the public reported golf ball size hail in north McAllen (via Facebook) near the Edinburg city line.
Multiple photos and reports of quarter size hail in San Diego.

Damage was reported to a property on Conder Road, approximately 8 miles southwest of Pidcoke. Large trees were uprooted, split, and damaged. Small outhouses were also overturned, and the skirting was removed off a manufactured home.

A survey team determined 80 mph straight-line wind damage caused the long damage swath in southern Lamar Co from near Roxton to Bairdstown. Several houses were damaged and large trees are uprooted and blown over.
Amateur radio reported golf ball sized hail approximately 16 miles northeast of Paris, TX.
Trained spotter and sheriff deputy on the west side of Hereford reported 55 to 60 mph winds with tree limbs broken off.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Morton measured a wind gust of 61 mph.
There were fallen trees and power outages. Pea sized hail was also observed.
The public reported hail to the size of quarters in Olton. No damage was reported.
Some skylights broken and a few roofs damaged due to the large hail.
Hood County Sheriff's Department reported quarter sized hail just south of Lipan, TX.
Trees and power lines were reported down.
Trained spotters reported wind gusts to 60 mph on the north side of Joe Pool Lake.
The public reported baseball size hail in Anson.

The derecho continued across Hays County where winds estimated at 60 to 70 knots knocked over trees, brought down large limbs and damaged homes and vehicles.  The worst damage was in the southeast part of the county, near the town of San Marcos, where several power lines were blown down.
A National Weather Service Cooperative Observer reported a 60 MPH wind gust.
Trees were blown down by high winds.
Lightning struck a house and caused considerable damage.
Hail reported at Briar Forest and Beltway 8.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that ripped the roof off a mobile home.
Several reports from social media of ping pong ball to hen egg, or two inch, hail just south of the Lyford area to the Cameron/Willacy County line.
Quarter size hail reported near the intersection of North Kings Highway and Interstate 30.
Quarter sized hail was reported.
Dime to nickel sized hail was reported north of Sanger.
A power pole was snapped near the base. Large tree limbs downed. Time estimated from radar.
NWS employee report of quarter size hail.
Pea to quarter size hail fell at the intersection of 3rd and Knox in Odessa.
The general public estimated thunderstorm wind gusts to be around fifty-six knots ten miles south of Pampa which had broken off small tree limbs.
A public report indicated quarter-sized hail approximately 8 miles north of the city of Callisburg, TX.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 75 mph that caused damage to the roof of the Toyota plant in southern San Antonio.
Local broadcast media relayed a report of hail up to the size of golf balls.

The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site south of Olton recorded thunderstorm wind gusts of 76 mph and 75 mph at 15:23 CST and 15:29 CST respectively. These winds occurred as a severe thunderstorm quickly moved northeastward over extreme western Hale County.  The outflow winds spread northwestward and impacted portions of eastern Lamb County near Olton.  Eye-witness accounts suggest that gustnadoes may have spun-up along the gust front as it raced north-northwestward in advance of the parent anticyclonic (left) splitting storm.  The winds, or perhaps an associated gustnado, caused significant damage at a residence in the community of Correy.  Stucco siding and roof shingles were blown off of the structure.  The U.S. Department of Agriculture additionally reported that a center pivot irrigation system also was destroyed.  No injuries were reported.
Report from mPING: Quarter (1.00 in.).
A public report indicated tennis ball sized hail approximately 1.3 miles north-northeast of the city of Aquila, TX.
Off-duty NWS employees reported baseball size hail.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Guthrie measured a wind gust to 76 mph.
Hen Egg size hail was reported 2 miles east of Ennis.
Emergency management reported  quarter-sized hail in the city of Tom Bean, TX.
A tree was downed on FM. 2015 north of Loop 323.
The public reported tea cup size hail 5 miles northeast of Brookesmith. The report was from mping.
Hail was reported in Uncertain, Texas.
Half dollar sized hail was reported 8 miles north-northwest of Alvord.
Wind gust was estimated by a trained storm spotter near Hwy. 726 and Hwy. 271.
A trained spotter reported a wind gust of 61 mph.
The hail was reported on FM 924.

Thunderstorm winds of between 45 and 52 mph knocked down several palm fronds and blew unfastened lawn furniture around portions of the City of Los Fresnos to Harlingen.  Harlingen/Valley International Airport recorded a wind gust of 52 mph at 2:46 PM CST.
Emergency management reported structural damage to a roof, bent fencing and multiple downed trees in Krugerville.
A spotter estimated a wind gust around 60 MPH in Vidor.
A house was unroofed in Walnut Springs.
Power lines and branches were blown down.  Carports were damaged and a roof was partially torn off of an apartment building.
Quarter sized hail was reported in the Copperfield area to the east of Bryan.
Reported at the Westgate Mall area of west Amarillo. Many roofs and skylights to homes damaged.
A tree was blown down and partially blocked FM 46.
Damage was not known.

A large and prolific hailswath crossed U.S. Highway 70 in far eastern Floyd County.  Hailstones as large as 1.5 inches in diameter caused damage to several vehicles in the area and shredded hundreds of acres of winter wheat.  The duration of hail was so great that it covered the ground with about three inches of hail resulting in hazardous travel conditions and dense fog.
Nickel-size hail at the intersection of Blackhawk Road and Whittier Oaks Road.
Numerous trees and power lines were downed all along the Highway 69 corridor from Pollok to Lufkin. Multiple power outages were associated with this wind damage.
Numerous trees and power lines downed across Nacogdoches County.
Penny size hail was reported in Andrews.

The tornado began at the intersection of RR12 and Hugo Rd. where some trees were snapped and a small business had considerable structural damage (DI MBS, DOD 5). The tornado traveled northeastward and likely traversed a large area of land that was inaccessible until reaching Hilliard Rd. and a neighborhood along Thousand Oaks Loop. There was a wide area of considerable tree damage, including a tree uprooted and dropped onto a vehicle (DI TH, DOD 4). The tornado then turned to the north-northeast and crossed the Blanco River before ending near the Kyle Cemetery on Old Stagecoach Rd. At this point, damage became much less significant and sporadic moving to the east toward I-35.  There is no estimate of monetary damages.
A tornado downed numerous trees in the community and caused minor roof damage. A mobile home was damaged northeast of town.
Golf ball sized hail was reported.
Severe thunderstorm winds lasted for several minutes.

A supercell thunderstorm produced a period of intense rainfall over Hutchinson County during the evening hours of the 14th.  This heavy rain led to minor flooding of streets in the town of Fritch (Hutchinson County). This minor flooding receded once the thunderstorm which produced the heavy rain moved south of the city.
A funnel cloud was sighted.
Dime sized hail was reported in Breckenridge.

A storm spotter reported a brief touchdown about six to seven miles north of Aledo on Farmer Road.  The tornado was on the ground for about a minute as it moved due east.  Power flashes were reported in association with the tornado.
A thunderstorm produced baseball size hail in Carta Valley.
Amateur radio operators reported hail increasing to 1.5 inches in diameter.
Trees were knocked down in the Montalba area.

Thunderstorms formed along a dryline stretching east-northeastward across Randall and Potter Counties during the afternoon hours of the 28th. These thunderstorms would take a northeast track which allowed them to move over the dryline. This caused the thunderstorms to produce isolated downbursts across the city. The Amarillo ASOS (Potter County) reported a 58 mph wind gust as a thunderstorm was overhead. The thunderstorm decayed quickly after moving to the dry side of the dryline due to ingesting much drier air into the updrafts.  No damage or injuries were associated with this gust.
The West Texas Mesonet located 3 miles west of Dozier measured a thunderstorm wind gust of 60 mph.
Softball size fell in Rising Star. The newspaper reported that the hail broke car windows, tore limbs off trees, damaged outbuildings, knocked out power, damaged gardens and knocked fruit off trees.
Nickel to quarter sized hail was reported at Palestine High School.
Penny sized hail was reported at the intersection of Farm to Market Road 1239 and Texas Highway 349.
A few homes had minor roof damage, however one home had the roof destroyed. Numerous trees were downed or had large limbs broken. Fences were also down in the area.
Multiple trees were blown down by a thunderstorm.

A short-lived tornado touched down in the Los Encinos subdivision near Holly and Greenwood in southwest Corpus Christi.  A NWS storm survey team found EF-0 damage, including several very large tree limbs snapped, fences blown down and minor roof and siding damage.|
A trained spotter reported mostly marble sized hail with a few just under golfball size.
A public report indicated large trees down along Interstate 635 from Hillcrest Road to Coit Road in the city of Dallas, TX.
Several trees and powerlines were downed. Trees fell in the vicinity of Karnack and Uncertain Texas near Caddo Lake.
The large hail broke out windows on several homes on the north and west sides of Adrian. No injuries were reported.

A downburst caused damage on the east side of Paris. Power lines and trees were knocked down, and roof and minor building damage was sustained to a few buildings; including the CVS pharmacy near Lamar Avenue and Highway 271. The metal-roofed garage next to a home on Smallwood Road was destroyed.
A HAM operator in Rotan reported penny size hail.

A swath of severe winds accompanied a complex of thunderstorms over central and northeastern portions of Lamb County during the evening hours of the 25th. A 59 mph wind gust was initially recorded by the Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site near Amherst at 17:50 CST. A wind gust up to 66 mph also was recorded by the Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet south of Olton at 18:35 CST. Local officials and newspapers additionally reported light damage in the city of Littlefield. A fence was blown down at the Littlefield High School, and a roof was partially blown off of a building. Several power lines also were blown down. Widespread blowing dust also accompanied the winds.

A discrete supercell developed during the evening hours of the 6th. As the storm intensified it produced a brief tornado over the rural portions of Hartley County. Due to the location of the tornado, minimal damage was located however multiple eye witnesses reported the tornado. The winds were estimated at 65 mph. After producing this brief tornado, the supercell began to diminish as it merged with a broken line of thunderstorms.
A thunderstorm moved across Ector County and produced wind damage just west of Odessa.  The wind caused a mobile home to turn over on its side.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.

Numerous large tree limbs were snapped and a few trees completely uprooted.  Several power poles were blown down.  At a high school, stadium lights were damaged and a dugout roof was ripped off at the baseball field. The high school roof auditorium was also damaged.  Part of a gymnasium roof was also torn off.  A NWS storm survey of the damage in Benavides revealed a divergent, downburst wind pattern about 1 mile wide and 3 miles long on the southwest side of the town, near Highway 359 and 339.  Damage was mainly to trees, metal roofs and weaker, west facing structures.
Penny size hail reported via m-PING.
Large limbs blown down.
The Haskell mesonet measured a wind gust of 58 mph.
Law enforcement in Muleshoe and an NWS cooperative weather observer reported quarter size hail in Muleshoe.
Power poles blown down.
A public report indicated dime sized hail near Whitesboro, TX.
The airport manager at the Birds Nest Airport reported hail.
Local law enforcement officials reported numerous power lines down due to thunderstorm winds from Channing to five miles north of Channing. No injuries were reported.

This tornado was captured on video by storm chasers.  It touched down just west of Highway 377 and just south of Loop 820.  It then travelled to Meadows West Park before dissipating.  The tornado damaged fences, trees, and street signs.  The facade of a business was also slightly damaged.

Around 2.5 inches of rain fell in less than two hours just southwest of Raymondville, leaving ponded water in streets and fields and some nuisance urban flooding behind.  The event, which occurred very early on a Saturday morning, had little impact with few people out.
Loose objects were tossed around and small tree branches were broken. Quarter size hail.
Hail covered the interstection of Routes 3074 and 137, and south along 137 to the county line.
The Lynn County Sheriff's Office estimated a severe wind gust along with penny size hail.  No damage was reported.
Quarter-size hail was reported in Greenville.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Anton measured a severe wind gust of 58 mph.
Public reported hail at I-35 and 45th Street.
Emergency management reported quarter sized hail near the intersection of Renner Rd and Murphy Rd.
A NWS employee reported 6.94 inches of total rainfall near Los Fresnos.
Wind was measured by the ASOS at Sheppard AFB (SPS) on northwest side of Wichita Falls.
Pea to quarter sized hail fell throughout the city of Midland.
Hail not measured, but received pictures on social media along with reports of at least two broken windows.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail east of Gonzales.

A tropical shower moved over the city of Amarillo (Potter County) during the early morning hours of the 17th. Due to the above average mositure content in the atmosphere, these showers produced intense downpours over the city. An off duty NWS employee reported that this intense rain caused minor flooding of the south bound lanes of Coulter Street near the Loop 335 interchange. This minor flooding quickly receded as showers moved away from the city. No swift water rescues or stranded motorist were reported in association to this minor flooding.
Reported by Bell Helicopter.
Ham radio operators and law enforcement reported another round of land spouts near the community of Roscoe.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail in Brackettville.
Quarter sized hail occurred in Rockport.
Quarter size hail was reported near Eagle Mountain Lake.
A thunderstorm produced two inch diameter hail in northern Austin.
Quarter sized hail was reported just northeast of Cypress.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts measured at 51 kts (59 mph) by the ASOS at Laughlin AFB.
Minor damage occurred to the siding on a home. A flag pole and some tree branches were also snapped.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Vigo Park measured a severe wind gust of 60 mph.
Golf ball size hail was reported at McCullough and Hobart in south Pampa.
Penny size hail fell in Fairfield.
The sheriff's Department reported dime to penny sized hail occurring at the sheriff's office in Zapata during a severe thunderstorm which was moving over their office.
A Trained Spotter reported wind damage with large tree limbs down in Hatchel.
A social media report indicated quarter to ping-pong ball size hail approximately one mile north of the city of Brownsboro, TX.
Reports of trees down all over county with several falling on structures, and a roof torn off a warehouse in Crockett.
A social media report indicated large branches down on a sidewalk on Rufe Snow Dr in Watauga, TX.
The Amarillo Emergency Manager reported downed power lines at the intersection of the Claude Highway and Washington Street in Amarillo.

An NWS Survey concluded and EF-1 tornado touched down approximately 1.5 miles southeast of Tynan, in a grain field south of FM 796.  The tornado was approximately 1/4 mile wide, and on the ground for roughly 2.51 miles in San Patricio County before crossing into Bee County.  The tornado then continued roughly another 5 miles to the east-southeast on the Bee and San Patricio County line, or just inside the Bee County line. Crops were flattened, several large crop sprinklers flipped over, a shed was partially destroyed, and power poles snapped along the path.  Maximum wind speeds of 90 mph were estimated.
Amateur radio reported penny sized hail near the junction of Interstate 14 and Interstate 35.
Damage to buildings, trees, power poles, and other infrastructure was sustained city-wide.
Law enforcement reported a power pole snapped in half along County Road 259, off of U.S. Highway 67.
Golfball sized hail fell on Texas State Highway 118, two miles south of the McDonald Observatory.
An NWS cooperative weather observer reported ping pong ball size hail on the northeast side of Matador.
The Fort Worth Spinks Airport (KFWS) AWOS measured a peak wind of 64 mph.
Measured by the Automated Weather Observation System at the Decatur Airport (KLUD).
Golfball sized hail fell at the intersection of Gaines County Roads 303 and 120.
The Emergency Manager of Limestone County reported nickel size hail 3 miles south of Kosse on Highway 14.
Quarter-size hail between Cut and Shoot and Grangerland.
Several trees were downed west of Nacogdoches.
Broadcast media reported nickel sized hail.
Multiple trees and limbs were blown down in Orange from a passing storm.
Dime size hail was reported just east of Tyler along Hwy. 31.
Trees and a trailer were damaged.

Trained spotters observed and recorded a multiple vortex tornado northeast of Brandon. While large, the tornado produced no visible damage, except to farm fields. However, the combination of a large tornado which moved slowly, produced quite a bit of damage to the fields.
The Sheriff's Office reported large trees were knocked down and blocking roads in McKinney.
A NWS cooperative weather observer reported hail up to ping pong ball size nine miles southeast of Floydada. No damage was reported.
Spotter submitted picture of tennis ball sized hail.
Trees and small tree branches were knocked down in Frisco. One weeping willow tree was uprooted in a backyard, knocking down the privacy fence.

An EF-1 tornado touched down near downtown Longview, Texas...traveling in a east northeast direction for approximately 1.32 miles before lifting some 5 minutes later.|Damage consisted of roof damage to a nursing home.  A nearby mobile home park also sustained damage. The tornado did minor to moderate damage to homes along the Eden Drive/Eastman Road corridor.  Three mobile homes were completely destroyed by fallen trees.  The tornado also tore the roof off a local church on Eden Drive.
Emergency management reported golf ball sized hail on FM 3109 approximately 8 miles west of Graham, TX.
A power line was downed and there was a lot of unknown sized hail.
A severe thunderstorm produced winds estimated at 65 mph.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail near New Corn Hill.

Large hail fell for about 15 minutes at an outdoor adventure park on the north rim of the canyon with the largest hail up to around ping pong size. At least 3 RVs were damaged and  had skylights broken out. Porta potties were also blown about 40 feet from the thunderstorm winds.
Storm chasers observed a very brief and narrow tornado over open land east of Enochs.
A member of the media reported 60 to 65 mph winds along with nickel size hail along the Midland/Upton County line.  No damage was reported.
A spotter reported Hen Egg size hail 3 miles northwest of Strawn.
Penny size hail was reported at Schlemeyer Airport in Odessa
A tree was downed on FM. 2869 eleven miles east of Mineola, Texas.
An amateur radio report indicated quarter-sized hail in the town of Boyd.
Public reported nickel sized hail at the Family Dollar Store in Zapata.
Golf ball sized hail was observed.
Ping pong size hail reported just north of Kirbyville.
An NWS cooperative weather observer reported quarter size hail in Morton.
A 64 mph thunderstorm wind gust was measured by a KCBD storm chaser.
Trained spotters estimated 80 mph winds at the Cleburne hospital.
Nickel sized hail was reported at Interstate 20 and Kelly Elliott Road.
Amateur radio measured a 58 MPH wind gust near the intersection of Highway 380 and Jackson Road.
The Amarillo Department of Emergency Management reported that numerous power lines were down in parts of south Amarillo.
A lightning strike started a fire at a deep well injection disposal site in the Salt Creek Area. Ten tanks were engulfed.

Penny to nickel size hail accompanied a severe thunderstorm that moved north-northeastward across eastern Cottle County. The public initially reported nickel size hail at Chalk at 16:20 CST. Penny size hail was later reported at Swearingen just before 17:00 CST.
A trained spotter reported quarter-sized hail in Como, TX.
A 64 mph gust was measured at the West Texas Mesonet station 11 miles south-southwest of Romero. No damage was reported.
Amateur radio reported golf ball sized hail 2 miles south-southwest of Krum, TX.
Austin news station reported that 2 homes were damaged by a fire that was started due to a lightning strike. The homes were located on Carson Creek Road near Highway 71 in Del Valle.
A storm chaser estimated 60 mph wind gusts north of Paducah.
Several mobile homes, roofs (shingles and metal panels), sheds, and outbuildings were damaged in the Homestead area north of Venus.
A public report indicated downed trees and damage to some trailer homes on Curtis Ray Drive in Midlothian, TX.
Broadcast media reported that a section of roofing at Arlington High School was lifted off and blown onto Cooper Street.
Amateur radio reported wind gusts between 60 and 65 MPH near the intersection of Highway 377 and Dixie Road.
Trees were downed on Macedonia Road northwest of Marshall, Texas.
Large hail ranging in size from dimes to golfballs was reported in West Odessa.
Late report of heavy rain and up to quarter size hail, time estimated from radar.
Power lines and poles were blown down across Hillsboro.
Several reports of quarter size hail in Wellington were received south and southwest of of town.
Tree downed in the Jamestown community.

A NWS storm survey determined that a microburst with estimated 70 mph winds caused the collapse of the Dallas Cowboys' 80,000 sq ft bubble practice facility at Valley Ranch. The facility was approximately 85 feet tall and composed of a fabric shell and metal. A rookie minicamp was being held at the time and 12 people were injured. One coach was paralyzed from the waist down. Also in the area, trees were splintered and heavily damaged, but most of the damage was confined to around the practice field.
Amateur radio operator reported golfball size hail 15 miles south of Merkel.
Trees down
Quarter sized hail was reported in Graham.
The public reported golf ball size hail 4.2 miles south of Loyal Valley. The time was estimated by radar.
Reported near Sunday Canyon or just west of the Palo Duro Canyon State Park entrance.
The Fire Department/Rescue reports a large carport wrapped around a tree just north of Ballinger on Farm to Market Road 2111.
Funnel cloud northwest of location and halfway down.
Several trees were downed along with power lines.  One tree was down across a car in the northern portion of the county.  No injuries were reported.
Amateur radio spotters reported half dollar sized hail in Celina.
Large trees were blown down on the road near Nimitz Street and Rosebud Avenue in Victoria.
Quarter sized hail was reported in Graham multiple times. One report was from a trained spotter, and another was from a broadcast media partner.
A thunderstorm produced penny size hail near Natural Bridge Caverns.

At least five power poles were blown down by severe thunderstorm winds along State Route 176 near the intersection of Farm to Market Road 1788.The first of four supercell thunderstorms to affect the northern Permian Basin during the evening of the 7th and the early morning hours of the 8th developed over Andrews County. This storm resulted in large hail and damaging thunderstorm winds. The storm then propagated southeast across unpopulated areas of southwest Martin County, and eventually across Midland (including the city of Midland proper) and northern Upton Counties.
A wet microburst caused a strong wind gust which was measured by the West Texas Mesonet site near Goodlett.
Tornado touch down at intersection of FM 521 and CR 58. No reported damage.
Large limbs were reported down throughout town and trees were uprooted.  The strong winds also destroyed a garage on the outskirts of town.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet station.
A member of the public reported 1.5 inch hail in southwest Cypress.
Amateur radio reported dime sized hail in north Paris.
A thunderstorm produced three inch hail east-northeast of Enchanted Rock State Natural Area.
Broadcast media reported a metal roof removed from a farm building and large tree limbs blown down between Whitney and Blum.

A 1 foot diameter tree was uprooted along Highway 380 north of Little Elm. The damage was caused by strong outflow winds around 60 mph from a thunderstorm tracking across the northern portions of Denton County.
Quarter sized hail was reported by the Bowie Fire Department spotters.
Lightning started a house fire on Silverlake Road in McKinney. The entire second story of the home was destroyed.
Baseball and softball size hail 4 miles north of De Leon.
A tree was blown down at the intersection of FM 449 and FM 450.
A trained spotter reported Ping Ping ball sized hail one mile north-northeast of Plano, TX.
A public report indicated a wind gust of 60 to 65 MPH near the intersection of Interstate 35W and Highway 114 near Roanoke.
Golf ball sized hail was reported in Hempstead.
Power lines were downed along County Road 4507.
A thunderstorm produced penny size hail between Liberty Hill and Leander.
The public reported tree branches...six inches in diameter...blown down.
Storm chasers witnessed a brief tornado about 5 1/2 miles west of Goodnight. No damage was seen. The tornado was rated EF-0.

A storm chaser video documented a brief landspout which occurred 3 miles west-southwest of Groom, touching down and then lifting after one minute. The rating assigned was EF-0 due to the lack of damage to any structures impacted.
Large trees and tree limbs were also blown down along Alamo Road south of Montague. Several of these trees were rotted inside.
Canopy lifted from a tented play area at the Centro Cultural of Cameron Park, per pictures from the Emergency Manager.
Frisco Fire Department reported a lightning strike which led to extensive damage to a home on Robin Creek Ln in the city of Frisco, TX.
Half Dollar Sized hail was reported 3 miles northwest of Kerens.
Mesonet station reported 7.61.
Occurred between Balch Springs and Seagoville.

An EF-2 tornado with winds estimated between 105-115 mph touched down along County Road 2807 just east of Farm To Market Road 220 South about 4.5 miles southwest of Alto, and lifted north of County Road 2438 about 3 miles north of Alto. Over 27 homes sustained damage, including two homes that completely lost their roofs. Several outbuildings were damaged or destroyed, and at least two travel trailers were destroyed. The total path length was 7.3 miles.
A peak wind gust of 69 MPH was measured at the Fort Worth Meacham Airport.
Several golfball sized hail stones fell at the intersection of Avondale Haslet Road and Willow Springs Road in the city of Haslet. The hail stones broke apart on impact and no damage was observed.
Golf ball size hail was reported by the public around Veribest.

A thunderstorm moved over the city of Wellington (Collingsworth County) shortly before 5 pm on the 29th. The National Weather Service COOP Observer 1 mile south of Wellington reported golf ball size hail as the storm passed over their residence.
Golf ball sized hail was reported at the Olney Municipal Airport.
Several trees and powerlines were downed across the entire county.
Golfball sized hail fell north of Paris at the intersection of Highway 271 and FM 1499.
Damage was reported along Highway 79 east of Buffalo.
