A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Hart measured a wind gust of 59 mph.
A thunderstorm developed over Terrell County and produced pingpong ball sized hail one mile southeast of Sanderson.
Emergency management reported a large metal barn flipped on the northern side of the city of Breckenridge, TX.

A cluster of discrete thunderstorms moving across the Texas Panhandle transitioned into a broken linear structure during the late evening hours of the 6th. As this broken line of storms where near the town of Clarendon (Donley County), the KVII Schoolnet site in Clarendon (Donley County) reported a 59 mph downburst gust. After producing this gust the line of thunderstorms continued moving eastward across the Panhandle.
The public reported that the hail ranged in size from dimes to quarters. No damage or injuries were reported.

Lightning started a house fire in the 7000 block of Rainbow Falls Drive in Frisco. The origin of the fire was from the roof. There was fire damage to the roof, attic, and second floor.  There was smoke and water damage throughout the structure. The damage is estimated at $500,000.
A trained spotter reported 5 to 6 inch tree branches broken 4 miles west-northwest of Temple, TX.
A funnel cloud was sighted in the Hunters Creek Village area near Houston.
Mping report of quarter size hail.
A thunderstorm produced two inch hail at the Kerrville Municipal Airport.
Quarter size hail was observed neat the intersection of South Fry Road and Kingsland Blvd.
A trained spotter reported quarter size hail in Haskell.
Trees were downed in Red Water.
A 62 mph wind gust was measured by the Automated Surface Observing System at the Borger airport.
Public reported golf ball sized hail around 4 miles south of Goldthwaite.
Report from mPING: Quarter (1.00 in.).
Dime sized hail was reported on the north side of Laredo near Shiloh Road.
Occurred at the intersection of Highway 80 and Interstate 35.

Slow moving thunderstorms trained across the region from the afternoon of the 20th into the early morning hours of the 21st. Reports of 4 to 5 inches of rain was received and minor street flooding in Jasper, Buna, and Kirbyville.

A NWS storm survey team concluded a tornado touched down near the intersection of Maria Elena Ave. and NW 38th St. The tornado traveled a couple of blocks before lifting near NW 36th St. Damage was primarily to trees, but one house on Woley Dr. did suffer major roof damage and several nearby houses suffered minor damage mainly to roofs and vehicles parked nearby. Another home on Woley Dr. was reported to have had a carport roof removed and displaced two blocks to the north onto the same street near Culebra Rd. Peak winds were estimated at 100 mph.
Golfball size hail fell at the Red River County Sheriff's Office in Clarksville.
A thunderstorm moved across Martin County and produced a 60 mph wind gust six miles north of Stanton.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 58 mph that knocked down large tree limbs.
Power lines down 6 miles west of downtown Houston on I-10.
A thunderstorm produced half dollar size hail in Lexington.
A thunderstorm moved across Ector County and produced an estimated 65 mph wind gust in Odessa.

Thunderstorms formed along a dryline stretching east-northeastward across Randall and Potter Counties during the afternoon hours of the 28th. These thunderstorms would take a northeast track which allowed them to move over the dryline. This caused the thunderstorms to produce isolated downbursts across the city. The KVII Schoolnet site at Duke Electric (Randall County) reported a gust of 66 mph while a thunderstorm was overhead. The thunderstorm decayed quickly after moving to the dry side of the dryline due to ingesting much drier air into the updrafts.  No damage or injuries were associated with this gust.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts measured at 56 kts. by the AWOS at the Randolph AFB Auxiliary Field east of Seguin.
A thunderstorm in Pecos County produced a funnel cloud one mile northwest of Fort Stockton.
Hail up to baseball size did extensive damage in Sherman to cars and houses.  This is the same storm that hit the Whitesboro area earlier.
Strong winds blew over a scoreboard and storage building. A/C units were also blown off their slabs.
Thunderstorm winds of 70 mph were estimated in Mabank. Trees were knocked down in the area. One tree fell on a vehicle causing an injury.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball to golf ball size hail north of Uvalde. The hail broke several windows in a house.
Dime size hail covered the ground in Leesburg.
Law enforcement reported a tree down with a 12-inch diameter trunk near the intersection of State Highway 64 and FM 859.
Golfball size hail fell 3 miles north of Aledo.
Tree downed onto a power line on South Cedar Street in Clarksville.
Several trees were downed in Gary City.
Dime size hail was reported just north of Garrison, Texas.
Trees downed.
The hail was six inches deep.
Trees and powerlines were downed throughout the county.

A line of thunderstorms developed in response to a cold front moving through the southeastern Texas Panhandle during the late evening hours of the 11th. As the line moved toward the town of Clarendon (Donley County), a law enforcement official reported golf ball size hail (1.75 inches) 1 mile south of Clarendon. After producing this hail the line continued to slowly move to the east.
1.00 inch hail countywide...including the Huntsville area, FM 247, FM 1696 and FM 1791.
Trees were blown down north of Como.
Quarter sized hail fell in Frisco.
A mesonet observation station measured a 63 mph wind gust.
Quarter size hail was reported on the north side of town.
Several trees were blown over near Burkeville during a severe thunderstorm.
Law Enforcement reported tennis ball size hail 2 miles west-northwest of Wall.
Reports of hail up to ping pong size from law enforcement and an NWS cooperative weather observer in Kirkland. No damage was reported.
A trained spotter reported nickel sized hail in Decatur, TX.
Thunderstorm wind gust estimated at 65 kts caused downed power lines and power outages at University and Eastover Drive in Odessa.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Trees were blown down near vineyard.
A deputy reported part of a roof on the road near Tuscola.
A large tree was blown down on Highway 729 near Lake O' the Pines.
Trees and power lines were blown down along Highway 315.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail near Runge.

Scattered thunderstorms developed across Potter County during the evening hours of the 12th. As a storm approached the town of Amarillo (Potter County), local broadcast media reported a 60 mph downburst 6 miles north-northwest of Amarillo. After producing this downburst the storm continued to move eastward across the county.
Hefner (HEFN) Mesonet observation.
Thunderstorm winds knocked down trees in Oak Lawn. Some of the trees were over a century old. Numerous power outages were reported across the Oak Lawn and surrounding areas.
A trained spotter estimated quarter size hail three miles east of Afton. No reports of damage were received.
A thunderstorm produced 4.0 inch diameter hail southwest of Lake Victor. A picture of the hail was forwarded to the NWS by a broadcast media partner.
A 60 mph wind gust was reported at the McDonald Observatory. No damage was reported.
Golf ball size hail was reported.
Knox City (KNOX) Mesonet observation.
The tornado remained over open country and the path length and width were estimated.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Wolfforth measured a wind gust to 59 mph.
Nickel size hail fell at the intersection of Farm to Market Roads 1053 and 1233.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail northwest of Briggs.
Tennis ball size hail fell 6 miles south-southeast of Masterson.

Numerous storm chasers reported a swath of extremely large hail west of Matador along US Highway 62/70. Hail ranged in size from quarter size to three inches in diameter. No damage was included with the reports.

The National Weather Service in Fort Worth conducted a damage survey and found that the tornado which originated in Hill County continued on its destructive northeast path into Johnson County.  Damage to sheds and vegetation was noted along County Roads 1205 and 1204.  The most significant damage to structures was found near FM 916, CR 1202, and CR 1205, northeast to near Highway 171.  Several structures were unroofed while others suffered partial roof loss.  Major damage to trees was also noted here.  Damage to homes and trees continued along the track near CR 421, CR 423, and CR 415 just north of Highway 4.  The tornado then crossed FM 2415.  The last observed damage was along the south shore of Lake Alvarado.  County officials reported that twenty-two residences were destroyed, twenty were heavily damaged, and twenty more had minor damages.  Ten people were taken to local hospitals.  Most were for minor injuries, but two suffered more serious injuries and were released from the hospital the next day.  The Governor designated Johnson County a disaster area.

A strong thunderstorm produced a series of wet microbursts over portions of Hale County. One such microburst occurred just south of Plainview, and the winds were estimated to be severe as they spread northeastward over the city. A Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet station just south of the city recorded a 53 mph gust. Local law enforcement officials estimated wind gusts as high as 65 mph in Plainview. No significant damage was reported.
An MPING report indicated trees snapped or uprooted approximately 12 miles southeast of Oakwood, TX.

A severe thunderstorm moved across western portions of Callahan |County late Sunday afternoon which produced a brief tornado about|6 miles south to southwest of Clyde, Texas near FM 604. Clyde VFD|sent a video of the tornado touching down west of Lake Clyde. |Time and exact location estimated from radar. No significant |damage was reported with this tornado as of today. Therefore...the|tornado has been classified as EFU, which means the winds |associated with the tornado are unknown at this time.
Golfball, tennis ball and baseball sized hail covering the ground.  Hail lasted for 4 minutes.

A small EF-0 tornado was seen on video from a school campus in Sweet Home.  The survey concluded that the small tornado began just down the road from the school on FM 531 and then traveled northwest hitting the school playground area at approximately 5:02 PM.  The video showed the small tornado moving through the playground damaging the playground and the school gymnasium door. The tornado then moved northwest behind the school and into an open field behind a nearby church.  The tornado crossed County Road 378 and produced some minor tree damage before dissipating near FM 318. Special thanks go out to Sweet Home Independent School District and KSAT-12 TV in San Antonio for providing information and video of this tornado event.

Four homes and one apartment building was struck by lightning in Flower Mound when a complex of thunderstorms moved through in the late evening hours. The largest house fire was on Dickens Lane with others on Remington Park Drive, Beacon Street, and Crescent Drive. The damage at the Lantana Apartments on Long Prairie Drive was only electrical.
Baseball sized hail fell in the Edgewood Community in Van Zandt County.
A storm chaser reported quarter size hail about three miles north of Floydada along Texas State Highway 207. No damage was reported.
One man was fatally injured when an apparent downburst flipped his mobile home.
The Odessa Automated Surface Observing System measured a thunderstorm gust of 54 knots. No damage was reported.
Ping pong ball size hail reported via social media in Omaha.
A thunderstorm produced pea to golf ball size hail for five minutes. This hail caused dings on some vehicles.
Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet meteorologists reported that golfball size hail blown by thunderstorm winds damaged instrumentation at Reese Center.
Thunderstorm winds downed trees along FM 949 from Nelson Lane to Lehrmann Road.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet recorded a wind gust to 58 mph.
Trees and power poles were downed by severe thunderstorm winds.
Multiple picture of golf ball size hail was posted to a local new channel social media.
A storm chaser reported quarter to golfball size hail.
One inch hail reported in Breckenridge.
A thunderstorm produced one inch hail in Georgetown.
Quarter size hail fell in Glenn Heights.
Seymour (SEYM) Mesonet observation.

Discrete supercells began transitioning to a linear structure during the late evening hours of the 16th. As this cluster of storms neared the town of Dumas (Moore County), an amateur radio operator 2 miles west of Dumas (Moore County) reported an estimated 65 mph thunderstorm gust. After producing this gust the cluster of storms continued to move to the southeast.
Crops...mainly cotton and corn...were damaged by the large hail.
Trees were blown down and into the roadway on Farm to Market Road 888.
A trained spotter reported a large grain bin door blown off.
Golfball size hail covered the ground east of Caddo inside the Stephens county line.
Hail estimated up to quarter size fell between New Deal and Shallowater.
Law enforcement in the city of Floydada reported half dollar size hail.
Power lines were blown down by high winds.
The combination of strong winds and very large hail damaged all north facing sides of buildings.
Quarter to half dollar size hail fell in Sunray.
Report via Twitter.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong to two inch hail stones near Crane, TX.

Tornado touched down just east of Highway 288 in the Third Ward. One church completely destroyed, 50 homes damaged, and extensive tree damage. Wind damage to several downtown buildings in SE Houston near Minute Maid ballpark.
Golfball hail was reported at the Benedum Gas Plant on the Reagan/Upton County line.
A report from the public was received of one inch hail three miles east of Graham.
A large tree was blown down on CR 2041 near Appleby.
Powerlines were downed.
Lighting caused a house fire on Knoboak Drive near the intersection of Hammerly Blvd and Gessner Road.
Occurred in the hospital district in southwest Ft Worth.
Anderson County Emergency Management reported quarter sized hail in Harmony.
Golf ball size hail fell near Lake Bob Sandlin on County Road 2320.
Lightning from a thunderstorm struck a house causing a fire. There was smoke damage to the kitchen.
Numerous trees downed in the Lake Cherokee area off of Farm to Market Road 1716.
Damage to a large Madix warehouse building was reported near the Terrell Airport. One side was blown in and the roof partially collapsed.
The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site east of Silverton recorded a peak thunderstorm gust of 65 mph at 18:05 CST. No damage was reported.

A tornado resulted in significant (F2) damage along a one and half mile path through the north side of Childress during the evening hours of the 9th. The tornado developed in a residential are of northwest Childress at 20:30 CST. Damage in the neighborhood was characterized as weak, with numerous downed trees, street signs, and damaged roofs. A resident was injured when a tree fell and struck him, breaking his arm and causing minor lacerations.The tornado then moved east toward the high school. Damage to the high school was extensive. A local television network, KVII-TV in Amarillo, operates an automated weather station on the campus as part of a regional school net. The instrument measured a 109 MPH wind gust as the tornado ripped through the facility at 20:32 CST. Damage at Childress High School was rated F1, with large brick walls blown inn and portions of the building's roof removed. The gymnasium was declared a total loss.The tornado intensified as it continued to move east across Fair Park. A large industrial building used to house city owned emergency vehicles was completely destroyed, with extensive damage to the fleet of vehicles that were parked inside. A tennis court was destroyed by wind-blown debris, and numerous large trees were uprooted. A large stone picnic table was blown northward along the wind fields convergent axis associated with center of the tornado's path. A well-built metal bridge that spanned Park Lake was blown a considerable distance downwind. Damage along the tornado's path through the park justified a significant rating (F2) on the Fujita Tornado Damage Intensity Scale. This given the magnitude of damage observed at the industrial building site, where large steel beams were completely torn from their bolted fixtures.The damage survey indicated that the tornado quickly weakened as it continued to move east of the park, and into more rural areas in the northeastern outskirts of the city.
The public reported quarter to golfball size hail east of Plains along U.S. Highway 82/380. The hail damaged an estimated 2,500 acres of cotton crops.
Lightning caused a fire in an attic on Roselawn Lane in Frisco. There was extensive fire damage to the structure; the estimated loss is $800,000.
Emergency management reported tree branches down on Justice Ln in Garland, TX.
Trees were downed at Lansing and Lighthurst Street just east of the Gregg County line.
Half dollar sized hail occurred at Mustang Island State Park.
A private weather station measured measured a wind gust to 59 mph near Ben Bolt.

A storm survey conducted by NWS personal found wind damage consistent with wind gusts of 60 to 70 mph. Several softwood trees were found with broke branches from Rio Hondo to about 1.5 miles east of Rio Hondo along General Brant Road. There were also several buildings with damage, including loss of wood or metal roof panels on some outbuildings and mobile homes. This includes most of an aluminum roofing covering two adjacent single-wide mobile homes blew off. At least two of these pieces were blown across adjacent State Highway 106.
A report of ping pong ball-size hail was received from mPING.
Several trees were blown down around the lake.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail in Brackettville.
Nickel sized hail was observed.
Shingles were blown off a roof.
Storm chasers reported a tornado northwest of Burkett in northern Coleman County, causing several telephone lines to be cut.
A thunderstorm produced one inch hail near Wilderness Oak and Hardy Oak Blvd. in the Stone Oak section of San Antonio.
Observer reported 2 inches of rainfall occurred in 50 minutes.
A tree fell through a home in Gilmer.
The public reported golf ball size hail 4.3 miles east-northeast of Sweetwater.
Trained storm spotters reported hen egg size hail.
There was a report of tree branches down just southeast of the Highway 59 and Highway 6 intersection.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph near Parmer Ln at RR620 in Jollyville.
There was a mix of 1/2 inch to golf ball sized hail.
Public reported several tree branches broken and a wind gust of 60 mph.
A lightning strike caused a fire that was contained to the attic. There was fire, smoke and water damage to the home.
NWS employee reports lots of nickel to quarter-size hail.
Emergency management reported trees snapped and damage to the roof and carport of a house about a mile south of Olney, TX.
Nickel sized hail and 55 mph winds were reported in Parker.
A trained spotter reported golf-ball sized hail near Highway 205 and Ralph Hall Parkway.
Amateur radio operators estimated winds of 60 mph at the Lebanon exit of the Dallas North Tollway. Pea sized hail was observed as well.
The public reported quarter size hail near Radium.
Reported via mPing.
Broadcast media relayed a photo of measured 2.76 inch hail.
A large tree, measuring at least 2 feet in diameter, was downed by strong thunderstorm wind gusts in the Greatwood area.
Half dollar size hail fell near the intersection of Farm to Market Road 2064 and County Road 4905.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Morton measured a wind gust to 59 mph.
A tree fell on a power line.
Large tree limbs were blown onto FM 1220 by high winds.
Quarter sized hail fell at the Corpus Christi National Weather Service Office.
Tree limbs broken.
CoCoRaHS observer reported pea to quarter size hail covering the ground.

Numerous reports were received of a tornado in extreme northwestern Lynn County. The tornado was highly visible from Lubbock, Wolfforth, and even from portions of Terry County. ||A Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet meteorologist initially witnessed a developing funnel cloud to the distant south from Reese Center at 12:49 CST. A ground circulation was first seen at 12:51 CST, and the tornado reportedly dissipated rapidly at 12:55 CST. ||The tornado remained over open fields southwest of the intersection of Farm to Market Roads 179 and 41 (intersection actually in extreme southwestern Lubbock County). A Wolfforth city employee observed the tornado from just south of Farm to Market Road 41 west of that intersection, and reported that it was south of his location, in extreme northwestern Lynn County. Radar additionally indicated a weak convective shower there. Initial reports indicated that debris was spotted in the tornadic circulation, but no damage was discovered by local authorities.
A storm chaser reported two-inch diameter hail approximately 1.3 miles southeast of the city of Rockdale, TX.
The public reported a tree snapped in half in front of Abilene City Hall.
Tennis ball size hail was reported 6 miles west-southwest of Wayside.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet.
Hail caused broken windows and hail damage.
Trees were downed on Hwy 87.
Severe thunderstorm winds broke large tree limbs up to half a foot in diameter near a rural residence in northeastern Winkler County.
The Jefferson County PD reported a funnel cloud near Fannett. Multiple pictures were also posted to social media.
Several medium and large size tree limbs reported blown down throughout Bishop.  One power pole was reported snapped in half.
Half dollar size hail was reported near Salado.
A peak wind gust of 53 knots (61 mph) was measured at the Al Mangham Jr. Regional Airport just southwest of Nacogdoches.
Law enforcement reported tree damage in Cooper.
Public report of ping pong ball size hail.
Resident on the Double Dime Ranch reported nickel size hail.

Ping pong size hail was reported by a trained spotter. This storm's southern flank later produced nickel to just under quarter size hail that fell twenty to thirty minutes in the Brenham area. Five hours later, this hail was still on the ground.
Dime size hail reported via mPING.
The Childress County EM reported 16 power poles that were toppled by a bow echo thunderstorm.  Time was estimated from radar.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Jayton measured a severe wind gust of 64 mph.
Golfball size hail was reported in Caddo.
A funnel cloud was sighted near FM 2666 between SH 150 and FM 2025.
Trees down in and around Bellville.
Severe thunderstorm winds blew over an 18 wheeler truck on Interstate 45 around the 145 mile marker.
A trained spotter reported baseball size hail in Voca.
Wind gusts damaged fire station and blew off the top of the pavillion at the community center.

A discrete supercell developed over Sherman County during the evening hours of the 16th. As the storm moved near the town of Stratford (Sherman County), a trained storm spotter captured a brief tornado on video. The tornado lasted less than a minute and was estimated to have 70 mph wind speeds. The storm continued to move southward after producing this tornado. No damage was reported with this tornado.
A trained spotter observed a tornado to the northeast of Loving. The tornado was observed for two minutes, and did minimal damage over open range land.
Nickel size hail was observed at the intersection of Briar Forest and Eldridge Parkway.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail east of Willow City.
Large pine trees were downed by high winds...taking out powerlines and blocking Hwy 87.
Half-dollar-size hail was reported near Fort Davis.

A supercell thunderstorm produced a period of intense rainfall over Hutchinson County during the evening hours of the 14th.  This thunderstorm produced 2.00 inches of heavy rain in the town of Fritch (Hutchinson County).
Golfball size hail fell along Farm-to-Market Road 323 about 7 miles southeast of Palestine.
Numerous trees down all over Southwestern Sabine County near Pineland. Trees were down on power lines, and power poles were leaning over.
A few trees were downed west of Henderson, Texas.
A thunderstorm produced quarter to ping pong ball size hail in Helotes.
The Muleshoe Sheriff's Office estimated quarter size hail in the city.  Damage was unknown.
The mesonet station located three miles north-northwest of Palo Duro Canyon measured a wind gust of 60mph.
Measured by the Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet.

A cluster of thunderstorms developed along a stalling cold front during the evening hours of the 8th. This cluster of thunderstorms moved to the south across the northern Texas Panhandle. A trained storm spotter 5 miles west-southwest of Glazier (Hemphill County) reported a 70 mph downburst. The storm that produced this downburst continued moving to the south across the county.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail near downtown San Antonio.
A thunderstorm moved across Midland County and produced a 66 mph wind gust at Midland International Air and Space Port.
The West Texas Mesonet site near O'Donnell measured a 63 mph wind gust.
Reported by Coop Observer.
Multiple sources reported 1.75-inch to 4-inch diameter hail in the city of Ponder, TX.
Power poles knocked down between Hillsboro and Abbott.
Law enforcement reported quarter size hail.

At 1655 CST, the Automated Surface Observing System at Childress Municipal Airport measured a severe wind gust of 60 mph. Shortly after at 1709 CST, a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site two miles north-northeast of Childress measured a severe wind gust of 64 mph.

Severe winds caused spotty damage, mainly in the eastern half of Uvalde County, where they knocked down trees, blew down a dozen power lines, and caused damage to roofs in the area.  Damage was also reported to windows in the eastern part of the county.
Post event report spotter estimated winds to be around 50 gusting 60-65. There were tree limbs down one 3 to 4 inches in diameter.
A (landspout) tornado was reported by a storm chaser over open country.  The tornado remained nearly stationary.
Emergency manager reported a tree in the street about 3 miles south-southeast of Canutillo.
The AWOS site KORG reported 4.76 during the heavy rain event over a few hours.

A second severe storm developed and impacted the MacKenzie Reservoir, less than half an hour after a severe storm brought nickel size hail and strong winds. The second storm produced quarter size hail at a local marina, as reported by the public.
A brief touchdown was reported on the southeast edge of Bremond.  The tornado downed power lines and damaged trees.

Additional thunderstorm activity over Lubbock County produced localized severe winds. The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site at Reese Center measured a 63 mph gust at 21:50 CST. No damage was reported. In addition, very frequent cloud-to-ground lightning activity accompanied this complex of storms.
Emergency manager reported dime sized hail in Eddy.

An isolated area of damage occurred in Lagarto. Large tree branches were broken at two homes along South Vista Lane along with minor damage to siding and soffits on one home. A swath of small broken tree branches was observed along Farm to Market Road 534 between Farm to Market Roads 3162 and County Road 174. Maximum wind speed was estimated between 70 and 80 mph.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail near the intersection of Hwy 281 and FM 1863 in Bulverde.
The Cooke County Emergency Manager reported to the local newspaper that some homes near Lake Kiowa sustained roof damage from high thunderstorm winds.
Microburst signature was found with divergent winds causing damage to portions of homes and fences near Peoples Blvd in Laredo, TX.

Several power poles down and power lines tangled in trees were reported throughout the city of Edinburg by the local fire department.  Radar estimated potential wind gusts in excess of 50 knots (58 mph) from the bow echo within the squall line, which would imply such gusts in pockets despite the measurement at the Edinburg International Airport, about 8 miles north-northeast of town, of 39 knots (45 mph).
Wind gusts estimated by storm spotter east of Winnsboro, Texas.
Ping pong ball sized hail was reported near downtown Dallas.

An EF0 tornado first touched down at the intersection of Church Street and Grant Avenue and began to move east southeast through southeast Lufkin.  During this stretch, several large trees were uprooted , knocking over power poles and taking down power lines.  A few of these trees fell directly on to homes.  The tornado crossed the 287 loop between Highway 69 and CR 841.  Several large trees were uprooted and numerous large branches were broken off as it paralleled Fannie Carrell Road as it continued southeast, eventually crossing CR 841 near Fish Road.  The tornado lifted near the intersection of Flen Gary Road and CR 326 but not before knocking over several more large trees there, with one on a home.
Trees were blown down in the Greenpond area, southwest of Como. Some of these trees were blocking roads.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 62 mph in Staples.
The hail was reported on the northwest side of town.
Damage to roofs and structures reported.
A thunderstorm produced nickel size hail in Jourdanton.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail near TX360 and Lakewood Dr. in northwestern Austin.
Trained spotter reports 1 inch hail at the intersection of CR 607 and CR 917.
A 71 mph (62 knot) wind gust was measured by the Graham Municipal Airport AWOS.
Video showed hail dominant precipitation along P.J. Garza Road near Expressway 83.
NWS Employee estimated a 60 MPH wind gust.
Hail up to 1.5 fell for nearly 15 minutes on Seessums Road in Springtown.
Report received from the spotter network.
An amateur radio operator reported nickel size hail and approximately 70 mph winds.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that uprooted trees at the Lighthouse Country Club in Kingsland.

A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 80 mph. Power lines were blown down at Ave. B and Del Rio Blvd. in Eagle Pass. There was a roof blown off a house and onto a car in the 900 block of Ave C.
Thunderstorm winds cause damage to buildings in Kennedale. Storage units had damage to doors and walls, while one building lost a roof.

A swath of golfball size hail accompanied a storm northeastward from the Halfway community in northwestern Hale County over portions of southwestern Swisher County. Golfball size hail was reported west-southwest of Kress at 15:50 CST. The report was relayed by the National Severe Storms Laboratory SHAVE project.
Nickel size hail fell at the intersection of Farm-to-Market Road 321 and County Road 401 about 8 miles north of Palestine.
A thunderstorm produced half dollar size hail. Hail covered a portion of Hwy130.
A public report said half dollar hail fell near Wilshire Elementary School.
Occurred in North Ft Worth
A public report indicated quarter sized hail about 5 miles southeast of Bonham.
Strong thunderstorm wind blew down trees and power poles.
Quarter sized hail was reported in Highland Park.

A cluster of thunderstorms moved out of the Oklahoma Panhandle during the late evening hours of the 24th. As this cluster of storms near the town of Gruver (Hansford County), a local law enforcement official 4 miles west of Gruver (Hansford County) reported hail up to the size of nickels (0.88 inch). After producing this hail, the cluster of storms continued to slowly move southeastward across the Texas Panhandle.
A thunderstorm gust was reported at the intersection of Highway 191 and Farm to Market Road 1788.
Minor damage to vehicles was reported.
A spotter for the broadcast media estimated the thunderstorm wind gust on the west side of Pampa Texas.
A power line was reported down in Albany. The time was estimated by radar.
A 72 mph wind gust was measured at Highway 377 and Tiger Trail in Benbrook. Tree damage and uprooted trees were reported around Benbrook.
Car windsheilds were smashed in.
Tractor trailers were blown off the road near the intersection of Highway 287 and FM 407 by thunderstorm wind gusts.  Trained spotters estimated 65 mph winds.
A tree was blown down along County Road 1220.
Reported at Farm to Market Road 281 and County Road 8.
Tree limbs down; relayed by city officials.
Small landspout tornado reportedly remained over open country. No damage and no injuries were reported. The path length and path width were estimated.
The West Texas Mesonet station 1mile northwest of Palo Duro Reservoir measured gusts in the 59 to 63 MPH range during this time period. The highest gust of 63 MPH occurred at 19:41.
Nickel to quarter size hail was reported north of Slaton along Farm to Market Road 400. Post-storm surveys indicated that 5,000 acres of cotton were damaged.

The third tornado of the family developed near the west shores of Lake J.B. Thomas. The tornado affected open range land just west of Farm to Market Road 1205 for more than five minutes. The tornado was photographed by storm spotters and the public as it remained over open range land. It caused no damage.
Trees were downed in the Line Street area.
The Texas Tech West Texas Mesonet station measured a 68 mph thunderstorm wind gust.  Power poles were snapped by the strong wind.
Local fire department officials observed penny sized hail in Rhea.
Public reported quarter size hail.
NWS employee reports golf ball size hail and possible roof damage due to hail. Property damage cost is an estimation.

The next tornado associated with the eastern Lubbock County supercell developed immediately south of U.S. Highway 82 and quickly crossed the highway about four miles east of Idalou. This tornado, filmed by veteran storm chasers, was briefly ongoing simultaneously to the first tornado. A business sustained minor damage when tin panels were raised on the structures roof as the tornado crossed U.S. Highway 82. The tornado then continued north-northwestward as the parent mesocyclone occluded, intermittently touching down and at times taking on a multi-vortex structure. No significant damage was found by local officials or during a post-storm National Weather Service survey.
A tractor-trailer was overturned.

This strong EF1 tornado with estimated maximum winds near 105 mph touched down in the Sabine National Forest along Forest Road 144, where numerous softwood trees were snapped and uprooted. The heaviest concentration of damage was near the intersection of Forest Road 144 and Forest Road 144A, where the tornado was at its strongest and widest. This tornado tracked northeast across inaccessible areas of the forest, before crossing Highway 87 just south of the Six Mile community. Numerous additional softwood trees were snapped and uprooted between Forest Road 182 and Shawnee Shores Drive, before lifting within a cove in Toledo Bend Reservoir along Shawnee Shores Drive. The tornado had a maximum width of 625 yards and tracked over 5 miles.
A few tree limbs 9 to 16 inches in diameter were blown down.

An official storm damage survey was made on the tornado path length and width.  The tornado destroyed several grain bins and a grain elevator to Agco facility.  Extensive damage also occurred at a local farm...including the home...barns and equipment.  Several power poles also were blown down.
A tree fell across farm-to-market road 1615.  A roof was also partially damaged at a nearby house.
Baseball sized hail was reported on I-35 on the south side of Gainesville.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail in Burnet.
The fire department reported quarter size hail lasted for 15 to 20 minutes, beginning around 445 pm, 3 miles east of May on Farm to Market Road 1689. Also, 40 to 50 mph winds were reported.
A thunderstorm moved across Pecos County and produced a 60 mph wind gust in Iraan.  No damage was reported.
A trained spotter reported golf ball size hail.
Numerous trees were downed in The Woodlands area.
Power lines and power poles blown down. Also...high winds caused damage to roofs.
A thunderstorm produced a strong outflow boundary that caused a wind gust measured at 62 mph at the Austin Executive Airport.
Tree down across Highway 82 and Farm to Market Road 2253 about one-quarter of a mile from the Leary exit.
A swath of hail between 1 and 1.75 inches in diameter fell from 4E Jayton to 2S Peacock. No damage was reported.
Numerous large trees were reported down in the Bridgeport area. These winds could have been caused by strong inflow to the tornadic storm just north of this area or the rear-flank downdraft.
Thunderstorm winds downed some trees.
The West Texas Mesonet station in Menard measured a wind gust of 73 mph.
Several large trees down.
Quarter size hail was reported in Temple.
Broadcast media relayed reports of a wall of dust with damaging winds in Springlake. Damage was mostly light and confined to small tree limbs and fencing.
Emergency management reports broken windshields and hail covering the ground.
A public report stated that the roof was blown off of a business near the intersection of Saginaw Main and Loop 820.

A tornado along the leading edge of a squall line was captured on video by multiple storm chasers in the area. It was weak and in open country and did not cause any reported damage including to power lines where it crossed Highway 287.
Dime sized hail at the UTA Campus in Arlington.
The 60 mph wind gust occurred during light rain.
Large hardwood trees were uprooted and snapped in this area.
A trained spotter reported quarter size hail in Santa Anna.
A storm chaser on Highway 287 reported Pea size hail covering the highway.
Alice International Airport ASOS measured a gust to 58 mph.
Local agricultural officials reported that large hail up to the size of nickels resulted in damage to cotton crops near South Plains.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 65 mph that damaged a house on the north side of Taylor.
A photo was posted on the KLTV Facebook page of golfball size hail that fell near Lake Winnsboro.
The severe thunderstorm winds in Albany blew shingles off of roofs, and the intense winds also toppled telephone poles.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that knocked down five power poles near RM 1431 and RM 2545 in Kingsland.

Numerous local officials and members of the public reported a funnel cloud northeast of Plainview. The funnel persisted for at least fifteen minutes. Despite the well-developed nature of the funnel as seen in photographs and its duration, no evidence of a circulation at the ground was found and no damage was reported.
A photo was posted to the KLTV Facebook page of large hail that was measured to be tennis ball size that fell near the Bettie community in Northern Upshur County.

Tornadic damage was indicated on the south and east sides of McLean and centered on South Farm to Market Road 3143. A barn...outbuilding...and farm equipment were damaged in the tornado. No injuries were reported.
A thunderstorm produced dime to nickel size hail along with wind gust estimated at 50 to 60 mph southeast of Concan.
Report received via mPING.

A tornado developed near Van Zandt CR 2213, then tracked northeast across HWY 19 south of Canton. Shingle damage occurred to a home, as well as tree branches were broken. The tornado then began to dissipate east of Hwy 19, damaging another home on Van Zandt CR 4201 near Mill Creek. Maximum winds with the tornado were estimated at 75 mph.
Reported at Western Street and Amarillo Boulevard.
Quarter sized hail was reported 2 miles south of Sadler.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph at Rundberg Ln. and I-35 in northern Austin.

The supercell underwent another odd handoff from the Palo Duro Canyon tornado near Highway 1258 which was documented by storm chasers in the area. Again, both the initial and new developing tornado co-existed for a period of time creating a wide damage path Near County Road 1 in Armstrong County. This tornado path remained in very rural country with few damage indicators and was likely stronger than suggested by the very limited rating. Along the path the tornado snapped a few small diameter power poles and destroyed a couple out buildings. It also pushed over a semi before it dissipated just north of Highway 287.
Reported at Border Patrol checkpoint.
Local emergency management officials reported quarter size hail along U.S. Highway 385 south of Seagraves.
Storm chasers provide multiple reports of a cone shaped tornado approximately 8 miles northwest of Throckmorton.  The path length and width of the tornado were estimated.
Quarter sized hail occurred and covered the ground a couple miles north of the Downtown Houston area.
The Zapata County Airport AWOS reported 2.32 inches of rainfall in less than an hour and a half.

National Weather Service meteorologists, in collaboration with Navarro County Emergency Management officials, determined that a brief tornado occurred on the south side of the City of Corsicana late Wednesday morning, December 30th. A video of the tornado was shared via social media. The tornado formed at the Nature Park Optimist Softball Complex, where it damaged a small concession/storage building, toppled a light pole, and destroyed awnings, fencing, and signage around the complex. The tornado moved east-northeast into adjacent wooded areas, and merged |into a nearby residential area near Cottonwood Circle Trailer Park. At least 13 manufactured and frame-built homes sustained some damage to roofs, siding, and skirting. Two other homes were damaged by falling trees. Several large tree branches were also snapped off. The tornado dissipated shortly after exiting the trailer park. The tornado track was approximately 1 mile in length, with a maximum width of 75 yards. Damage at the softball complex and to some of the manufactured homes was consistent with high end EF-0 intensity tornado winds, with top speeds estimated at 85 mph.
Lightning from a thunderstorm ignited a fire at an oil tank battery northeast of Cuero.
Trees blown down countywide. Key map locations 533C, 492P, 454K, 494D, 493S, 492N, 538F, 572E, 618C). Trees blown onto houses at Fry Rd and FM 529.
Golfball to baseball sized hail fell on Texas Highway 302 near the Winkler and Ector County lines.
Emergency management reported a 15-inch tree blocking Highway 114 west of the city of Boyd, TX.
Trampoline was blown over and onto a house.
Golf ball sized hail was reported just west of Eastland on Interstate 20.
An awning at a house on First Street was torn down by thunderstorm winds.  Oak trees were split and blown down.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph.
Several reports were received of very large hail from west of Post into the city of Post. Hail sizes ranged from two inches in diameter to 3.50 inches in diameter. No damage was reported.
There were uprooted trees reported at Oak Park Rd and Far East St east of Lone Oak, Texas.
Several trees were blown down.

A few trees were snapped at their base and had large limbs broken off with the initial touchdown along FM 2138.  The tornado continued northeast causing various tree damage along and intersecting path across FM 2142 and FM 1716.  It continued along a northeast path where it destroyed a storage outbuilding and uprooted several trees at FM 2187 and Hwy. 149.  The tornado continued northeast where it uprooted several trees and ripped off the tops of several more along FM 2216 and FM 2221.  The tornado then briefly crossed into Panola County.  Maximum winds were estimated at 86-95 mph.
Quarter sized hail was reported in Temple.
Damage to awnings at an apartment complex in Hudson Oaks. Some tree damage was also noted in this area.
Estimated 60 mph wind gust in Caddo Mills. Power outages were reported across the city.
A storm chaser reported quarter size hail 4 miles south of Pantex.
Crop damage resulted from large hail up to the size of tennis balls.
Lightning struck the communications tower on top of the Fannin County Jail destroying the radio consoles in the building and disabling the computer system.
An estimated wind gust of 60 MPH was reported 3 miles southwest of Irving.
Hail in the Great Hills area.
A lightning strike started a residential fire that engulfed a majority of the home's roof.
Public reported penny size hail 10 mile NE of Edinburg near Elsa at the intersection of FM2812 and Val Verde Road.
Victoria Regional Airport ASOS measured multiple gusts to 76 mph.
Large pecan limbs with a diameter of 6 to 12 inches and a length of 8 feet were blown down.
Power lines, road signs and trees were downed near the intersection of SH 288 and Broadway Street.
Trees were downed just west of town on Hwy 21.
A severe thunderstorm produced hail up to golf ball size in Loveland.
A thunderstorm moved across Dawson County and produced a 78 mph wind gust two miles southeast of Lamesa.
Relayed by amateur radio. Location is approximate.
A thunderstorm moved over Culberson County and produced a 59 mph wind gust at Pine Springs in the Guadalupe Mountains.
Quarter to half dollar sized hail reported.

Emergency management reported pea to dime-sized hail covering the ground with a few stones up to quarter-sized near the intersection of Cole Rd at Brushy Rd approximately 2 miles southeast of the city of Bowie, TX.
Trees were downed on FM 1972 near Larksper.
Hail duration was 6 to 8 minutes and covered the ground.

A National Weather Service damage survey concluded that a weak EF0 tornado formed just south of the Colorado River near Smithville on FM 2571. There it produced tree damage and some visible wind damage to a few residences along FM 2571. The tornado moved northeast and crossed Hidden Shores Road where more tree damage was observed. The tornado then crossed the river before dissipating near the intersection of Highway 71 and Kellar Road. Maximum winds were estimated at 80 mph.
Golfball size hail fell in the Kildare community.
Half dollar size hail occurred 4 miles east of Masterson.
The KVII schoolnet mesonet site southeast of Buffalo Lake in Randall County recorded a 68 mph thunderstorm wind gust.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that blew some large trees onto roads, downed powerlines, and blew the roof off a building.
A thunderstorm produced a measured wind gusts of 59 mph at the Dripping Springs RAWS station (DSRT2).
The broadcast media relayed reports of tennis ball size hail in Caprock Canyons State Park. No damage was reported.
Several trees were downed and a barn was damaged near the intersection of Hwy 1159 and Hwy 82.
Golfball size hail fell on the west side of Paris.
A 60 MPH wind gust was measured in Midlothian, and a tower was blown down in Waxahachie.

A local newspaper reported that thunderstorm winds caused significant damage to metal structures and light weight buildings in the Memphis vicinity. The roof was blown off of a large cotton warehouse. Another metal storage facility failed in the winds, with the roof and one wall blown off of the structure. A number of car windows were additionally blown out at a local business. No injuries were reported.
Penny-sized hail with a few golfball-sized hail reported.

The Villas at Waterchase apartment complex in Lewisville was hit by an EF-1 tornado. Sixteen units sustained some type of structural damage. Four chimneys were snapped off roofs on various buildings, a brick wall crumpled on one building and the roof of the same building was peeled back exposing the apartment homes.
Several trees snapped in Bullard.
Thunderstorm winds downed trees and caused power outages in the Londonderry neighborhood.

A discrete supercell thunderstorm developed over northern Sherman County during the evening hours of the 16th. As this storm moved southeastward over the town of Stratford (Sherman County), a trained storm spotter reported an estimated 70 mph thunderstorm gust which downed power lines on US Highway 287 thee miles south of Stratford (Sherman County). After producing this hail the storm continued moving southeastward across the county.
Large branches were blown down across a driveway on East Lake Drive adjacent to Lake Gladewater.
Hail that ranged in size from peas to quarters was reported in Southland just after 21:00 CST.
City of Houston OEM reported several trees down across the Mission Bend area of Southwest Houston.
Amateur radio reported trees blown down approximately 2 miles southwest of Cundiff, TX.
A tractor trailer was blown over at a rest stop 3 miles north of Anson.
A public report from a former NWS employee estimated wind gusts of 65 MPH.
Skywarn storm spotters reported nickel to quarter size hail along U.S. Highway 380 west of Tahoka.
An NWS cooperative weather observer estimated wind gusts of 80 mph lasting for approximately 20 minutes. No damage was reported.
Power lines down around the city.

A decaying thunderstorm from a prior storm merger produced quarter size hail 1 mile south of Lefors (Gray County) as reported by the Gray County Emergency Manager. Four inches of accumulated quarter size hail was also reported by the Gray County Emergency Manager on US Highway 273. This created slick road conditions, but no vehicle accidents were reported.
An amateur radio report indicated half dollar sized hail in the city of Mabank, TX.
Dime size hail fell in Avery. Report relayed via social media.
Hailfall began 30 minutes prior (1635 CST) to report time.
Several motorists on Interstate 20 east of Sweetwater encountered baseball size hail that produced damage to their vehicles.

There was a swath of wind damage that lasted about 20 minutes between Montgomery and Conroe. Just southeast of Montgomery, a large tall tree sliced through a home. Just outside Cut and Shoot, ten trees were downed included a 100-year-old oak tree. In and around the Conroe area, large tree limbs were stripped off of trees.
Public reported quarter size hail.
Amateur radio reported quarter-sized hail in the city of Prosper, TX.
Center pivot irrigation system flipped at the intersection of HWY 87 and 102.
Roof damage occurred at several buildings including an apartment complex and a restaurant.  Damage to trees was also reported.
A severe thunderstorm winds blew down trees north of Boerne.

Damaging winds spread southward over Garza County as a large complex of severe thunderstorms impacted the area during the late afternoon hours on the 22nd. Storm spotters initially estimated wind gusts up to 70 MPH in Post at 15:23 CST. By 15:25 CST, local authorities reported that many large trees and utility lines had been blown down in the city. The Texas Tech West Texas Mesonet observations indicated peak gusts to 73 MPH in the vicinity. The severe winds began to affect the Lake Alan Henry area by 16:10 CST, when a gust of 69 MPH was recorded by the West Texas Mesonet near the lake. Severe thunderstorm winds intermittently gusted to near 70 MPH at the lake until 16:22 CST. A local newspaper additionally reported that some minor structural damage also occurred in Post. No injuries were reported.
Powerlines were downed in Pittsburg, Texas.
One inch hail fell in Wheeler.
Amateur radio operators reported golf ball sized hail in Honey Grove. The hail broke windows at one residence.
1.00" hail along Hwy 105 in Cut and Shoot that covered ground. Law officer had to pull off road during the event.
A small short lived tornado did minor roof damage and broke numerous tree branches.
A trained spotter reported quarter sizeD hail and estimated wind gusts of 30-45 mph.

A partial roof collapse occurred at the Wayside Plaza Apartments near Pennsylvania Ave and 9th Avenue in Fort Worth. Nearly half of the roof of a building was torn off. The damage was caused by a strong downburst.
Powerlines were downed in Jefferson, Texas.
Severe thunderstorm winds blew down trees between Ingram and Kerrville.
Public report via MPing application of quarter-sized hail.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail in Runge. We were sent a picture of the hail.
Penny size hail.
Half dollar size hail fell 2 miles north of Nocona.
An NWS cooperative observer reported quarter size hail in Wells.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that blew down trees and power lines in Cost.
Eye witness reported a brief tornado just northeast of Happy Valley in southwestern Taylor County.
A report of baseball size hail from mping, 2 miles east of Sweetwater.
Quarter size hail was reported on Highway 190.
Trees were downed northeast of Tyler, Texas.
The report was relayed by WFO Lubbock.

Trees were downed along Hwy. 59 near Marshall, Texas.  Several trees were also downed along Rosborough Springs Road near Liberty Church Road.  One tree fell on top of a house doing moderate damage but no injuries were reported.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that toppled a double decker billboard on Hwy 80 east of San Marcos near the Caldwell County line.
A funnel cloud was spotted to the north of Angleton on FM 521 to the west of Highway 288.
A trained spotter reported golfball size hail on the side of the road.
A ranch owner in rural Ector county reported that 6 inch diameter limbs were knocked off trees by high winds associated with a thunderstorm.
Mobile home flipped over with trees and powerlines down.
One person was injured after a tree fell on top of his pickup truck he was driving.  The incident occurred on FM 2767 near Barber Road.
Hail was located at University Blvd and Moss Ave.

This EF-1 tornado was the first of four tornadoes from a parent mesocyclone associated with a large HP supercell that tracked across southeast Harris County and into Chambers County. This small track tornado spun up quickly along the back side of the parent mesocyclone with a track from the north northwest to the south southeast, passing directly over a business and damaging metal industrial buildings from south of Fairmont Parkway to west of Bay Park Road. Cars were pushed and stacked into and on top of each other in the parking lot. A large semi-trailer was slid into several vehicles. There was significant roof damage to a large storage facility before the tornado ended in a small open track of land to the south. Estimated peak winds were 110 mph.
A large pecan tree was blown down by high winds.
A thunderstorm produced a funnel cloud moving north in the vicinity of FM 969 and Burleson Manor Road near Webberville.
Radio station KCLW AM had their antenna blown down.
A 2 foot diameter tree was snapped in the city of Paris. The damage occurred near the intersection of 10th Street SE and Hearon.

The tornado touched down on the east side of Lavon Lake then moved northeast and dissipated approximately 2 miles north northwest of Copeville.  Damage occurred to mobile homes, houses, trees, and utility poles. 8 homes were left uninhabitable and 16 sustained heavy damage.  Two people were injured when the mobile home they were in was moved 150 feet.
Quarter sized hail was reported between Latexo and Crockett.
Nickel sized hail fell on Hwy. 69 just north of Jacksonville, Texas.
A citizen reported penny size hail in Cotton Center.
Dickens County Sheriff's Office reported baseball size hail near Red Mud.
A trained spotter reported nickel sized hail about a mile east-southeast of Streetman, TX.

A cluster of thunderstorms moved into the Texas Panhandle during the early afternoon hours of the 14th. As storms neared Texline (Dallam County), a trained storms spotter reported a 60 mph downburst in town. After producing this downburst the cluster of storms continued moving southward across the Panhandle.
Law enforcement reported quarter size hail in Kirkland. No damage was reported.
Hail of 2-2.5 was reported in Gunter.
The West Texas Mesonet station, 5 miles west of Rotan, reported a wind gust of 61 mph.
A NWS employee estimated a 60 mph thunderstorm wind gust as the line of thunderstorms moved over his residence.
Trees downed.
Quarter size hail was reported near Fosterville which is located about halfway between Brushy Creek and Poynor.

An area of enhanced wind damage occurred from near Hwy 121 and Bedford Rd in Bedford to just north of Hwy 183 on Main Street in Euless. Scattered significant tree damage was observed along this path, walkway awnings were damaged at Trinity High School, and the roof was damaged at the Napa Auto shop on Main Street. All the damage was pushed to the east and maximum winds were estimated at 65-70 mph.
Several trees knocked down.
The Breckenridge Airport AWOS measured 54 kts of wind.
Trained spotters observed a tornado to the north of the city of Proctor, on the northeast side of Proctor Lake. Several trees were damaged, but no structures suffered damage.
Penny size hail fell along Loop 335 and the Fritch Highway.
Emergency management reported damage to a marina in the Lakeside Village area of Lake Whitney. Winds were estimated at 50 to 60 MPH.
Late report of quarter size hail.
Semi truck blown over near the Hardeman/Wilbarger county line.

Several trees fell in Park Cities and signs were blown down in the Fair Park area.  At least one carport was damaged.  Billboard panels near Main Street and Central Expressway was blown onto a parking lot full of cars.
Lightning struck three tank batteries off Longhorn Drive near FM 2264, igniting the tank battery in a fiery blaze.
Amateur radio storm spotters reported golfball size hail.

The public reported thunderstorm wind damage at 25th Avenue and Arthur Street where a carport was damaged. There was also a fence with metal poles and wooden pickets that was blown over and a telephone pole was leaning in the backyard of another residence. There were no reports of injuries or fatalities.
Quarter size hail fell at the Lake Striker RV Park Restaurant and Marina.
Some trees were downed in the Lufkin area.
Emergency management reported quarter-sized hail on Ponderosa and Shepherd Roads in Howe, TX.
Numerous tree limbs were reported down.
A public report indicated a wood utility pole snapped in the south part of Canton, TX.
Golfball size hail fell south of Hueco Tanks State Park. This was the first of two supercells in El Paso County this day, but it remained over mainly a sparsely populated area.
Pea and quarter size hail fell in the Huntsville area.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet station.

The large Love's Travel Center sign was knocked down in very strong thunderstorm winds. The sign fell on a part of the gas pump awning, damaging the awning and causing minor damage to a few of the gas pumps. Also in Van, large trees were uprooted, a few trees fell on the roofs of homes, and light poles and power lines were also down.
Egg sized hail was observed.
Multiple reports of trees down southeast of town.
A 58 mph wind gust was recorded at the Texas Water Development Board Mesonet site at Lake Striker.
A thunderstorm produced nickel to golf ball size hail east of Lexington. Hail fell for 15 minutes.
The AWOS in Midlothian measured a wind gust to 69 mph.
Public reported quarter size hail.

The tornado touched down about three miles south southwest of Pringle at 0056 CST. The National Weather Service survey team found a metal barn completely destroyed with the sturdy steel frame found forty feet north northeast of its original location. Several large tractors suffered significant damage with the cab windows blown out. One tractor was moved a few feet to the north. The tornado was on the ground for less than one half mile and dissipated at 0057 CST with a maximum path width of one hundred yards. No injuries were reported.
A National Weather Service cooperative observer reported that penny to nickel size hail accompanied severe winds.
A brief tornado touched down east of Texas State Highway 70 in an open field. The tornado remained over open country and no damage or injuries occurred. The path length and path width were estimated.
Public reported quarter size hail.
The public reported hail of approximately one inch in diameter continued falling as a severe thunderstorm raced through western Hidalgo County.
Penny to golf ball sized hail fell at the KOA Campground and over southeastern portions of Fort Stockton.
Multiple trees downed across Highway 37 between FM Road 2118 and FM Road 195.
A member of the public reported nickel sized hail along CR 318 near Cleveland.

The collision of two outflow boundaries caused the development of thunderstorms over the southern Texas Panhandle during the evening hours of the 14th. This allowed storms to quickly intensify to produce a mixture of heavy rain and quarter size hail (1.00 inch) in the Hillside Terrace Neighborhood on the southwest side of Amarillo (Randall County). After producing this hail the storms slowly moved southward across the southern Texas Panhandle before weakening as sunset approached.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts measured at 52 kts. by the Bird RAWS station near Stonewall.

Trees were uprooted and snapped in Decatur. The golden arches at McDonald's were knocked down, and the Dairy Queen and Taco Bell signs were also damaged along with other business signs in the city. Power lines were also knocked down and shingles were torn off roofs. A home weather station on Highway 287 on the north side of town measured a 62 MPH wind gust. A 50 foot hackberry tree, the largest in the county, was knocked down in Decatur by the storm, and it fell on a garage, crushing the car underneath.

The public reported thunderstorm wind gusts that downed large tree limbs up to three inches in diameter near the intersection of Texas Highway 214 and Farm to Market Road 145 west of Lazbuddie. The damaging winds were accompanied by hail up to the size of pennies.
Penny to quarter size hail was reported 5 miles west-southwest of Alanreed. The hail covered Interstate 40.
Trees were blown down along FM 1415 in Burkeville.
Dime to quarter size hail fell for about 10 minutes.
A 58 mph wind gust was measured by broadcast media observation site. No significant damage was reported.

The manager and security officer of the Long Island Village (Port Isabel) swing bridge reported damage from a likely small and brief tornado that crossed the bridge just after 1 AM CST (2 AM CDT) on March 28th.  Dollar value of the damage is estimated.
Large trees fell on several homes in Nursery.
Numerous trees were blown down by high winds.

Two separate microbursts were observed with thunderstorms in the Skellytown and Pampa areas on Saturday evening. In Skellytown, 21 power poles were snapped with an additional 50 poles snapped in the northwest and northern parts of the city of Pampa. Numerous trees were uprooted or snapped and portions of roof coverings were removed from several homes. A large RV was also overturned. After talking with county EM's and gathering other reports, winds of 90 MPH were estimated to be the cause of the damage.
Emergency management reported quarter sized hail 1.5 miles north of Iredell, TX.
The EF-1 tornado severely damaged a farm house and barn then flipped three trailers over at an RV park before weakening. Estimated peak wind was 90 mph.

This is a continuation of the Wood County EF-2 tornado. This tornado crossed Highway 115 and County Road 4426 in the Scroggins community, where numerous trees were snapped or uprooted, a tree fell through a mobile home, and another tree had fallen on a home. The tornado continued northeast crossing County Road 4410 where a few trees were snapped or uprooted, and a metal outbuilding suffered minor damage. The tornado then moved across Farm to Market Road 1519 and along the west side of Lake Bob Sandlin where a few additional trees were snapped or uprooted, before lifting along the lake just off of County Road 4397. Throughout its path across extreme Southeast Franklin County, the maximum estimated winds had weakened to near 105 mph.

A cyclic tornadic supercell produced several tornadoes over a period of approximately two hours. An NWS storm survey revealed that this supercell produced nine separate tornadoes. This tornado was the ninth and final tornado. The NWS storm survey team discovered several locations along Farm to Market Road 303 with wooden power poles snapped at the base and two pump jacks overturned. Maximum winds were estimated at 120 mph. The instantaneous width and center of the tornado was estimated from TTU-Kal radar data.
High water was observed near the intersection of FM 1155 and South Meyersville Road.
A mesonet observation station reported a 61 mph wind gust.
The public reported hen egg size hail in Blanket.
Hail was reported via MPING near College Station.
Nickel sized hail was reported near Windhaven Parkway and Arbor Hills Way in The Colony.
Accumulating hail reported just west of Simms area.
Nickel size hail fell along FM 2011 southwest of Longview.
Dime to penny sized hail occurred in the Panorama Village area.
Thunderstorm wind gusts knocked down trees and damaged a large storage building.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail northeastern Austin.
Wind gust estimated at Reliant Stadium.
Three homes were severely damaged after being struck by lightning during a round of thunderstorms Sunday morning.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail near Government Canyon State Natural Area.

A non-mesocyclonic tornado was photographed by the public as it traversed across open county just north of Lubbock around 17:20 CST on the 27th. The tornado apparently developed as towering cumuliform clouds formed above an advancing low-level boundary. Witnesses report that the tornado persisted for five minutes. No damage was reported.

A NWS storm survey found significant tree damage along a one mile wide path.  It was concluded that the damage was caused by straight line winds from a microburst.  Tree damage was found at the Ford dealership off Jollyville Road, where a large tree fell on some new trucks.  Across Highway 183, more tree damage was found on Duval Road, Bull Run, and a few other streets in the Angus Valley subdivision.  Tree damage continued east along Duval towards Mopac Loop 1 where several large trees were uprooted at the entrance of an apartment complex.

An apparent downburst occurred as a severe thunderstorm dissipated near Floydada shortly before 19:00 CST. A 74 mph gust was measured by the Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site just northeast of the city. No damage was discovered during surveys by Texas Tech University personnel.
Penny size hail was reported at Fort Hood on the Coryell County side.
A public report indicated quarter sized hail about 8 miles southeast of Fort Gates, TX.
A National Weather Service Cooperative Observer reported a tree was toppled and six inch limbs were downed by at least 60 mph thunderstorm wind gusts.
Occurred at Loop 12 and Interstate 30 on the west side of Dallas.
The public estimated a damaging thunderstorm wind gust of 60 mph.
Sheriff's office reported trees and power lines down.
Ping pong sized hail was reported just northeast of Bryan.

Far east El Paso was hardest hit by this second supercell, with extensive golfball to possibly tennis ball size hail falling for 20 minutes. Thousands of automobiles were damaged, with several dealerships suffering much loss. Skylights were destroyed, roofs damaged and windows broken on thousands of buildings. Several injuries were reported from hailstones as well.
Golfball to baseball size hail damaged 26 cars at CTECC.
Spotter reported quarter sized hail on Farm to Market Road 1582 north of Fowlerton.
A thunderstorm produced severe size hail. The largest hail was 2.5 inches and the average size was 1.75 inches.
The Waco ASOS measured a 63 mph wind gust.
The Automated Surface Observation System at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport  Airport measured a wind gust of 59 MPH.
Golf ball size hail was reported in Mason.
Nickel  to quarter size hail. Very few hail stones in general.
A severe thunderstorm produced golfball size hail near the intersection of Creighton Road and FM 1314.
A public report indicated half dollar sized hail in Harker Heights.
Quarter size hail was observed near the intersection of Veterans and Bammel.
Baseball size hail and high winds in Miles broke windows and skylights on multiple homes and businesses.  The large hail also dented several vehicles.

The public reported several high line power poles were snapped at the intersection of Farm to Market Road 809 and Farm to Market Road 2587...and the winds were estimated to be between fifty-two and sixty-one knots.
Local emergency managers reported a travel trailer knocked over by strong thunderstorm wind gusts.
Reported near Dunn Road and State Highway 102.

A cluster of thunderstorms produced a period of intense rainfall over Armstrong County during the evening hours of the 14th.  These thunderstorms led to water collecting on U.S. Highway 287 in the town of Claude (Armstrong County). This minor flooding receded once the thunderstorm which produced the heavy rain moved south of the city.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail at the Poth Fire Department.
Several trees were downed east of Huntington, Texas.
Hail reported in Pleasant Valley about four miles north of Amarillo.
Trees blown down.
Quarter size hail fell in the Antioch community.
Funnel cloud reported near Highway 190 East.
Report from mPING: Quarter (1.00 in.).
Quarter sized hail was reported near Graham.
Large limb and power lines downed.
A theater sign and several large tree limbs were blown down.
A public report indicated large tree limbs down and minor roof damage in the Eagle Mountain area.
A thunderstorm produced hail from quarter to golf ball size in Utopia.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail along RM2523 south of Carta Valley.
Ham radio operators and law enforcement reported land spout swarms developing around the Roscoe area.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail southwest of Leander.
3/4 inch hail.
A thunderstorm moved across Midland County and produced a 65 mph wind gust five miles northwest of the City of Midland.
A 60 mph wind gust was reported in Egan.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 52 knots along with pea to nickel size hail.
A thunderstorm wind gust of 58 mph was recorded by the Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site near Muleshoe. No damage was reported.
A vacant mobile home was wrapped around a telephone pole due to the high winds. No injuries were reported.
Tornado damaged some trees near Evergreen.
Several roofs and trees were damaged or downed by 65 mph thunderstorm winds, including one 25 foot tree with a three foot diameter trunk.

NWS storm survey indicated a tornado touched down 5 miles west northwest of Taft along Highway 181. The tornado struck and collapsed a grain elevator. The tornado crossed Highway 181 knocking over a utility pole and caused tree damage. The tornado snapped 3 utility poles as it crossed County Road 73 about 1 mile north of Taft. The tornado continued for another couple of miles passing through a subdivision near the intersection of County Road 98 and County Roads 77A and 77B, about 3 miles north northeast of Taft. An 18 wheeler was flipped. Large trees were snapped and nearly 20 homes were damaged in that subdivision. The tornado dissipated in a field northeast of the subdivision. Maximum winds were estimated to be around 90 mph.
Thunderstorm wind gusts damaged the roof of a medical office in Deer Park. Radar confirmed downburst in that area.
On FM 518 in Friendswood, wind damage occurred to an auto repair shop, with loss of the sheet metal awning, and power lines were down.
A picture of a hail stone that was slightly smaller than a baseball was sent in 4 miles southeast of Breckenridge.
A thunderstorm produced hail up to two inches at Vance Jackson Rd. and De Zavala Rd. in northwestern San Antonio. Most the hail was nickel to ping pong ball size.
Occurred at McCart Street and Interstate 20.
Nickel sized hail was reported near Highway 377 and Dixie Road in Sandusky.
Hail fell at the intersection of FM 839 and Hwy. 79.
Thunderstorms moved across Culberson County and produced a 67 mph wind gust at Pine Springs at the Guadalupe Mountains National Park Mesonet site.
A trained spotter measured a wind gust of 58 MPH near the Parker/Tarrant County line, approximately 2 miles southwest of the city of White Settlement, TX.
Power lines and tree were downed onto a home on Holland Cemetery Road.
Hail up to the size of half dollars was reported in Swearingen. The hail, accompanied by very heavy rainfall, damaged the interior of an exposed ranch home that was undergoing roof repair.
Emergency management reported golf ball sized hail near the intersection of FM 917 and Interstate 35 near Egan.
Video footage at the SpaceX facility captured a microburst with objects flying in the wind, and a tree was broken nearby.
Winds of 70 mph occurred in the gust front in Miami.
A League City area funnel cloud lasted around fifteen minutes.
A trained spotter reported tennis ball size hail 1.5 miles north of Bradshaw.
A tree was downed along Hwy. 110 at County Road 48 near Tyler, Texas.
Golfball to baseball sized hail was reported in Cleburne for nearly 15 minutes by several sources including spotters, broadcast media, and a local COOP Observer.
Hail reported on HWY 287.
Between 4 and 7 inches of rain fell over a three hour period across the Weslaco area. Weslaco Co-Op observer reported over 5 inches of rain.
A roof was blown off of a barn and onto U.S. Highway 183.
Hail was reported near FM 569 and FM 990 near Simms, Texas.
Hail up to two inches in diameter was observed. Damage to vehicles or property was unknown.
Public reported a large tree fell on a RV camper located at the Morgan Shady RV Park.
3/4 inch hail.
An officer reported 60 MPH winds.
Trees were downed in town and a large limb fell onto a home in Diboll, Texas.
Tornado that was observed by the general public caused little or no damage.
The public observed a tornado crossing the field about 4 miles northwest of Elbert north of Highway 79 near FM 2459.
Canopy blown down at Clinics of North Texas building. Time estimated via radar.
A staff member at the West Texas State School reported a tornado touched down briefly in open rangeland to the northwest of the school.
Law enforcement reported nickel size hail.
Quarter-sized hail was reported by a HAM radio operator in Decatur, TX.

A tornado was visually confirmed by storm chasers, but only scattered broken tree branches were found. The first tree branches were found near the intersection of Seaton Road and Big Elm Creek, with additional branches found along rural roads. The tornado lifted over Twister Road shortly after crossing FM 437.
Lightning struck a car and set it ablaze at the intersection of Williams Way Blvd. and Highway 59.

National Weather Service damage survey indicated that wind blown hail damaged residences and several other nearby residences. North facing windows blown out and north facing siding were damaged along with hundreds of acres of crops destroyed.  The wind damage was likely due to the rear flank downdraft.
Up to quarter size hail fell 5 miles south of Clarendon along Highway 70.

Discrete thunderstorms developed over Hansford County during the evening hours of the 22nd. As the storm moved north of the town of Gruver (Hansford County), a member of the public reported nickel size hail (0.88 inch) 5 miles northeast of Gruver (Hansford County). After producing this hail the storm moved southwestward across the county.
The COOP Observer at Prade Ranch reported a thunderstorm producing wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that damaged some trees.
Comanche County Volunteer Fire Departments reported golf ball sized hail near the community of Rucker.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail in La Grange.
Trees were blown down by high winds.
Quarter size hail fell near the Jenkins community north of Lone Star.
There were trees and power lines downed across multiple locations around the Conroe area and off to the north and east.
Trees downed.
Public reported quarter size hail.
Large trees snapped, playground equipment broken, roof blown off into nearby field.
Numerous trees and powerlines were downed across the entire county.

A downburst with winds estimated as high as 70 mph at times traveled northeast from near Frankford Avenue and Spur 327 in southwest Lubbock to the Lubbock International Airport and to just north of Idalou. Peak winds on the periphery of this downburst were officially measured at 63 mph at 2200 CST at a Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet located 3WNW of the University, 59 mph at 2203 CST at the Lubbock ASOS, and 65 mph at 2223 CST at a KAMC weather station in Idalou. The downburst caused moderate damage to a greenhouse located at Lowe's Home Improvement store. At a nearby Home Depot store, the canopy to a greenhouse was partially damaged and several steel fence posts embedded in concrete were bent. At an apartment complex located near 50th Street and Slide Road, the roof of one unit was blown off. Damage to homes was generally light and consisted of some downed fences, broken rain gutters and torn roofing shingles. Many trees lost limbs of various sizes and in a few cases entire trees were toppled. Power outages were confined mostly to small grids in and around the path of the downburst. Total monetary damage from this downburst is estimated around $350,000; much of which was incurred at the home improvement stores.
Numerous trees were downed in severe thunderstorm winds near the town of Kennard.

Strong thunderstorm winds caused tree damage and downed power lines along a stretch from north Waco to downtown Waco. Large trees were blown down by thunderstorm winds on Lake Shore Drive near McLennan Community College. Four large trees were also down at 19th Street and Tanglewood Ave near the McLennan Community College. Other downed large tree limbs and splintered trees were reported along the path towards downtown Waco.
Large limbs were knocked down by thunderstorm winds in Fort Worth. The local newspaper reported several streets were blocked by fallen trees in Fort Worth.
Hail larger than baseballs of about 3.5 inches was measured on the east side of Eden.  This wind driven hail storm damaged and destroyed many buildings across Eden.
Penny size hail was reported 2 miles east-northeast of Azle.
The Cochran County sheriff's office reported quarter size hail southwest of Morton. No damage was reported.
Thunderstorm winds were estimated near 65 mph near Interstate 35E and East 8th Street in Dallas.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Anton measured a wind gust of 67 mph.
A trained spotter reported electric poles down in the Bluffs Neighborhood of San Angelo.
A tree was downed on Jim Hogg Road in Lindale, Texas.
Several trees down.
Winds blew over a 12-inch diameter tree and snapped 10 power poles.
Broadcast media reported a 65 mph wind gust in Woodway.
Report received from Twitter.
A thunderstorm produced wind gust measured at 50 kts by the AWOS at Kenedy Regional Airport.
The Automated Surface Observation System at the Denton, TX airport measured a wind gust of 59 MPH.
This tornado occurred over open country near the intersection of Farm to Market Road 281 and State Highway 70. No damage or injuries were reported.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail in Jollyville.
