Lightning started a tank battery fire near FM 455.  Three firefighter departments battled the fire.

This long track EF-3 Tornado damaged or destroyed several homes and outbuildings.  |It snapped tree trunks and even swept one home completely off its foundation.  The tornado wrapped a woman in carpet and threw her for 150 feet.  Thankfully, she survived with minimal injuries.  This tornado was multi-vortex at times as it also remained mostly in rural areas.  It even lodged a steel C-Purlin into a branch of a Mesquite tree at the Ballinger Country Club.  This tornado destroyed the Ballinger High school Baseball field and threw a steel axle into the water tower and punctured it, causing all of the water to drain.  This tornado affected 30 homes and destroyed six homes.

A thunderstorm moved over southern Fayette County near I-10 between Flatonia and Schulenburg.  A weak tornado touched ground near Farek-Loth Rd where it turns north and becomes Ehler-Grasshof Road.  A storage shed was destroyed along Ehler-Grasshof along with some minor tree damage.  The tornado appears to have moved north and crossed Salem-Freyburg Rd where power lines where damaged off Gebert Road and large trees were down on Schultz Road.  North of this area there was no visible damage as the path was not accessible. For this reason the tornado path was ended on Schultz Road. Maximum winds were estimated to be 80 mph.

A swath of strong winds and damage associated with a rear flank downdraft occurred over a three county area. This swath of winds that caused damage in Dickens and Kent County ended approximately 13 miles southwest of Aspermont.

Training thunderstorms moved over Collingsworth County during the early morning hours of the 16th. The KVII Schoolnet site in Samnorwood (Collingsworth County) reported a storm total accumulation of 3.47 inches. No swift water rescues or stranded motorist were reported in association to this heavy rain.
Quarter size hail covered the ground.
Tennis ball hail.
A thunderstorm produced a measured wind gust of 53 kts. at the San Marcos Municipal Airport.
Large trees were blown down along Farm to Market Road 1262.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 65 mph that knocked down a small tree and some tree branches in southwestern San Antonio.
Trees downed along FM Road 1798.

According to eyewitness and video the second tornado started in a field west of County Road 1164. It moved northeast striking a home at the intersection of CR 3389 and FM 1567. This home sustained EF2 damage when the winds took the roof and attic off the house. The tornado continued NE across open field before striking a few homes off of CR 1181. One home along 1181 sustained EF2 damage and was pushed off its support. Two more homes were damaged on the east side of 1181, and the tornado dissipated soon after. Maximum estimated winds were 120 mph.
Quarter-sized hail in Avinger.
Power lines were downed by large tree branches.
A public report of roof damage was received approximately 8 miles northeast of Gainesville, TX.
Trees were snapped. A roof was blown off of a building. Report from mPING.
Trees downed over Hwy 515 in the northern part of the county.
Hail was reported in the Dalby Springs community.
A pine tree was blown down in the 8500 block of Highway 43 northeast of Henderson.
A thunderstorm produced two inch hail near FM1796 and CR321 north of D'Hanis.
Numerous trees and power lines were downed in Mount Pleasant.
Significant roof damage to a home, and a tree downed onto an RV on adjacent property along County Road 382.
The public and local newspaper articles reported nickel size hail in O'Donnell shortly after 17:00 CST.

Two foot diameter trees were snapped in half along Highway 95 in Little River Academy.  Numerous signs and billboards were blown down between Salado and Little River Academy.  Trees fell on and damaged cars in Little River.
COOP observer at Cope Ranch measured 2-inch hail.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that knocked down some six inch diameter tree limbs along the Guadalupe River south of New Braunfels.
Reported at Lakeside Street and Loop 335 about seven miles northeast of Amarillo.
Hail was reported 3 miles north of Daingerfield, Texas.
Emergency management reported nickel size hail near the city of Krugerville, TX.
Amateur radio reported ping pong ball sized hail approximately 3 miles south of the city of Celina, TX.
A thunderstorm produced half dollar size hail along Hwy 87 south of Fredericksburg.
A spotter reported nickel size hail in the Medical Center area of San Antonio.
Wind gusts of 58 mph or greater were  measured for 5 minutes beginning at 1827CDT.
Broadcast media reported golf ball sized hail in Berryville.
Numerous trees were downed across the northern part of the county.  Some accidents were caused by trees in the roadways.
Quarter size hail was reported through CoCoRaHS.
Trained spotter estimated a 70 mph wind gust on Hwy. 11.
A trained spotter estimated 70 mph winds about two miles east of Happy. No damage was reported.

According to a press release from the Nacogdoches County Sheriff's Office, NCSO deputies arrived at the home on Shoreline Drive at approximately 11:30 a.m. cdt and discovered the victim lying on the ground in his backyard. A witness reported hearing a loud boom that shook the house. The victim was found in the backyard a few minutes later. The NCSO deputies on the scene noticed that the tree that the man was lying near had clearly been struck by lightning. In addition, the victim had a burn mark on his stomach.
Dickens County Sheriff's Office reported golfball size hail.
Measured a 73 mph wind gust with reported tree and roof damage in Sachse.
An mPING report indicated quarter sized hail 3 miles southeast of Paradise.
A tree was blown down across CR 115 in Southern Smith County.
A trained spotter estimated a wind gust to 70 mph.
Public reported quarter sized hail in the community of Cruz Calle.
The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site in Dimmitt measured a 62 mph wind gust.

The National Weather Service damage survey crew found damage that began near U.S 380 and traveled north, just on the northwest side of Farmersville. Several homes, including six mobile homes in close proximity, were either damaged or destroyed.
Texas Tech West Texas Mesonet measured a wind gust to 61 mph.
Baseball size hail was reported in the city of Muenster.
Mping report was received of a thunderstorm producing damage to a home with shingles blown off along with tree limbs broken near Mission Valley.

A mobile home was completely destroyed by a downburst near Highway 287 and FM 2706 in the Bethel area. The single-wide home was sitting on a pier and beam concrete foundation, but the entire home was torn apart by winds estimated around 100 mph. On the same property, a vehicle was turned over and two tractor trailers were blown over.
A thunderstorm produced quarter to golf ball size hail at a gas station in Smithville.
Measured by the Texas Tech/West Texas Mesonet.  A wake low developed behind dissipating convection across the area and generated severe winds.
A large tree was uprooted.
KLST TV relayed a report of pea to nickel size hail covering ground.
Emergency management reported a semi truck overturned by wind in Grandview along Interstate 35 near mile marker 15.
Roof blown off a convenient store by strong thunderstorm wind gusts.
Several reports of trees and powerlines downed throughout Red River County.

An EF0 tornado with maximum winds of 75 mph touched down in far northeastern Lamar County. The tornado touched down near FM 195 and CR 46650, and then moved due east, crossing FM 195. Tree damage was noted early in the track. Near the end of the track, the tornado damaged a few barns; causing them to lose part of their roofs. Near this same location, on CR 45600, a manufactured home was damaged and lost part of its roof.
Mitchell County Sheriff's Office reported nickel sized hail along I-20 near exit 210.
Hail fell along Hwy 87 in Shelbyville, Texas.

A local weather spotter reported minor flooding along Mesa Hills drive near Sunland Park Mall. Water reached the height of the curb in some spots. A  public report of .55 inches of rain in less than one hours time was reported at the same time near Putnam School in the same area.
Trees blown down.
Several fences and trees were blown down around the Saint Paul area.
Law enforcement reported a funnel cloud between Tuscola and Lawn. The funnel cloud came within 500 feet of the ground.
Quarter size hail reported near the intersection of Hynson Springs Road and FM Road 450.
A photo was posted to the KLTV Facebook page of quarter size hail that fell near Lake Holbrook.

A swath of destructive winds in the rear flank downdraft of a supercell exited Floyd County and engulfed much of northern Crosby County for at least 45 minutes. The slow movement of the supercell and its eventual collapse near Crosbyton prolonged the duration and intensity of these winds. Wind gusts in Crosbyton were measured as high as 77 mph resulting in scattered minor structural damage. Several tree limbs were broken and a few trees were completely snapped or uprooted. Multiple power outages resulted from snapped power poles throughout portions of northern Crosby County. These fierce winds also created a dangerous haboob that produced near zero visibility in blowing dust for several minutes. An unknown quantity of young grain crops in the area were damaged or destroyed after being sand blasted by wind and dust.
Several reports were received of hail northwest of Silverton along State Highway 207 ranging in size from half dollar to ping pong balls.

An intense gust front associated with the RFD surged south from the tornadic supercell in northern Mitchell County. This gust front was visually demarked by a classic dust foot that tracked from northwest to southeast across the town of Colorado City. The RFD winds resulted in downing at least two power poles. Utility lines were blown down across the city, and numerous large trees were uprooted. One tree fell onto a car. In addition, a portion of a roof was blown off of a mobile home, and damage was reported to a radio tower. No injuries were reported, but a local utility company reported at least fifty-two customers were left without electricity after the storm.

Newspaper articles reported damaging thunderstorm winds up to 70 miles per hour across northern Yoakum County. The worst damage was reported near Farm to Market Road 1780 where a number of irrigation systems and utility poles were damaged.
Tree limbs down and power reported out east of Whitehouse.
Mesonet station reported a 64 mph wind gust.
Trees were blown down and the high school lost some bricks.  A historic home and a restaurant in Salado suffered roof damage.
Reports of large hail were received as a severe thunderstorm passed over the city of Pecos. Hailstones ranged in size from pennies to quarters.
There was a brief Tornado touchdown in the El Lobo Subdivision, 6 miles east of Hungerford, near the county line.  Emergency management reported the event.
There was quarter sized hail in Liberty.
Several tree branches and a Crepe Myrtle five inches in diameter were reported down one mile east northeast of Garland Road and Buckner Boulevard.
Hail broke out windows at the Alumax Plant at interstate 30 and Nash.
Penny sized hail in far NW Somervell County.

A storm chaser documented a tornado that developed near County Road 405 and Farm-to-Market Road 2794 in far western Dickens County. Despite crossing a road with utility lines, video indicated no apparent damage from this tornado.
A swath of hail from 1 to 1.25 inches in diameter fell from 6SW Jayton to 4W Jayton. Reports were received from law enforcement and Skywarn spotters. No damage was reported.
Hefner (HEFN) Mesonet observation.

This tornado was the southern one of a pair on near parallel tracks a few miles south of Hwy 79. It moved toward the north-northeast through the small town of Noack and then turned to the north approximately a mile north-northeast of the town. Damage was sporadic, but concentrated when it occurred. The most significant damage was to a 3-bin grain storage facility where the bins were completely destroyed and swept from their foundations (DI SBO, DOD 8). Additional damage occurred to an extension of Christ Lutheran Church of Noack on FM112. The extension was ripped from the main building where the walls had been bolted to the foundation (DI LRB, DOD 6).  There is no estimate of monetary losses.
Damage was reported to multiple buildings in downtown Greenville along with downed trees. Time was estimated via radar.

A thunderstorm moved across Scurry County and produced wind damage in Snyder.  A storm survey was conducted and it was determined that the winds were 75 to 85 mph.  There was heavy roof and carport damage in Snyder.  There was a roof blown off of a business, and a store was filled with insulation and rain water.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
A NWS cooperative weather observer reported quarter size hail three miles south of Tell. No damage was reported.
A social media report indicated nickel size hail approximately one-half of a mile west of the city of Montague, TX.
A tornado touched down just south of town. It then moved northeast, damaging two homes.
Spotter reported a funnel cloud near Odem.
Quarter to lime size hail fell in Seminole.
A trained spotter reported two inch hail 1 mile northeast of Loop 286 on the north side of Paris.
Multiple large power poles were snapped and some road  signs were bent. Report came in over social media with  photos of the damage.
Reported at Valley De Oro northwest of Amarillo.
Power poles were downed near CR 55 and Highway 70 in rural Kleberg County.
Reported at the county EOC.

Severe thunderstorms struck Crystal City, knocking down trees and blowing over power lines.   Falling trees damaged several homes and vehicles in the city.  Thunderstorm winds caused slightly less damage north of Crystal City, taking off tree limbs in  LaPryor and Batesville.  Wind gusts there were estimated at 40 to 50 mph.
DELAYED REPORT: Picture from fire department of grapefruit size hail 4 miles east of Ballinger along County Road 123.
Several large trees were snapped and uprooted along and over fences and portions of Highway 154 just east of the Upshur County line in Northwest Harrison County.
Tornado downed power lines across Highway 90.
A thunderstorm produced three inch hail on Blanco Rd. north of Loop 1604 in northern San Antonio.
Unknown wind damage was reported by law enforcement.
A 65 mph wind gust was measured 6 miles south-southeast of Borger, just into Carson County.
A wall of a building under construction was blown down at Bell Helicopter.
Golfball sized hail fell on U.S. Highway 90 for a duration of ten minutes.
A thunderstorms produced one inch hail near I-37 and Loop 1604 in southern San Antonio.

A cluster of discrete thunderstorms moving across the Texas Panhandle transitioned into a broken linear structure during the late evening hours of the 6th. As this broken line of storms moved away from the town of Amarillo (Randall County), the KVII Schoolnet 1 mile north-northwest of Lake Tanglewood (Randall County) reported a 63 mph downburst gust. After producing this gust the line of thunderstorms continued moving eastward across the Panhandle.
Dime size hail was also reported at Gun Barrel City.
A small tornado struck just southwest of Driftwood, knocking 2 trucks off SH12.  None of the vehicle occupants were injured.  One of the trucks was operable after being righted.

The broadcast media relayed reports of giant baseball size hail ten miles east of Farwell along Farm to Market Road 145. Agricultural officials reported that cotton, wheat, and corn crops were severely damaged across portions of western and central Parmer County.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail south of the Dominion.
Thunderstorm winds downed large tree limbs in a neighborhood in La Porte.
A thunderstorm produced two inch hail on a ranch northeast of Brackettville.
Golfball size hail was observed in Bonita.
Measured wind gust caused some damage.
A 67 mph gust was measured at Waco Regional Airport AWOS (KACT) at 2:09 PM and 2:13 PM.
An storm spotter reported half dollar size hail near McKinney.
A few trees were blown down.
Golf ball size hail was reported 3 miles northwest of Stratford.
Funnel cloud reported by law enforcement north of Three Rivers.
Emergency management reported golf ball sized hail at Loop 286 in south Paris, TX.
Local law enforcement reported a downed tree and several downed power lines due to strong thunderstorm wind gusts.
Hen egg size hail reported at County Road 155 and Loop 323 on the southwest side of Tyler.
Lightning started a fire at the Chatham Creek Apartments on Thomason Circle in Arlington. This was a two-alarm fire. Eight people were displaced from their home.
First wind gust was 58 mph at 1817CDT. Peak wind gust of 71 mph was measured at 1825CDT.  Last severe wind gust of 65 mph was measured at 1831CDT.
A trained spotter reported a four inch limb was snapped by strong thunderstorm winds at County Road 237 and FM 45 near the Camp Bowie Military Reservation.
Thunderstorm winds were estimated at 60 mph at Highway 121 and Glade Rd in Euless. Six inch tree limbs were knocked down in the area.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail at Trinity University.
Nickel size hail fell in Lewisville.
Occurred near the intersection of FM 2478 and FM 720.
Winds blew off roof of one wing of the San Pedro Elementary School.
Emergency management reported nickel sized hail in the city of Crawford, TX.

A 13 mile hail swath up to quarter size traveled from south of Wolfforth to near downtown Lubbock.  The hailstones were very hard and led to thousands of dollars worth of minor vehicle body damage in Lubbock.  At times, this hail was driven sideways by strong southerly outflow winds measured up to 43 mph at the NWS office in Lubbock.
Personal weather station measurement.
Trees down between Point Blank and Coldspring.
The Bandera County Courier reported numerous trees down along Highway 16 North.
Baseball size hail caused roof and automobile damage at a ranch in central Hall County.
Wind-driven golfball size hail was reported by law enforcement officials.  At least 8000 acres of cotton were destroyed.
There was a roof to a house was partially blown off.
Spotter reported a brief tornado just to the north of Winters. The tornado remained over open country just north of Winters.. The damage received at Winters was from high winds and hail.
The wind gust was measured at the Texas Mesonet station located one mile east of McLean.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Northfield measured a wind gust to 64 mph.

The tornado touched down four miles south southeast of Hartley at 1632 CST. The tornado was on the ground for one mile with a maximum path width of fifty yards. The tornado dissipated at 1636 CST. No damage or injuries were reported as the tornado remained over open country.
Relayed by amateur radio.
A thunderstorm moved across Brewster County and produced a 64 mph wind gust at Persimmon Gap.
Quarter size hail was reported at Lake Meredith Harbor.
Large tree limbs were downed.
Public reported half dollar size hail.
Large tree limbs reported blown down.
Amateur Radio reported half dollar size hail near Ladonia.

Building damage along the Port of Galveston, vehicle blown off the road and trees down. One house shifted about ten feet into another house next door dislodging it from its piers (both homes were Galveston 1900 Storm survivors).

Local law enforcement officials reported that a tractor trailer rig was blown off the road at mile marker 113 on Interstate 40 by a thunderstorm wind gust. There were no reports of injuries or fatalities.
Received a report of 15 power poles blown down or snapped on County Road X just west of Highway 207.
Quarter size hail reported between Garrison and Timpson.
The Abilene Police Department reported power lines down, power lines arcing, and signal light debris on the roadway in Abilene.
The Stonewall County Sheriff's Office reported golfball size hail.
Occurred at Collins Street and Interstate 20.
A trained spotter estimated 1.5 inch diameter hail in Silverton. No damage was reported.
Damaging thunderstorm winds knocked down trees, tore shingles off roofs, and snapped a power pole.
Power lines were blown down by high winds.
Public reported quarter size hail.
Social media image. Event time is estimated from radar observations.
A severe thunderstorm produced penny size hail in Pyote.
The Upton County Sheriff's Office reported 60 mph winds in McCamey.  No damage was reported.

The tornado touched down fourteen miles southwest of Wolf Creek County Park in extreme southern Ochiltree County at 0232 CST. The tornado was on the ground for approximately one mile and then dissipated about thirteen miles southwest of Wolf Creek County Park at 0234 CST. The tornado remained over open country and had a maximum path width of fifty yards. No damage or injuries were reported.
Quarter-size hail reported by law enforcement along Highway 44 between Agua Dulce and Banquete.
A thunderstorm produced quarter to half dollar size hail in Bertram.
Law Enforcement Officials witnessed a tornado for several minutes. No damage was noted as the tornado remained in open fields.
A thunderstorm produced three inch diameter hail south of Charlotte. Size estimated from picture on social media.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail near Valley Spring.
Two trees were downed southeast of Wake Village, Texas.
Trees downed and debris covering roads in the Kildare community.
Trees uprooted in the community of Brashear.
Garland Police Department reported ping pong ball size hail in the city of Garland, TX.
Quarter size hail was reported 1 mile north of Masterson.
Golf ball size hail reported by trucker on Interstate 10 via Twitter.
Hail between 1 inch and 1.75 inches was being reported between these two spots in town around the same time.

Many trees were downed around the community of Gist, along the Jasper-Newton county line. Some barns and a few roofs to homes were damaged. The maximum wind speed in the tornado was estimated at 100 mph.
Several large tree branches were snapped off trees and a fence was blown down.
Reported via mPING east of Westover Hills.
A trained spotter reported nickel-sized hail approximately one mile north of the city of Argyle, TX.

Report from Seminole Fire Department of 8-10 power poles down with damage to two nearby oil and gas plants due to wind near CR 237 and CR 208. Time is estimated from radar. The estimated maximum wind gust speed is 100 mph. Property damage cost is an estimation.
A thunderstorm produced two inch diameter hail northwest of Wimberley.
Downburst thunderstorm winds damaged several trees and dislodged a dock on the lake at Meridian State Park.  Several large, healthy tree branches were broken and entire trees were knocked down.
Video and pictures were relayed by a broadcast media partner of a land spout tornado from the public. The tornado occurred near Farm to Market Road 70 near Chapman Ranch.
The county emergency manager reported quarter to ping pong ball size hail in the Moss Lake area, approximately 8 miles northwest of Gainesville.
A storm chaser reported a brief tornado over open country.
A report was received of quarter size hail approximately ten miles south of Plainview.
Law enforcement reported tons of pea size hail with three inch drifts.
A public report indicated trees down in the city of Woodway, TX.
Lightning struck a salt water disposal tank near mile marker 624 just off Interstate 20 west of Waskom, Texas.  The resulting fire spread to other nearby tanks in the area as well.
61 MPH wind gust reported at the Lockheed Martin building located in the west part of town.
The West Texas Mesonet station south of Anton measured a 68 mph thunderstorm wind gust.
Emergency management reported an awning blown down at a gas station and a tree snapped about 3 feet from the base.
Orange County Rural Fire Department reported nickel size hail southeast of Vidor.
Trees were downed across FM 4919 south of Bloomburg, Texas.
Golf ball sized hail was reported at the Collin County Law Enforcement Center at Bloomdale Road and U.S. 75.
Quarter-size hail was reported.

A Pecos County Sheriff's deputy observed a tornado just east of U.S. Highway 385. The deputy described the tornado as a well-developed cone-shaped vortex, approximately 150 yards in width, that remained in open range land for about two minutes as it moved east. The deputy searched the area for damage after the tornado dissipated, and reported "shredded" mesquite trees in the tornado's path. Otherwise, no damage to man-made structures occurred.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail at the intersection of US Hwy 183 and Westwood Rd. south of Lockhart.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that knocked down numerous trees and rows of fences.
A heatburst associated with dissipating convection occurred in Young County. The Olney Emergency Manager estimated 60 MPH winds with the heatburst. No damage was reported.
A roof was partially removed from a building at the Fort Worth Stockyards.
Brief touchdown.
Tornado damage was found approximately one mile west of CR 2117 and SH 146.  There was damage to trees and power lines. One roof was torn off a mobile home.
A tree was downed near Interstate 30 southwest of Mount Vernon, Texas.
A tree was blown down on Ranch Acres Road near the intersection with FM 1375.
A trained spotter reported half dollar size hail in Novice.
A 60 mph wind gust was measured at the Gruver schoolnet site.
The Hardin County Sheriffs Department relayed a report of numerous trees and power lines down in Lumberton.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet near Tulia.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail near the intersection of E. Clayton St. and N. Clinton St. in Cuero.
The trained spotter reported the hail near the intersection of Interstate 40 and Texas State Highway 70.
Severe thunderstorm winds blew down trees and knocked over power lines along SH39 between Hunt and Ingram.
Several large trees down across Hwy 59.
A few trees were blown down and a small building was destroyed.
The Kent County Sheriff's Office reported 70 mph thunderstorm wind gusts.
The West Texas Mesonet station at Reese Center measured a 68 mph thunderstorm wind gust.
Several windows on a home were broken by the hail, but no known specifics were given with regards to replacement costs.
Power lines were blown down in Kaufman and surrounding areas.
Golfball size hail was reported 1 mile west of Haslet.
Pea to penny size hail was reported on Highway 70 7 miles northwest of Lake McClellan.
Hail was reported in the Manchester community.
A trained spotter measured a 63 MPH wind gust 1 mile southeast of Southmayd.
The public reported ping-pong ball size hail in Clairemont.
A National Weather Service employee reported quarter-sized hail covering the ground approximately 6 miles southeast of Decatur, TX.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Guthrie measured a wind gust to 59 mph.
Baseball size fell hail near Meridian State Park.
Quarter sized hail was reported in the Edna area.
Several houses were damaged, many RV trailers destroyed, trees, and power lines were blown down.
Law enforcement in Aspermont estimated golfball size hail. No damage was reported.
A power line was reported blown down in the vicinity of Clyde.
Late report of nickel to quarter sized hail.
Trees were blown down onto power lines.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail at the Fort Sam Houston golf course.
Golfball hail covered the ground along Interstate 10 east of Plateau.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Aspermont measured severe wind gusts from 1658 CST through 1704 CST. A peak wind gust of 66 mph was measured at 1704 CST.
Severe thunderstorm winds knocked over trees, and blew down tree limbs in and around the LaPryor area.

Based on a National Weather Service damage survey, this tornado touched down around 1055 pm, 5 miles east of Goodnight and lifted at approximately 1104 pm CDT, 4 miles east-northeast of goodnight. The tornado was rated an EF-0 with an estimated peak wind speed of 85 mph consistent with damage observed.
Power lines and power poles were downed by a passing storm.
A public report indicated quarter sized hail 6 miles west-northwest of  Jacksboro.
Amateur radio reported a 60 MPH wind gust approximately 6 miles southwest of Weatherford, TX.
Trees and road signs were blown down on Farm to Market Road 503 about 8 miles south of Doole.
The emergency manager reported roof damage at a pharmacy and trees down along FM 120 in Pottsboro. Broadcast media showed the metal roof of the pharmacy had been peeled off and was laying in FM 120.
Severe wind gusts were measured by a trained spotter along Highway 349.
A public report indicated trees snapped, one of which crushed part of a fence in Rowlett, TX.
Trees downed.
Powerlines were downed in Judson, Texas.
A social media report indicated golf ball sized hail in the city of Paradise, TX.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that damaged a fence in Hutto.
Six inch diameter tree limbs were downed on FM 1756.
Several trees were blown down in Center.
Windows were blown out of businesses in Clarksville due to strong winds blowing debris around.
A 59 mph gust was measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet station located at Caprock Canyons State Park.
Numerous reports of quarter sized hail along Interstate 10 between Beltway 8 and Bunker Hill Village.
Amateur radio operators observed a tornado to the northeast of Huckabay. The tornado was brief, and only produced damage to ranch land in north central Erath County.
A trained spotter measured two inch diameter hail in Silverton. Damage reports were unavailable.
Powerlines were blown down on Hwy 271 at Hwy 135.  Numerous powerlines were blown down elsewhere across the county.
A peak gust of 66 mph was recorded by an off duty NWS employee in northeast El Paso.
A public report of baseball sized hail was received approximately 3 miles west of Desedoma, TX.

Hail up to the size of golf balls were reported on the south side of the city of Lubbock. This hail was from one of several severe thunderstorms that developed off of the outflow of the initial thunderstorm in southwestern Lubbock County.
Quarter-size hail was reported between Lometa and Adamsville.
A trained spotter reported dime size hail near the Highland Park area of Dallas, TX.
The Texas Department of Transportation reported baseball size hail at the intersection of Farm to Market Road 2400 and Texas Highway 349.
Trees and powerlines were downed in town on County Road 3013.  A tree was also down on a home in Tyler, Texas on the 600 block of Chilton.
Amateur radio operators reported a brief tornado near Cottonwood.
Trees and powerlines were downed south of Kilgore, Texas.
A social media report indicated ping pong ball sized hail near Parks Mall in the city of Arlington, TX.
Numerous power lines blown down across the city.
Several trees and power lines downed by strong thunderstorm winds.
Quarter size hail covered the road at the intersection of Farmington Road and Hall Cemetery Road between the towns of Dorchester and Howe.
Emergency management reported apartment building damage in Waco, TX.
Some accumulating hail on  I 27 south at Sundown exit.
A video was posted to the KSLA-TV Facebook page of half-dollar size hail that fell in the Gray community east of Smithland.
Floyd County emergency management officials reported very large hail that briefly fell up to the size of tennis balls near the intersection of Farm to Market Roads 54 and 378. No damage was reported.
Wind gust occurred at KGLS.

An EF-1 tornado with estimated maximum winds of 95 mph touched down northeast of Detroit along County Road 2127 North, where it twisted small and large limbs on a couple of trees. The tornado crossed CR 2140 and 2133, where it snapped and uprooted hardwood trees. The tornado was most evident in this location with the tall grass in a field pushed down and hardwood trees snapped in a convergent pattern. As the tornado crossed CR 2133, it just missed a single wide mobile home, only ripping a few metal panels off of its roof. The tornado continued to mostly twist and down large branches as it crossed CR 2234 and CR 2235, with a few hardwood trees snapped as it crossed CR 2235 before lifting. It is possible that the tornado continued on further beyond CR 2235, but a heavily wooded area prevented further access to the survey team.
This hail was observed 1 mile southeast of Howardwick.
Several large tree limbs were downed, an awning was blown off, and portions of a roof was peeled back of a building near the intersection of Main Street and North William Street in Downtown Atlanta.
A tree was downed on a vehicle on FM. 1798 near FM. 839.  There were no injuries reported.
The high thunderstorm wind gust was estimated along U.S. Highway 60 about five miles west of Canyon.
Report received through social media of wind damage in downtown Victoria. A power pole was blown down and trees were damaged at the intersection of South Navarro Street and East Forrest Street.
Half dollar sized hail was reported from mPING.
A trained spotter reported an 18 wheeler blown over at the intersection of U.S. Highway 84 and Interstate 20.

The public reported two separate wind gusts of 52 and 54 knots when a mini supercell raced south southeast through the Palmhurst/Mission/Sharyland area during the evening of June 3rd.  The wind gusts knocked down numerous live oak and other trees and large limbs as the storm passed through.
Brooks County Sheriff reported a large number of tree branches down in Falfurrias.
Hail fell at the Red River Army Depot.
Half dollar hail occurred at County Road CC and 26.
Several signs and a billboard were damaged by thunderstorm winds at the intersection of Highway 59 and Highway 80.
Quarter size hail was reported 4 mile southeast of Farnsworth.

A discrete thunderstorm developed over the city of Amarillo (Potter and Randall County) during the evening hours of the 2nd. While over the city, the National Weather Service office observed quarter size hail (1.00 inch) 7 miles east-northeast of town (Potter County). After producing this hail, the thunderstorm slowly moved off to the northeast.

The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site near Tulia recorded a thunderstorm wind gust of 61 mph shortly after 18:00 CST. These winds occurred as outflow spread well south of the parent thunderstorm, which was located nearly ten miles to the northeast. No damage was reported.
A public report indicated that multiple large trees were blown down in the city of Princeton, TX.
A Facebook post reported golf ball sized hail around 5 miles south of Wayland.
Amateur radio storm spotters reported half dollar size hail.
This is an extension of the hail track from near Hamlin as the storm was back building to the southwest for a period of time.
Report relayed from Broadcast Media.
A tree was snapped next to a home on FM Road 3098 northwest of Redwater.
A thunderstorm produced estimated 60 mph winds on the edge of the City of Midland.
Report was received via social media.
A thunderstorm produced three inch hail east of Medina Lake.
A law enforcement official reported an estimated wind gust to 60 MPH.

A tropical shower moved over the city of Amarillo (Randall County) during the early afternoon hours of the 16th. Due to the above average mositure content in the atmosphere, these showers produced intense downpours over the city. An off duty NWS employee reported that this intense rain caused minor flooding on the southbound lane of Ross Road south of Interstate 40. This minor flooding quickly receded as showers moved away from the city. No swift water rescues or stranded motorist were reported in association to this minor flooding.
The Menard Fire Chief reported baseball size hail on Ranch Road 2092.
Trees were downed on Highways 63, 96, and 190 around Jasper.
Trees and power lines toppled.
Trees knocked down.
The public reported penny size hail west of Lazbuddie near the intersection of Texas Highway 214 and Farm to Market Road 145. The hail was accompanied by damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.
The large hail damaged vehicle windows.
Several trees were downed on County Road 4201 in the Rocky Branch community.
Spotter came across mostly dime size hail with a couple quarter size stones on the ground at roughly 1731CDT.
Amateur radio operator reported 1 inch hail in Flower Mound.
Observed nickel-sized hail.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail that damaged car windshields in Brackettville.
A semi truck was blown over and blocked westbound lanes of Northeast Loop 820.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms developed across the southwestern Texas Panhandle during the evening hours of the 24th. These thunderstorms produced 1.10 inches of heavy rain 3 miles north of Dawn (Deaf Smith County), as reported by the KVII Schoolnet site at G and C Hydro Farms. Scattered showers and thunderstorms persisted for several hours before ending shortly after midnight on the 25th.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near White River Lake measured severe wind gusts from 1827 CST through 1835 CST. A peak wind gust of 64 mph was measured at 1833 CST.
A trained spotter reported a wind gust of 60 mph about 3.6 miles northeast of Wall.
A NWS trained spotter reported gusts to 60 mph associated with a downburst from a thunderstorm.

Damage in and around a residence near the intersection of East Osage Road and East Shawnee included a mobile home moved, shingles removed on a home, a large tree limb (unknown origin) down in the yard and a large mattress lofted across the property.
Multiple trees and power lines were downed on FM 412 and County Road 4222.
The thunderstorm wind gust was measured near Broadway Drive and Cherry Avenue.

Golf ball sized hail reported 2 miles north-northeast of Plano. The hail shattered windows in cars, homes, and businesses which is what caused most of the damage. The storm causing millions of dollars of damage in Plano and the surrounding area.

A complex of severe multicell convection back built into the southeastern Permian Basin from the west-central Texas area near San Angelo along and north of a stalled frontal boundary. This was first of several waves to affect the west Texas Permian Basin and the Trans Pecos region during an extensive severe weather episode. Pea to quarter size hail was first reported at the Cope Ranch in rural northeastern Reagan County.
Several signs along I-35 were damaged and blown over between the Red River and FM 372.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that damaged the roof of an outbuilding east of Rocksprings.
A large tree fell across the intersection of Oak Avenue and Beckham Street.
MPing report.
Thunderstorm winds downed a tree along Lake Conroe Dam.
Odell (ODEL) Mesonet observation.
Three inch diameter hail was reported 15 miles south of Claude.
A media report indicated that the roof of an unknown building was laying on the side of Battle Lake Road in the city of Mart, TX.

Mission police department reported several car ports damaged or destroyed in the 800 block of East 21st Street in Mission. ASOS at KMFE, about 5 miles to the SE, reported peak wind gust of 39 knots during the thunderstorm.
Occurred on the north side of town.
Power lines downed on County Road 4256 near Lake Striker, resulting in a fire.

The National Weather Service Office in Lubbock Texas relayed a report from a member of the public who said that two large trees were blown down by thunderstorm wind gusts about six miles north of Panhandles Texas. No injuries or other damages were reported.
Nickel size hail fell near Joaquin.
There were numerous reports of wind damage in the community of Payne Springs. Numerous trees and powerlines were down. There was roof damage to 10 homes due to fallen trees.
Trees down in New Ulm and in Bellville.
A thunderstorm moved across Martin County and produced a brief tropical funnel near Stanton.  No damage was reported.

A tornado formed near the intersection of CR 403 and CR 404 and moved north to near Elmwood, causing damage to homes, trees, sheds, and power lines.  Trees were split, twisted, and uprooted.  The county judge surveyed the damage and found the worst to be between FM 315 and CR 404.
Severe hail (1 in.) was observed by a member of the public as a squall line moved through Brazoria County.
Trained spotters estimated 60 mph winds in San Angelo.
Thunderstorm winds blew a one foot diameter tree onto a single family residence.  A two foot diameter tree was blown over onto FM 875.
Hail reported to be three inches deep in the extreme northeastern corner of Ochiltree county.
A few barns were damaged.  One home was damaged.  A few trees were also downed.
Fire department personnel estimated quarter size hail at 1903 CST and golfball size hail at 1905 CST in Floydada. No damage was reported.
Training thunderstorms brought heavy rain to Carson County during the morning hours of the 19th. A member of the public reported a storm total of 2.54 inches in Panhandle (Carson County).
Ping pong ball size hail was reported at Conlen Airport.
Thunderstorm winds downed power lines in the Apple Springs area.
A West Texas Mesonet Station measured a wind gust of 81 mph.
There was some roof damage to a home on Dorrell Road.
Penny-sized hail on FM 799.
Numerous tree limbs blown down and a roof ripped off of a shed in Merkel.
A 60 MPH wind gust was measured by a meso-net site in Heath, TX.
A spotter reported golf ball size hail in Stamford along the Jones-Haskell County line.
A thunderstorm produced two inch diameter hail near Pflugerville.
Minor street flooding was reported in Happy following up to two inches of rain that accompanied a strong thunderstorm shortly after midnight CST on the 16th.
Quarter sized hail was reported 10 miles west of DeLeon.
Hail fell in the Bald Hill community.
Tornado reported by a storm chaser, and was on the ground for several minutes.
Emergency management reported that 20 to 30 trees were blown down just west of Krum.
A bait shop and the roof of a restaurant at Eagle Mountain Lake were damaged by high thunderstorm winds.
A picture was posted to social media of half dollar size hail that fell between Shelbyville and Huxley.
Numerous trees down.
Nickel size hail was reported near Blanchard.

The Hidalgo County Emergency Manager reported strong winds occurred during a thunderstorm which knocked down some power lines in Weslaco. A funnel cloud was reported by the emergency manager approximately two miles west of Weslaco as the thunderstorm moved through the area. Peak winds of 43 mph were reported at the Mid Valley Airport, 2 miles east of Weslaco, estimated at around 812 AM CST.
Trees were blown down by high winds.
A trained spotter reported a brief tornado touchdown near Sagerton.
A picture with the hail measurement was sent to the NWS office over social media. Numerous reports of golf ball size hail in an around Booker were also received.
Lightning strike to residential home caused home fire.
Quarter sized hail occurred along Interstate 35 at mile marker 26 near Callaghan.
A tree was blown down on County Road 1840 just southeast of Yantis.
Stephens County sheriffs deputies reported quarter sized hail six miles west of Breckenridge.

A few trees were snapped at their base and had large limbs broken off with the initial touchdown along FM 2625 just west of Highway 59.  The tornado continued northeast paralleling FM 2625 causing sporadic tree damage until it reached the intersection of FM 2625 and Taylor Road.  The tornado strengthened rapidly in a short timeframe causing EF2 damage to two residential homes and EF1 damage to a third.  One house completely lost its roof while another had an entire room destroyed.  The third home had its metal roof peeled off while sustaining partial wall failure. Numerous trees in the vicinity of the homes were completely toppled or had their tops sheared off. The tornado continued to the northeast where it intersected Blocker Road near FM 2625 causing various amounts of tree damage to several trees there.  The tornado continued to the northeast dissipating over a logging road a mile to the east of Blocker Road.  Maximum winds were estimated at 120-125 mph.
Quarter size hail was reported in Mountain Springs.
Emergency management reported trees snapped or uprooted approximately 6 miles southwest of Sherman, TX.

Emergency management reported trees down in the town of Honey Grove, Texas. Powerlines are down on the south side of Honey Grove along HWY 34. It was reported that powerlines fell on top of one vehicle trapping people inside. Damage to a barn was also reported.
The public reported hail 2 to 2.25 inches in diameter 3 miles east of Irby.
A thunderstorm produced half inch to quarter size hail southeast of Concan. Hail dented some car hoods.
The broadcast media reported that the field house at River Road High School had part of its roof blown off.
Large limbs were downed northwest of Jefferson, Texas.
Nickel-sized hail was reported on FM 1428.
Dime size hail was reported in McGregor.
EM reported around 2 inch hail in the Morrisdale neighborhood.
Quarter sized hail and power outages were reported.
Emergency management reported trees down on FM 315, Highway 84, and County Road 391 in Anderson County.
Golfball sized hail fell in Iraan.
Report received via mPING.

A relatively broad, but weak, tornadic circulation developed beneath a well-defined wall cloud near the north Loop 289 and Interstate 27 interchange in north Lubbock shortly after 15:00 CST. The brief tornado, which was photographed by a National Weather Service meteorologist, struck the Beck Steel industrial facilities and severely damaged the roof of a large metal warehouse-type structure. Car windows in a nearby parking lot also were blown out. Damage was consistent with 70 to 80 mph wind speeds via estimates using the Enhanced-Fujita Scale. No injuries were reported.
Social media reports showed numerous trees were blown down across Bridgeport and surrounding areas. It was reported 20 large trees were blown down at the Bridgeport Country Club.
Nickel sized hail occurred near George West.

Large hail up to baseball size cut a swath from the northeast sections of San Angelo to the east side of San Angelo. This hail was from the main supercell that barely missed the downtown area of San Angelo.
A vehicle lost control on I-35E due to slick roads from rain and crashed through a guardrail. The driver of the vehicle was killed and the passenger was injured.
Ping pong to golf ball-sized hail reported by the public via social media. Time was estimated by radar.
Several trees were downed with debris across Hwy. 80 in Gladewater, Texas.
Numerous trees were downed across Brazoria County.
A trained spotter reported golf ball size hail. Most of the hail stones were quarter to half dollar size.
Numerous trees and power lines down between Cumby and Lone Oak.

This  tornado began nearly as the last tornado dissipated to the south and west. The parent supercell cycled another tornado about a mile to the east and northeast of the previous storm. This tornado quickly grew to a large tornado, becoming slightly less than one mile wide at its widest point. The tornado was at the strongest near Interstate 20 and FM 17 just north of Canton. The survey crews found continuous damage between Canton and Fruitvale, and then additional damage as far north as Emory, |and Lake Fork. Several homes, businesses, and farm buildings were damaged or destroyed in the 40 mile continuous damage path. This tornado occurred for over an hour, and spanned most of Van Zandt, and nearly all of Rains Counties during the 80 minute track.
A roof was blown off a mobile home.
A social media report indicated hail up to baseball size in Royse City.
Golf ball-sized hail was reported near Lake Colorado City.
Tree damage due to high wind around the town of Needville.
A cocorahs observer reported this hail.
A social media report indicated penny sized hail near the town of Blackland, TX.
The public reported golf ball size hail 4 miles east of Hawley.
Public reported quarter size hail.

A storm chaser observed a tornado at times across northeastern Clay County. The tornado initially developed south of Byers and moved north and then northeast into the far northeastern edge of Clay County dissipating near the Red River. The tornado may have extended into Jefferson County Oklahoma, but no evidence could be found on the Oklahoma side of the Red River.||At least two homes experienced significant roof damage, a couple of barns were significantly damaged and a few large trees were snapped or uprooted.

National Weather Service Storm Survey Team determined that damage across eastern Marion County was a result of straight line wind damage near 90 mph.  This is a continuation of the storm that produced damage earlier across Karnack and Uncertain, Texas.  The storm crossed Caddo Lake and again produced numerous trees and powerlines downed east of Smithland Texas.  Some structures also had trees on them.
An NWS cooperative weather observer located in Tahoka reported quarter size hail.
Numerous trees down and power lines snapped along TX-37 CR-500, FM-3357 and TX-115.
Quarter to ping pong ball size hail fell in the Norwood community.
A storm spotter in Mentone reported penny to nickel size hail.
Law enforcement reported trees and power lines down just east of Marlin, TX.
Trees and power lnes down throughout town.
Golfball sized hail was reported in Sivells Bend.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that blew part of the roof off of a restaurant along with downing numerous trees in Fredericksburg.
Amateur radio reported baseball sized hail in the city of Corinth.

Another brief tornado occurred along the northeast outskirts of Lefors. The most significant damage was to detached garages. One garage was completely destroyed...with debris from this building found in nearby trees. A travel trailer parked next to the garage was moved forty yards and destroyed. Large tree branches were snapped. |A second well constructed garage with steel roofing beams suffered damage. Roof paneling was peeled southward. At the north side of the garage was an interior room which suffered damage as the ground level wall mounted air conditioner was pulled inward into the room as the garage door failed and blew outward. Power poles were snapped at six foot level along with considerable fence damage. The north facing porch structure was damaged. A large antique car was moved approximately fifteen yards...and rotated cyclonically from its original position. Two large tanks...each weighing two thousand pounds...were moved seventy-five yards. No injuries were reported.
A 67 mph gust was measured at Guinn Hall TWU.
Late report of quarter sized hail around midnight with second storm.

National Weather Service conducted a storm survey across San Angelo.  A scattered line of thunderstorm produced a damaging thunderstorm outflow and multiple wet microbursts across the city.  This caused damaging straight line winds of 60 to 95 mph across the City of San Angelo, knocking down power poles and power lines, resulting in widespread power outages.  Numerous large tree limbs and some trees were uprooted. A wind gust of 86 mph was measured at the National Weather Service at 201 AM CDT.  The downburst was 10 miles long and about 2500 yards wide as it began about 2 miles northeast of San Angelo and continued for 8 miles southwest of San Angelo.||Radar and photographs clearly showed intense damaging thunderstorm downbursts impacting the city.  One impacted the north side near Chadbourne and Loop 306 where it damaged a gasoline station canopy, it knocked over a large power line that crossed Loop 306 and snapped a power pole. It also knocked down numerous large tree limbs and damaged some roofs in the area.  The severe wet microburst also damaged the Wool Hair building in the vicinity.  ||The downburst wind knocked down three power poles and power lines at Knickerbocker and Johnson Street.  The storm ripped off roofing material at the nearby Bellagio Apartments.  The damaging winds damaged the wall of a nearby commercial building.  The high winds also knocked down numerous tree limbs, broke windows and damaged roofs in the College Hills area.  ||The downburst winds removed shingles, knocked down signs, and numerous tree limbs on the southwest side of San Angelo near Lamar Elementary School.  As the downburst struck the KOA RV park near Lake Nasworthy, it knocked down numerous tree limbs and uprooted a few trees.  One Recreational Vehicle was knocked over on it's side.||Special thanks to the San Angelo Police Department, the San Angelo Fire Department,|San Angelo Emergency Management, San Angelo REACT and local residents and business owners for their excellent assistance.
A tree was downed across the access road of Highway 290 near West 43rd.
Quarter size hail fell about 4 miles northeast of Cameron.

Hidalgo County Emergency Manager reported thunderstorm wind damage in the Las Canas subdivision (colonia). A roof was blown off a carport, a sheet of a tin roof was lifted on a mobile home and power lines were down.  Homes in the neighborhood typically are very poorly built; other nearby residences were not impacted by the winds.
The Swisher County Sheriff's office reported dime to golfball size hail in town.
Numerous trees and power lines downed across Shelby County.
The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site near Hart recorded severe thunderstorm wind gusts of 62 mph at 19:25 CST and 60 mph at 19:30 CST. No damage was reported.
Wind damage occurred to approximately 6 houses. Most of the damage was to the roofs. Trees,signs, Trees, signs, and fences were also blown down.
A 62 MPH wind gust was measured by the Automated Surface Observation System at Dallas Executive Airport.

A discrete thunderstorm developed over Deaf Smith County during the evening hours of the 18th. This storm intensified as it neared the town of Dawn (Lipscomb County), the KVII Schoolnet site 3 miles north of Dawn (Deaf Smith County), measured a 60 mph thunderstorm gust. The storm continued to move to the northeast after producing this gust.
18 wheeler was flipped on its side on U.S. 281 just south of Premont.
Fences were blown down.
Sixty mph winds were reported in St. Lawrence. No damage was reported.

A cluster of discrete thunderstorms moving across the Texas Panhandle transitioned into a broken linear structure during the late evening hours of the 6th. As this broken line of storms where near the town of Canadian (Hemphill County), the West Texas Mesonet site 6 miles east of Canadian (Hemphill County) reported a 73 mph downburst gust. After producing this gust the line of thunderstorms continued moving eastward across the Panhandle.
A thunderstorm produced a tornado that produced EF0 damage. The tornado touched down near County Road 208 and caused damage to some hardwood trees with estimated maximum winds of 75 mph.

Local law enforcement officials reported that thunderstorm winds damaged utility poles and lines just southeast of Childress shortly after 17:30 CST. The damages resulted in widespread power outages between Childress and Kirkland.
A thunderstorm moved across Pecos County, and the Fort Stockton/Pecos County Airport measured a 58 mph wind gust.  No damage was reported.
The public estimated 50 to 60 mph wind gusts resulting in half inch tree limbs down.
Numerous trees blown down.
Quarter size hail fell in the community of Remuda in eastern Parker County.
Reported via mPING east of The Colony.

About 30 minutes after the first tornado sighting along US57, Skywarn-trained spotters from the Eagle Pass Fire Department reported a second tornado near the same location.  This tornado was reported to be on the ground for almost half a mile and was larger than either of the first two.  It tracked toward the east over open country at nearly 50 miles an hour.  It was also rated F0 on the Fujita Scale.
The Automated Weather Observation System at Fort Worth Spinks Airport measured a wind gust of 64 MPH.
A thunderstorm produced half dollar size hail in Camp Wood.
Emergency management reported that Silos were damaged in Muenster, TX.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail along Harris Branch Pkwy west of Manor.
A barn was destroyed along Wire Road.
A 58 mph wind gust was estimated by a rancher at Ramireno Ranch near Zapata.
Two inch hail was reported near Robinson via social media.
The roof was blown off a house.

An NWS Storm Survey team determined that storm damage north of Marshall near the Woodlawn community was consistent with that of an EF-2 tornado.  This tornado began along Suburban Acres Road and then moved north where it damaged several homes and outbuildings along FM. 1793.  Several more homes and outbuildings were damaged along Blackjack Road and Pope City Road as the tornado continued north.  The tornado lifted along FM 134 just before reaching the Little Cypress Bayou.

A left-moving supercell produced a swath of hail from Roaring Springs northeast to Matador. The largest hail estimated up to two inches in diameter occurred 3E Matador along Highway 70. Other hail reports included quarter size in Roaring Springs, golfball size 3SE Matador and also in Matador shortly thereafter. No damage was reported.
Quarter sized hail was reported west of Corsicana off Highway 31.
A Co-Op observer in McCook recorded a wind gust to 53 knots, or 61 mph. Hail between the size of peas and dimes was also noted at the time.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet.
Lighting illuminated a tornado just to the northeast of Avenger Field. The tornado touched down only a few minutes and was out in open country.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Memphis measured a peak wind gust of 67 mph at 1540 CST. Severe wind gusts were measured from 1540 through 1550 CST.
Ping pong ball size hail fell in the Macune and Norwood communities.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Jayton measured a wind gust to 60 mph.
The public reported numerous broken tree limbs. There was roof damage to a warehouse building. Also, there was widespread power outages in Ozona.
Trees were blown down on Farm to Market Road 1819 near the Angelina/Cherokee County line.
Numerous reports of severe hail in the city of Midland were received.  The largest hail observed was the size of golfballs.  No significant damage was reported.

Very heavy rainfall rates accompanied a wet downburst just south of Anton around 11:00 CST. The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site south of the city recorded a short duration burst of rainfall and damaging thunderstorm winds. The site recorded 1.24 inches of precipitation, however, local news reports suggest that portions of Anton proper picked up between 2.70 and 3.00 inches of rainfall. Storm surveys conducted by National Weather Service meteorologists the following day concluded that water spilled from a swollen playa lake and covered portions of Farm to Market Road 168 south of Anton.
Hail was reported via MPING near College Station.
The damaging winds associated with this storm blew over a carport and broke large tree limbs up to 8 to 10 inches in diameter.
Wind damage was reported to a roof at Hwy. 8 and the CR. 1238 intersection.
Thunderstorm winds snapped large softwood trees a few feet from their trunks. One to three inch diameter branches were broken off. There was minor home damage.

Storm chasers documented a satellite tornado which accompanied a cone-shaped and long-lived tornado near Cedar Hill in northeastern Floyd County around 19:20 CST. The small satellite tornado remained in open range land southeast of Farm to Market Road 97 and resulted in no damages.
Damage information was not available.

A thunderstorm moved across Reeves County and produced wind damage in Balmorhea.  There was a large tree down at El Paso Street and State Highway 17.  The tree was blocking Highway 17.  The cost of damage is a rough estimate.
Several trees were downed near Zavalla, Texas.
Very heavy rainfall was reported, through amateur radio, to have occurred about a quarter of a mile east of the KGNS-TV studio. The spotter reported 4.2 inches of rain was measured.

Although a large part of Abilene experienced 60 to 70 mph winds, the location receiving the most significant damage occurred on the south side of town near the mall and the Warwick Apartments.  These high winds snapped telephone poles, uprooted large trees, broke tree limbs, knocked down power lines, tore the roof off of an industrial building, removed metal roofing material from an Albertsons Grocery Store and knocked over tractor trailers.  The damaging thunderstorm winds broke large glass windows at the Mall in Abilene, at a nearby Albertsons Grocery Store and on a nearby Furniture Row Building.  One person was injured at the mall by the falling glass.  The winds also blew large pieces of metal off of a storage facility into the front yard of a nearby residence that were about 1 to 2 blocks south of the facility.  In addition to a freeway sign that was blown down,  fences, power lines and tree limbs were toppled by the high winds across a large part of the City of Abilene.
The Texas Tech Mesonet Station located about 4 miles north of San Angelo measured a wind gust at 74 mph.
A wind gust of 70 mph was recorded at the Tyler Pounds Field Airport.
A semi was blown off of Daniels road. The driver sustained minor injuries. Damages are estimated.
A trained spotter reported pea to penny size hail approximately 2 miles northwest of the city of Glen Rose, TX.
Reported via mPING southeast of Allen.
Trees down in the town of College Station.
Trees were downed west of Carthage, Texas.
A storm chaser reported quarter size hail along Interstate 10.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail in Stonewall.
Multiple trained spotters observed a brief tornado to the southwest of Dublin. This tornado occurred on the north side of U.S. 377 and produced spotty tree damage.
Reported by the general public.
A second funnel cloud was observed near Harborside Drive on Galveston Island.
The public reported ping pong ball size hail via social media.
A National Weather Service employee reported traffic railroad crossing arms were snapped in San Angelo at Knickerbocker Road on the south side of town.
Quarter size hail fell a few miles west of the Hideaway community.
Nickel size hail fell in Marshall.
Three storm chasers reported a brief touch down of this tornado in an open field.

A report of thunderstorm wind damage was received approximately 5.5 miles north of Wills Point. Silos were moved from their foundation, windows were damaged on vehicles, and metal shop doors were pushed inward. Trees on the property also sustained damage.
A trained spotter estimated the thunderstorm wind gusts two miles north of the town of Groom, Texas. No damage or injuries were reported.
A tree fell onto a house.
A thunderstorm produced 4.0 inch diameter hail one quarter mile east of Hwy 281 northwest of Lake Victor.
Penny to quarter size hail was reported in and around McCamey, including at the intersection of U.S. Highway 67 and Texas Highway 349.

A thunderstorm moved over Cotton Flat in Midland County and produced wind damage from a downburst.  Four inch diameter tree limbs were snapped.  A power pole was blown down on Highway 349, and there was damage to houses along west county road 130.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
A NWS cooperative weather observer in Northfield estimated half dollar size hail.
Trained spotter reported half dollar size hail.
A 70 MPH wind gust was measured at the Comanche, TX Remote Automated Weather Station.
A National Weather Service Employee estimated a thunderstorm wind gust at 60 mph.
A thunderstorm moved across Gaines County and produced a 61 mph wind gust near Seminole.
Amateur radio reported quarter-sized hail in the city of Irving, TX.
Trees down in the town of Alvin.

NWS storm survey concluded that a microburst with winds up to 70 mph impacted a narrow corridor through the central portion of the city of Skidmore. The axis of wind damage was concentrated near the intersection of U. S. Highway 181 and West Main Street. The perimeter fence of the high school baseball field was torn down. A portion of a roof was lifted off a home near North 7th Street and East Mathis Street, and a large tree limb as blown down on 2nd Street.

Local broadcast media relayed report of wind damage to gas station roof at the intersection of U.S. Business Highway 77 and Williams road.  Damage was also done to a nearby warehouse.  General public had indentified a possible funnel cloud in the area at the time of the report.  A survey completed by a NWS employee revealed damage consistent with that produced by straight-line winds.
A suspected downburst caused tree damage in Kaufman. One metal building along US Highway 175 southeast of town was also damaged.
A 60 mph wind gust was estimated approximately 6 miles north of Weatherford.
A trained spotter reported quarter sized hail about a mile east of Leagueville, TX.
A member of the public reported golf ball-sized hail in Pleak.
Public reported golf ball size hail.
The Stamford and Haskell Star Newspapers reported nickel size hail in Haskell.
Spotters reported approximately 100 power poles blown down by severe thunderstorm winds in and around Midkiff.
Large tree limbs were blown down.
Golf ball sized hail was reported near Lamar St and Highway 56 in Sherman, and also at the EOC in downtown Sherman.
The Johnson County Emergency Manager reported golf ball sized hail in the city of Covington.
Golf ball to baseball sized hail was reported by broadcast media and trained spotters in the city of Loving, TX.
The Amarillo Emergency Manager reported that four power poles had been blown down at Osage Street and 58th Avenue due to thunderstorm wind gusts estimated to be fifty-two knots.
Several roofs were reportedly damaged.
Report of two tractor trailers flipped over on Hwy 281 and FM 1554.
Part of a roof blown off a church building.
Strong thunderstorms downed power lines in the town of Progreso.  The damage was reported by the Texas Department of Public Safety.
Penny-size hail was reported between Farmers Branch and northwest Dallas.
Severe thunderstorm winds tossed boats from their trailers at the Dallas Corinthian Yacht Club on Lewisville Lake in Little Elm.

A thunderstorm moved across Brewster County and produced an estimated 65 mph wind gust in Alpine.  A tree fell on a vehicle.  The size of the tree and damage to the vehicle are unknown.  The cost of damage is a rough estimate.
Golf ball size hail was reported one mile northeast of Howardwick.

The San Saba Emergency Manager reported uprooted trees in Richland Springs and winds estimated at 80 to 90 mph, between 850 and 900 PM.   A National Weather Service Survey Team found lots of evidence of damaging straight line winds around 80 to 85 mph.  In addition to the damaging thunderstorm winds, softball sized hail fell in a 9 mile by 2 mile swath northeast and southwest of Richland Springs.  This swath of hail  extended northeast towards Locker, Spring Creek and Algerita and southwest across Richland Springs.  ||This combination of wind and hail damaged or destroyed numerous vehicles, broke windows, damaged siding and roofs on many homes.  One trailer was destroyed by the damaging thunderstorm winds.  All of the debris was aligned from northeast to southwest.  We observed many oak trees that were completely defoliated. There were many broken tree branches and some trees were uprooted.  Livestock were also killed by the damaging winds and large hail stones.
Amateur radio reported quarter-sized hail one mile northeast of Dodd City, TX.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that blew down tree branches in Shiner.

A severe thunderstorm produced a swath of nickel to quarter size hail, at times accompanied by severe winds, from near Dimmitt to Hart. Initial reports indicated that nickel size hail began near a farm northeast of Dimmitt at 18:07 CST. By 18:13 CST, quarter size hail was reported in Nazareth. Hailstones of unknown size, driven by severe winds, destroyed at least 5,000 acres of corn and cotton crops near Hart around 18:30 CST.

A brief but very intense thunderstorm wind gust of 66 mph was recorded by the Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site near Memphis. Local officials reported that the winds downed a number of power lines.
The public reported that giant baseball size hailstones briefly fell in New Home. Minor property damage was reported.
A tree fell on a home near the intersection of West 21st Street and Lawrence Street.
Wind damage of an unknown type was reported by the county Sheriff.

A long duration of quarter to half dollar size hail fell along Highway 147 between CR 348 and Highway 1277 near Broaddus High School. The hail completely covered the ground, and resulted in extensive hail fog along the highway.
A report from the public indicated hail to the size of quarters eight miles west of Lazbuddie.
Golfball size hail fell in the Selman City community.
A thunderstorm produced hail that covered the ground. The largest was nickel size.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site in Memphis measured a wind gust to 58 mph. No damage was reported.
No damage was reported.
A telephone pole was blown down by high winds.
A wind gust of 60 mph was reported at the Junction Airport ASOS.
Thunderstorm winds downed a tree and destroyed much of a two story house.  A tree also fell on the American Legion Pavilion.
Amateur radio reported quarter sized hail 3 miles northeast of Burleson, TX.
Report from mPING: Quarter (1.00 in.).
An 18-wheeler was blown over in a Walmart parking lot located one mile north-northwest of Cleburne.
Thunderstorm winds blew the roof off a residence and snapped power poles approximately 6 miles north-northeast of Rhome.
Golfball size hail was reported in Grapevine.
Numerous trees were blown down as a result of damaging straight line thunderstorm winds.
Golf ball sized hail was reported near Willis.
The public reported quarter size hail about 8.6 miles southwest of Hext.
Numerous trees and power lines were blown down throughout the city of Nacogdoches and Northern Nacogdoches County.
Wind damage was reported along Washington Street in Rockwall. Damage to athletic field fences, broken tree limbs, and wooden sheds were damaged.
A picture on social media showed a 2.25 inch hail stone fell near Parker.
Severe thunderstorm winds blew down trees and power lines in and near Moulton and produced nearly 3.5 inches of rain in just one hour.
Trees downed.
Penny sized hail fell northeast of Lamesa.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail north of Dripping Springs.
Trained spotters reported golf ball sized hail near Alvord.
The hail was reported in White City.
Golf ball sized hail was reported outside of Caddo.
Ping pong-size hail report relayed by city officials.
A microburst generated by an isolated thunderstorm produced strong winds which tore off part of a roof, exposing 3 apartments at the Car Mel apartment complex in Waco, TX.
Emergency management reported half-dollar sized hail in the city of Willow Park, TX.
Trees were reported down on FM 343 and FM 1648.
Shingles blown off roof at a church...damage to cars at a local Walmart in north Beeville.

A thunderstorm moved across Pecos County and produced a downburst in Fort Stockton.  Power lines were blown down as a result of this downburst.  The number of power lines blown down is unknown so the cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that knocked down trees and power poles from Sandy Mountain to Sunrise Beach on Lake LBJ.

A severe thunderstorm produced large hail over the northern portions of Lubbock shortly before 15:00 CST. Initial reports indicated that penny size hail fell over University Avenue, about four miles north of Loop 289. By 14:55 CST quarter size hail was reported in New Deal.
RAWS site COAT2 reported a wind gust of 62 mph.
Power lines down in Winnie and tree down on a car in Ahahuac.
A large tree was downed west of Winnfield, Texas along Hwy 67 east.

A second tornado developed southeast of Temple near Bob White Rd north of FM-3117 tracking mostly over open field. Major roof damage was found near the intersection of these roads (DI 2, DOD 4). Additional but less extensive roof damage was seen to others homes as the tornado tracked southeast near Heidenheimer Rd. The team also found significant damage to several transmission lines along this area with more than a dozen towers flipped on its side. Many trees along the tornado track were also heavily damaged. Another home on Shaw Rd near Stallion Rd lost all its roof material and most of the wood beams constructing the roof. The tornado lifted soon after crossing Shaw Rd. This tornado was rated EF-1 with maximum estimated winds of 110 mph.

Estimated golf ball size hail caused damage extensive damage to a home near Fort Stockton. Hail may have been even larger. All windows and exterior walls facing the hail were broken or damaged. Time estimated from radar. Property damage cost is an estimation.
A National Weather Service damage survey crew found evidence of a tornado northwest of the city of Rio Vista. This tornado produced minimal damage to trees across open fields.
A thunderstorm moved over Brewster County and produced a 63 mph wind gust about one mile southeast of Rio Grande Village as indicated by the Big Bend Portable.
Trees downed on FM Road 123 south of De Berry.
Member of the public shared a picture of a hail stone estimated to be around 2 inches. Timing based on radar.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail between Lockhart and Uhland.
A thunderstorm produced three quarter to one inch hail which covered the ground.
The broadcast media reported golf ball size hail.
The Canyon Fire Department reported that a power pole and an associated transformer were pulled out of the ground in Canyon.
Public reported ping pong ball size hail.
A thunderstorm produced dime to quarter size hail in Crystal City.

A severe thunderstorm tracked northeastward from Hockley County and produced large hail over the western portion of Lubbock County. Numerous reports were received of quarter size hail along a swath from Reese Center to Shallowater between 17:52 and 18:02 CST. Ping pong ball size hail was additionally reported as the storm tracked west of Abernathy.
Several trees were uprooted and multiple power poles were downed throughout Borger.
Quarter size hail was reported at Blue Mountain Peak Ranch.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 65 mph that damaged trees and a house along Hwy 90 between Kingsbury and Luling.
The tornado occurred over open country and the path length and path width were estimated.
Trees and powerlines were downed near FM. 1519 in Camp County.
A public report of large trees down on Hwy 79 was received approximately 1 mile east-northeast of Neches, TX.
Beaumont Enterprise reported the Old First Baptist Church along Interstate 10 in Orange caught fire from a lightning strike.
Several trees were blown down.
Hail report via mPing.
Storm chaser reported hail up to 1 inch in diameter just west of La Gloria.
The hail was reported by the Texas Department of Public Safety on Interstate 40 in the town of Shamrock, Texas.
Ping pong ball sized hail was reported 2 miles west of Runaway Bay.
Sporadic downed trees were reported near Private Road 3496. Time was estimated via radar.
Hail reported at Holly Lake near Hawkins, Texas.
A 46 diameter tree was knocked onto a storage building on Sanders Street in Bowie. The storage building was heavily damaged.
Trees were downed in Carthage, Texas.
Golf ball size hail was reported at Goldthwaite High School.
Reported by  the co-op observer.
Several trees were blown down...mainly over the eastern portions of the county.
A trained spotter measured a wind gust of 60 MPH near the intersection of Green Oaks Blvd and Interstate 20 in the city of Arlington, TX.
Nickel sized hail was reported on the west side of Palestine.
A tree was blown down near the Golden community.

A slow-moving high precipitation supercell produced copious amounts of damaging hail across northern Swisher County with some hailstones as large as baseball size in Happy.  A 12-mile stretch of Interstate 27 from Happy to north of Tulia was covered in hail up to six inches deep.  In addition to damaging roofs of homes and businesses, intense straight line winds in the rear flank downdraft of the supercell carried hail sideways which shattered many north and west facing windows.  Countless vehicles along Interstate 27 suffered broken windows and significant hail dents.  It is estimated that 500 acres of winter wheat were flattened by this barrage of hail, wind and torrential rains with 40 percent of the winter wheat crop suffering lesser degrees of damage.  Preliminary combined monetary losses are estimated at $4M.
Two trees blown down.
The roof of a barn was torn off and a large tree was uprooted. Several structures also suffered minor damage.
Trees and signs were blown down by high winds.
Roof damage.
Occurred in Forreston.

NWS damage survey information found that a tornado touchdown first occurred about 11 miles SSW of Spearman at 0336 pm CDT and lifted at 0349 pm CDT approximately 8 miles SSW of Spearman. The tornado crossed the Hansford County line around 342 pm CDT.  The tornado was rated EF-unknown, with track and times based on eyewitness accounts and video.
A thunderstorm produced 3.5 inch hail near N. Foster Rd. and I-10 in eastern San Antonio.
Nickel size hail was reported 2 miles southwest of Hewitt.
A thunderstorm moved across Brewster County and produced a 60 mph wind gust five miles south of Marathon.
A wind gust of 51 knots was measured at the Houston Dunn AWOS station.
Quarter sized hail was reported.

Law enforcement sighted a funnel cloud near the intersection of Grand Parkway Highway 99 and Mason Road. This was likely associated with the circulation that produced the EF0 tornado just a few minutes earlier to the west of this location.
Trees and powerlines were downed in the town of Gladewater.  One tree fell on top of a brick home.  There were no report of any injuries.
Nickel size hail fell in the Carroll community.
A storm chaser observed hen egg size hail between Silverton and Quitaque. No damage was reported.
Emergency management reported 2 inch diameter hail in the Smith's Bend area of Bosque County.
A severe storm near Paducah produced severe wind gusts that ripped an aluminum roof off of a structure and downed power lines and large trees. No injuries were reported.
Several tree limbs were downed.
Numerous trees were downed near the intersection of F.M. 1971 and F.M. 999. southwest of Carthage, Texas.
A large tree was blown down by severe thunderstorm winds just west of Monahans.
Trees downed throughout the county...including one on a home in town.
A large tree was blown down along Rieck Road in South Tyler.
Ping pong ball size hail was reported by the National Park Service 15 miles south of the intersection of Highways 180 and 54 in western Culberson County.
