An electrical transmission line was reported blown down by the high winds causing two hundred and seventy-two homes in the town of Channing to be without power.
An off duty police officer reported 75 to 80 mph winds in Roscoe.

Multiple reports of large hail up to the size of golfballs, and occasionally larger, were received from local law enforcement officials northeast of Dickens shortly after 19:00 CST. This occurred as a newly developed supercell thunderstorm impacted central Dickens County.
Hail fell along Hwy. 271 northwest of town.
Lightning struck a church in Little Elm and caused a fire in the attic. The attic was damaged and the interior of the building sustained water damage.
A mobile spotter measured an 88 MPH wind gust in Hillsboro.
A thunderstorm produced two inch diameter hail in Kirtley. We received a picture of the hail on Facebook.

The emergency manager in Floydada reported widespread minor flooding in the city of Floydada. Several city streets had become impassable. The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site near Floydada reported over two inches of rainfall in less than two hours.
A social media report indicated penny-sized hail in the city of Hurst, TX.

A discrete thunderstorm moved northward across Hutchinson County during the evening hours of the 8th. A trained storm spotter reported golf ball (1.75 inches) size hail as the thunderstorm moved north of the city of Fritch (Hutchinson County). The thunderstorm continued to move to the north before merging with a line of thunderstorms moving eastward across the Texas Panhandle.
Some power poles were knocked down due to the strong thunderstorm winds.
Amateur radio spotters as well as an off duty NWS employee observed a tornado over the upper end of E.V. Spence Reservoir. The tornado was observed for about six minutes.
Wind gust was observed at the College Station ASOS site (KCLL).
Nickel to quarter size hail was reported in Skellytown.
Large limbs and a few trees were downed.  Dime sized hail was also reported.
Golf ball size hail covering I-10 at mile marker 221.

Law enforcement in Turkey reported several power lines downed by high winds as well as a portion of a roof blown off of a house. Several minutes later, the Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet station observed a wind gust to 60 mph.
Train was blown over with possible 80 to 90 mph wind gust. Also, there was a tree snapped in half and laying across roadway.

An EF-0 tornado touched down just west of Henry Prairie Rd south of Franklin and moved northeast across FM 46 and McNutt Road before lifting near Old Hickory Grove Road. Several trees and large tree limbs were blown down along the path, with minor damage to a few homes and outbuildings. Max winds were estimated at 80 mph.
A storm chaser reported two inch size hail near the intersection of Farm to Market Roads 213 and 435 southeast of Plains. No damage was reported.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts measured at 50 kts by a CoCoRaHS observer along Canyon Lake.
Storm spotters reported golfball size hail.
Trees downed near Scroggins.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that damaged a barn roof, front porch awning, and knocked down a 100 year old tree.
Penny sized hail was observed on County Road 428 just south of Wharton.
A trained spotter reported penny size hail in the town of Rosanky.
Numerous trees were reported down across the county.  The worst tree damage was in a straight line from Maydelle to FM 241 where several roads were closed due to the downed trees.

A downburst caused scattered tree damage in the Shiloh area of Limestone County. Several large tree branches were knocked down and some large trees were broken across the trunk. One metal barn was destroyed. Winds were estimated at 70-75 mph.
Amateur radio relayed report of measured half dollar hail in Little Elm.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Abernathy measured severe wind gusts from 1743 CST through 1746 CST. A peak wind gust of 66 mph was measured at 1743 CST.
Quarter size hail fell on the north side of Waskom.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Hart measured a wind gust to 59 mph.
Nickel sized hail was reported near the intersection of FM 4 and FM129.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts measured at 55 kts. by the ASOS at Randolph AFB (KRND).
Three barns were destroyed.

This tornado, rated F1,  touched down 1 mile southeast of Manor shortly after 7 am, and moved northeastward to 5 miles northeast of Manor before dissipating.  Rated as an F1, it damaged nearly a dozen homes and mobile homes and two businesses.  It destroyed four mobile homes and overturned several vehicles as well.   A young woman suffered a shoulder separation injury as the tornado blew over her mobile home.
Nickel sized hail was covering the ground in Weatherford.
A thunderstorm produced pea to quarter size hail in the Sherwood Forest Faire campground northwest of Paige.
A member of the public reported multiple broken tree limbs on FM 677 just south of the Red River.
A local official estimated golfball size hail eight miles north of Mackenzie Reservoir. No damage was reported.
Dispatch for Sheriff's office reported quarter size hail near the Brown County line on CR210.
Amateur radio operator relayed report if nickel size hail in Bremond.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail southwest of Liberty Hill.
Report from mPING: Quarter (1.00 in.).
High winds moved a large water tank with 100 gallons of water in it about a quarter of a mile, destroying the tank. These same winds also blew 3 metal doors off a barn.
Multiple trees were blown down on Highway 315 several miles northeast of Mount Enterprise.
Hail up to the size of quarters was reported 2 miles east of Wylie. Most of the hail was pea to penny sized with a few nickel and quarter sized hailstones.
Half dollar size hail was reported on South Kiowa Street near Highway 60 in Miami.
Several trees were knocked down by thunderstorm winds by a storm that tracked just north of Palestine.
A trained spotter reported quarter size hail at the intersection of I-20 and State Highway 70.
Local fire department officials reported wind-blown nickel size hail in Afton. No damages were reported.
A public report indicated quarter sized hail about 4 miles west of Elkhart, TX.
A sheriff deputy reported a tornado along Highway 190 near Holly Springs moving northeast. An NWS Storm Survey found no damage.
Large limbs were knocked out of trees and large trees were blown down by severe thunderstorm winds in a path that stretched from near Leander to Cedar Park.
Viewed on Houston Metro traffic cameras.

Member of the public shared a picture of large palm tress down across the westbound lane of Coffee Road, near Casa de Oro. Several pieces of private fencing were knocked down as a result of the downed palm trees. Timing based on radar.
Hail up to the size of quarters fell at Mayhill Road and I-35E in southeast Denton.
Hail up to golfball size severely damaged an estimated 30,000 acres of cotton.
Severe thunderstorm winds tore down a building's veneer wall near the intersection of Texas Avenue and University.
Hail was observed near the Red River.
Several trees were blown down across Marshall. One tree had fallen down on the 300 block of Merrill Street.
Lightning struck a 200 barrel oil storage tank on North Swift Street creating a large oil fire. Multiple emergency vehicles were required to contain the fire.
Public reported half dollar hail fell around 1.4 miles ESE of Belton via mPING.
A roof and tree were damaged.
A thunderstorm produced hail up to half dollar size east of Lake Victor.
Several trees were downed across the northern portion of the county. Trees were reported down north of Hwy 67 as well as County Road 4025.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Slaton measured a wind gust to 60 mph.
Quarter size hail reported near Lake Brenda.
Large power poles were reported down on U.S. Highway 62 about 12 miles north of Childress.
Trees and power lines were blown down in Kilgore.
The rope like funnel cloud was spotted at the intersection of East Mount Houston and Homestead Roads.

A National Weather Service damage survey crew found evidence of a tornado east of the city of Rio Vista. This tornado occurred mainly over open fields, causing several areas of tree damage. However, one well built home had a large portion of a roof missing.
Three persons injured by baseball size hail.

Widespread damaging straight-line winds occurred across much of Wise County during the predawn hours of March 4th, 2025. Within this broad wind field, a NWS WFO Fort Worth survey team identified a relatively short track tornado north of the Cottondale community. This tornado formed near the intersection of FM 2123 and FM 3552, where a wood frame residence lost much of its roof and internal rafters. The peak intensity of the tornado was determined from the damage at this residence, with EF-1 intensity winds estimated around 110 mph. The tornado impacted two outbuildings nearby, producing EF-0 roof damage. The tornado moved eastward, roughly paralleling County Road 3470 for at least two miles. Along this path, many larger hardwood trees exhibited limb damage, and a few outbuildings, frame residences, and manufactured homes also exhibited mostly high end EF-0 and low end EF-1 roof and fascia damage. The tornado dissipated near the intersection of County Road 3470 and School House Road.
Right around 1730 CST two reports were made for 1 hail around northeast Amarillo. One of which was an official NWS observation at WFO AMA.
A public report indicated nickel to quarter sized hail approximately 2 miles east of the city of Denton, TX.
Quarter size hail was reported in Bellmead.
Large trees down all over Charco. Reported by Goliad County EMC.

Thunderstorms formed along a dryline stretching east-northeastward across Randall and Potter Counties during the afternoon hours of the 28th. These thunderstorms would take a northeast track which allowed them to move over the dryline. This caused the thunderstorms to produce isolated downbursts across the city. The KVII Schoolnet site at Highland Park High School reported a 58 mph gust while a thunderstorm was overhead. The thunderstorm decayed quickly after moving to the dry side of the dryline due to ingesting much drier air into the updrafts.  No damage or injuries were associated with this gust.
An off-duty NWS meteorologist reported quarter to golfball size hail.
Quarter size hail was reported 5 miles northwest of Amarillo.

A narrow tornado was videoed in a field for 2-3 minutes. The exact location is unknown but is close to the plotted track. This tornado was the first of 4 brief tornadoes a parent supercell produced as it moved across Falls and Limestone counties.
Willacy County EM reported golf ball size hail in Port Mansfield.
Several roofs and skylights were damaged by the large hail and some windows were broken.
A trained spotter reported two-inch diameter hail approximately 2 miles southeast of the city of Rockdale, TX.
Hail reported at intersection of Highway 290 and Beltway 8.

Numerous reports were received of a swath of hail from approximately three miles south of Muleshoe to the Parmer County line along Texas State Highway 214. The hail ranged in size from golf ball to tennis ball size. The hail swath continued into Parmer County. No damage was reported.

Both a storm chaser and an off duty NWS employee observed a weak tornado in Dickens County south of McAdoo, just south of US Highway 82 / Texas Highway 114. The tornado remained over open land and did not cause any known damage.
Measured by a KVII-TV schoolnet anemometer at the Lazbuddie High School.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet near Aiken.

Metal roofs were torn off of 3 buildings at the UNT's Rafes Urban Astronomy Center. The ASOS at the airport next to the property measured 74 mph winds. The rain inside the exposed buildings caused hundreds of thousands of dollars in water damage to several telescopes.
A trailer was overturned due to a high wind gust at the South Texas State Fair at Ford Park.
Multiple trees were downed.
A trained spotter reported nickel sized hail near the intersection of FM 2838 and Highway 84 approximately 5 miles west of the city of Mexia, TX.

Severe thunderstorm winds resulted in several roofs being blown off of businesses in Monahans, including the Boys and Girls Club. In addition, a new radio antenna tower which was installed by the city just nine months prior to the storm was blown down and destroyed.

An EF1 tornado touched down on the southeast side of the city of Alice just south of the intersection of Highway 359 and Stadium Road. The tornado traveled 2.3 miles and lifted just north of the intersection of County Road 1352 and County Road 382. This tornado produced shingle damage to the roof tops of several homes, lifted the roof deck off of several homes, and snapped a dozen power poles at their mid-point. The tornado destroyed a metal building and a portable building, broke overhead doors, blew out the siding of several metal buildings, and downed numerous trees.
A public report indicated that the top part of a cedar tree was blown down by thunderstorm winds. Two other large cedar trees were also knocked down. A shed was lifted and moved 20 feet.
Five to 6 power poles blown over onto FM Road 1573 seven miles east of HWY 287.
The wind gust was measured at the Hereford West Texas Mesonet site located two miles northwest of Hereford.

Local law enforcement officials reported baseball size hail along Texas Highway 256 south of the Antelope Flat community. This giant hail was produced by the cyclonic right-moving member of a supercell storm split.
A trained spotter relayed a report of nickel to quarter size hail along State Highway 158 just west of Lake E.V. Spence.
Reported near County Road 7 and Farm to Market Road 2018.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that knocked down some three inch diameter tree limbs near Hollyhock Rd. and Whisper Point in northwestern San Antonio.
Several trees were blown down in the Huntington area.
Strong thunderstorm wind gusts overturned a travel trailer injuring one person inside.

Hawley PD and U.S. Post Office reported widespread broken treel limbs and two Mesquite trees toppled over on FM 1082.  Also, two trampolines were blown away.  The winds blew very strong from 3 to 315 PM CDT.
Hail was reported on FM 1431 4 miles east of I35.

NWS storm survey concluded tornado touched down in Long Mott and crossed Highway 185.  Tornado damaged a home and adjacent barn as well as uprooted several large trees.  Eleven power poles along Highway 185 were downed.  An ultra-light aircraft also sustained damage.
Pea to quarter size hail covering the ground with heavy rain for 20 minutes south-southeast of Texline.
Severe thunderstorms downed power lines in Crockett and also downed trees throughout the county.

A large swath of hail began near New Moore near the intersection of Farm to Market Roads 213 and 179. The hail tracked to the east-northeast across Lynn County crossing US Highway 87 ending to the northeast of the intersection of Farm to Market Roads 3332 and 2956. The size of the hail varied from golf ball size near New Moore to tennis ball size east of US Highway 87. Extensive damage was also reported the next day from this hail storm including damage to vehicles and farm equipment. It was also reported that 302 birds were killed by the hail.
The hail was reported to be golf ball size to hen egg size.
A thunderstorm produced wind damage four miles east northeast of Wink. There were powerlines down on Highway 18. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
A light pole was blown down on Carlisle Court.
An off-duty National Weather Service employee reported the hail.

The strongest of the Friday night tornadoes struck the town of Stonewall.  This tornado, rated F3 on the Fujita Scale, was preceded by brief gusty winds of 30 to 40 miles per hour, very heavy rainfall and spotty .5-inch hail.  The tornado formed around 830 pm CST near the intersection of Hahn Road and SH290.  It moved north-northeastward for .75 miles, crossing SH290 and the Pedernales River.  Just north of the river, it made a slight turn toward the east, now moving another mile toward the northeast.  It crossed North River Road and continued over open country until it crossed Ranch Road 1623.  After passing RR1623 for approximately .25 miles, it dissipated.  The worst damage, F3 level, was to trees and homes between RR1623 and SH290, across the northwest and north central part of Stonewall.  Ninety homes sustained damage with 6 destroyed.  In addition, 7 mobile homes were destroyed and 20 damaged.  Damage was also reported to 22 buildings.  A two-story home had the entire second story destroyed, and a concrete building lost most of its walls and all of its roof.  Other damage along the path typically included destroyed and damaged roofs and walls of homes and businesses as well as widespread damage to trees.  The tornado path was approximately .25 miles in width and 2.5 miles in length.  Although the tornado was not seen due to the late hour and darkness, residents did report that after heavy rain and hail, the wind became calm, and it was followed by a "roaring sound" so often reported in tornadoes.  Five persons were injured with one man hospitalized as a result of the tornado.

The Paris AWOS measured sustained winds of 43 kts with gusts up to 58 kts due to a heatburst caused by dissipating storms. The temperature at Paris rose 11 degrees in one hour while the dewpoint dropped 18 degrees. Trees were snapped and knocked down in town, the power was knocked out, and a barn was blown across a road.
The 911 Call Center reported hail lasted for 11 minutes.
Several trees were downed and damage occurred to a storage building on J Meyer Road.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Morton measured a peak wind gust of 77 mph at 2145 CST. Severe winds were observed from 2145 through 2150 CST.
Video of a brief tornado near Mertens that appeared to be over a field. No damage was reported, and this tornado was rated EF-Unknown.

Deputies from the Maverick County Sheriff's Department observed a small and short-lived tornado as it touched down very briefly in open country north of Eagle Pass.  The tornado was reported to be moving toward the east at nearly 45 mph.  It was rated F0 on the Fujita Scale.
A large tree was blown down.
NWS employee reported 1.25 inch hail on HWY 180 just west of Palo Pinto.
The Levelland Police Department reported golf ball size hail in Witharral. No damage was reported.
Several trees were uprooted in the Vidor area.
A tree was blown onto a power line on County Road 967 in Cushing.
Half dollar size hail fell 8 miles north-northeast of Claude.
A reporter observed penny sized hail in north Dallas on Preston Road, one half mile south of the Collin County line.
An amateur radio operator reported penny size hail on the southwest part of Loop 335 or Hollywood Road at Soncy Road.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail near Talley Rd. and Culebra Rd. in western Bexar County.
The automated weather station at Waco's Madison Cooper Airport (KACT) measured a 63 MPH wind gust. This wind gust occurred from nearby light rain helping to drag strong winds aloft to the ground.
There was a lightning strike that caused a fire in a home at the 1700 block of Trail of the Woods near the shore of Lake Travis.  No injuries were reported.

Several reports were received from local emergency officials, the media, and the public of thunderstorm wind gusts between 60 and 65 MPH in the immediate Lubbock vicinity. An anemometer recorded a 65 MPH gust at a local television station at 18:02 CST. Reported damage was relatively light and included several downed trees and utility poles. One lightweight tin structure also was damaged. About 200 Lubbock residents lost power as a result of the downed power poles and lines.

The thunderstorm wind gust or microburst was estimated to be seventy to seventy-eight knots which resulted in damage to outbuildings, carports, fences, an overhead garage door, and construction framing. There were no reports of injuries or fatalities.
Report relayed by a broadcast media storm chaser.
Several trees were downed and mobile home covers were damaged along CR 317 just south of FM 16. Fences and telephone poles were also snapped.
Measured by the Texas Tech West Texas Mesonet.
Hail fell at the intersection of South Broadway and 5th Street totally covering the ground.
Ping pong ball size hail at the HEB grocery store.
Severe thunderstorm winds downed some trees in the Weimar area.

Skywarn storm spotters reported that heavy rainfall which accompanied a severe thunderstorm resulted in minor flooding in some Lubbock city streets.  By 19:30 CST, 2.31 inches had been measured by the Automated Surface Observing System at Lubbock's Preston Smith International Airport.  The Lubbock Police Department reported that vehicles stalled in ponding water along portions of the Buddy Holly Avenue and Marsha Sharp Freeway underpass, and along Slide Road and Fourth Street.  No injuries or major damages were reported.
A public report indicated dime sized hail in the city of Sulphur Springs, TX.
A roof was damaged by high winds.

A broken line of thunderstorms moved across the southern Texas Panhandle during the evening hours of the 27th. As this line approached the city of Alanreed (Gray County), a member of the public reported that a thunderstorm wind gust blew a tree down onto the Interstate 40 on ramp. This tree blocked the one ramp for several hours before it could be removed. This line continued to move eastward across the southern Texas Panhandle after producing this damage.
There was quarter size hail reported in Frisco.
Social media report received of a large tree blown down southeast of Orange Grove.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Roaring Springs measured severe wind gusts from 1844 CST through 1856 CST. A peak wind gust of 65 mph was measured at 1858 CST.
Land spout captured on video and relayed by a storm chaser. Started at 5:38pm and lifted at 5:41 pm.
Amateur radio reported one-inch diameter hail approximately 6 miles north of Weatherford, TX.

A microburst damaged part of the southern portions of the city of Greenville. Several businesses and residential structures sustained roof damage. The roof of a Braum's was heavily damaged, and the roof at an automobile service station on Business 67 was partially blown off. In addition, the garage door at the service station at the Enterprise Rent-A-Car was blown in and a gash was torn into the wall. Several large trees were blown down, a gas station sign was blown down, and a sign at Crossroads Mall fell on a car. Three power poles were snapped on Sayle Street causing a black out in the area. Maximum wind gusts were estimated to be 65 mph. One person sustained minor injuries, and was treated and released from the medical center.
Trees blown down in North Zulch and in Normangee, reported by Sheriff.
Mineral Wells Automated Surface Observation System reported a wind gust of 59 MPH.
The AWOS at KT65 reported 1.74 inches of rain fell in 2 hours, with 0.97 inches falling in 1 hour.
A thunderstorm produced nickel size hail that dented a car east of Barksdale.
The public reported a steel frame structure and porta potties knocked down at the intersection of FM 380 and North 4th Road near Mereta.
Quarter to golfball sized hail fell in Grapevine.
MPing report.
A thunderstorm produced baseball size hail in Uhland.
NBC broadcast media relayed public report of golf ball size hail.
A trained spotter reported quarter size hail. No damage was reported.
Sheriff's office reported trees down.
Ping pong to golf ball-sized hail was observed in Alpine.
A spotter north of Garden City reported that a storage shed was knocked down and a golf cart was tipped over by thunderstorm winds.
A trained spotter reported hail accompanied by wind gusts to near 50 mph.
Law enforcement reported several trees blown down, power lines down, and several carports turned over.
The time was estimated from radar.
Winds snapped or uprooted trees near Los Angeles.
Reported via mping.
Texas Tech University researchers measured a wind gust to 78 mph associated with a gustnado along a leading edge of a squall line near Reese Center.
Two to three foot diameter trees were uprooted in Corinth and shingles were blown off roofs.
Pea to penny size hail fell in Wellington with wind gusts estimated to be 50 mph.

A pair of nearly stationary supercell storms inflicted heavy tolls on thousands of residents across South Lubbock.  The largest hail from tennis ball to just over baseball size occurred along a swath from near Quaker Avenue and 130th Street to Slide Avenue and 122nd Street.  On both sides of this line and extending outwards for a few miles, hail from quarter size to golf ball size was common.  With very little storm movement, large hail fell for up to 15 minutes at some locations causing even greater damage.  In Lubbock's Vintage Township alone, it was estimated that every home would require a new roof.  Preliminary insurance data indicated approximately 4000 auto claims were filed, with an estimated 1200 homes potentially in need of new roofs.  Many area auto body shops were required to work overtime to meet the onslaught of customers.  Fortunately, very little wind accompanied the hail which prevented even greater damage to the siding and windows of most homes and buildings.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail in Georgetown.
Quarter sized hail was reported near the intersection of Highway 6 and FM 529.
Emergency management reported power poles down and minor roof damage in the towns of Rice and Frost.
The public reported half dollar size hail.
Ham radio operator reported quarter sized hail at the Laredo International Airport.
Large tree limbs were blown down.

Mostly golfball size hail was observed, but a few hailstones just under the size of grapefruits were observed and shown to the NWS storm survey team the following day.  Windows were broken out of a few homes by the hail.  There was also damage to some vehicles.  The NWS survey team also found damage to small vegetation caused from the hail.|
Harlingen ASOS reported a 58 mph wind gust.

The public reported thunderstorm wind gusts estimated to be in excess of 60 mph in Lockney at 20:20 CST, where the winds contributed to power outages.  A street light was blown down onto power lines along U.S. Highway 70 in Muncey.  At 20:25 CST a Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site near Floydada measured a 63 mph thunderstorm wind gust.
Numerous trees were down just north of Star.
Three-quarter inch hail was reported at I-10 and Acala Rd.
An Automated Weather Observing System at the Denver City Airport measured a wind gust of 60 mph.
Trucks were reported blown off the roadway and there was extensive damage to a home west of Panhandle when a large tree fell on the home.
Half Dollar size hail fell in the city of Desoto.
Ping pong ball size hail was reported via social media two miles northwest of Cockrell Hill.
Wooden billboard measuring 20' by 30' blown down.
A tree with the diameter of two feet was snapped by the wind at a home in the Clareville subdivision.
An air traffic controller at Grayson County Airport stated the airport had measured a wind gust of 75 mph.

Ground survey and radar analysis indicated straight-line winds along a bowing segment caused a long swath of 75-85 mph winds across southeastern Van Zandt County. In this area, trees were damaged, metal structures/barns were damaged or destroyed, & the roofs of some homes were damaged. The damage swath was approximately 1.75-2.5 miles wide across the center line of this entry.
Guinn Hall at TWU in Denton gusted 83 mph. Trees were also reported down around downtown Denton.
Numerous trees downed in the Linden area.
KAVU-TV reported strong downburst winds produced roof damage to an apartment complex on the north side of Victoria. Some trees were also blown down.
Power lines blown down.
A large tree was blown down near the intersection of Farm to Market Road 2049 and County Road 243 north of the community of Ray Point.
A public report indicated nickel-sized hail in the city of Sherman, TX.
Mercedes Police Department reported 10 to 12 power lines down and 15 to 20 trees down across the city of Mercedes.
Amateur radio reported golf ball sized hail 10 miles southeast of Troy, TX.
Large branches were blown down along Phillip Springs Road.
Penny hail was reported approximately 9 miles northeast of Kaufman.
A tree was downed near the intersection of CR 128 and FM 976.
Dime to quarter sized hail with heavy rain was reported in Evant.
Amateur radio operators reported the hail grew to the size of quarters near the community of Tom Bean.
Quarter size hail fell on Highway 70 10 miles north of Clarendon.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts measured by the Del Rio International Airport ASOS at 63 mph that damaged the National Weather Service upper air facility.
The Ballinger Fire Department reported golf ball size hail in Ballinger.
Amateur radio reported quarter-sized hail in the city of Leroy, TX.
The Jasper County Sheriff's Office reported multiple trees down along Highway 150 near Steinhagen Lake.
Amateur radio reported that trees approximately 24 inches in diameter were blown over near Chambers Cemetery on County Road 153.
The Childress County Sheriff's Office reported golfball size hail along U.S. Highway 287 just west of Kirkland.
Emergency manager relayed a photo of quarter to half dollar sized hail.
A social media report indicated 2-inch diameter hail in the town of Decatur.
A tree was downed blocking County Road 177.
Penny to dime sized hail was reported just north of the Galleria in far north Dallas.
Trees and power lines down across the county.
Law enforcement and multiple spotters reported five power poles were downed by a brief EF0 landspout tornado.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that knocked down a large tree limb in Kyle.
Reported on Grand Street.
Hail fell in the Pleasant Grove Community.
Public reported penny sized hail occurred in Encinal.
Penny size hail was observed near the intersection of FM 2296 and Highway 75N.
Winds of 65 mph were measured by a CoCoRaHS observer located 3.4 miles northwest of Kerens.
A large tree was split in half by high winds.
A spotter reported penny size hail fell for approximately 3 or 4 minutes east of San Perlita near the intersection of FM 3142 and Highway 186.

A small tornado was spotted by a member of the Austin Police Department 3 miles east of San Marcos.  The tornado was on the ground around five minutes as it moved northeastward to near the Caldwell County lin e before dissipating.  No damage was reported.
Trees down and power outages reported west of Retreat.

A National Weather Service damage survey team found evidence of brief tornado approximately four miles northeast of the city of Lampasas. The tornado damage several trees, and removed a large part of a roof of the only house the tornado impacted.
The public estimated 50 to 60 mph winds.
Numerous large trees were uprooted or destroyed in Reno. Clean up efforts took 3 days to complete.
Public reported half dollar size hail in Chandler.
Delayed report. Time estimated from radar. No damage reported.

Between 3 and 7 inches of rain fell across the southern Coastal Bend of South Texas over a two period.  This rainfall was associated with rain bands from Hurricane Dolly.  Unfortunately, the primary impact from the rainfall was to cotton and sorghum crops across the region.  Much of the cotton crop was waiting to be harvested, and the rainfall either severaly damaged or destoyed it.  At the time of this writing, estimates on agriculture losses were very rough and final figures were still pending.||A record rainfall was set on the 23rd at the Corpus Christi International Airport with 2.86.  On the 24th, another record rainfall was set for the date when 2.61 fell.
Ham radio operator reported golf ball sized hail near Papalote.
An amateur radio report estimated thunderstorm wind gusts of 65 MPH in the city the Tigertown, TX.
Ping pong ball size hail fell in the Laird Hill community.
The Mineral Wells Airport (KMWL) ASOS measured a 58 mph wind gust.
A thunderstorm moved through the Uvalde area and produced nickel size hail.
Wind gust occurred at the SH 75 S Tempest weather system site.

Tornado touched down on the south side of College Station and tracked to the southeast near Greens Prairie Road and Highway 6. Storm spotters also observed this tornado that caused very little damage.
Public report of pea to ping pong ball size hail between Grandfalls and Crane. Time and location are estimated from radar.
Numerous trees were downed in the towns of Onalaska and Livingston, with a roof blown off of a home in Livingston.
Quarter size hail reported in the Maydelle community.
Report of a tool shed destroyed and tree branches knocked down.

Firefighters responded to a house fire caused by a lightning strike. The fire initially began in the attic, but the heat and smoke forced the firefighters back. The 4,000 square foot home was built in 2002.
A social media report indicated hen-egg size hail in the city of Allen, TX.
Numerous trees and powerlines were downed across Shelby County.
A trained spotter reported hail from golf ball to tennis ball sized west of Comanche.

A brief tornado touched down in rural southeast Moore County just south of Highway 152. Tree damage was observed in a narrow path and included numerous broken limbs and one tree which was uprooted. This was consistent with EF-0 damage on the Fujita Tornado Damage Scale.
KHOU ASOS station recorded a 61 mph wind gust.

A 67 mph wind gust was reported at KOSA CBS 7 Studios in Odessa. Fifteen utility poles were downed by these winds as well as a section of concrete block wall at a warehouse in Odessa.  In addition, an estimated 90 mph wind gust was reported in Odessa.
A wind gust of 60 mph was reported.
The ASOS in Harlingen measured a wind gust of 70 mph.
Lightning struck a home along Highway 79 East, starting a fire in the attic.

This severe thunderstorm produced widespread wind damage in and around the Huntsville area.  Numerous trees were downed throughout the city, and a light pole was blown down on a new truck.  There was also some roof damage to a bank in the middle of the city.  A student at a local university was injured by a falling tree limb.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that downed several trees causing widespread power outages in Fredericksburg.
Nickel sized hail was reported near Bryan.

A thunderstorm produced wind gusts measured at 70 mph that knocked over some trees in San Marcos.  The City of San Marcos Office of Emergency Management reports near 750 thousand dollars in damages to public facilities, infrastructure, broadband tower repairs, and debris removal.
Amateur radio reported baseball sized hail in Wylie.
Reported on Highway 185.
Strong thunderstorm winds blew down power lines, power poles, and trees.
Numerous trees and powerlines were downed throughout the county.
The report was from mping.
A Sheriff Deputy reported quarter size hail in Channing.
Strong winds downed a power pole on Haskell Street in Wellington.
Penny sized hail fell in I-20 near mile marker 209.
Nickel-size hail.
Mostly dime to nickel with a few quarter size hailstones fell 1 mile south-southwest of Wellington. The time of the report was estimated from radar data.
Tennis ball sized hail was reported by amateur radio near Highway 287 in New Fairview, TX.
Golfball sized hail fell in Trophy Club and Roanoke.
Penny to quarter sized hail was observed between Cypress and Tomball.
A large tree was uprooted in Shelbyville.
Trees were blown down by high winds.
A public report stated that a roof was blown off of a house at the 700 block of Our lane.

A large tree was blown down on the road near the Edinburg/McAllen line 5 miles southwest of Edinburg. Large branches were also blown down nearby.  Peak wind gusts at McAllen/Miller International Airport reached 41 mph (36 knots) but reached 52 mph (45 knots) at South Texas International Airport (about 11 miles north of Edinburg) during the same time period.
Tennis ball size hail fell 5 miles east-southeast of Panhandle.
The Hart Fire Department estimated hail of 1.25 inches in diameter.  Damage was not reported.
Hail up to golf ball size was reported to cover the ground near the WalMart in Pampa.
Heavy wind damage was reported to a local Sconic Drive-In and to the Tefteller Law Office.
Public reported shingles blown off roofs.
An amateur radio operator estimated a thunderstorm wind gust of 71 mph about a mile northeast of San Angelo.
Hail up to the size of golf balls was reported in Dalhart.
Baseball size hail was reported about 1 mile north of the city of Windom.
Trained spotter reported via social media pictures of paneling removed from a gas station awning, and scattered trees that were snapped. A glass window of a business was shattered.
Downed trees were reported in the 3000 block of Old Hearne Road.
Hail was reported via MPING near College Station.
A brief tornado was seen by the public with no damage reported.
Quarter sized hail was reported 5 miles north of St Jo.
There were windows broken in Boerne.
Estimated severe wind gust.
Skywarn storm spotters reported nickel size hail just north of Post.
A weathernet station recorded a wind gust of 83 mph at the Sabine Pass School.
Trained spotters reported golf ball sized hail in Pottsville.
Baseball sized hail was reported just south of Runaway Bay.
Golf ball size hail was reported in Eustace.
A roof collapsed onto a mobile home.
A large tree was blown down on Highway 259 between Henderson and Kilgore.
A thunderstorm produced baseball sized hail in Coyanosa. The hail resulted in broken windshields. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
A thunderstorm moved across Pecos County and produced a 64 mph wind gust at the Fort Stockton ASOS site.
Telephone poles were reported broken along with metal twisted and tree limbs down.

A trained spotter reported a few utility poles were blown down in addition to a fence post being snapped.  A field of grass and sunflowers were also bent in an east to northeast direction which was in line with storm motion. The time of damage was estimated from radar.
A tornado destroyed a barn on the west side of town.
A thunderstorm produced hail for 20 minutes. The largest was tennis ball size and was mostly penny to nickel size. The hail cracked a window.
The Millsap Fire Department reported damage to one structure just north of town.
A father and his son were struck by lightning walking home from the bus stop. The father died the same day but the son died weeks later, in June.
Amateur radio reported that hail from ping pong ball to hen egg sized fell for 8 minutes near the intersection of Malone Street and Main Street in Allen, TX.
Trained spotters from the Chevron-Warren Petroleum Plant estimated 60 mph winds. No damage was reported.

Estimated gusts were reported by a National Weather Service employee.  Widespread minor wind damage was reported in Brownsville, Harlingen and Los Fresnos due to strong outflow winds produced by thunderstorms in the area.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet.
Golf ball size hail was reported in Canyon.
The West Texas Mesonet near Mertzon measured a 64 knot wind gust.
Video from local media Facebook page showed a brief tornado touched down in an open field.
Amateur radio reported penny sized hail on the northern side of Cleburne State Park, approximately 5 miles southwest of the city of Bono, TX.
Pecos County Emergency Manager reports ping pong ball size hail and heavy rain north of Fort Stockton on Highway 18. Time is estimated from radar.
A tree was blown down on to FM 1943 near Warren.
5 MILES SE OF CHARCO.

A thunderstorm produced wind damage in Garden City as well as across portions of Glasscock County. This damage included multiple downed power poles, uprooted trees, shingles and roof damage, and numerous cases of wind-driven hail damage. Given that damage was all found oriented in a similar direction across the surveyed area, the damage was determined to be caused by strong downdraft winds. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
A KVII-TV school net site in Sunnyside measured a wind gust to 67 mph.
Trained spotters reported golf ball sized hail moving closer to Weatherford.
Report from MPing.
Tree limbs downed.

Tornado touched down near Trailer World RV and Boat Storage facility then crossed Interstate 10. It did minor damage to Bucees car wash area then ripped large air conditioning units off top of Pepperl-Fuchs building. Finally in damaged awnings near Builders First building before lifting. Tornado crossed from Fort Bend into Waller County. This entry documents Waller County segment.
A public report indicated quarter sized hail just north of Lavon, TX.
Lemon, to near baseball-size hail, reported by the general public from just northeast of Spring into the southwestern area of The Woodlands.
Amateur radio reported 1 inch hail in Flower Mound.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site in Smyer measured a severe wind gust of 69 mph.
A picture of golf ball size hail that fell in the Sterrett Hill community was posted to social media.
Texas Department of Public Safety reported trees were blown down in Benavides.
Large hail up to the size of golfballs stripped trees along a swath northeast of Gail near Four Mile Lane and Farm to Market Road 612.
A 70 MPH wind gust was reported southeast of Kosse.
A 70 MPH wind gust was measured by the Automated Weather Observation Station at the Joint Reserve Base in northwest Fort Worth.
The Fort Chadbourne Mesonet recorded a wind gust to 68 mph.

Thunderstorms developed over Amarillo shortly before 7:30 PM CST. These thunderstorms lasted for a half hour and produced brief heavy rain. A total of 0.52 inches of precipitation was reported in southwest Amarillo (Randall County) by a member of the public.
The duration of the funnel cloud was estimated.
Highway signs with tip overs designed for 60 mph blown over as well as power lines and power poles blown down.
Two inch hail was reported 1 mile east of Holder.

Rain, heavy at times during the daylight hours of the 16th, accumulated between 1 1/2 and 2 1/2 inches between 6 AM and 6 PM in a pocket of central Cameron County along and near Highway 77, between Brownsville and Harlingen. The rainfall caused areas of nuisance (minor) flooding of poor drainage roadways in the area during the daylight hours of the 16th, slowing traffic.  Event totals in Cameron County included 4.52 inches in Rancho Viejo, 3.82 inches near Brownsville, and 3.79 inches just west of Harlingen.
Seventy mph winds were estimated on the west side of Runaway Bay.

A cluster of thunderstorms moved into the Texas Panhandle during the early afternoon hours of the 14th. As storms neared the town of Dalhart (Dallam and Hartley County), the Dalhart ASOS reported a 58 MPH downburst. After producing this downburst the cluster of storms continued moving southward across the Panhandle.
Dime sized hail occurred at Artesia Wells.
There was some roof damage to a Texas City business.
Emergency management reported power poles blown down between Bells and Whitewright, TX.
The public reported a carport was blown off of a residence north of San Manuel.
Quarter size hail was reported 7 miles west of Groom.
The spotter reported nickel hail almost covered the ground.
Nickel size hail was reported near Fort Hood Regional Airport in Killeen.
A mobile home was severely damaged, a grain bin was moved 100 yards, and a large tree and limbs were blown down by strong winds.
Measured 1.00 ; Report found on social media. Time of report was estimated based on radar.
Golf ball size hail was reported 4 miles southeast of Dalhart.
Trees and powerlines blown down.
A thunderstorm produced half dollar size hail along Arabian Colt Dr. in Georgetown.
Amatuer radio operator reported quarter size hail.
A tree was blown down on Highway 1013 west of Kirbyville.
Widespread tree damage was reported across the Jacinto City area.
Golf ball sized hail reported by the public.
Trees were uprooted and thrown onto cars and houses.
Emergency management reported quarter-sized hail near the intersection of Highway 19 and County Road 1280 south of the city of Emory, TX.

Strong thunderstorm wind snapped or uprooted at least a dozen trees, destroyed a radio antenna, and damaged the roof of a house.  A NWS survey determined that wind speeds associated with the damage were about 70 mph.
A 200 year old barn was destroyed and several 200 year old oak trees were downed from strong straight line winds.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail northwest of Leander.
An amateur radio operator reported that there were numerous windows broken out of construction trailers.
Half dollar-size hail covering the ground.
Several large limbs were downed in Leesburg. Winds were estimated to be near 60 mph.
A tree was downed across Farm to Market 307 west of Deberry, Texas.
Golfball sized hail fell just west of Lone Elm.
Trees were downed across Hwy. 37 near Silver City and the Red River bordering McCurtain County, Oklahoma.
Public estimated hail slightly larger than quarter size. Hail dented a car and broke out the side window.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 65 mph that knocked down some large tree limbs in the Wildwood subdivision in northwestern San Antonio.
Hail occurred on Hwy. 21 at Lake Bob Sandlin.

This is a continuation of a tornado that formed in the extreme northeast portion of Jack County. The tornado moved northeast, producing scattered tree damage, before crossing the Jack/Wise County line and dissipating in the vicinity of the Crafton community in far NW Wise County. This tornado was rated an EF-0 with maximum winds of 75 mph.
Hail covered the ground.
Nickel size hail fell in Johnson Creek Park 3 miles east of Valley View.
The San Angelo ASOS located at Mathis Field recorded a 78 mph wind gust.
Trees were downed across FM 114 between the English community and the Bowie County line.
A tornado along the leading edge of a squall line was reported by multiple chasers and an NWS employee in the area. The tornado remained in open grassland country and no damage occurred.
Quarter size hail was reported at the intersection of I-30 and Bryant Irvin in southwest Ft. Worth.

A NWS Storm Survey determined an EF-0 tornado began approximately 2 miles north of Mart. This tornado had a path length of approximately 1.5 miles and an estimated width of 30 yards. Some tree damage occurred with this small rope tornado and winds were estimated near 75 mph.
Quarter size hail was reported by the public in the town of Scurry.
A law enforcement officer reported a tornado on the ground for a short time. No structures were damaged from the tornado.
A large barn was blown down and large trees were uprooted.

The roof and door of a large barn along Duncanville Road in Cedar Hill was torn off by severe thunderstorm winds. Trees in the area were also knocked down. Another home in the area also received extensive wind damage. Officials reported about 2 dozen barns and homes in the area has some type of wind damage.
Penny size hail at FM 2025 and FM 925.
Public reported on social media golf ball size hail.
Measured wind gust was recorded by the Automated Surface Observation System at the Gregg County Airport.
Penny sized hail was reported on the west side of Runaway Bay.
The Grayson County Emergency Manager reported a teacher at Lamar Elementary school was struck by lightning while walking to her car.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Childress measured a wind gust of 60 mph.
Public report of baseball size hail 1 mile north of Christoval.

An intensifying thunderstorm over the southern Texas Panhandle produced nickel size hail. A storm chaser reported this hail 3 miles north of the city of Howardwick (Donley County). No other information was given with this report.
Dime to nickel size hail was reported along Texas Farm to Market Road 86 west of Estelline.
Measured 6.77 of rain between 6 am and 116 pm five miles south of Slidell.
Storm spotters reported golfball size hail.
Trees were knocked down on FM 1434 near Bono. The time and location are estimated as the storm remained in that area for a few hours.

Saturated grounds caused a 40-foot oak tree to fall onto a house.  The fallen tree caused the carport to collapse, crushing a car.  The tree broke windows in the side of the house and tore a large hole in the roof.  The weather observer for the town reported 6.5 inches of rain in the 48 hours prior to the occurrence.
A carport was blown over onto a vehicle on Willow Crest Circle.
The Amarillo Emergency Manager reported that power lines were blown down near Hastings Avenue and U.S. Highway 287 in Amarillo Texas.
Quarter size hail was reported on the west side of Palo Pinto.
Fences were blown down by high winds.

Local law enforcement officials reported that utility lines were blown down along Texas Highway 83 west of Denver City. The damage occurred near the path of a Doppler radar indicated mesocyclone, but the occurrence of a tornado could not be confirmed.
Penny sized hail was reported along Highway 377 near Proctor.
A tree was downed north of Hemphill, Texas.
A social media report indicated quarter sized hail in the city of Red Oak, TX.

An emergency manager reported a partial train derailment was caused by very strong straight line winds. There were 20 to 25 train cars blown over. The estimated wind speed was 80 mph. The estimated wind speed is based on doppler radar.
Sporadic tree damage occurred.
Quarter size hail fell at the intersection of Highway 36 and FM 589 northwest of Comanche.
An Abilene TV station showed a brief tornado touchdown near the town of Tuscola. There were no injuries and no reported damage.
Amateur radio reported a wind gust of 60 mph.
Powerlines were downed by severe thunderstorm wind gusts in Clarksville, Texas.

An EF-0 tornado touched down around 9.5 miles east of Canton along CR 1321 then moved northeast passing south and east of Grand Saline before crossing US Highway 80 and lifting north of Silver Lake. One home on FM 1255 lost part of the wall on an addition built over the garage, and a mobile home along FM 1255 near CR 1605 had roof and porch damage. Another home suffered roof damage on CR 1701. Several trees were also uprooted or damaged along the path. The tornado may have crossed into Wood County for a short distance, but due to the lack of roads in the area this could not be confirmed. Maximum estimated winds were 80 mph.
Emergency management reported large trees damaged or uprooted, and multiple metal roofs damaged, along Clements Road near Collinsville.
Law enforcement reported large hail up to the size of quarters between Bronco and Plains. Reports indicated severe damage to cotton crops east of Bronco.

An NWS Storm Survey found that an EF-0 tornado initially touched down on the west side of Dilley where damage to hardwood trees was noted. The tornado then moved in a northeasterly direction, causing damage to roofs of buildings on either side of I-35. The |tornado lifted on the east side of the interstate and covered approximately 0.7 miles over a span of 2 minutes. Maximum winds were estimated at 75 mph.
A public report indicated that roof damage occurred to a mobile home in Krum, TX. Part of the roof was peeled back.
Estimated winds of 60 mph were reported near CR 141 near the Comanche/Mills county line.
Trees were knocked down around Trophy Club, and at least one was blocking traffic.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet near White River Lake.
Occurred just west of town.
Trees were downed near the intersection of Highway 75 and FM 1696.
A large Cottonwood tree branch crashed through the porch of a home on Eagle Mountain Lake in the Newark area. Strong winds with a storm an hour earlier likely weakened the branch.
Thunderstorm winds downed a large tree and numerous tree limbs.
Trees were blown down with the lead gust front on Hwy. 42 just north of Hwy. 13 in the Price community.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that knocked down several trees.
Trees were downed in Pollok, Texas near Hwy. 69 and Hwy. 7.  Glass was also broken out of a school in Pollok, Texas.
Power lines were downed.
Quarter sized hail was reported from the intersection of Dennis Road and Interstate 20, north towards Greenwood.

NWS damage survey information found that a cone tornado touched down for approximately 3 minutes in the Canadian River valley. The tornado received was given an EF-0 rating, with time and track based on trained spotter information.
Quarter sized hail fell at Fort Worth Alliance Airport.
The public reported quarter size hail in Christoval.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail in Kerrville.
Facebook report with photos.

Scattered thunderstorms moved northward into the southern Texas Panhandle during the early afternoon hours of the 16th. These thunderstorms had access to a high atmospheric moisture content which allowed for periods of heavy rain. As the thunderstorms moved over the city of Amarillo, the heavy rain led to minor flooding of Danbury Street, portions of Bell Street between Interstate 40 and interstate 27, Soncy, Wolflin, and Coulter. Once the thunderstorms moved away from the city of Amarillo (Potter and Randall), the minor flooding subsided. No stranded vehicles or swift water rescues were reported in association to this minor flooding.

A social media picture indicated a 5.6+ inch diameter hail stone in Salado, TX. Swift actions were taken by NWS Fort Worth and the IBHS (Insurance Institute for Business & Home Safety) to preserve and document this record hailstone. The IBHS officially measured the hailstone at: Maximum diameter  5.676 in, Mass  409.3 g, Volume  29.5 in3 making it the largest hail stone on record in the FWD CWA to date. Other large hailstones also fell in this same area.

The tornado began near County Road 303 west of Highway 96 and traveled northwest. The tornado then continued across Highway 96, but dissipated before reaching Marshall Lake just east of County Road 302. Along the path many large pine trees were downed or snapped with some falling onto homes. Also along the path, one building was pushed about 25 feet off of its blocks.
Nickel size hail was observed near the intersection of South Fry Road and Greenwind Chase Drive.

A second supercell storm developed over northeastern Lamb County, and produced giant hail in the Olton vicinity. Local officials reported four and a half inch diameter hailstones along Farm to Market Road 168 just south of Olton shortly after 19:00 CST. At least minor damage occurred to several vehicles.
Local law enforcement officials reported small tree limbs around the town of Spearman, Texas. There were no injuries or other damage reported.
Amateur radio reported trees down near the intersection of FM 1602 and Hwy 36.
A thunderstorm moved across Gaines County and produced a wind gust of 63 mph near Seminole.
Limbs down wind 65 mph gust
Amateur radio reported golf ball sized hail in the city of Bellmead, TX.
Hail report received via mPing.
Law enforcement reported pea to nickel sized hail occurred at the intersection of Farm to Market Roads 534 and 3162.
The broadcast media relayed a report of thunderstorm wind gusts estimated up to 65 mph at Bledsoe. No damage was reported.
Winds were estimated to be 70 mph in eastern McLennan County.
The roofs of two barns were blown off.
A thunderstorm produced two inch diameter hail just west of Harper.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Hackberry measured a wind gust to 58 mph.
Hail nearly covering entire ground at the intersection of Gessner and Hammerly Roads.
Several trees, fences and about 20 utility poles were damaged.
A 60 mph wind gust was estimated near Venus.
A tree partially fell onto a home on McNeill Street in Stephenville. Significant damage did not occur.
A barn was damaged and power lines were down in the Adell/Whitt area.

An isolated thunderstorm developed and moved northeast across the central Permian Basin during the late afternoon on the 18th.  Quarter size hail was reported at the intersection of Highways 137 and 158 in western Glasscock County by the DPS.
Trees were blown down by high winds.
Ping pong-size hail fell.
Large tree limbs were blown down on FM 909 near Scatter Creek.

A strong cloud to ground lightning bolt struck and set ablaze a wind turbine and tower at the Willacy County Los Vientos wind farm during the initial severe thunderstorm that impacted the county during the early evening of June 24, 2019.  Another strike destroyed a small grain silo just to the west of Lyford and Raymondville.  Time of the strike is estimated from peak lightning frequency, which exceeded 300 cloud to ground strikes in 15 minutes.
Quarter sized hail was observed.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail southeast of Cuero.
A trained weather spotter reported quarter size hail northeast of Bovina.
A well-built carport, along with the vehicles in it had wind damage. Also, part of the roof on the home was damaged as well.
Pine trees down west of airport.
Emergency management reported that a barn was destroyed, along with out buildings blown over and fences down in Bardwell, TX.
Emergency management reported a roof blown off of a home just northwest of the city of Breckenridge, TX.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Amherst measured severe wind gusts of 85 mph from 2037 CST through 2038 CST.
A large tree was blown down by high winds in southwest Arlington.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 58 mph that blew down some small trees.
Report from mPING: Quarter (1.00 in.).
Amateur radio operators reported several trees blown down by thunderstorm winds in Frankston.
A HAM radio spotter estimated tennis ball size hail.  Damage was unknown.
Law enforcement reported a power pole down in the area.
A member of the public reported 1 inch of accumulating hail south of College Station.
Hail up to the size of pennies was reported from near Florey to Frankel City.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail near Jourdanton.
Numerous reports of wind damage in Burleson County. Trees and powerlines downed along FM 1362 in Caldwell and trees downed along County Road 268 near Snook.
The high wind was measured at the Pampa West Texas Mesonet station located two miles east of Pampa.

Tornado began as a weak EF0 in East Bernard then tracked NW across SH 90 where it strengthened to EF1 snapping the trunks of several large mature oak and pecan trees. A house suffered significant brick facade damage to one side of the home. Four apartments were damaged on college street.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site in Happy measured severe wind gusts from 1735 CST through 1739 CST. A peak wind gust of 59 mph was measured at 1739 CST.

A short-lived F0 tornado uprooted several trees, blew over a semi-trailer, produced roof damage to several homes and a warehouse.  The Weslaco Police Department also reported several cruisers with broken windows.
A few trees were blown down during a severe thunderstorm.

A cluster of thunderstorms moved out of the Oklahoma Panhandle and into the Texas Panhandle during the evening hours of the 30th. As this cluster of thunderstorms moved near the town of Lipscomb (Lipscomb County), a local law enforcement officer reported an estimated 60 mph thunderstorm downburst. After producing this downburst the cluster of thunderstorms continued to move to the southeast.

The bow-shaped line along the Comal-Bexar-Wilson line moved into Hays and Guadalupe Counties near midnight, continuing to produce widespread wind gusts of 40 to 50 knots, with spotty higher gusts near 70 knots.  Most of the damage consisted of knocked-over trees in southern Hays County.
Telephone poles were blown down near CR 38 and CR 81.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that uprooted trees in Smithville.
A 77 mph wind gust was reported in Little Elm.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 75 mph. A CoCoRAHS observer reported three large Oak trees, estimated at one to two feet in diameter, snapped in half near FM 474 in Boerne.

An NWS employee in southwest Lubbock estimated wind gusts of 55 to 60 mph from a virga shower. These winds snapped a 20-foot antenna and caused sporadic minor damage to property fences in far southwest Lubbock.

A cluster of thunderstorms developed over Donley County during the afternoon hours of the 28th. As these storms neared Greenbelt Lake (Donley County), a trained storm spotter reported half dollar size hail (1.25 inch) one mile east of Greenbelt Lake (Donley County). After producing this hail, the storms continued to move to the northeast across the county.
Trees down on FM 3382.
Reported via mPing.
A porch was blown off a house.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet.
A tree was blown down on power lines on County Road 351.

A left-moving supercell produced large hail along a swath from Mentone to near the Texas and New Mexico border in northern Loving County. Initial reports indicated penny size hail in Mentone and just east of the city along Texas Highway 302. A rancher reported golfball size hail fell in rural areas of the county before the storm moved over the state line. No damage was reported.
A thunderstorm produced a measured five inch diameter hailstone which ties the record for the largest hailstone ever reported in South Central Texas.
Strong wind blew large tree limbs onto roads.
Quarter size hail reported by FAA at Valley International Airport.

A small EF0 tornado touched down just southeast of Lexington.  A combination of eye witnesses, storm chasers, and a NWS survey concluded that it produced little damage in mainly rural areas southeast of Lexington.  A few trees were damaged near the area but little in the way of a path could be found.  There was minor roof damage to a house but inconclusive whether it was tornado damage or microburst damage.  Most tree damage was found near the intersection of county roads 405 and 408.  A few other brief touchdowns may have occurred along the storm path in Lee County but no major damage was found.
Hail was reported at Slaughter Lane and Manchaca Road.
Golf ball sized hail was reported near Allen.
A large tree was split at the base due to high winds.
The Decatur Police Department reported baseball sized hail, which produced damage to several of their police vehicles.
The public reported 1 inch hail in Gatesville.
A large tree branch was blown down, blocking FM 778 just southeast of Quitman.
Penny size hail

Emergency management reported wind damage in Granbury near 701 Pintail Ct. Three bays in the marina were damaged with several sunken boats and jetskis. Widespread uprooted and damaged trees were also reported in this area.
Local law enforcement reported nickel size hail on U.S. Highway 380 west of Tahoka.
Accumulating hail was occurring at the time of the report along parts of HWY 136.
A mobile home was unroofed on F.M. 875.
Reported on Interstate 45.
The Amarillo ASOS reported a 60 mph wind gust as the line of thunderstorms moved over the station. Also visibilities were briefly reduced to a 1/2 mile due to dust with the initial outflow.
Hail from quarter size (1.00") to golf ball size (1.75").
Golf ball size hail fell 9 miles southwest of Wildorado.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Aspermont recorded a wind gust to 61 mph.
Thunderstorm winds downed a tree on a mobile home and split it in half. Two people were trapped inside, but were rescued without injury.
Strong thunderstorm wind destroyed a 40' by 60' barn.
Social media reported a tree blown down at the Runnels County Courthouse in Ballinger.

A NWS Storm Survey analyzed wind damage along a line from Springtown to Haslet and determined that straight-line winds of 75 to 85 MPH caused much of the damage. Outbuildings, barns, roofs and trees were damaged by a supercell that tracked east across the area.
Half dollar sized hail was observed in Cleveland.
A thunderstorm produced two inch hail on Pioneer Gold Rd. in northwestern San Antonio.
Hail was observed on Highway 172 near the Archer-Clay County line.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph and pea size hail near the intersection of Lower Turtle Creek Rd. and Deer Park Ln. E. south of Kerrville.
A trained spotter reported quarter-sized hail near the intersection of Interstate 35 and FM 407, approximately 5 miles east of Justin, TX.
Large trees were reported down along Tejeda Road.
Golfball-size hail reported at Northeast Mall.  Many cars had dents and some had cracked or broken windshields.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph in Blanco.
A 60 mph wind gust was estimated by a storm spotter in Shafter.  No damage was reported with this gust.
A mesonet station reported 74 mph wind gust.
Quarter size hail occurred near Weimar.
A thunderstorm produced baseball size hail near the intersection of Hwy 304 and Wolf Run Rd. that killed a cow and severely damaged a law enforcement vehicle in Delhi.
A tree was blown down by high winds.
A storm moved across Pecos County and produced a 58 mph wind gust as recorded by the local mesonet station.

A building on Highway 190 E, east of Lampasas, was heavily damaged by high winds. The building suffered partial roof loss and partially collapsed walls. Seven units at a nearby storage facility were also damaged by 2x6 timbers and debris from the building. Timbers were also driven into a nearby double-wide mobile home, and a window was broken out at the residence. Some timbers were sticking up out of the ground around the residence. One 50-60' tall elm tree near the home was snapped in half and fell on a car. Only minor dents were sustained to the car. Also nearby, a fireworks stand was destroyed.
The public reported that numerous tree limbs had been blown down due to thunderstorm wind gusts which were estimated to be near fifty-two knots.
A phone call was received of nickel to quarter size hail near Odessa High School.
Tennis ball sized hail was reported in Lyons.
Nickel sized hail was reported approximately 3 miles west of the intersection of I-20 and U.S. Highway 281.

The Denton County Fire marshal reported a house in the 9300 block of Blanco Drive caught fire after lightning struck the roof. The house was severely damaged, causing the home to be temporarily uninhabitable. Due to the fire, the roof is completely gone and the first floor suffered water damage. The siding of a neighboring house was damaged by the heat of the fire.
A 71 MPH wind gust was measured at the Comanche Airport (KMKN).

In surveying damage in northeast San Antonio, staff found indications of a tornado at two locations. It is thought that the severe thunderstorm winds struck the area near 1:25 am CST and the tornado struck after the severe thunderstorm winds. The tornado damage was similar to the other damage in the area, consisting of fences blown down and trees snapped off or blown over, except that the debris was tossed in all different directions. It touched down near 1:30 am CST close to the intersection of Knollbluff and Flowing Spring and moved southeast for approximately 1000 feet before lifting and moving over a utility plant. At one point along Flowing Spring it fired pieces from the top of a fence toward the south into the second story of a home, and shortly afterward, it threw other pieces into a roof of a different home back to the northwest. The tornado touched down again near the intersection of Saddle Ridge and Cedar Moss, a little over a half-mile to the southeast of its lift point. Here it knocked over two large trees, tossing one to the east and one to the south. Residents at this location reported high winds, followed by hail, and then a calm period before their ears suddenly popped and they heard a sound like a freight train. The tornado moved toward the southeast for approximately 300 feet then lifted and dissipated. A review of the damage indicated tornado winds of 80 to 100 mph at both locations, making it an EF-1 on the Enhanced Fujita Scale.

An off-duty NWS employee observed a cone tornado develop near the edge of the Caprock about 2.5 miles southeast of Crosbyton. This tornado crossed U.S. Highway 82, but did not produce any visible damage to trees or power lines in the area.  This tornado was later absorbed by a larger mesocyclone to its north that went on to produce a sizable tornado in northeast Crosby County.
Hail report received via mPing.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Lesley measured a wind gust to 65 mph.
Quartersize hail fell 1 mile southwest of Briscoe.
Penny sized hail was reported just near the intersection of Artcraft Road and Interstate 10.
Power poles were snapped and trees were blown down on County Road 3545 near Leesburg.

Two reports were received of baseball size hail along Farm to Market Road 1610 west of Knapp. The local newspaper editor reported windows knocked out of rural homes by the large hail stones. Several second hand reports of crop damage were received, but local authorities said the damage was very isolated in nature. Roof and vehicle damage also resulted.
Bedroom windows were blown into a house.
Hail at the Travis County Exposition Center.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Aiken measured a wind gust to 58 mph.
A center pivot was toppled southwest of Olton.  Time estimated from radar.
No damage reported.
A thunderstorm produced tennis ball size hail near Knippa.
A severe thunderstorm produced a downburst that uprooted trees, twisted tops off trees and split and damaged other trees between Canyon Lake and Fischer.
Power lines blown down.
A lightning strike resulted in a power outage affecting several hundred residents in the area.
No damage was reported.
Trees were downed along Hwy. 69 near the Cuney community.
Strong thunderstorm winds associated with a microburst resulted in wind damage at Ducote Airpark located about 10 miles southwest of San Angelo.  Several hangar doors were blown out.
A thunderstorm produced hail for 11 minutes. The largest hail was 1.5 inches in diameter.
Social media videos indicate a house fire was likely caused by lightning. The time was estimated by radar.
Reported by storm spotters.
Trees and power lines were blown down across the county.
A local construction company reported that thunderstorm winds caused minor roof damage to a structure in northwest Lubbock. The winds were accompanied by small hail. No injuries were reported.
Reported between Antelope and Squaw Mountain.
MPing report.

A storm survey conducted by the National Weather Service in Fort Worth found that a second tornado began just east-northeast of Godley.  A mobile home was rolled and destroyed with substantial damage to a nearby car.  At least one shed was damaged and power lines were downed.  This tornado was rated an EF-0 with maximum winds of 80-85 MPH.  Some debris was carried approximately 75 yards from their original locations.

A brief yet strong tornado moved onshore along the coast in Sargent causing significant damage to one home and overturning a motor home. Numerous trees were snapped and/or downed along the path as well as minor roof damage to several homes and businesses.
No damage observed. Track and times estimated based on three separate videos and pictures.

Power poles were downed in the northwest portion of town. The steel roof of a business was peeled back. An air conditioning unit was also blown off the roof of an auto shop where it fell on top of a car, damaging the windshield and denting the hood. Some minor roof damage to some buildings was also reported.
A wind gust of 65 mph was reported just north of Abilene.

Pictures from the Raymondville area of Willacy County showed damage from a line from south of HWY 186 and S 1st Street to a quarter mile north of the Raymondville Country Club along S 7th Street. Some of the pictures included a part of a wood roof peeled back from a porch on W Gem Street and some gate and metal roof damage to a garage along S 7th Street. There was also a video shared from the Holiday Inn Express near the intersection of US-77/I-69E and HWY 186 looking to the southwest showing a large gust front blowing through Raymondville in the areas mentioned above. A closer inspection of the video shows some debris lofted into the air and was used a guide for the estimated 70 mph wind gusts. The time is based on the video and radar.
From trained spotter.

Scattered thunderstorms developed across Roberts County during the afternoon hours of the 16th. A diminishing thunderstorm approaching Codman (Roberts County) produced an estimated 70 mph downburst. A member of the public reported this downburst blew over several 2ft in diameter Cottonwood trees roughly 27 miles north-northwest of Codman (Roberts County).
Broken trees, roof damage, and a collapsed carport were reported on Weldon Lane in Royse City.
A public report indicated quarter sized hail in Plano.
Large trees in DeLeon were snapped at their bases or knocked down.
A large tree was blown over a highway east of Woodville. Reported by Tyler County Sheriff Office.
An EF-0 tornado caused no damage.
A tree was downed onto Highway 190.
Trees were blown down along both County Road 384 and FM 2908.
Nickel size hail.

A National Weather Storm Survey team found evidence of an EF1 tornado with wind speeds of about 107 mph, which began about 3 miles southeast of May, Texas in Hogg Mountain.  It moved southeast, then northeast and then turned back to the northwest and west.  Because it was nearly stationary, the tornado appeared to rotate with the parent mesocyclone.  The tornado uprooted many trees, snapped many tree trunks and branches of large Oak trees.  The tornado tore off a roof of a mobile home, destroyed a chicken coop, damaged outdoor furniture, ripped off sheet metal from a barn and tossed it for over 100 yards.  As the tornado continued to move west across County Road 478, it became about a half mile wide as it uprooted large Oak trees and snapped some tree trunks.  Eyewitness accounts and a photograph indicated this tornado had multiple vortices.
Emergency manager reported downed power poles and significant damage to an RV.
Golfball to Baseball size hail fell on Woodley Road between the Crossroads and Elysian Fields communities.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet.
Trees, power lines, and large tree limbs down around the city.  A carport was also blown away.  Most of the damage was reported on the south side of Highway 190.
Nickle size hail reported by Fire Chief.

The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site near Floydada recorded a peak wind gust of 66 mph as a gust front raced southward in advance of a severe convective complex over Floyd County. Local officials reported that numerous street signs were downed and several tin roofs sustained damage. Tree damage was additionally reported to be widespread.
Quarter sized hail was reported 5 miles southeast of Powell.
A delayed CoCoRaHS report indicated ping-pong ball sized hail 3 miles northeast of Little Elm.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail north of Cuero.

A cluster of discrete thunderstorms moving across the Texas Panhandle transitioned into a broken linear structure during the late evening hours of the 6th. As this broken line of storms moved towards the town of Dumas (Moore County), the TXDOT AWOS 3 miles west of Dumas (Moore County)  reported a 61 mph downburst gust. After producing this gust the line of thunderstorms continued moving eastward across the Panhandle.
Shed blown down.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail east of Brackettville mainly south of Hwy 90.
Tornado was verified by storm spotter video but the area is inaccessible. In the video, tree limbs were seen being lofted in the air. Maximum estimated winds were 75 mph.
Several trees were snapped on East Wynns Creek Drive east of Kilgore.
Power lines were blown down by high thunderstorm winds.
Thunderstorms produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph which knocked down large tree limbs, 2-3 inches in diameter, at the Judge Roy Bean visitor center.
A condo in DeCordova Bend Estates sustained minor roof damage due to thunderstorm winds. Also, some large trees were knocked down.
This hail was observed 4 miles west of Groom.
Measured by a Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet.  Severe wind gusts of 60 mph, 66 mph and 75 mph were measured at 1955 CST, 2000 CST, and 2005 CST, respectively.

Several homes and businesses were damaged, a barn was destroyed, with numerous reports of roof and structural damage from high winds.  There were numerous reports of trees, signs, and power lines blown down. The Corsicana radar reported wind gusts to 65 mph at 1011 pm cdt.
One Confirmed fatality and many injuries. The Tornado was first indentified by the public approximately 8 miles south of the CCI airport. Most extensive damage reported across Del MAr College.

At 12:32 pm CST, members of the TWISTEX research team confirmed a rope tornado approximately 5.5 miles south southeast of Goldsmith, TX, and north of Highway 302.  The tornado then moved northeast a little over a mile where it dissipated at 12:36 pm CST.  No significant damage was observed with this tornado.
Law Enforcement reported golf ball size hail 2 miles north of Stamford.
A thunderstorm moved across Dawson County and produced an 88 mph wind gust at the Lamesa mesonet site.
A thunderstorm moved across Reagan County and produced a 59 mph wind gust near St. Lawrence at the mesonet site.
A lightning strike near the Copperas Cove Solid Waste Department on South FM 116 damaged the phone line and a computer in the building.

Thunderstorms formed along a dryline stretching east-northeastward across Randall and Potter Counties during the afternoon hours of the 28th. These thunderstorms would take a northeast track which allowed them to move over the dryline. This caused the thunderstorms to produce isolated downbursts across the city. One such thunderstorm produced a localized downburst which downed power poles on US Highway 60 west of the city of Canyon (Randall County). The thunderstorm decayed quickly after moving to the dry side of the dryline due to ingesting much drier air into the updrafts.  No injuries were associated with this gust.

Thunderstorm remained stationary over the same area for nearly 1 hour.  Hail to the size of baseballs for for nearly 40 minutes totally stripping trees and vegetation.  No reports of damage to property was received.
Golfball-hail was reported in Moffat.
A trained spotter reported a tree 3 feet in diameter blown down in the city of Cameron, TX.
Eighty MPH thunderstorm winds damaged several manufactured homes.
Hail between one half inch and three quarters of an inch in diameter was reported 4 miles east of Dalhart.
A tree was uprooted onto a home in the area of Redwood Drive and Maryland Drive in Liberty Eylau, with power lines and several more trees also downed across roads and onto other homes in this area.
A storm chaser reported trees down between the communities of Flat and The Grove.
The West Texas Mesonet site near Seagraves measured high winds from a collapsing thunderstorm. 60 to 70 mph gusts lasted for approximately ten minutes. No damage was reported.
Baseball size hail fell at a residence about four miles southwest of Westbrook.  No damage was reported.
