Several trees were downed near the town of Newton during a thunderstorm. An outbuilding and dog kennel was also reported damaged.
Two barns destroyed and trees knocked down.
Quarter size hail fell in Muenster.
A trained storm spotter reported 1 inch hail in Columbus.

A National Weather Service damage survey team found evidence of an EF-0 tornado across portions of northern Fannin County. The tornado began near the Duplex community, where it damaged several trees and a roof on a church. The tornado then moved northeast, damaging two homes, and uprooting several trees along Fannin County roads.
A member of the public reported a funnel cloud east of Kingwood.
Law Enforcement Officials reported damaging winds from a severe thunderstorm resulted in numerous power outages across Tye.
Utility pole and power lines downed.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Wolfforth measured severe wind gusts from 0117 CST through 0118 CST. A peak wind gust of 59 mph was measured at 0117 CST.
Emergency management reported quarter-sized hail at Steele Creek Park, or approximately 8 miles west-northwest of Lake Whitney.
Several large tree limbs were blown down.

Downburst winds caused widespread damage across the northern half of the county.  A metal barn was damaged on CR 134.  Tree damage occurred along Highway 84 between Lake Mexia and Prairie Hill on Lazy Lou Ranch.  A metal roof of a residence was damaged on FM 2310 near the community of Sandy.  The most significant damage occurred along the northwest shore of Lake Mexia near the Red Bud subdivision.  Numerous trees were uprooted or blown down, with some falling on cars and mobile homes.  Some damage to roofs was also noted.
Storm spotters reported golfball size hail on Highway 62 between Brownfield and Wellman.
Penny size hail.
Several large trees were blown over around the city of De Leon.
Lightning struck a house and burned a hole in the roof.
A wind gust of 75 MPH was measured by the Automated Surface Observation System at the Mineral Wells, TX Airport.
A trained spotter reported multiple structures with roofs gone and trailers flipped over. One person was rescued from inside the trailer. A definite damage path of 100 yards occurred.

The Tulia Police Department reported that four cars were blown off Interstate 27 about six miles north of Tulia. These winds were likely caused by an intense rear flank downdraft to a supercell that would later produce a tornado in Briscoe County. No vehicle damage was reported.
A section of power lines was damaged about four miles south of Valley Schools.  A goat shed nearby was also damaged.

A thunderstorm moved across Mitchell County and produced wind damage near Loraine. Multiple high profile train cars derailed just south of I-20 near mile marker 223 along Lucus Road. The survey team estimated that the wind speeds were roughly 90 mph through this area. The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that knocked down a few trees, a large section of fence, and blew over a shed in Del Rio.
A large tree was downed on CR 3204 just off of FM 992.  Another tree was downed on CR 3206.
The AWOS near San Saba reported a wind gust of 67 mph. Also, power lines were blown down in San Saba.
Cotulla-La Salle County Airport ASOS measured a gust to 59 MPH.
Penny size hail fell near Lake Kiowa.

The Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet site recorded a thunderstorm wind gust of 64 mph southwest of Guthrie at 19:05 CST. By 19:22 CST, the public estimated wind gusts up to 80 mph in Guthrie. Since no damage was reported the estimated wind speed appears too high.

Local law enforcement officials reported that the thunderstorm wind gusts knocked down power lines and also knocked over an irrigation sprinkler system. There were no reports of injuries or fatalities.

An EF-1 tornado moved through Grapevine beginning near the Mustang Elite Car Wash on Ira E Woods Ave south of Hwy 114. The tornado crossed Ira E Woods Ave causing significant roof damage to the Sam's Club. Large sections of the roof were peeled off leaving large holes. The tornado then damaged a storage unit facility and a Discount Tire store. Many of the windows of the Discount Tire lobby where blown out, and a few power poles next to the store were also damaged. The tornado continued moving northeast damaging trees and shingles in a residential area. Near the intersection of Northwest Highway & North Dove Road the tornado damaged another car wash and a restaurant. The tornado next caused damage to two HVACs at Grapevine Middle School. The next notable damage was to the Grapevine Service Center where significant roof damage was observed, and several garage doors where blown out. One small truck was also overturned. The tornado continued through a residential area where it caused minor damage to several trees and roofs, but it damaged several large trees at the Grapevine Cemetery. The tornado continued to weaken from here until it dissipated near the Glass Cactus on the Gaylord Texan Resort property. Maximum estimated winds were 110 mph.
The public reported golf ball size hail at South Western and Loop 335 in Amarillo.
The Travis County Sheriff's Office reported that a woman was struck and killed by lightning in northwestern Austin. She was found dead on a hiking trail off of River Place Blvd.
A thunderstorm produced quarter to golf ball size hail between Hunt and Ingram.
A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail near the intersection of I-410 and Hwy 151 on the westside of San Antonio.
Funnel clouds were seen by storm spotters on Highway 24/50 between Commerce and Campbell and also on Highway 224 and Interstate 30.

A discrete thunderstorm developed over the city of Amarillo (Potter and Randall County) during the evening hours of the 2nd. While over the city, the National Weather Service office observed quarter size hail (1.00 inch) 7 miles east-northeast of town (Potter County). After producing this hail, the thunderstorm slowly moved off to the northeast.
Hail at the intersection of Old Hearne Road and Texas Avenue.

A line of thunderstorms moved across the southwestern Texas Panhandle during the evening hours of the 5th. This line took on a classic bow echo signature, and golf ball size hail (1.75 inches) in the city of Bootleg (Deaf Smith County). The line continued to move to the south-southeast across the county, and quickly moved into northwest Texas.
One tree was downed along CR 207 northwest of town.
The DeWitt County sheriff's office reported nickel size hail.
MPing report.
Thunderstorm wind gusts, estimated at 60 mph, knocked down trees. One tree landed on a car and others tore down power lines.

Hail fell for more than 15 minutes near Zapata County during the mid evening.  The Zapata County Emergency Management Coordinator received a report of quarter size hail in the Las Palmas subdivision, about 4 miles northeast of the City of Zapata.  The Manager of the Zapata County Airport noted quarter size hail as well, which cause indentations in some vehicles' hoods. Some larger stones of unknown size were embedded with the quarter sized hail field.

A tornado touched down about seven miles west of Canyon around 1740 CST and tracked northeast where it lifted about four and a half miles east northeast of Umbarger just west of the intersection of Farm to Market Road 1062 and City Lake Road. The tornado remained over open country and was on the ground for about two minutes. No damage or injuries were reported.
Resident reported broken windows, trees down, siding on houses damaged, and a car window blown out.
A wood frame house was damaged on ACR 367.
A swath of hail ranging from ping pong ball size to golf ball size was reported in rural southwestern Hale County.
Greater than 2 diameter tree limbs down.
MPing report.
Wind damage across portions of western and central Navarro county.  Barns heavily damaged or destroyed along State Highway 22 west of Corsicana.
Sighted between El Campo and Danevang.
Quarter size hail fell about 9 miles north of Jefferson on Highway 59.
Several trees were blown down in Nacogdoches.
Public called and reported slightly larger than ping pong ball sized hail in Stinett.

A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Roaring Springs measured severe wind gusts from 1951 CST through 1958 CST. A peak wind gust of 80 mph was measured at 1953 CST. There was minor damage to the mesonet site.
A brief tornado touchdown was reported.
A trained spotter reported quarter-sized hail near the intersection of FM 2490 and Hwy 1637; approximately 4 miles east-southeast of China Spring, TX.
A trained spotter reported quarter size hail in rural east-central Yoakum County.
The tornado remained over open country and caused no damage.  The path length and width were estimated.
A thunderstorm moved across Howard County and produced less than golfball sized hail and 60 mph winds.
A picture of ping pong ball size hail that fell just southwest of the DeBerry community was posted to social media.
Reported at the Amarillo National Weather Service Office.
The tornado remained over open country. No damage or injuries were reported.
Awning blown off a building in town.
The Federal Aviation Administration contract weather observer at the tower reported the hail.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail in Castroville.
Amateur radio reported three to five inch diameter trees were broken and 2 to 4 inch diameter branches were broken from half a dozen trees.
A coop observer reported numerous power poles snapped at the base.

Numerous storm chasers and Texas Tech University researchers observed a large dusty tornado that tracked from eastern Bailey County into western Lamb County. The tornado became multi-vortex for a short time, then became occluded toward the end of its life cycle. Several small gustnadoes were also observed along the rear-flank gust front. No reports of damage were received.
A thunderstorm produced quarter to ping pong ball size southeast of Castell.
Multiple trees were blown down in the town of Eloise.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Hart measured severe wind gusts from 1707 CST through 1735 CST. A peak wind gust of 60 mph was measured at 1735 CST.
Trees and limbs blown down.
The public reported quarter size hail along U.S. Highway 84 East, between Early and Zephyr.
A social media report indicated quarter sized hail in the city of Lampasas, TX.
The Hardin County Sheriffs Department reported numerous trees down and power outages in the Lumberton area.
An NWS Employee reported baseball size hail 2 miles southwest of San Angelo.
Lightning sparked a house fire about 10 miles east of Centerville.

Strong thunderstorm wind destroyed several billboards, damaged the roofs of a number of homes, and blew down power lines, power poles, and trees.  An NWS storm survey indicated that the wind gusts associated with this damage were likely in the 70 to 90 mph range.  Wind-driven hail caused extensive property and crop damage.
Trees and powerlines downed.

Severe thunderstorm wind gusts accompanied thunderstorms, and at times large hail, along a swath from near Lazbuddie to Friona. Local fire department officials reported severe winds just north of Lazbuddie at 18:05 CST. Meanwhile, gusts up to 64 mph were recorded by both the Texas Tech University West Texas Mesonet and the KVII-TV schoolnet near Friona.
Broadcast media reported quarter sized hail near the Waco Regional Airport.
Multiple reports of hail between the size of nickels to baseballs was reported in Lindsay for over 20 minutes.
Large tree limbs were blown down near Central Expressway.
A 62 MPH wind gust was measured near the intersection of Highway 78 and CR 549 on the east side of Lake Lavon. Power flashes were also reported.
NWS HGX relayed a report of quarter sized hail 10 miles northwest of Bryan.
A thunderstorm produced nickel size hail near Hwy 183 and I-10 southeast of Luling.
Trees were downed northwest of Kirbyville.
Golfball-size was reported approximately two-and-a-half miles west of Priddy and just south of Democrat.
Trees blown over, outbuildings destroyed and irrigation systems blown over near intersection of FM 282 and FM 2391.
Nickel sized hail was reported in Gainesville but hail up to 0.50 was reported in several locations across the county along the track of the storms.

A gust of 53 mph was recorded at McAllen/Miller airport at 735 AM CST. At around the same time (735 AM),  several power lines blown down in the south side of Pharr, just 2 to 4 miles east of the airport.
Wind-driven golfball size hail destroyed more than 1000 acres of cotton.

The second of several tornadoes touched down north of Matador in an open field east of State Highway 70. The tornado then tracked to the south through open country until it reached just north of Farm to Market Road 94 where it damaged a few power poles. It then traveled to the south-southeast where it destroyed a house on the far north side of the city. Three vehicles at this residence were rolled at least a few hundred yards away from the house with two of the vehicles unable to be located. The tornado continued to track south along State Highway 70 where it damaged two additional houses and rolled another truck several hundred feet. The tornado then tracked back to the southwest and crossed State Highway 70 and damaged several houses northwest of the intersection of State Highway 70 and US Highway 62, as well as rolling several vehicles including a tractor-trailer. The tornado then crossed US Highway 62 between the Texas Department of Transportation facility and State Highway 70 where it rolled an RV, destroyed a house, and steel framed retail store, and partially collapsed a power substation. The tornado continued traveling to the southeast paralleling State Highway 70 and damaged several more single family residences with another house being destroyed. The tornado then crossed State Highway 70 just south of Cross Lane where it destroyed a 500 foot radio tower as well as some light poles. The tornado then dissipated over an open field southeast of the Matador rest stop.
A large metal building suffered roof damage as a result of a microburst from a collapsing thunderstorm.
Penny to quarter sized hail fell southeast of Guadalupe National Park.
Strong thunderstorm winds blew the roof off of a building.
A tree was downed onto a powerline in Kilgore, Texas.
Penny-size hail reported at Beechnut and Hwy 6 intersection (Key Map 528J).
A barn was destroyed by high winds.
Large tree blown over, knocking down electric and utility poles.
A thunderstorm moved across Glasscock County and produced a 60 mph wind gust north of Garden City.  No damage was reported.
A thunderstorm produced quarter to half dollar size hail around Manor. Reports came from amateur radio and mPING.
Severe thunderstorm winds downed numerous trees and power lines in and around Orchard and Simonton. Some car damage was reported from these storms.
A trained spotter reported nickel sized hail 1 mile north of Paris. This was from a second storm that moved over the area.

A very small but intense thunderstorm complex which was nearly stationary produced heavy rains near Falcon Dam along the Starr Zapata county line during the evening of September 9th. The Falcon Dam CO-OP observer reported a 24 hour rainfall of 7.70 inches.
A tree was blown down on County Road 3859 north of Hawkins.
Media relayed a report of golfball sized hail at the Ratliff Stadium in Odessa. Several residents of Odessa reported hail up to quarter sized.

Pecos County Emergency Manager reports multiple power lines down, affecting approximately 2,200 customers. Wind and hail damage caused minor roof damage and roof leaks. Wind speeds were estimated to be approximately 80 mph. The time and amount of property damage are estimates.
Golf ball sized hail on highway 60 southwest of Pampa.
A gazebo was damaged and a basketball goal and playground equipment were blown into a pool at a home near Eagle Mountain Lake.
Several trees and power lines were blown down by thunderstorm winds in China Spring.
Law enforcement observed ping pong ball size hail near Spur.
Hail fell near the community of Appleby, Texas.
Multiple reports were received of a swath of hail up to golf ball size from southwest of Levelland to southeast of Levelland crossing US Highway 385. No damage was reported.
Reported via mPing.

A National Weather Service survey team surveyed this tornado on June 13, and |found evidence of another tornado track.  This EF-1 tornado began on the north side |of Abilene and tracked north northeast into Jones County.  This twister tore the roof of a metal building, blew out windows and damaged an exterior wall on the north side of Abilene.  The twister also ripped up a billboard and flipped over an eighteen wheeler.  As the tornado continued to travel north northeast, it damaged or uprooted trees as it moved into Jones County.  It tore off part of the roofs of two residences and damaged trees and outbuildings in Jones County just northwest of Fort Phantom Lake.  This tornado was also videotaped on the north side of Abilene.
The West Texas Mesonet site near Morton measured a 62 mph wind gust.

A National Weather Service damage survey team found damage to a building under construction near Hwy 290 and Toll Road 130. Minor damage was seen at the Ford dealership on Hwy 290 and to a gas station near the intersection of 290 and Manor Downs Rd. where a large billboard was blown over into the gas station parking lot.  Tree and roof damage was also noted at the gas station along with minor damage to a few businesses at the Lexington St./Hwy 290 intersection. All of this damage along Hwy  290 was rated EF0. The small tornado either weakened or reformed just to the north of Hwy 290 in Shadowglen with fence and shingle damage found to houses on several neighborhood roads. One house had significant EF1 roof damage where winds looks to have peaked at 110 mph. The small tornado appears to have weakened again as it moved ENE into the Stonewater neighborhood. Multiple homes had a significant amount of shingles removed, fences damaged, trampolines tossed, and some tree damage. The tornado appears to have dissipated somewhere NE of the Stonewater area.

Merging thunderstorms moved over the town of Spearman (Hansford County) during the afternoon hours of the 7th. The heavy rain produced from these storms caused minor street flooding across the town. No reports of swift water rescues or stranded vehicles were reported in association with this flooding. As the thunderstorms moved southeastward away from the town, the minor flooding quickly receded.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that knocked down a tree across Gravel Pit Rd. in rural Guadalupe County.
A thunderstorm moved across Mitchell County and produced wind damage south of Westbrook.  Highline wires were blown down.  The cost of damage is a rough estimate.
Quarter sized hail fell near the Laredo International Airport.
A wind gust of 64 mph was reported at the Abilene Regional Airport.
Trees were blown down by thunderstorm winds.
Damage to metal buildings and trees was reported on Southwind Place near Krum. Some siding was also removed from a home in the Krum area in addition to shingle and fence damage.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail in the small community of Warda north of La Grange.
Law enforcement in Muleshoe reported quarter size hail as an isolated thunderstorm moved over the city.

An isolated thunderstorm produced extensive wind damage in rural northeastern Childress County near the intersection of US Highway 62 and Farm to Market Road 1642. Several power poles were snapped and a center pivot irrigation system was overturned.
A storm moved across Midland County and produced a 62 mph wind gust near Midland as recorded by the local AWOS.
Golf ball size hail was reported on the west side of Sterling City.
A house fire was caused by a lightning strike.
A 70+ foot black jack oak tree was blown down onto a shop on Stallion Road, damaging the roof.

A trained NWS storm spotter came across penny size hail covering the ground southwest of Bakersfield an hour after the last storm went through the area.  Hail size estimated given potential melting over that period.
Power lines were blown down.
A 64 MPH thunderstorm wind gust was reported by AWOS at the Addison airport.
A local broadcast media outlet reported that lightning struck the awning of a coffee shop at Indiana Avenue and 34th Street in Lubbock, causing the awning to break and fall to the ground.
Golf ball size hail reported south of Brownwood in southern Brown County.
Tree down across Dean Road between County Road 1130 and County Road 1113.
Nickel sized hail covered the ground.

The fourth and most significant tornado of the day developed in east Fort Worth just south of Ramey Avenue east of Loop 820, moved north and dissipated between Forest and Haynie streets, south ofGreenlee Street.  Damage occurred to a strip mall, with heavy damage to a duplex.  Several homes were partially unroofed,  two businesses suffered heavy damage, and roof damage occurred to the sanctuary of a church.
Golf ball sized hail on Highway 60 southwest of Pampa.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near Turkey measured severe wind gusts from 1905 CST through 1922 CST. A peak wind gust of 62 mph was measured at 1922 CST.
65 mph wind gust along US 290.
The fire department chief in the town of Rhea reported quarter size hail.

A tornado formed along the eastern edge of the Hackberry Creek neighborhood, near the intersection of Kinwest Parkway and Parkridge Boulevard. Minor roof and tree damage was observed in this area. The tornado moved quickly toward the northeast, producing roof damage to a grocery store and nearby trees, lightpoles, and commercial signage near the intersection of North MacArthur Boulevard and Las Colinas Boulevard. Continuing northeast, exterior wall damage occurred at a nearby hotel, and window and roofing damage impacted two restaurants fronting Interstate 635. The tornado crossed the Interstate and produced minor tree and roof damage before dissipating near Ranchview Drive. This tornado was rated an EF-0 with maximum winds of 75 mph.
Small trees were downed and debris was thrown across FM 225 south of Henderson.
Strong thunderstorm wind blew down power poles and trees west of town.
Starr County Sheriffs Office reported street flooding occurring in the town of Alto Bonito. Estimated depth of water was up to a foot in some locations. An estimated 2.5 to 3 inches of rain fell.
Baseball to softball sized hail was reported in De Leon.
Severe quarter size hail fell for several minutes in the Grape Creek community.
Numerous trees, as many as 50, were downed south of town.
Received a phone call of quarter size hail 8 miles south of Alpine along State Highway 118. Time is estimated from radar.
Winds gusted to 60 MPH associated with the thunderstorm.
A 61 mph wind gust was reported 6 miles north of Leonard.
A power pole was snapped in Downtown Buna.
Hail fell for about seven minutes.
Hail of quarter to half dollar size fell for about ten minutes.  No reports of damage accompanied the hail.
A thunderstorm produced a 60 mph wind gust near Goldsmith.
A thunderstorm produced one and one half inch hail which destroyed a sky light in a house. The hail was four inches deep a few places.
Quarter size hail was reported 2 miles north of Moody.
A thunderstorm produced one inch hail in Elgin.
A thunderstorm moved across Ector County and produced wind damage in Odessa. A semi-trailer was blown over in the Sam's Club parking lot. The cost of damage is a rough estimate.
McAllen Emergency Manager reported a tree down on Kennedy Avenue near 10th Street in McAllen. Time estimated by radar imagery and KMFE ASOS.
A tank battery caught fire after being struck by lightning.
Public reported quarter size hail in Silver Valley. The report was relayed through a social media account.
Trees were down on houses and roofs were blown off some buildings (tractor sheds).
Numerous large tree limbs, 6-8 inches in diameter blown down.
A trained spotter reported golf ball size hail approximately 4 miles west of the city of Lindsay, TX.
A tree went through a wood frame house causing considerable damage to much of the kitchen.
Quarter size hail was reported 2 miles south of Claude.
Damage, if any, was unknown.

An EF-1 tornado with winds estimated near 100 mph touched down along Kellyville Cutoff Road south of Farm-To-Market Road 729 in the Kellyville community. This tornado travelled north and crossed FM 729 along Kellyville Cutoff Road, snapping and uprooting numerous trees and downing power lines along the tornado's path. Much of the damage occurred along Kellyville Cutoff Road between FM 729 and Highway 49, where one home was damaged and the roof removed from a single wide mobile home. One large tree also fell on a metal workshop near Highway 49 before lifting just shy of the Berea community.
Roofs were damaged by winds at the Bobo Lumber Yard.  Some trees were also downed on powerlines along Hwy 31.
Cooke County EM reported golf ball sized hail on the east side of Gainesville on Hwy 82 east of Radio Hill Rd.
A storm chaser photographed a brief tornado in a rural area of central Throckmorton county.
A porch was damaged by the thunderstorm wind, along with debris from the damaged porch blown over 200 yards.
Quarter size hail covering the ground.
Baseball-size hail between Ponder and Krum.
Golf ball hail size covering the ground 1 mile southwest of Evant.
The ASOS at McKinney National Airport recorded a gust to 66 mph.
A trained spotter reported quarter-sized hail at County Road 758 approximately 1 mile east of the city of Thornton, TX.

The heavy rain led to widespread urban flooding. The flooding included several roads with at least two feet of water across in poor drainage locations and where drainage ditches and canals were filled above capacity. Some resacas filled to bank full; running trails and playgrounds located some of them were covered in water during the peak of the flooding. The high waters forced road closures into the night, and several vehicles became stranded.

A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet measured a wind gust to 70 mph near Hart. Reports were also received of wind damage in the town of Hart. A roof was partially removed from a large warehouse.
Post office employees reported golfball size hail in Smyer as a supercell thunderstorm moved westward into Hockley County from northwestern Lubbock County. No damage was reported.

Two tractor trailer rigs were blown over in the Wal-Mart parking lot, Wal-Mart roof blown several hundred yards, at least 8 utility poles blown down, and car windows were blown in. The Certified Auto Glass building was destroyed, there was widespread roof and sign damage, storage building and garage doors were damaged, windows were blown out, and numerous reports of fences, trees, and utility poles blown down.
Barns were blown down, trees a blown down onto houses and utility poles blown down.
Nickel sized hail was reported at FM 3902 and FM 678 on the east side of Gainesville.
The public reported a 50 foot tree uprooted by thunderstorm winds which also caused damage to a shed, some power lines and a fence.
A storm chaser reported two inch size hail in rural southeastern Hall County. No damage was reported.
A trained spotter measured one inch hail near GB Turnpike and Coit Rd that lasted approximately 4 minutes.

Multiple public reports of golfball size hail were received along a swath northwest of Petersburg. This hail accompanied an isolated supercell storm that developed along a pre-existing outflow boundary. No damages were reported.
The West Texas Mesonet station 6 NW White River Lake measured a 65 mph thunderstorm wind gust.

Winds from severe thunderstorms blew down trees down and damaged power lines between Blanco and Johnson City.  Power was out to both cities for several hours.  The storms also caused damage to roofs in Johnson City, with considerable damage to the roof of the Blanco County Jail.
Several trees and power lines were downed along Highway 59 between FM 2021 and Winston 8 Ranch Road in the Redland community.
Numerous reports of golfball to racquetball-size hail.

A NWS Storm Survey Team found evidence of a very brief tornado touchdown along FM 666, between Banquete and CR 44.  Several mesquite trees were almost uprooted and a telephone line pulled down to the ground.  Winds were estimated to be around 65 mph, with a path length of roughly 50-100 yards.  This tornado occurred in the outer rainbands of Hurricane Alex.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail in Bandera.
Late report from a spotter.

Trained spotters estimated 60 mph winds along Highway 281 in the northeast part of the county. Power flashes were also observed in the area. These winds appear to have occurred as the outflow from the storm began to surge out ahead of the storm.
A large tree and power lines were blown down near the Silver Shores community.
A tree was blown down onto Highway 8 just north of New Boston.

The automated weather station at the Cameron Municipal Airpark (KT35) recorded a 58 mph wind gust. Several trees and power lines were blown down in the city. The newspaper also reported that some metal roofs were damaged and the roof of a historic, two-story building at US 79 and FM 908 was partially torn off.
Two independent storm chasers got video of a small, brief tornado near US Highway 287 on the northwest side of Bellevue. No damage was reported.
Strong thunderstorm winds moved a hay ring on property that was located between south Sherman and north Howe. In addition, trees were knocked down onto fences.
Numerous reports of trees down and causing roads to be blocked across west El Paso.
Law enforcement in Lamb County reported several power poles blown down in the city of Littlefield.
A thunderstorm moved across Scurry County and produced an estimated 80 mph wind gust in Inadale, TX.
Quarter size hail reported at FM Road 850 and U.S. Highway 259.
Late report of wind gust and blowing dust in association with thunderstorm. Time estimated from radar.

Wind damage occurred in the Haslet area where many small tree limbs were broken off in the Ashmore Farms subdivision. To the southeast of this area, additional tree damage was reported on White Lane, and a 10'x10' wood frame gazebo collapsed on Bayne Road.
Golfball size hail fell in the city of Montague.
Amateur radio reported half-dollar sized hail near the intersection of McPherson Blvd and Chisholm Trail Parkway.
Quarter size hail was reported in Bowie.
The emergency manager reported golf ball-sized hail. The time was estimated from radar.
A funnel cloud was observed near the intersection of Gibb Creek Road and Nicholson Lake Road.
Teacup-size hail reported in town.  Hundreds of cars, homes, and businesses were damaged.

Video from near the Leon Tuttle Athletic Complex showed the start of a tornado over the ball fields. Some minor damage occurred as bleachers were lifted and pushed into a backstop. A scoreboard sustained some minor damage and metal sheet roofing was lifted into the air. The tornado moved north and crossed the airfield at Rockwall Municipal Airport, but no damage was reported there. Picture evidence from numerous citizens in Rockwall and Fate shows the condensation funnel of the tornado became more pronounced as it moved north of W Holiday Road between N John King Blvd and N|Stodghill Rd, through some low density residential areas and ranch-land. No additional damage was found along this track, and the tornado is believed to have terminated before reaching FM 552 based on radar and picture evidence. Maximum winds with the tornado were estimated at 75 mph.
Quarter sized hail occurred in Driscoll.
Half dollar sized hail was observed.

A mobile home was unroofed southeast of Italy and numerous barns and outbuildings were damaged.  A family was trapped in a collapsed mobile home in Avalon, and another mobile home was blown over.Southwest of Avalon a high tension tower was bent over.
A trained spotter reported ping pong ball size hail approximately 6 miles west-northwest of the city of Alvord, TX.
Spotter reports wind damage to silo and trees between Harrold and Electra. Winds estimated 80 to 90 mph.
Quarter size hail was reported along Highway 285.

Multiple observers photographed a tornado that developed just southwest of Silverton at 16:43 CST. This tornado crossed Texas Highway 86 just west of Silverton. Local law enforcement officials reported that seven utility poles were damaged along with lightweight buildings as the tornado impacted the outskirts of the city. Storm chasers continued to track the tornado until it roped out north of Silverton over open terrain around 17:00 CST.
Quarter sized hail was reported in the community of Grisby, Texas.

A tornado caused mainly roof damage to several brick homes on the southeast side of Lake Ray Hubbard near Heath. Another home had its chimney knocked over and some large tree damage also occurred along the path of this tornado. The winds were estimated to be between 85-95 mph.

The C-MAN station at Brazos Santiago, just inshore of the Isla Blanca jetty but adjacent to the park on the barrier island, recorded a 51 knot gust at 2 AM CST on March 27th.  No damage was reported as of this writing.
Spotter reported 3.53 inches of rain fell in an hour along with some hail.

A National Weather Service storm survey crew found evidence of a tornado in a much wider swath of straight line wind damage. The tornado occurred in a one mile path  approximately 4 miles southeast of Aledo, between River Ranch Road and Farm to Market Road 1187 in Parker County. The tornado did minimal damage to trees and power lines.
A 64 mph wind gust was recorded at Scholes Field in Galveston at the KGLS ASOS site as a strong thunderstorm moved through the area.
Part of the roof of a manufactured home in Pert was removed. Another part of the roof was partially lifted off the home.
The KVII weather station located 4 miles north of Dawn measured a wind gust of 66 mph in a thunderstorm.
A thunderstorm produced one inch hail that dented a pickup truck between Rio Medina and Castroville.
The Garza County Sheriff's Office reported penny size hail in Post.
Slick roadways are believed to be the cause of a fatal accident on FM 1753. A man riding a motorcycle lost control on the wet road and slid off the road. He died while en route to the hospital.
The Bosque County Sheriff's Department reported quarter sized hail in the northeastern part of the County.
Trees were blown down by high winds.
A social media report indicated quarter-sized hail near Trophy Club, TX.
Part of a roof was blown off of a house. Monetary damages were estimated.
Emergency management reported trees damaged, snapped and uprooted around Lost Prairie Lake.

A 65 MPH wind gust was measured in northern Denison. Throughout the city, numerous trees were uprooted, large limbs were knocked down, damage occurred to outbuildings, and minor damage to local businesses was reported. The awning of a gas station at Highway 75 and FM 120 was torn off.
A thunderstorm produced golf ball size hail east of Enchanted Rock State Natural Area.
Trees down between Ashwood and Pledger which damaged automotive windshield.
Trees and power lines were downed over the city of Coleman due to strong thunderstorm winds.
This brief tornado developed near the community of Richland and moved to the northeast, causing minor tree damage to the west of Highway 14.
Quarter sized hail reported in Fresno.
A 60 mph wind gust was measured at the East Texas Regional Airport south of Longview.
Very strong winds blew down power lines and unroofed several residences. Assistance was required by American Red Cross and the Fabens Volunteer Fire Department.
A thunderstorm produced a wind gust measured at 50 kts. by the ASOS at Laughlin AFB. No damage was reported.

Large, split trees and many downed branches were reported in the Lost Creek Estates neighborhood in Talty. Elsewhere around Talty, trees, roofs, and fences were damaged. A NWS survey of the area determined winds up to 85 mph caused the damage around Talty.

An EF0 tornado occurred near Hwy. 77 and moved north approximately 1.5 miles.  A storage building was destoyed and a carport was lifted from a home and dropped in a yard along County Road 4798.  A large tree fell across a parked vehicle near a residence as well.  A utility trailer was picked up and thrown into the side of another parked vehicle.  There were no injuries reported.  Multiple trees were snapped or downed along the 100 yard wide path.
Golfball to Baseball size hail fell in Sherman. In some places the hail formed drifts and partially covered the ground.
Reported along Highways 1840 and 98.
A thunderstorm produced penny size hail in Ingram.
Golf ball sized hail was reported.
Penny hail was reported in Pleasant Farms.
A trained spotter estimated up to 80 mph winds and three trees blown down by the high winds.
Trees down along Highway 82 east of Clarksville.
A brief tornado was reported just south of 174 to the west of Blum. The location and time was right before the development of the larger EF-2 tornado just to the east of this location.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 70 mph that damaged the roof of a house in Del Rio.
There was some roof and car damage from the storms in Robert Lee. These storms brought Golfball size hail and high winds.

The same line of storms that produced the Allen tornado moved east and produced a brief downburst wind event east of Farmersville. Approximately 15 homes were damaged by straight line winds to the southeast of Farmersville on CR 697. One mobile home was rolled approximately 100 feet and destroyed, resulting in injuries to 3 of the occupants. Damage to the other homes in the area consisted primarily of minor roof damage and damage to underpinning.
A strong storm with a definite hail core produced quarter size hail across the city of Three Rivers for a couple minutes according to the public.
A thunderstorm produced tennis ball size hail in northwestern San Antonio near Silvertip Dr. and White Tail Dr.
Numerous windows and skylights broken along with many roofs damaged in the city of Borger.
Storm spotters reported quarter size hail along Texas Highway 256 southwest of Memphis.

A thunderstorm moved across Pecos County and produced a tornado about 25 miles south southeast of Fort Stockton, Texas.  This tornado was spotted by experienced storm spotters and emergency management.  The tornado was located between US 385 and US 285.  Reports indicated that the tornado touched down at 4:53 pm CDT and remained on the ground for ten minutes before dissipating at 5:03 pm CDT.  Since the tornado stayed in open fields and there was no evidence of damage, the tornado was rated as an EF-0.
Local law enforcement reported several trees and power lines down in Henrietta. Monetary damages estimated.
Damage was reported to roofs and outbuildings.  Barns were also blown down.
A thunderstorm produced ping pong ball size hail in northern Austin.
Numerous trees and power lines were downed across much of Rusk County.

Law enforcement officials reported that quarter sized hail fell along U.S. Highway 380 west of Tahoka from an isolated severe thunderstorm that had developed over central Lynn County. The storm continued to produce quarter size hail as it slowly moved southward. Law enforcement officials reported quarter size hail between New Moore and O'Donnell at 15:47 CDT.
Nickel sized hail was reported at N Coit Rd and Campbell Rd.
A trained spotter reported quarter size hail in the city of Whitesboro, TX.
Fire and rescue reported nickel size hail near the intersection of West White Avenue and North Hardin Blvd in the city of McKinney, TX.
A public report indicated half-dollar sized hail near Wolfe City, TX.

Severe thunderstorms moving southward through eastern Fayette County produced damaging winds that blew down trees and power lines from Fayetteville to Schulenburg.  Power was lost to nearly 1400 persons for several hours as a result of the storm.  One man pumping gas at Schulenburg narrowly avoided injury when winds detached the roof from a store and it landed beside him.

A discrete thunderstorm moved across Carson County during the early evening hours of the 8th. As the thunderstorm moved over Pantex (Carson County), it produced 0.95 inch of rain. The majority of this rain fell over the span of a half hour. No swift water rescues or stranded motorist were reported in association to this heavy rain.
Baseball-size hail reported at the forecast office.
A public report indicated that power poles were knocked down approximately 3 miles southwest of the city of Post Oak, TX.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near New Deal measured severe wind gusts at 1718 CST and 1728 CST. A peak wind gust of 68 mph was measured at 1718 CST.
Public reported big tree branches blown down around Kingsville through social media.
Law enforcement estimated a wind gust of 60 mph.
This is a continuation of the large hail swath from the super cell thunderstorm moving just to the east of San Angelo. These reports were from just north of the Goodfellow Airforce Base.
A trained spotter reported baseball size hail 25 miles south of Ozona.
Trees were downed west of Center, Texas.
Storm chasers documented a brief EF-0 tornado west of US Highway 208 about 8.5 miles southwest of Girard.  No damage survey was conducted as the tornado remained over undeveloped land.
Emergency management reported a 67 MPH wind gust on Highway 289 just west of Sherman.

A NWS Storm Survey determined an EF-0 tornado began approximately 1.5 miles southwest of Personville. This tornado had a path length of approximately 0.75 miles and an estimated width of 100 yards. Some tree damage occurred with this tornado and winds were estimated near 75 mph.
Strong thunderstorm wind severely damaged a metal building, destroyed a barn, destroyed a center pivot irrigation system, and snapped several power poles.

Slow moving thunderstorms, containing more than an hour of torrential rains, dumped between 3 and 6 inches in central Willacy County during the early and mid afternoon of June 22nd.  In Raymondville, up to a foot of standing water was observed by storm spotters and the county Emergency Manager; several roads were temporarily closed due to the urban/poor drainage flooding.  No water reached structures.  Observed rainfall ranged from just under 3 inches on the west side of Raymondville to 6.10 inches 6 miles east of Raymondville (San Perlita). Other minor flooding was reported in Sebastian (just north of the Cameron/Willacy County line), with backyards turning to low water lakes and streets with more than a foot of water in them.||The flooding in Sebastian intensified on the 23rd, reaching into properties as poor drainage structure in town (pipe structure) could not handle the heavy rains and flooding reached into the ground floor of a number of structures in town.
A 72 mph wind gust was measured at a Frisco Fire Station.
Penny sized hail was reported in north Bryan.
Trained spotter reported hail up to golf ball size in Temple.
Quarter size hail occurred 4 miles northeast of Amarillo.
Peak winds of 60 mph were estimated in Waxahachie. Power lines and a few trees were knocked down.
Postal workers at Old Glory reported pea to penny size hail that was accompanied by 50 mph wind gusts.
This report was received over social media. The hail  lasted about 20 seconds.

Tennis ball sized hail was reported in the Los Villareales section of Rio Grande City, and Golfball sized hail at two nearby locations, by the public and local Sheriff's Office, between Midway Road and Hospital Drive, and along US 83 and FM 3167, all just a few miles east of Los Villareales in the west portion of Rio Grande City between 705 and 715 PM CDT.
Hail up to an inch in diameter was deposited east of Manor in drifts 3 to 6 inches deep.
An eighteen wheeler was reported blown over.
The public reported a tree blown down across U.S. Highway 83 about 1 mile south of FM 2133.
Trained weather spotters reported winds of 60 mph and hail half an inch in diameter.

Significant structural damage occurred to some homes in the Nichols Way neighborhood of Irving. Roofs were damaged, part of a roof was torn off a house, and siding was stripped off a few homes. Trees were also knocked down or large limbs were broken off.
Trees were blown down south of Cushing.
Time of the hail was estimated. Reported nine miles west southwest of Lake Meredith.
Wind gust occurred on El Campo Beach Road.

Storm chasers observed a brief tornado just south of Whitsett. The tornado damaged large trees and a mobile home and uprooted a hay shed. This damage was observed just east of Highway 281 about a half of a mile southeast of Whitsett.
Power lines down in the Evergreen area along FM 945 South.

The public reported golfball to baseball size hail in and around town.  The hail damaged homes and buildings, knocked out windows, and damaged vehicles.  The storm also resulted in significant crop damage between Sudan and Amherst.

A thunderstorm moved over Ector County and produced a wind gust estimated at 65 mph six miles north northwest of Odessa.  As a result of the wind, 40 to 60 foot trees with three foot wide trunks were uprooted.  The cost of damage is a very rough estimate.
Photos of tree damage and tin roof damage were relayed from broadcast media via NWS chat.
An amateur radio report estimated 70 MPH winds and quarter sized hail in Saginaw, TX.
The report was relayed through mPING.
Two large trees broken in half.  Numerous other trees, power lines, and transformers were knocked down or damaged.
Quarter size hail was reported on FM 291 6 miles south-southeast of Lefors.

A tornado touched down near the intersection of Muller Road and Fairview Road to the west-northwest of Burkburnett and moved northeast to at least an area 3 miles north-northwest of Burkburnett. No significant damage was reported.
Thunderstorm winds blew down a 10 inch diameter tree approximately 1 mile north of Troy.
A thunderstorm moved across Culberson County and produced a 61 mph wind gust at the Pine Springs ASOS site.
Trees downed along Highway 69 between Rusk and Alto.

The wind gust was measured at the Texas MesoNet station near McLean. The high winds twisted up a barn and the roof tin was blown into a neighboring yard...large tree limbs broken and some trees blown over...a couple of guard lights ripped up...a press box was blown into the stands at a football field...and three tractor-trailers were blown over on Interstate 40 near McLean.
Quarter size hail was reported in South Sulphur.
A public report indicated quarter sized hail near Hackberry, TX.
An automated weather observation station at Brady Municipal Airport measured a 63 mph wind gust.
A public report indicated that trees were either snapped or uprooted near the intersection of FM 121 and Lovers Leap Lane.
Numerous trees were reported down across the entire county.
Amateur radio reported golf ball sized hail in the city of Hubbard, TX.
A trained spotter reported nickel-sized hail near the intersection of Interstate 30 and Bobtown Road in Garland, TX.

The volunteer fire chief in Friona and the NWS cooperative weather observer reported extensive damage to the south of Friona due to large hail and wind. At least six pivot irrigation system sprinklers were overturned in addition to downed utility poles along State Highway 86 west of State Highway 214. Numerous cattle were injured due to flying debris and hail. Over 200 head of cattle had to be put down due to their injuries. Hail up to baseball size was reported within this swath of severe winds and hail.
The Winkler County Airport ASOS measured a severe wind gust from thunderstorm outflow.

Scattered thunderstorms developed across Potter County during the evening hours of the 12th. As a storm approached the town of Bushland (Potter County), the KVII Schoolnet site three miles east of Bushland recorded a 59 mph downburst. After producing this downburst the storm continued to move eastward across the county.
Large hail up to the size of softballs occurred for 20 minutes near Callaghan Ranch at mile marker 28 on Interstate 35. Several car windows were broken out.
Quarter size hail was reported in Grapevine.
Trees were downed near the intersection of State Highway 21 W and FM 1580.
Emergency manager reported golf ball sized hail 1 mile north of Tom Bean.
Several trees were downed.

Numerous trees uprooted around Wallace Pack prison complex. One of the watch tower standers witnessed tremendous increase in wind embedded in heavy rain; vehicles in parking lot were moved in different directions.
Ping pong ball-sized hail reported by NWS employee about 5 miles ENE of Saint Lawrence. Time is estimated from radar.
A brief tornado touched down near a shopping center near Huntsville. Caused some minor damage. Circular winds observed in parking lot on video.

The Port Isabel Police Department shared pictures on social media showing damage to the Sunoco Gas station awning at the corner of Highway 48 and Highway 100 and an ice chest that had moved several feet from the front of the building. Several pictures of powerlines down were also shown. NOAA's National Ocean Service (NOS) site at Port Isabel (PTIT2) recorded wind gusts of 52 knots, or 60 mph, at 1:54AM CDT, and was used as a guide for when the strongest winds were ending.
Dime size hail near Beltway 8 and U.S. Highway 290.

After an initial report of baseball to softball sized hail in Sebastian, visual evidence from an NWS storm survey indicated no discernible hail impact in Sebastian. Estimated size was penny sized based on conversations with affected residents. the hail lasted up to 10 minutes.
Small hardwood tree limbs broken (up to 1 inch diameter).
A public report indicated multiple 6 to 12 inch diameter branches split and trees down near the intersection of Perkins Road and Pleasant Wood Trail.
Strong wind blew down trees.
Severe thunderstorm winds blew the roofs off homes around Burnet.
Numerous large limbs were downed northwest of Jefferson.
Trees were downed by strong thunderstorm wind gusts.

A supercell crossed the El Paso/Hudspeth County line and continued to produce a swath of golf ball size hail, covering I-10 and leading to the overturning of a tractor trailer rig. No injuries were reported.
Late report of strong winds behind outflow along with blowing dust.
Golfball-size hail was reported in town.
A 20 foot section of roof was removed from the Gilmer Cable TV business.
COCORAHS report OF 4.55 inches of rainfall in two hours.
A public report indicated golf ball sized hail approximately 1 mile east-northeast of the city of McKinney, TX.
Penny sized hail was reported approximately 5 miles north of Lampasas.
A house fire was reported due to a suspected lightning strike. Event time is approximate.
Nickel to half dollar sized hail fell across western portions of Odessa.
A storm chaser followed a tornado from just east of Memphis (in Hall County) to about 13 miles west of Loco.  The tornado snapped trees and power poles and downed power lines.
A 60 mph wind gust was estimated in De Kalb.
A thunderstorm moved over Martin County and produced wind damage in Lenorah.  Part of a roof was blown off of a house.  The cost of damage is a rough estimate.
The KVII schoolnet site 7 miles east-northeast of Channing measured a wind gust of 67 mph.
A couple of vehicle awnings blown down.
Several vehicles were damaged in the high school and junior high-elementary parking lots. Some homes were also damaged.
A Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet site near McAdoo measured intermittent severe wind gusts from 1621 CST through 1630 CST. A peak wind gust of 72 mph was measured at 1629 CST.
A metal roof was peeled back on a home near Blumentritt Road and Loop 306.
Mostly nickel size hail with a few quarters at the Canadian Golf Course.
Trees were felled by high winds.
Trees and power lines were reported down in Canutillo from thunderstorm winds.
Numerous trees and powerlines were downed throughout the entire county.
Reported by a pilot.
A thunderstorm produced half dollar size hail east of La Vernia.
Estimated by a HAM radio spotter.  Multiple gustnadoes were also observed.
High winds with a thunderstorm snapped 10 electrical and telephone poles along San Francisco Street and Azteca Creek.|
Large limbs downed across roads between New Salem and Laneville communities.
A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that blew down a number of residential fences.
Several power lines down across Hwy 69.

Multiple reports indicated large hail that ranged from nickel to golf ball size along a swath from south of Morton to Whiteface. Nickel size hail was initially reported along Texas Highway 214 between Morton and Lehman at 21:35 CST. By 22:25 CST hail stones up to the size of golf balls were falling in Whiteface. No damage was reported.
A thunderstorm produced nickel size hail along Grand Ave. west of I-35 in Round Rock.
Large tree limbs were blown down.
As the severe line of thunderstorms moved eastward, they produced winds that uprooted trees both to the east and the west of SH95, south of the town of Elgin.
Nickel-sized hail was reported in Callisburg.
A tree was downed on Swansons Landing Road in Karnack, Texas.
A gas station in Orange Grove sustained damage due to high winds.
Hail reported at the intersection of Jones Road and FM 1960.
Emergency management reported quarter sized hail in Southmayd.
Power outages were reported in town.
Motorist was blown off the road by the high winds. No injuries were reported.

Thunderstorms formed along a dryline stretching east-northeastward across Randall and Potter Counties during the afternoon hours of the 28th. These thunderstorms would take a northeast track which allowed them to move over the dryline. This caused the thunderstorms to produce isolated downbursts across the city. The KVII schoolnet site at the Discovery Center (Potter County) reported a gust of 60 mph while a thunderstorm was overhead. The thunderstorm decayed quickly after moving to the dry side of the dryline due to ingesting much drier air into the updrafts.  No damage or injuries were associated with this gust.

Thunderstorm winds downed trees in the Woden community.  One tree crashed through the roof of a mobile home on FM 3228 which trapped a 91 year old woman in the home.  She was rescued by EMS units but was not injured.  Downed trees and powerlines were also reported across the county from FM 1275 to FM 95.
Quarter sized hail reported.
There were trees and power lines blown down near Kingwood High School.
Several large mesquite trees and one full tree were snapped by winds.
Roof damage from a thunderstorm was reported to a law office and an apartment complex near Central Mall.
The roof of metal building at the U-Haul storage facility was blown on to a neighboring house on French Drive near Mount Vernon Drive.
Peak gust of 63 mph reported at the South Franklin Peak Mesonet site.

A cluster of thunderstorms produced a period of intense rainfall over Armstrong County during the evening hours of the 14th.  These thunderstorms led to water rising to the underside of the bridge of U.S. Highway 207 at the Prairie Dog Town Fork of the Red River. This minor flooding receded once the thunderstorm which produced the heavy rain moved south of the city.
A public report indicated ping pong ball sized hail in Frisco, TX.
Scattered wind damage to mostly wood and metal structures was observed in Avalon, including carports and older barns.
A tree was blown over County Road 190.
The large hail reportedly stripped corn fields east of Hereford. No injuries were reported.
A trained spotter reported power flashes near Runaway Bay, TX.

Based on a National Weather Service damage survey, this tornado touched down around 1043 PM, 4 miles southeast of Goodnight and lifted at approximately 1049 PM CDT, 4 miles east of Goodnight, TX.  The tornado was rated an EF-0 with an estimated peak wind speed of 70 mph, consistent with the minor damaged observed.
A picture posted to social media indicated a tree downed onto a home on Trout Street.
A utility company reported 37 power poles down along FM 1836 in Kaufman County.
